HEADLINE: University of California President Says He Will Resign Next Year 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA WHITAKER

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
The president of the University of California system, Richard C. Atkinson, who sought changes in college admissions tests, announced today that he would retire on Oct. 1. 
 Dr. Atkinson, 73, has been president of the university for seven years. He had been chancellor of the University of California at San Diego for 15 years before heading the sprawling system. A cognitive scientist, Dr. Atkinson was formerly director of the National Science Foundation in Washington. 
"I think I'm due to step down," he said, "and this is the perfect time to do it." 
This year, the College Board announced that it would revamp its primary college entrance examination, the SAT I, a move viewed as a direct response to Dr. Atkinson's effort to replace it with a test that would more directly reflect what students had learned in high school.
Under Dr. Atkinson, the university system grappled with budgets and ending affirmative action. He started in the position just as the Board of Regents adopted a resolution that eliminated consideration of race and ethnicity in admissions. That change led to declining numbers of minority students.
In recent years, the numbers have begun to rebound, as the university increased its contact programs with elementary, middle and high schools and focused on improving academic performance and college preparation. The university also expanded admissions criteria to consider when students overcome economic or educational hardships. Last year, the board rescinded the resolution, although state law continues to ban affirmative action.
A panel will be formed to conduct a nationwide search for a successor to Dr. Atkinson. Of the 17 presidents of the university system, only four held the post longer than Dr. Atkinson.
The chairman of the Regents, John J. Moores, said: "I was deeply sorry to learn of his decision to retire. But he has certainly earned it after a lifetime of contributions to education, to scientific research and to the people of the state of California."
Dr. Atkinson and his wife, Rita, plan to return to San Diego after retirement.

HEADLINE: Taiwan Imports a Made-in-U.S. Political Issue: Central Park 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
Central Park has captivated New Yorkers for more than 130 years, but now it has become the subject of daily debate in an unlikely venue: the mayoral race here in Taiwan's capital.
 Lee Ying-yuan, the challenger for the mayor's office, wants to raze this city's downtown airport for domestic flights and replace it with what he describes as an imitation of Central Park, complete with a surrounding ring of luxury apartment buildings. 
 Ma Ying-jeou, the popular incumbent, has a different vision as he campaigns before the vote on Dec. 7. He wants airlines to offer nonstop flights from the airport to Shanghai, an 80-minute flight that would make day trips to the mainland possible. 
China and Taiwan have been negotiating whether to allow direct flights. Travelers between Taipei and Shanghai must currently fly south to Hong Kong or Macao, change planes there and then fly back past Taiwan to Shanghai, a six- or seven-hour trip.
Taipei residents have just a quarter of the park space per person of New York City residents, and virtually no playing fields. Closing the downtown Sungshan Domestic Airport and sending planes to the outlying Chiang Kai-shek International Airport could revive the city's economy, Mr. Lee contends, by opening the way for taller buildings, which are currently banned for air safety reasons.
Taipei's financial district, a 10-minute walk from Sungshan Airport, looks like downtown Washington, with rows of boxy buildings, all of practically the same height. "All the roofs are terrible to look at," said Mr. Lee in an interview at his campaign headquarters here today. "We don't have a skyline like Manhattan's."
Taiwan is building a high-speed rail system to whisk travelers in 90 minutes from Taipei in the north to Taiwan's other main city, Kaohsiung, near the island's southern tip. Stopping along the way in several other cities, the trains will provide an alternative for most of Sungshan Airport's passengers.
Pointing out that he worked for a securities law firm in Manhattan in the 1970's and earned a master's degree at New York University, Mr. Ma says the airport site is unsuitable for a Central Park look-alike because a river and a freeway run alongside it. 
"I played softball in Central Park, I jogged in Central Park," Mr. Ma said in an interview at City Hall today. "I know Central Park quite well, and I know this would not be a Central Park."
Underlying the debate are presidential politics and Taiwan's relations with China.
Mr. Ma is from the Nationalist Party, which favors eventual reunification with China and closer transportation ties now. Mr. Lee is from the Democratic Progressive Party, which leans toward greater independence for Taiwan, and does not want Chinese flights landing at a domestic airport instead of an international one.
Mr. Ma, who is favored to win re-election, is a likely Nationalist Party candidate to run in 2004 against President Chen Shui-bian, of the Democratic Progressive Party. Mr. Chen has campaigned heavily with Mr. Lee.
The fight is partly personal: Mr. Chen was elected Taipei's mayor in 1994, but lost his re-election bid to Mr. Ma in 1998. Only then did Mr. Chen run for president, and unexpectedly won.

HEADLINE: Takeover of Indian Point By Westchester Is Proposed 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
The Westchester County executive, Andrew J. Spano, said today that he wanted to shut down the two nuclear power plants at Indian Point by buying them, or if necessary, taking them through a condemnation process.
 Citing concerns about the safety of the plants, Mr. Spano said he was setting aside $500,000 in his proposed 2003 budget for a six-month study on acquiring the Indian Point plants in Buchanan, about 40 miles north of Midtown Manhattan, and replacing them with a new natural gas plant. He estimated the purchase and construction costs alone at $2 billion to $3 billion, at least twice the amount of the county's annual budget. 
 "We think that these plants should not have been built here in the first place, and we'd rather have them somewhere else, and we're going to pursue this attack," Mr. Spano said during a news conference at his office.
But Mr. Spano and other county officials offered few details about their proposal, except to say that the study would address a wide range of questions, including where the money would come from and whether the county would act alone or try to seek partners. Mr. Spano has said he would not raise taxes to buy the plants.
Indian Point's owner, the Entergy Corporation, said today that it was not interested in selling the nuclear plants and that it would oppose any effort to close them.
"Entergy hasn't put out a for-sale sign," said Jim Steets, an Entergy spokesman. "We'll talk to the county executive about whatever he wants, but we're not looking to sell Indian Point. It's too valuable to Entergy and to the residents of New York State."
The company bought the plants in the last two years, and Mr. Steets said it had spent hundreds of millions of dollars to upgrade equipment and increase training. Together, the two plants generate about 2,000 megawatts of electricity for homes, businesses and public buildings in Westchester and New York City; one megawatt is enough to power about 1,000 average homes.
Mr. Spano's announcement follows more than a year of divisive public debates here over the safety of Indian Point since the Sept. 11 terror attacks. The Westchester Board of Legislators and dozens of villages and towns across the county have passed resolutions calling for the nuclear plants to be decommissioned.
Brian Nickerson, director of the Michaelian Institute for Public Policy at Pace University, said that while Mr. Spano was clearly responding to the concerns of his constituents, his proposal for a takeover of Indian Point faced many logistical and regulatory hurdles. "I don't know if it's completely unrealistic," he said. "But I think it's a difficult sell."
Several Westchester legislators and others questioned whether the financially strained county could afford to buy the plants, let alone build a new one. Just last month, Mr. Spano, a Democrat, proposed a 31.7 percent increase in the county's share of the property tax levy to help offset a projected gap of more than $100 million next year in the county's roughly $1 billion budget. 
"I'm not willing to sign off on Westchester County becoming Westchester Lighting Company," said Legislator George Oros, the Republican minority leader. "I think there are basic, fundamental questions that you have to address first before you commit the $500,000 for the study."
But Legislator Michael B. Kaplowitz, a Democrat, said that whether or not the county took over the nuclear plants, the proposed study would take a serious look at issues that need to be addressed.
"The economic arguments to keep it open are very powerful," he said. "And yet the reasons to close it for public safety are more compelling. This is a way to do both. You would close the nuclear side and build a natural gas plant."

HEADLINE: Profit Up 23% At Wal-Mart; Others Gain 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Wal-Mart Stores, the largest retailer, reported higher fiscal third-quarter profit yesterday. Wal-Mart said that net income increased 23 percent, to $1.82 billion, or 41 cents a share, in the quarter ended Oct. 31. 
 The company, based in Bentonville, Ark., was expected to have a third-quarter profit of 40 cents, according to Thomson First Call. 
 Revenue at Wal-Mart increased 11 percent, to $58.8 billion, and sales at stores open at least a year rose 3.5 percent. Fourth-quarter revenue is expected to rise 3 to 5 percent, the chief executive, H. Lee Scott Jr., said. Food sales, which have led much of Wal-Mart's revenue increases, slowed in the quarter. 
Another big retailer, Federated Department Stores, said earnings rose to $106 million, or 54 cents a share, in the period ended Nov. 2, from $3 million, or 2 cents, a year earlier. Federated, which owns Macy's and Bloomingdale's, among others, said profit was helped by a gain of $31 million from the sale of some catalog businesses. It has also reduced debt and expenses amid concern that traffic may slow. 
Excluding the sale of the businesses, Federated would have earned 38 cents. On that basis, profit was 1 cent more than the First Call estimate. 
Sales rose less than 1 percent, to $3.48 billion, and sales at stores open at least a year fell 2 percent. Those sales are expected to fall as much as 2 percent in the fourth quarter and as much as 2.5 percent in November and December combined. 
Tiffany & Company said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter profit rose to $35.2 million, or 24 cents a share, from $24 million, or 16 cents, a year earlier. Tiffany cited cost controls and a one-time tax benefit. Revenue rose 9.9 percent, to $366 million. It said partnerships with diamond-mining companies had helped cut costs. Tiffany reduced its fourth-quarter profit and sales forecast, attributing this to slower American economic recovery than expected.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Wal-Mart shopper moved through a store yesterday in Little Rock, Ark. Company earnings narrowly exceeded analysts' expectations. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
E-Mail Ties Analyst's Switch To Nursery School Spots
Jack B. Grubman, a former star telecommunications analyst, told a friend last year that his boss, Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Citigroup, helped to secure spots in an exclusive Manhattan nursery school for Mr. Grubman's daughters after he began recommending that investors buy AT&T stock. Citigroup acknowledged Mr. Weill's attempt to help Mr. Grubman's children, but denied it was connected to the analyst's upgrade of AT&T.
 The circumstances surrounding Mr. Grubman's abrupt change in the fall of 1999 to an upbeat view on AT&T from a negative one have come under scrutiny as investigators try to assess whether research practices at the Salomon Smith Barney unit were corrupted by its investment banking relationships with corporations or desired relationships. Page A1. 

Cable Merger Clears Final Hurdle
The largest merger in cable television history cleared its last regulatory hurdle when the Federal Communications Commission approved license transfers necessary for Comcast to acquire AT&T Broadband. Together, the two companies would account for about 30 percent of the cable TV market. In a 3-to-1 vote, members concluded that the new company would speed up the introduction of high-speed Web connections and advanced TV services. C7.

Debit Cards at Center of Fee Dispute
Retailers have released court documents that they say show that Visa and MasterCard colluded to monopolize the market for debit cards. Visa and MasterCard say they did not try to mislead merchants. C10.

Simon Bids for Taubman Centers
Simon Property Group, the nation's largest owner of shopping malls, made a $1.48 billion bid to buy Taubman Centers. But Taubman Centers said the board and the Taubman family had rejected the offer. C4.

Judge Refuses to Bar 2 Doctors
A judge has ruled that two California doctors who are under investigation for possibly performing unnecessary procedures can continue practicing for now. The judge said the Medical Board of California, which had sought to bar the doctors, had provided mainly hearsay that the doctors posed a threat. C4.

Chief Resigns at Schering-Plough
Schering-Plough, the pharmaceutical company, said that its chief executive, Richard Jay Kogan, would step down. C2.

Earnings Rise at 2 Large Retailers
Third-quarter net income at Wal-Mart increased 23 percent, to $1.82 billion. Earnings at Federated Department Stores rose to $106 million, from $3 million a year earlier. C4.

Dow and Nasdaq End the Day Higher
The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 12.49 points, at 8,398.49. The Nasdaq rose 11.78 points, to 1,361.34. But the Standard & Poor's 500 index slipped 0.42 points, to 882.53. C11.

Germany Tops Deficit Limit
Even as the European Union released new forecasts of anemic economic growth in the 12 nations using the euro currency, the union's commissioner for monetary affairs, Pedro Solbes, left, proposed punishing the largest member, Germany, for running too big a budget deficit as it slips toward recession . World Business, Section W.

Gates Finds a Seattle in India
Old if they were over 30, the elite of India's high-tech revolution met with Bill Gates, Microsoft's chairman and, more importantly for this crowd, its chief software architect. A14.

Prosperity That Runs in the Family
It seems increasingly apparent that the secret to success is to have a successful parent. As more recent and better data have become available, economists have marked up the estimate of the impact of parents' socioeconomic status on their children's likelihood of success. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: The Neediest Cases; 
In Need of Help Herself, But Still Helping Others

BYLINE:  By ARTHUR BOVINO 

 BODY:
To Ana Rodriguez, the instinct to help others is like a light switch that cannot be turned off.
 And a call for help? That's something she cannot ignore, no matter how dire her own situation might be. 
 So when she heard a distress call from somewhere down the hallway at the Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan, where she was recuperating from surgery, Ms. Rodriguez didn't have to think twice. She slipped out of her bed and went to see what she could do. 
"I hear them calling and go in the hall and the nurse asked me where I was going," Ms. Rodriguez recalled. "Just for a walk. I go in the room and the man said, 'Help!' I say, 'What you need help for?' He say his diaper need changing."
Then, Ms. Rodriguez pulled out her identification as a longtime home health care attendant: " 'Roll over,' I tell him. 'I do it.' "
Since Ms. Rodriguez, 50, arrived in the United States from the Dominican Republic in 1978, she has held many jobs: sewing, preparing airline food, making caps for milk bottles.
The jobs kept her blissfully busy while her husband was working. But she also wanted to do more with her life. So she took training courses and became a home attendant. From 1985 until last year, she offered care and comfort to scores of sick and elderly people in New York City, often providing round-the-clock, live-in service.
"God gave me life for some reason," she explained in her native Spanish. "So I help people."
Now Ms. Rodriguez can use some help herself. She is waging a battle with cancer, complicated by other illness and injury. Even so, nothing -- not cancer, not hospitalizations, not financial straits -- has dampened her passion for living life fully, or for helping others do the same.
In December, Ms. Rodriguez was coughing and losing weight. At first, her doctor thought she might have tuberculosis and prescribed medication accordingly. The medicine helped, but in January she became sick again and was hospitalized. The doctor did exploratory surgery and removed a spot on her lung. Weeks later, she found out she had cancer.
In the months since then, she has been unable to work because of problems breathing. To complicate matters, during tests done in January before her surgery she was told that she had osteoporosis, and has to walk with a cane.
Most daunting for her and her family is her doctor's prognosis that she may have only two years to live.
For Ms. Rodriguez's two children -- a son, Edward, 23, and daughter, Dayanara, 20 -- it's hard to imagine a life devoid of their mother's strong and vital presence. They describe her as a vibrant woman who danced and sang for them when they were little.
Even after she became ill, her energy and compassion did not flag, they said.
"At the hospital she'd go around opening the juice boxes for people and even picking up the phones," her daughter said.
Staying strong and upbeat was far from easy. Ms. Rodriguez lost 65 pounds, and chemotherapy made her lose her hair. Her son took her illness particularly hard.
Ms. Rodriguez's treatments were covered by Medicaid, but without work she began falling behind on rent and utility bills. Ever since she came to New York, she has lived in the same apartment in Hollis, Queens. In 1978 the rent was $269; now it is $536.51 -- low compared with neighboring units, but an imposing sum to a woman who is gravely ill and unemployed.
Ms. Rodriguez has no other relatives in New York. She and her husband, who were married in 1978, separated in 1993 and divorced three years ago. He sends $100 to Dayanara every two weeks. She gives it to her mother for the rent.
In April, a neighbor referred Ms. Rodriguez to the Catholic Charities of Brooklyn and Queens, one of seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
"At that time she really looked sick," said Rosa Orihuela, Ms. Rodriguez's caseworker. "I said, 'We need to help her.' She's such a great lady and she really needs the help."
Ms. Rodriguez began receiving $591 a month of temporary Social Security in September 2001, but it ended in June. Using $1,073.02 from Neediest Cases, Ms. Rodriguez was able to pay her rent in April and July and stay in her home. She has applied for disability, and is also trying to get Section 8 status to lower her rent.
"I'm very grateful," Ms. Rodriguez said, "not just because Catholic Charities helped me, but because it's here for other people."
Meanwhile, other uncertainties linger. The doctors tell Ms. Rodriguez that she is doing better than expected, but they have not changed their prognosis.
Ms. Rodriguez knows the value of a laugh. In the spirit of helping, she tries to leave others chuckling whenever she can.
When she last visited Catholic Charities she talked to those around her about life's problems.
"I tell them, 'I have this amount of time to live,' " she said with a grin. " 'What, are we going to think about dying? Maybe you'll die before I do. We won't think about it. What's the point? We have to laugh.' "
And they did.

HEADLINE: Bishops Take No Action on Calls for Audit 

BYLINE:  By SAM DILLON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
The American Roman Catholic bishops ended a discussion of financial issues today that included approval of a $53 million budget for 2003 but did not address calls by Catholic philanthropists for a nationwide audit detailing how much the crisis of sexual abuse by priests has cost the church.
 The lack of a hearing on a proposed audit at the bishops' semiannual meeting angered lay leaders who have called for increased financial accountability, and it especially stung Erica John, an heiress to the Miller brewing fortune, whose donations were used secretly to pay $450,000 to a man who accused the Milwaukee archbishop of sexual assault. 
 "We are the church, and the leaders to whom we entrust our religious patrimony are failing us," Ms. John said today in an interview. "We as funders think it's important that the bishops open their books and come clean, because some of us are beginning to feel disappointed and even alienated from the church." 
With their adoption today of revised policies for dealing with abusive priests, the bishops hoped to move beyond the crisis that has undermined parishioners' confidence. But several prominent Catholics from both the church's liberal and conservative wings said that until the bishops spelled out the financial costs of the crisis they would not regain the trust of many parishioners.
In June, a group that represents 50 wealthy Catholic donors, including Ms. John, wrote to Bishop Wilton D. Gregory, the president of United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, asking the conference to hire an outside auditor to survey the money paid by the nation's 194 dioceses over two decades for abuse settlements, lawyers' fees and other costs resulting from sexual misconduct by clergymen. The group argued that reports of hush money and other secret payments had alarmed contributors and that the audit was needed to restore trust.
The Archdiocese of Boston and a few other dioceses have acknowledged financial problems because of reduced giving by parishioners, yet because diocesan finances are kept secret by many bishops, the severity of the church's financial difficulties remains unclear.
Bishop Gregory, a proponent of increased financial disclosure who reported in May that his Southern Illinois diocese of Belleville had paid $2.8 million over nine years to cover the costs of sexual abuse by clergymen, forwarded the proposal to two committees within the bishops conference for consideration, said Francis J. Butler, president of the donors' group, Foundations and Donors Interested in Catholic Activities.
In recent months the proposal gained the backing of several nationwide lay groups and of prominent Catholics. But it was never mentioned in the bishops' public deliberations here this week.
At a news conference concluding today's session, Bishop Gregory was asked whether he was concerned that the church was heading for financial difficulties because parishioners were upset about the crisis and might reduce their donations.
"Trust is only possible when we are open in our stewardship," Bishop Gregory said. In an interview this evening, Bishop Gregory said bishops had no power to compel each other to reveal diocesan finances, and he suggested that as a result the proposal for a nationwide audit was not included in the agenda. 
Earlier in the conference, Bishop Joseph A. Galante, the coadjutor of Dallas who is chairman of the conference's communications committee, said he could not explain why the proposed financial survey went undiscussed.
"I don't know, I guess it didn't get put on the agenda," Bishop Galante said.
Kenneth W. Korotky, the chief financial officer for the bishops conference, said bishops were providing more detailed financial reports to parishioners than in the past.
"Each diocese stands alone, and we cannot promulgate rules on financial accountability," Mr. Korotky said in an interview here. "But from what I've seen, the bishop's reports are offering more information. The trend is toward more openness." 
Charles Zech, a professor of economics at Villanova University who studies church finance, said that some dioceses, like Chicago, issued fairly thorough annual reports, "but most dioceses resist giving out any detailed financial information." 
Because Catholic parishioners often do not know how the money they put in the collection plate is spent, they donate a smaller part of their income to their church, about 1 percent on average, than do most Protestants, Mr. Zech said. Southern Baptists, for instance, donate more than 3 percent of their income to their church.
"There's a clear relationship," he said. "Churches that do a better job of telling people where their money is going get more donations."
The bishops do demand financial data from their conference, which distributed budget documents this week that were quite detailed, and included an accounting of how much each diocese would contribute to the conference's $53 million budget for 2003.
The Archdiocese of Chicago will contribute the most, $412,000, and New York will be second, contributing $405,000. The Diocese of Brooklyn will contribute $165,000 and Rockville Centre, which covers Long Island, $236,000.
The budget documents made no mention, however, of the financial difficulties in dioceses like Boston, Los Angeles and Providence, R.I., as a result of huge legal settlements and other recent costs relating to priestly misconduct. The mushrooming legal costs come as church revenues are down because the crisis has undermined parishioners' confidence that their donations will be used for charitable purposes.
Nowhere was donor confidence more damaged this year than in Milwaukee, where Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland resigned in June after acknowledging that he had paid $450,000 to a man who accused him of sexual assault. Church officials later reported that the money had come from the sale of a building donated to the church by a foundation endowed by Ms. John's family.
"If the bishops think that the laity doesn't count, that this is business as usual, then they are going to prolong the agony," Ms. John said.

HEADLINE: Visions of Jobs, or Danger, In Hudson Pipeline Project 

BYLINE:  By LISA W. FODERARO 

DATELINE: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Nov. 13 

 BODY:
One by one, hour after hour, they approached the podium -- homeowners, village managers, school officials, environmentalists, county legislators, parents, union officials, real estate agents and State Assembly members.
 A majority of the speakers came to the daylong hearing to denounce a proposed natural gas pipeline that would cross the Hudson River and wend its way through Westchester County. The speakers identified a wide range of possible threats, from the disruption of almost half of New York City's water supply to the loss of trees and streams in a 20-acre arboretum in northern Westchester. 
 Many speakers, mostly union workers, voiced support for the gas conduit, known as the Millennium Pipeline, citing the need for jobs and for additional energy sources. 
The hearing, held in the ballroom of the Hilton Tarrytown Hotel, could prove to be the final showdown between the pipeline's critics and supporters. It was called by the United States Department of Commerce in response to an appeal by the pipeline's builder, Columbia Gas Transmission of Fairfax, Va., of a decision by New York State to block the gas line.
The proposed 425-mile gas line from Lake Erie to Westchester County has drawn fierce opposition from many residents, environmentalists and elected officials.
New York's Department of State, which must approve any changes to the Hudson River's shores, determined in May that the pipeline would hurt fragile wildlife habitats, tarnish waterfront development and threaten New York City's water supply.
Because the appeal centered on the state coastal-zone finding, many speakers addressed that issue. "The environment for me is the key," said Naomi C. Matusow, a state assemblywoman who represents northeastern Westchester. "Haverstraw Bay is one of the most biologically productive areas in the Hudson. It is a hatchery and a fishery and has regional and national importance."
But organizers of the hearing permitted far-ranging testimony. "The purpose of today is to allow people to talk," said David P. Miller, a spokesman for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the agency within the Department of Commerce that is handling the appeal.
Many educators and parents from the village of Briarcliff Manor turned out to criticize the location of one section of pipeline 75 feet from a kindergarten playground.
Alicia R. Zalesin, the school board president, said that the potential placement of the pipeline near the school had "produced tremendous fear and anguish" in the community, especially given heightened fears of terrorism.
The threat of terrorism also figured prominently in testimony given by a representative of New York City's Department of Environmental Protection. Michael Meyer, a project manager with the agency's Bureau of Water Supply, explained that the pipeline would run within two feet of the Catskill Aqueduct at a critical juncture known as the Byrn Mawr Siphon.
A rupture of the siphon, caused by either a construction accident or a terrorist act after the pipeline's completion, would "trigger a violent release of an enormous volume of water," Mr. Meyer said. New York City, he said, would be "without 40 percent of its water supply."
At 7 p.m., the crowd in the ballroom overflowed into another room. Many people held signs and clapped or jeered, depending on who was speaking. An official repeatedly threatened a recess if order was not maintained.
"When I'm not working," said Bob Connolly, a member of Operating Engineers Local 825, "New York State pays me $405 a month. I have five children, and that's not enough. I can't afford to be unemployed for a year."
But Jonathan Glaser, a Croton resident, said, "Placing a high-pressured natural gas pipeline within clear range of Indian Point, the Con Ed electrical towers and the watershed is a recipe for disaster -- all for Millennium's profits."
Soon came chants of "Stop the pipeline!" and opposing chants of "Build the pipeline!" The meeting was recessed for a half-hour. When it resumed, an official said, "We have to live with each other for a while here."
In announcing the decision in May, Gov. George E. Pataki said the planned route -- across the Hudson River near Haverstraw Bay -- was inconsistent with the state's efforts to clean up the Hudson River. In recent months, the state has proposed alternative routes, but each one has elicited a torrent of negative reaction from local officials and homeowners.
The Department of Commerce, which oversees state plans for managing coastlines, will consider today's comments, along with written briefs and letters. A determination is not expected until well into next year. Whatever the finding, either side could then take the matter to court.
In September, federal regulators gave their approval to the pipeline. But among the conditions of the approval is the resolution of objections raised by New York State over the river's ecology.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Proponents and opponents of a gas pipeline across the Hudson River were out in force yesterday at a hearing in Tarrytown, N.Y. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: For a Split State Legislature, Bipartisan Fiscal Problems 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
Legislative leaders poured millions of dollars into races this year to ensure that the Republican majority in the Senate and the Democratic majority in the Assembly not only retained their power but became more firmly entrenched than ever.
 It worked. The divided Legislature, known for its partisan disputes and gridlock, late budgets and general legislative paralysis, is still going strong, with the majorities in both houses growing. 
 Once again, New York has bucked the national trend. Across the nation, Republicans took over seven legislative chambers previously in Democratic hands, giving the G.O.P. for the first time since 1952 slightly more state legislative seats than Democrats, according to the National Council of State Legislatures. The Republicans now control 21 legislatures, while the Democrats have 16. 
Twelve states finished the election with split party control, but in only one, Delaware, do the ruling parties have large margins in each house. (Nebraska has a unicameral legislature.) 
Indeed, in three of those states -- Georgia, Indiana and North Carolina -- a switch of just one seat would give one party complete control.
Not so in New York -- and deliberately so. The leaders of the two houses have a 20-year tradition of drawing legislative district lines to benefit their majorities. 
The mutually agreed-upon gerrymandering, coupled with millions of dollars in campaign contributions that the leaders direct into those few races that are competitive, creates a potent machine for protecting each majority.
"This election was essentially decided in April when the majority parties of both houses rigged the redistricting process," said Blair Horner, the legislative director of the New York Public Interest Group. 
"The strategy the parties work on is that you limit the number of districts with competitive enrollments, then they drop truckloads of money into those competitive races."
The Democrats gained four Assembly seats and now have the largest majority they have ever enjoyed in the lower house. They hold 103 of the 150 seats, for the first time giving the Assembly speaker, Sheldon Silver, the votes to override the governor's veto.
The Senate Republicans also gained a seat in southern Brooklyn, after spending more than $1.5 million to oust the Democratic incumbent. They also picked up a formerly Democratic seat outside Rochester.
That gives the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and his party 37 of the 62 Senate seats, which equals the largest majorities the Republicans have enjoyed in 30 years.
The split could have even more ominous consequences than usual this year, given the urgent agenda ahead. The state has not passed a budget on time in 19 years and has had difficulty compromising on important legislation.
This year, the Legislature will face the worst fiscal crisis in a generation: a budget shortfall of at least $5 billion, a bleak economic outlook, few reserves and the equally dire plight of New York City.
"We don't have enough resources to satisfy everyone's desire," Mr. Bruno said.
The legislative leaders have said they hope partisan bickering will not hinder reaching an agreement with Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, on how to balance the state's books.
However, Mr. Silver made it clear that he believed that, given the election results, the key to successful budget talks would be for "the Senate and the governor to recognize we are equal partners in the operation of government."
Mr. Silver also said he would resist cutting education aid or Medicaid, the two largest pieces of the $89 billion state budget. Instead, he suggested the governor should seek more aid from Washington, where his party controls both houses of Congress and the presidency.
For his part, Mr. Bruno said he doubted that the dynamics between the two houses would change. He said the key to smooth budget talks would be for Mr. Silver to drop his past insistence that the governor promise not to veto changes the Legislature makes to the spending plan, a stance Mr. Silver is unlikely to alter.
"If he plays that game or negotiates that way, then the dynamics can't change," Senator Bruno said. "It can't be sort of drawing lines in the sand."
Neither man is in danger of a revolt within his house. The vast majority of the 189 incumbents who ran were re-elected, with only six losing to challengers in either the primary or the general elections.
Among incumbents in the majority parties, there were even fewer losses.
Only one Democratic incumbent in the Assembly, Naomi Matusow, of Mount Kisco, was defeated, and that was in the primary to another Democrat, Adam Bradley, who went on to win her seat. Senator Pedro Espada, a Democrat who earlier this year pledged his allegiance to the Republicans, was defeated. 
That is not say the election was without surprises and oddities. In southern Westchester County, the incumbent assemblyman, Ronald C. Tocci, lost the Democratic primary to Noam Bramson, went on to run in the general election as a Republican and won. But he will rejoin the Democratic majority when he returns to Albany.
For the first time in modern history, Manhattan's Upper East Side has no Republican representatives in Albany, as Democrats took two open seats that have long been held by liberal Republicans.
Jonathan L. Bing, a Democrat, narrowly defeated Gail Hilson to win John Ravitz's old seat. Senator Liz Krueger, a Democrat, hung on to defeat Andrew S. Eristoff in the fight for Roy M. Goodman's old seat.
Mr. Silver spent lavishly to help elect Democrats upstate. In all, his Democratic Assembly Campaign Committee spent at least $1.4 million in the last month of campaigning to protect its incumbents and challenge a few vulnerable Republicans. 
Senator Bruno's New York Senate Republican Campaign Committee went through at least $3.7 million in that time and picked up several new members upstate, too.
But the sweetest victory for the Republicans was in southern Brooklyn, where Martin J. Golden, a former Republican City Council member, defeated Senator Vincent J. Gentile, a Democrat who held onto the seat for six years, even though it has historically been Republican.
Mr. Golden was helped by Mr. Pataki and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who stumped with him. Senator Bruno funneled at least $1.5 million into his campaign.
Both leaders said the election results had given their party a mandate, which does not bode well for bipartisan cooperation. Senator Bruno saw in the national vote tallies a ringing endorsement of Republican policies, like lower taxes and tighter security measures to fight terrorism.
"What I saw was that people's priorities in the majority are more in tune with what the Republicans have stood for and have been espousing, starting with homeland security," he said.
Mr. Silver saw the election differently, saying, "I think we have clearly staked our claim that all the Republicans' messages haven't worked, that we are a viable part of state government."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sheldon Silver, left, the Assembly speaker, and Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, say elections gave their parties a mandate. (Associated Press)(pg. B10)

HEADLINE: Auction Season's Finale Sets Records for 6 Artists 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Great American masters like Jasper Johns and Roy Lichtenstein, Andy Warhol and Barnett Newman fueled the week's final and most buoyant evening sale of postwar and contemporary art. Collectors, dealers and curiosity-seekers packed Christie's Rockefeller Center salesroom beyond capacity last night, and records were set for six artists.
 "Bidding was fast and furious," said a triumphant Christopher Burge, honorary chairman of Christie's in America and the evening's auctioneer. "It was a very very strong sale right across the board." 
 Of the 75 works on offer, only 13 failed to sell. The auction totaled $66.9 million, above its $60 million low estimate.
"Estimates played a large part in the outcome," said Susan Dunne, a dealer at PaceWildenstein. One reason for last night's success was that Christie's didn't inflate what it thought the market would pay, dealers said. And while Sotheby's sale on Tuesday night brought a higher total -- $78.2 million -- it might have done much better if the estimates had been less ambitious.
At Christie's, a Jasper Johns was the evening's biggest seller: "0 Through 9" (1961), a superimposition of the numerals in a range of grays. Estimated at $6 million to $8 million, it attracted three serious bidders. In the end, there was a valiantly fought war between a telephone bidder and Andrew Fabricant, who runs the Richard Gray Gallery in New York. The telephone bidder won, with $9.9 million. The price seemed low, considering that the Whitney Museum of American Art recently acquired a similar Johns, though in color, for a reported $15 million. The painting sold last night had been in several respected collections, including that of the publishing magnate S. I. Newhouse Jr.
After the sale, rumors about the buyer's identity began circulating. Many experts believed it was David Geffen, competing against Leslie Wexner, the retailer for whom Mr. Fabricant was said to be bidding.
The Johns was one of nine works being sold by the Israel Phoenix Assurance Company, which owns one of the few corporate collections in Israel, formed by Joseph Hackmey, the company's former managing director. The collection was estimated at $14.2 million to $20 million. Rather than give the corporation a guarantee, an undisclosed minimum sum regardless of the sale's outcome, Christie's had bought the nine works outright.
(Final prices include Christie's commission: 19.5 percent on the first $100,000 and 10 percent on the rest. Estimates do not reflect commissions.)
Another much-desired painting last night was Lichtenstein's "Happy Tears" (1964). Two bidders competed for the painting, which ended up selling for $7.1 million, just above its high estimate, $7 million, and a record for the artist.
The image, a close-up of a woman with flaming-red hair holding her head in her hands and crying with a big smile on her face, was being sold by Robert and Janet Kardon. He is a retired industrialist from Philadelphia; she is the former director of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia and the American Craft Museum in Manhattan. Christie's had given the Kardons a guarantee that experts say was $6 million. It was a risk worth taking.
Another Pop painting brought more than its high estimate. Six bidders wanted to take home Warhol's "Big Electric Chair" (1967), an image from one of the artist's famous series, this one with a hot pink background. The painting finally sold to Philippe Segalot, a private Manhattan dealer, for $4.9 million, nicely above its $4 million high estimate. The painting was being sold by Francois Pinault, the French luxury goods magnate who owns Christie's. He could be spotted in a skybox above Christie's salesroom, looking down on all the bidding.
Not all Warhols did so well. "Camouflage Last Supper," a 1986 image in bright red and pink that was being sold by the San Francisco collectors Kent and Vicki Logan, was expected to bring $1.5 million to $2 million, but there wasn't a bid in sight.
Perhaps the rarest painting was Barnett Newman's "White Fire I" (1954), the first major Newman on the market since Christie's sold "The Word II," from the same year, for $3 million, a record for the artist, in 1995. That record was broken last night when an unidentified telephone bidder was willing to pay $3.8 million, just below its $4 million low estimate. The painting consists of an aqua background punctuated by two zips, as the artist called them: a wide pale beige band on the left and a bleeding blue stripe on the right. Not only had it been in the recent Newman retrospective at the Philadelphia Museum of Art this year, but it had also hung on the walls of the Tate Modern until two weeks ago, when it was brought from London for the sale. (The Tate hopes the new owner will let it go back to the exhibition, which closes on Jan 5.)
The Newman came from the Israel Phoenix Assurance Company. So did an untitled 1967 work by Eva Hesse. Fashioned from sculpt-metal over steel washers and wood, it was estimated at $300,000 to $400,000. Two telephone bidders tried to buy the piece, which brought $405,500.
Years ago there was no appetite whatsoever for Color Field artists, but that is changing. Last night five bidders went for an untitled Morris Louis painting from 1959-60 that was estimated at $700,000 to $900,000. An unidentified buyer snapped it up for $1.6 million, a record for the artist.
Alexander Calder's work seems to perform well in any economic climate. Last night, his "S-Shaped Vine," a (1946), a hanging mobile made of black sheet metal and wire, brought $2.5 million. The buyer was Larry Gagosian, the Manhattan dealer, who was willing to reach far beyond the $1.6 million high estimate.
Amy Cappellazzo, who heads Christie's contemporary-art department in New York, said she thought the reason for last night's consistently strong prices was that the sale was commercial and "just what the market wanted": Pop Art and top examples of classic contemporary artists.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-16

Iraq Accepts Resolution But Denies Having Arms
In a testy letter to the United Nations, Iraq said it would accept a Security Council resolution obligating it to disarm and would allow U.N. weapons inspectors to begin work. But Baghdad also denied having any weapons of mass destruction. A1

Secretary General Kofi Annan urged the United States to be "a bit patient" and not to rush toward military action. A1

Bin Laden Tape Analysis
Administration officials said government linguists believed that a new audiotape broadcast on Arab television contained the voice of Osama bin Laden. But initial analysis by electronics experts could not determine whether the tape was genuine. A1

Governments of Western countries named in the tape as potential targets of terrorist attacks said they were treating the tape's message seriously but that the implication that Mr. bin Laden is alive had not forced them to change security arrangements. A17

Russian Investigation Rejected
Russia's lower house of Parliament rejected two proposals to set up an independent commission to investigate the siege of a Moscow theater that resulted in the death of at least 128 hostages and 41 Chechen hostage-takers. A6

Iran Professor Refuses Appeal
A reformist academic who received a death sentence for saying that Muslims should not blindly follow leaders like "monkeys" declared that he would refuse to appeal the verdict, driving a fifth day of student demonstrations against Iran's hard-line leadership. A5

Israeli Forces Sweep Nablus
Israeli forces took up positions and searched houses across Nablus after a large force of tanks and troop carriers pushed into the city in response to an attack that killed five Israelis, including two children, in a kibbutz near the West Bank. A12

NATIONAL A21-33

Bishops Approve Revisions To Sexual-Abuse Rules
After nearly 11 months of unrelenting scandal, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops voted overwhelmingly to pass revised rules that they insist will eventually remove from public ministry any priest who has ever sexually abused a minor. A1

HEADLINE: Coral Reefs Off the Florida Keys Get Protection From Large Ships 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
Coral reefs off the Florida Keys, part of the world's third-largest barrier reef ecosystem, will be protected from damage by large ships under a new international agreement, the Bush administration said today.
 The body of water stretching from Biscayne National Park to the Tortugas, 3,000 square nautical miles, is the first area designated in the United States to protect the reefs from anchoring, grounding and collisions from passing ships, officials from the Commerce Department said. 
 The protected region, in the Florida Straits, includes the Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary, which Congress and President George Bush created in 1990. 
Starting on Dec. 1, captains of ships longer than 164 feet will have to avoid certain areas in the protected zone and will be prohibited from anchoring in some other places. Nautical charts produced throughout the world will show the protected zone and reflect its requirements. Violators will face fines up to $100,000 per violation per day.
Samuel W. Bodman, deputy commerce secretary, called the agreement a triumph of cooperation between federal officials, the shipping industry and the International Maritime Organization, a United Nations group that regulates the shipping industry.
"This rare international form of protection now awarded to fragile Florida Keys coral reefs is an example of how federal resource managers can work closely with industry to protect vulnerable natural resources while simultaneously supporting shipping and economic growth," Mr. Bodman said. "Both ship trade and the tourism tied to the Keys coral reefs have vital economic significance to the state and region."
The proposal has been supported by the Coast Guard, the State Department and environmental groups in Florida. 
More than 40 percent of the world's commerce passes through the Florida Straits each year, officials said. Ships have damaged the reef ecosystem through anchoring, groundings, collisions and the discharge of harmful substances. Ten large ships have grounded in the now-protected zone since 1984.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has said coral reefs are threatened by pollution, overfishing and coastal development. A study on the health of 7,600 square miles of coral reefs within waters controlled by the United States and its territories, released last month by the agency, found that global warming also caused significant long-term damage to the reefs.
There are four other protected areas like the one announced today: the Great Barrier Reef off Australia; the Sabana-Camaguey Archipelago in Cuba; Malpelo Island in Colombia; and the Wadden Zee in the Netherlands .

CORRECTION-DATE: November 16, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about an international agreement to protect coral reefs in the Florida Straits from damage by large ships cited an incorrect figure from the Department of Commerce on the amount of cargo that passes through the straits each year. It is 40 percent of the world's shipping commerce, not of all commerce.

GRAPHIC: Map of Florida highlighting Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary: An area along the Florida Keys is now protected water.

HEADLINE: Bush Administration Halts Payments to Send Oil to North Korea 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
The Bush administration said today that it would stop financing monthly shipments of fuel oil to North Korea, which are required under a 1994 arms control agreement, to punish North Korea for pursuing a covert nuclear weapons program.
 But the White House, in a bow to its closest Pacific allies, Japan and South Korea, said it would not demand that a tanker carrying this month's shipment of 42,500 metric tons of oil turn around before reaching North Korea. The ship is just days from port, officials said. 
 The compromise decision, made by President Bush during a meeting of the National Security Council today, underscores the administration's desire to maintain a united front with its allies in pressing North Korea to abandon its nuclear program, administration officials said.
Japan and South Korea have resisted the administration's urgings to cut ties to North Korea, arguing that engagement is the best way to change its behavior.
The administration will make its case against future fuel shipments at a meeting of the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization in New York on Thursday.
Japan, South Korea and the European Union also sit on the organization's board. Though the organization operates on a consensus basis, the United States carries a powerful bargaining chip: it pays for almost all of the oil costs, which amounted to $86 million in the last fiscal year.
The energy organization does not have enough money to buy the December shipment, officials said. While South Korea or Japan could foot the December bill, they are expected to adopt the United States' position opposing future shipments, at least temporarily, American and Asian diplomats said.
"One of our goals here has been to present North Korea with a united front," a senior administration official said. "We are interested in maintaining that consensus when we come out of that meeting."
But the future of that consensus remains in doubt. Should the standoff continue deep into the frigid Korean winter, pressure may grow in South Korea to resume oil shipments. Some officials in the Bush administration also want to preserve elements of the 1994 agreement, though more hard-line officials contend that it should be scrapped.
The 1994 agreement called on North Korea to freeze and then dismantle its nuclear weapons program in exchange for help in building two light-water nuclear reactors and for the annual delivery of 500,000 metric tons of fuel oil. North Korea admitted last month that it had violated the pact by developing a program to enrich uranium for nuclear bombs.
The president's decision on future shipments was praised by a number of lawmakers in Congress, although some urged him to take an even harder line.
"I'm pleased to hear that the Bush administration isn't going to fund further fuel oil shipments to North Korea," said Representative Edward J. Markey, a Massachusetts Democrat who is co-chairman of the Bipartisan Congressional Task Force on Nonproliferation.
"But if all the Bush administration does is step aside and let the South Koreans or the Japanese pick up the tab," he said, "it hasn't really accomplished very much. The most important thing the president could do right now is to announce today that the United States will not support the continued construction of two light-water reactors."

HEADLINE: Democrats Select Boston for 2004 Convention 

BYLINE:  By PAM BELLUCK 

DATELINE: BOSTON, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
As cities go, Boston has had its share of recent chips on its shoulder. 
 The Big Dig, the endlessly expensive endeavor to bury bulky highways underground, has been a mammoth eyesore and a national joke. Race relations were a mess in a city where the battleground of busing still smoldered. Business in the bassinet of American history was not exactly booming. 
 But today the city received word that at least some of those legacies have lifted, as the Democratic National Committee declared that Boston would be the site of its 2004 convention. The decision gave the city its first national political convention and provided a major salve to its ego. 
After five years of angling for the convention and being slapped down in its bid for the 2000 event, Boston beat out Miami (it would have been hurricane season), Detroit (which lacked the hotel rooms) and, especially, New York, the other leading contender. But New York rejected the demand to drop its desire to be host to the Republican convention, too. 
In Boston today, it was pretty much impossible to find a skeptic to play down the significance of the victory. 
"It's huge," Thomas Piper, an urban-planning research scientist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said. "It's a sign that Boston is a heads-up place. And it's a sign that there is something called the 21st century. People forget that this is a place where people often can't come together. But this suggests that there may be a future out there." 
Boston won after intensive lobbying by Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Mayor Thomas M. Menino, especially their Herculean effort to prod businesses to contribute $20 million. It was the first time that a city had "put money on the table" before a convention bid was awarded, Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said.
Solid financing was considered paramount, because the Democrats were still smarting from the chaos of the 2000 convention in Los Angeles, where the city fell short of its budget and Mr. McAuliffe, then in charge of fund-raising for President Bill Clinton, was hastily named convention chairman and had to raise $11 million in a matter of weeks.
Today, Mr. McAuliffe said the Boston bid "puts us on fiscally sound footing." In addition to the business role, $17 million was pledged by federal, state and local governments, along with $12.5 million of in-kind donations from private sources.
New York convention backers were not pleased. A loyal Democratic contributor, John A. Catsimatidis, wrote to Mr. McAuliffe that New York had been "passed over in our time of need" 
"By choosing Boston over New York," Mr. Catsimatidis said, "our task of raising money for our nominee will be much harder."
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York said: "I was told they wanted to go to Boston. They'd never been there before."
Mr. McAuliffe, referring to the prospect that the Republicans might go to New York, said, "We have to do something unique with our convention in 2004." 
Democratic officials said Boston officials had convinced the party that the city had resolved many of the problems that dogged it in 2000. The Big Dig would be 85 percent complete by the start of the convention, scheduled for July 26, and any potential traffic problems would be ironed out, the city said. 
Boston officials also worked to address whether this historically racially polarized city could evoke enough positive feelings from minority groups. Its bid included appointing a "diversity director," in charge of topics like making sure that minorities are involved in convention planning and that minority contractors are amply represented in convention-related work. 
At a news conference at City Hall, Mayor Menino insisted that the city no longer deserved to be considered racially divided. "That's the old reputation of Boston," he said. 
He introduced two black legislators and the president of the local Urban League. 
"I'm black, I'm woman, I'm immigrant," said Marie P. St. Fleur, a state representative from Boston who came from Haiti. "I'm excited about the new Boston, a Boston that is inclusive."
Ms. St. Fleur added that Mr. Menino was "trying to make it the city it ought to be." 
"We're not there," she said. "But at least, we're dealing with it frankly." 
Several experts were surprised that on the heels of Nov. 5 the Democrats chose a city known as a bastion of liberalism.
"With the fact that they're not going to get one more Democratic vote out of Massachusetts than they would have otherwise, it's sort of astonishing that the party has decided to come to Boston," said Alex Krieger, chairman of the urban planning department at Harvard.
Some Democrats said emphasizing the liberal side could help the party look more assertive. Committee leaders said that was not a factor in their decision.
Having the convention here means it will be in the home state of Senator John Kerry, who will probably seek the presidential nomination. Asked whether the choice would help him because he had the potential to be the nominee, Mr. Kerry asked, "Can you share with me how great that potential may be?"
By all accounts, Mr. Kennedy's role was pivotal, going beyond fund-raising to include a presentation to the site committee in which he recited a poem based on Longfellow's "Midnight Ride of Paul Revere," accompanied by a fife and drum band. The senator also presented Mr. McAuliffe with an eight-page white paper that he asked a former columnist for The Boston Globe to write, emphasizing Boston's strengths and beginning with, "Nobody wants it like we do."
A jubilant Mr. Kennedy presented Mr. McAuliffe with a gavel made of wood from the U.S.S. Constitution, saying he could use it at the convention. Executives celebrated, saying the convention would not only provide a direct lift economically -- Mr. Menino has estimated $156 million in revenue -- but would also have ripple effects by giving a good impression of the city. 
Jack Connors, an advertising executive who was co-chairman of the Boston convention committee, said the donations by businesses like Raytheon and FleetBoston Financial were a "way for big business to demonstrate that they care about small business, restaurant owners, hotel operators." 
Sal Tecce, owner of Joe Tecce's restaurant in the North End, will be perfectly happy to accept the help. 
"It will put the city in the national spotlight," Mr. Tecce said, "and will help bring business back to Boston. He added with a hint of the old underdog image, "Or we can make a mess and no one will come back."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Edward M. Kennedy presented a gavel made of wood from the U.S.S. Constitution yesterday to Terry McAuliffe. Also on hand were Senator John Kerry and Alice Huffman of the site advisory panel. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Staring Into the Abyss 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
"We are still a city of big dreams, of big ideas, big projects and a big heart," said Michael Bloomberg in his inaugural address as mayor of New York last Jan. 1.
 It was a good line, given that it was delivered less than four months after the horror of Sept. 11, 2001. But it was weakened a bit by the fact that it came right after a line that rang obviously false in a city that was faced not only with a crisis of confidence, but with a terrible budget crisis as well. 
 "We cannot raise taxes," said Mr. Bloomberg. "We will find another way." 
I knew the mayor was wrong and I thought at the time that he was making a mistake politically. He was a fresh face at City Hall. He carried none of the baggage of his predecessors. And he had insisted throughout his campaign that he was not a typical politician. At that moment, Mike Bloomberg, of all people, was in a position to level with the public, to tell the truth. And the truth was that the budget situation was dire, so dire that there was no way to avoid increased taxes as part of the solution.
Instead, like a typical politician, Mike Bloomberg dissembled.
And he kept on dissembling. "It is exactly the wrong time to even contemplate raising taxes," he said at the end of February. "I think considering it does a disservice to New York City."
He hewed to that disingenuous line for months, until the reality could no longer be concealed from even the least discerning eye. The city is in a budget meltdown, and the state is not far behind. It's the worst fiscal crisis since the disaster of the 1970's.
The mayor's flip-flop -- he's now in favor of raising taxes -- was only part of the problem. The bigger disservice to both city and state residents was the overall refusal of Mr. Bloomberg and the other top politicians of both major parties to be candid and to work together in figuring out the most responsible ways to cope with the billions of dollars in deficits that have piled up in the city and state budgets.
Mr. Bloomberg, a Republican, should have been leading the fight on behalf of the city, working tirelessly, among other things, for whatever assistance might be secured from his fellow Republicans in Albany and Washington. The mayor was right when he insisted that severe budget cuts were inevitable. But that was never going to be enough. As the speaker of the City Council, Gifford Miller, has argued for the better part of a year, "The city cannot cut its way out of this crisis."
New York City has to close a gap that is estimated at $1 billion for the remainder of this fiscal year and $6 billion for next year. This comes at the same time that the state is facing a shortfall next year of up to $10 billion.
No new taxes? That refrain has finally been shelved, and the whole hideous constellation of service cuts and potential tax hikes is emerging for all to see. Mayor Bloomberg now seems to be moving to the opposite extreme, seeking a property tax hike of as much as 25 percent and enactment of a politically untenable income tax on commuters several times as large as the commuter tax that was scrapped a few years ago.
Calls are also going out for transit fare hikes, and tolls on the East River bridges.
We are witnessing the first stage of what may become a precipitous decline in the city's quality of life. All the tax arrows are pointing up and all the service arrows are pointing down. Hunger, homelessness and unemployment are big problems. Library hours are shrinking and resources are being carted away from a school system that was already in deep trouble.
It won't be long before sharp cuts are felt in such vital areas as police, fire and sanitation.
The city cannot arrest the decline by itself. It does not have the resources. Only a concerted effort that includes substantial help from the state and federal governments can do that. But there is no one leading such an effort.
Mayor Bloomberg spoke in January about a city of big dreams and big ideas. It was a nice sentiment. But at the moment the city is broke and its future is bleak. A galvanizing vision is needed. If the mayor has some real sense of how to get beyond this crisis that is threatening to undo the hard-won progress of the past decade, now would be a good time to disclose it.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Says He Supports Bush Tax Cut 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, weighed in today in favor of President Bush's campaign to make last year's tax cuts permanent, lending a powerful voice to a high priority of the new Republican Congress.
 "It would probably be unwise to unwind the long-term tax cut, because it is already built into the system," Mr. Greenspan told members of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee. 
 Mr. Greenspan refuted the Bush administration on a crucial point, however, saying that continuing the planned schedule of tax cuts would provide almost no stimulus to the economy because the move would affect taxes that kick in mostly during the second half of the decade. 
Mr. Greenspan's comments on taxes came in response to questions from lawmakers. In his earlier testimony to the committee, the Fed chairman remained cautiously optimistic on the economy, saying it seemed to be in the midst of a "soft patch" rather than a renewed downturn. The recent Fed rate cut, to 1.25 percent from 1.75 percent, he said, was primarily an "insurance premium" in case the economic troubles were worse than Fed officials generally believed.
Mr. Greenspan's support for making the tax cuts permanent is likely to make it even more difficult for those lawmakers, mostly Democrats, who argue that the planned tax cuts should be postponed or scaled back because the government is already facing years of big deficits.
While cautioning that Congress will face difficult choices down the road in bringing government spending more in line with revenues, Mr. Greenspan said that not making the tax cuts permanent would disappoint investors and make things worse.
"There are potential adverse consequences, which I don't think are desirable," he said.
At the White House, Mr. Bush insisted again today on making last year's tax cuts permanent and intimated that he might propose additional tax measures on top of that to stimulate the economy.
"I sent a signal to Congress that I believe that we need to have further discussions how to best stimulate the economy," he told reporters at a news conference today. "And I'm very serious about that."
Largely because of the economic slowdown, the downward plunge of stock markets and the initial round of tax cuts approved by Congress last year, the federal budget swung from a surplus of more than $100 billion last year to a deficit of about $159 billion this year. 
Though neither Democrats nor Republicans have any appetite for trying to balance the budget amid the gloom and uncertainty in today's economy, there is a big debate about whether to cut taxes even further in the years ahead.
The Congressional Budget Office, the nonpartisan agency that analyzes the government's trends in taxes and spending, estimates that making last year's tax cuts permanent will reduce federal revenues by nearly $200 billion a year by 2012. 
Many budget experts worry that the extension of tax cuts will take hold at the same time that the aging of the baby boom generation begins to create the need for a surge in outlays for Social Security and Medicare.
Mr. Bush reiterated his view that the main reason for the new budget deficit was the faltering economy, and he argued that the best way to balance the budget was to stimulate more economic growth.
"The deficit is caused by the fact that revenues have not come in," he said. "And there's two things we can do about it: one, stimulate the economy to create more revenues; and, two, hold down spending." 
Despite repeated hints since August about proposals for additional tax cuts, the Bush administration has so far refrained from offering any specific proposals for new breaks.
Among the ideas under study are additional tax breaks for individual investors, like increasing the amount people can put into tax-deferred retirement plans; increasing the amount people can deduct on their taxes from investment losses; increasing business tax breaks for investment; and possibly reducing taxes on corporate dividends. 
"The key will be to maintain cash flow in the private sector," said Lawrence B. Lindsey, head of the White House's National Economic Council, in a speech to the United States Chamber of Commerce.
But Mr. Lindsey cautioned that Mr. Bush was still "evaluating options" and hinted at the administration's own concerns about the rising deficit. "We do not live in an environment in which we have unlimited income," he said. "It is a balancing act."
Among Republicans in Congress, support appears to be considerably stronger for cutting taxes rather than worrying about narrowing the budget deficit. "Nobody is closing the door" to tax cuts, said one Republican staff member on the House Ways and Means Committee, where tax bills originate. 
Meanwhile, one of the Senate's most forceful Republican advocates of fiscal austerity -- Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico -- let it be known today that he will step down as chairman of the Senate Budget Committee to become chairman of the Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. 
His successor will be Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, who has long been an advocate for tax cuts.
In his testimony today, Mr. Greenspan also expressed confidence that the United States could shoulder the costs of a war with Iraq, arguing that the economic impact would be significantly less than that of the wars in Korea and Vietnam.
Less than two weeks after the Fed cut interest rates by an unusually large half a percentage point, Mr. Greenspan acknowledged that the economy was weighed down by uncertainty and "geopolitical risk" -- a euphemism for the prospects of a war with Iraq.
Mr. Greenspan said there was no evidence, "at least up to the moment," that an economic downturn was accelerating. And while saying the Federal Reserve remained ready to intervene again if the economy did deteriorate, he said the "most probable path" was one of gradual improvement and that another round of monetary stimulus would not be necessary.
But even if the economy deteriorated further, Mr. Greenspan said, he still disputed economists who worried that the Federal Reserve had exhausted its tools for fighting potential deflation in prices or was close to losing the ability to revive the economy because interest rates had reached such low levels. If need be, he said, the Federal Reserve could still stimulate activity by buying up a wide range of securities in the financial markets.

HEADLINE: House Approves Domestic Security Bill 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 

 BODY:
The House hurriedly approved a revised domestic security bill tonight to reflect a new agreement with the White House on reducing worker protections, brushing aside Democratic objections that Republican leaders had added several provisions benefiting businesses and Republican interests.
 The bill, approved 299 to 121, would reverse an earlier measure and allow American companies that have moved offshore in order to evade taxes to contract with the Homeland Security Department. It would also extend protection against liability suits for airline screening companies and many other businesses that contract with the department, and adds a similar provision protecting the makers of smallpox vaccines. 
 Most Democrats voted against the bill, with many raising objections to the new provisions and the altering of Civil Service rules. 
The House voted 215 to 203 along party lines not to create an independent commission to investigate the Sept. 11 attacks. Several members of both parties in the two chambers said they would try to include the commission in an intelligence spending bill that has still not been passed. But Republican House leaders said the commission needed more planning, drawing complaints from relatives of attack victims that they were trying to hide failures that might have prevented the attacks.
Working to conclude the year's legislative business by week's end, the House also passed a stopgap spending measure to keep the government operating through January. Many members of both parties had hoped the House would pass at least a few of the pending appropriations bills the government uses to keep operating, but House leaders said they would take up the bills once the new Congress convened next year.
As expected, Republican House members elected Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, formerly the majority whip, to the new post of majority leader in the next session. 
Democratic House members are scheduled to conduct their leadership elections on Thursday, and are likely to choose Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, now the minority whip, as their leader.
This morning, however, a new candidate for the job emerged, demonstrating the continuing disagreements among Democrats over how to respond to their losses in last week's elections. Representative Marcy Kaptur of Ohio said she would run for the position to draw votes from members who object to Ms. Pelosi's emphasis on fund-raising.
"We will never raise more money than the Republicans -- never," said Ms. Kaptur, who is known for her opposition to free-trade measures and federal funding for abortions. "We must elevate the non-money wing of the Democratic Party and create populist symbols to convey our message."
Ms. Kaptur joins Harold E. Ford Jr. of Tennessee in contesting the Democratic leadership election, for which Ms. Pelosi claims to already have sufficient support to win.
In the Senate, Republicans chose Trent Lott of Mississippi to be the majority leader in the next term, along with Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky as majority whip and Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona in the third-ranking job of leading the Republican Policy Committee. Mr. Lott said after today's election that Republicans would focus on national and economic security, mentioning specifically a prescription drug program for low-income older people and making individual retirement accounts easier to use.
Senate Democrats also held their leadership elections today, unanimously choosing Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota as chairman of the caucus, along with Senators Harry Reid of Nevada and Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland in the No. 2 and No. 3 positions. Mr. Daschle will be minority leader in the next Senate, Mr. Reid will be minority whip.
Senators also voted 58 to 36 not to block their annual pay raise, which would increase their salaries by 3.1 percent to $154,700 to $150,000 next year. Passage of an energy bill was deferred until next year because of continuing partisan disagreements over regulation and conservation.
The Senate began a lengthier process of approving the domestic security bill, which is expected to pass as early as Friday.
Senators showed that they remained closely divided on the bill, deciding 50 to 47 to drop the Democratic version of the bill on a closely watched test vote. The new version of the bill will have enough votes for passage, but many Democrats remain upset that President Bush won virtually his entire plan to cut back on civil service protections for workers, making it easier to fire and transfer them.
Many Democrats in both chambers were furious today when they read the fine print of the new version of the bill and found that Republicans had inserted provisions that had not been discussed in the six months of debate on the antiterrorism department, or that had been cut in the Senate bill.
The new language, for example, allows the administration to reorganize the department after it is created, differing from the Senate Republican version that would require congressional approval of a reorganization. It revises a provision, passed 318 to 110 in July, that prohibited contracts with offshore tax-evading companies, allowing the department to waive the ban in the name of saving American jobs.
The bill would allow immunity from liability for companies that make faulty antiterrorism devices or technology, and would make it difficult to sue companies that make smallpox vaccinations if the vaccines cause illness.
In one last-minute addition, Representative Dick Armey, Republican of Texas, inserted a provision that was apparently intended to protect Eli Lilly, the pharmaceutical giant, from lawsuits over thimerosal, a mercury-based vaccine preservative that some parents contend has caused autism in their children.
"I'm really quite surprised they would put in the fine-print provisions we never saw in any other versions, that never even went through committees," said Representative Henry A. Waxman of California, the ranking Democrat on the House Government Reform Committee."
But Republicans, like Representative William M. Thornberry of Texas, said the additions were minor and paled next to the importance of creating a department to protect the nation's safety.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Trent Lott after being chosen by the Republican caucus yesterday to be the next majority leader. (Doug Mills/The New York Times)
