HEADLINE: Teachers Wrap Lessons In Fiction 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA COHEN 

 BODY:
Little did the hapless Richard Burns know that the strange, bedraggled man who pounded on his door one rainy night would end up making him the obsession of a long-dead spirit.
 Or more to the point, subject him to long disquisitions on savings and capital accumulation, the gains of trade and the role of the "invisible hand" in markets. 
 That is because the irksome spirit in this new novel is none other than Adam Smith, the father of modern economics, who is so distraught that his theories have been wretchedly misunderstood that he is driven to return to Earth and set the record straight. 
Though the book, "Saving Adam Smith," may not offer much page-turning competition to Stephen King's collected works, the novel has found its way onto reading lists in economics courses at Rutgers University, LaSalle University, the University of Richmond and a handful of other colleges around the country. 
Looking for fresh ways to engage overloaded students, a growing number of professors at big universities and small colleges are supplementing traditionally sober textbooks with a curious genre: the textbook-novel. 
Written specifically with the college classroom in mind, these works are often by professors who have created characters ranging from a free trade-spouting angel to a short, bald professor (take a bow, Milton Friedman) who likes to solve mysteries. And while pedagogical novels are not new, their growing popularity is. 
"It's an old genre in economics," said Deirdre McCloskey, professor of economics, history and English at the University of Illinois at Chicago. "In the early 19th century, it was quite common to teach free market principles this way." Harriet Martineau, for instance, wrote the nine-volume "Illustrations of Political Economy" in 1832, moral tales intended for adults following classical economics. "It also became a common form later in the late 19th and earlier 20th century in thinking about socialism," Professor McCloskey said. 
What's different now, she continued, is that economists are assigning such books: "That is new. Economists think of themselves as scientists with a capital S, and assume there is a big gap between science and art."
Indeed, these textbook alternatives can be found on syllabuses in hundreds of college economics courses and related subjects around the country. Their use has become the subject of articles in scholarly publications and conferences. Earlier this year, the American Economic Association for the first time held a session on using novels to teach. Publishers, too, are beginning to take notice. "They really do well for us," said Anne Bunn, sales manager for MIT Press, which has published two economics novels since 1998. "We're bringing another one out next year."
Nor is economics the only field to feel the literary impulse. "Evidence suggests that use of the accounting novel in classrooms is fairly widespread and growing in acceptance," the CPA Journal reported in March. And in addition to economics and accounting, fictional texts have also crept into physics and cryptology courses, according to The Chronicle of Higher Education.
"I'm trying to teach economics in a different way," said Russell Roberts, an economics professor at Washington University in St. Louis, who is one of the best-known economics novelists. "There are really two goals. One is to put some sugar with the medicine, as students try to master something that is inherently difficult. The second is to bring economics to life in the way a formal presentation can't. It has weaknesses. It's not as rigorous, but there is rigor elsewhere. I'm trying to bring the poetry and the soul to economics, and you can't do that with a graph and a chart."
Professor Roberts has written two novels. The first, "The Choice: A Fable of Free Trade and Protectionism," uses as a model Frank Capra's film "It's a Wonderful Life." In this case, an angel -- none other than the 19th-century English economist David Ricardo -- works to win his wings by offering a protectionist businessman a glimpse of a mean and pinched world without free trade. First released in 1994, the book has sold more than 50,000 copies, most if not all for use in the classroom, Professor Roberts said. The updated 2000 edition is being used by 95 different colleges, according to its publisher, Prentice Hall.
The latest Roberts novel, "The Invisible Heart: An Economic Romance," published last year by MIT Press, examines corporate responsibility and consumer safety while following the blossoming love story between a high school economics teacher and an English instructor. It has been assigned in over 25 universities so far. The publication even prompted Hollywood to come knocking, with DreamWorks asking to see a copy. (Alas, Professor Roberts said, the studio wasn't interested).
In his introductory course, Allen Sanderson, the associate chairman of the economics department at the University of Chicago, uses "The Choice" and an economics mystery novel called "Fatal Equilibrium," part of an extraordinarily popular series by Kenneth G. Elzinga and William Breit, two economists who use the pen name Marshall Jevons. They patterned their protagonist, a Harvard professor and amateur sleuth named Henry Spearman, on Milton Friedman. ("Fatal Equilibrium" is already in its 20th printing and has also attracted some sniffing from Hollywood. The first in the series, "Murder at the Margins," has been used at more than 400 colleges and universities, Professor Breit said.) 
"One of the challenges and goals is to get students to think as economists think about how do you approach a problem," Professor Sanderson said. When he assigns a book like "Fatal Equilibrium," what he hopes is that a student will "sit in the bathtub for a couple of hours and begin to approach problems and think as we do," he continued, adding, "They really are a relatively painless way to learn economics."
Robert Garnett, an economics professor at Texas Christian University in Fort Worth, decided to spend the first five weeks of his senior economics seminar last spring teaching "Saving Adam Smith." He had been told about it by a student who came across the book on Amazon.com. 
"What really works well with this particular book," Professor Garnett said, "is that there has been a lot of new scholarship on Adam Smith in the past 10 years, and this book makes that accessible to students in a narrative. It really opens their eyes to what Adam Smith was all about, that he wasn't just a hard-headed free-market economist; that to him, economics was a branch of moral philosophy." 
Jonathan B. Wight, the author of "Saving Adam Smith" and an economics professor at the University of Richmond, said that recent scholarship had revised the conventional view of Adam Smith as a no-holds-barred free-market crusader who believed "greed is good." Just as important as the seminal "Wealth of Nations," Mr. Wight says, is "The Theory of Moral Sentiments," in which Smith argues that a moral community -- with its social norms and government institutions -- must undergird any viable economic one. 
Indeed, the Adam Smith in Mr. Wight's novel may not be all that recognizable. Dispensing advice to the lovelorn and urging inner peace and transformation, Adam Smith's spirit seems to have crossed wires with Dear Abby and Buddha while traversing the spirit world. 
If the students in Professor Garnett's class found the economics compelling, they were less taken with the novel's hard-to-swallow fictional soup. (For instance, there is a love story involving a put-upon economics doctoral student, Richard Burns, who is stalked by an assassin, a disillusioned antiglobalization crusader who rails against the treachery of the World Trade Organization but is secretly backed by the Russian mafia.)
"The best part about it was that it made it very accessible and easy to understand," said Joseph Blosser, an economics and religion major, who was in Professor Garnett's seminar. "The worst part was the literary quality. You can't approach this book as a fine work of literature. You have to approach it as a tool for learning about Adam Smith, and in that sense it definitely accomplishes what the author set out to do." 
Indeed, these novels aren't likely to cross over to the English department anytime soon. 
That is why Professor McCloskey -- who says, "I got into economics because of 'Grapes of Wrath' and Joan Baez" -- prefers serious literature to the narrative textbooks. "I assign Dickens's 'Hard Times,' which is awful as economics but creates interesting discussions," she said.
Professor Roberts candidly admits most of the pedagogical novels aren't very good. "In some of them," he says, "the fiction is great but the economics is mediocre or the economics is great but the fiction is mediocre."
Teaching economics through novels is not to everyone's taste, though. N. Gregory Mankiw, the author of "Principles of Economics," one of the largest-selling introductory economics textbooks, said that he had included the Jevons and Roberts novels in his text's suggested reading list, but that he had never used them in his undergraduate classes at Harvard. "I'm more of an eat-your-spinach kind of professor," he said. "My sense is that they're useful teaching tools in that they're fun, they get students to realize economics isn't quite as dismal as they claim it to be." But to learn about economics, he added, "you're probably better off sitting down for an hour with a textbook than with one of these novels."
Even Professor Elzinga added a note of caution: "I think the main drawback to pedagogical novels is with the instructor, at least in my field of economics, not knowing how to teach from the book, as opposed to simply assigning it as a 'fun' book." 
Although Professor Elzinga collaborated on the mysteries with the express purpose of teaching economics to students, he is happy to note that the books have a number of other readers. "My favorite fan letter came not from a student, but from a woman who was a professor of economics whose marriage was on the rocks," he said in an e-mail message. "She gave one of our mysteries to her husband who, upon reading it, said he now understood his wife's way of thinking. Their marriage was saved. True to her professional colors, she told us buying our book was more economical than marital counseling."

HEADLINE: When Peace Did Not Go Unpunished 

BYLINE:  By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
When Margaret MacMillan began working on her new history of the negotiations leading up to the Treaty of Versailles in 1919, she first had to revise her opinion of her great-grandfather, David Lloyd George, who was Britain's Prime Minister at the end of World War I. To her surprise, she discovered that he was not such a bad chap after all.
 "I grew up hearing what a great man he was and, in the adolescent way one reacts to things, I thought he probably was not that great," she recalled with a smile. "I had come to share Keynes's view that Lloyd George was without moral scruples and ruthless, dangerous and cynical. But in studying the peace conference, I decided he was actually very brave. He was a very good politician." 
 But by the time Ms. MacMillan had completed "Paris 1919: Six Months That Changed the World" (Random House), she had reached a far more radical conclusion: that the Treaty of Versailles, which was imposed on Germany by Lloyd George, President Woodrow Wilson and the French Prime Minister, Georges Clemenceau, was not responsible for the rise of Hitler and the new world war that followed. 
"Hitler did not wage war because of the Treaty of Versailles, although he found its existence a godsend for his propaganda," the Canadian-born historian writes. As for the three peacemakers, she believes they were genuinely well intentioned: "They could not foresee the future and they certainly could not control it. This was up to their successors. When war came in 1939, it was a result of 20 years of decisions taken or not taken, not of arrangements made in 1919."
The traditional view is that onerous war reparations drove the German economy to the collapse that brought Hitler and the Nazis to power in 1933. But Ms. MacMillan demonstrates that the reparations demanded of Germany were less than those paid by France after its defeat in the 1870 Franco-Prussian war. Further, she notes, Germany paid only about one-third of what it owed in compensation for its occupation and destruction of Belgium and northern France.
Rather, she believes, the real problem was that Germany did not feel defeated. "They didn't think they had lost the war," she said during a recent visit to Paris. "They'd never seen foreign troops on German soil. The German army marched back in good order to Berlin. German industry was intact. Germany was still the biggest European country west of the Soviet Union. It never really disarmed, and it was strong enough in 1939 to conquer most of Europe."
So, she was asked, should the Western powers have continued the war and taken it into Germany?
By fall 1918, she said, while the United States had only recently entered the war, France and Britain were exhausted by prolonged trench warfare that had cost them millions of lives. And they had another, more political, reason for signing the armistice on Nov. 11, 1918: "The French and particularly the British felt that, if the war went until spring 1919, the Americans would be that much more powerful, and they didn't want the Americans to be the dominant partner."
Thus, when Wilson, Lloyd George and Clemenceau gathered in Paris to prepare a permanent peace just two months after the armistice, they met on relatively equal terms. 
"They spent an enormous amount of time together," Ms. MacMillan said. She was being interviewed in the Hotel Crillon, which had served as headquarters of the American delegation. "One of the reasons I think the peace conference so fascinating is that it's never going to happen again. You will never get world leaders sitting in the same place for six months."
How the politics and personalities of Wilson, Lloyd George and Clemenceau shaped history, then, stands at the heart of "Paris 1919." Indeed, the British edition of this book, which in June won Britain's prestigious Samuel Johnson Prize for nonfiction, was called "Peacemakers: The Paris Conference of 1919 and Its Attempt to End War." ("I like 'Peacemakers,' but they told me at Random House that anything with Paris in the title tends to sell very well in the United States," Ms. MacMillan said with a laugh.)
"Lloyd George was the most affable and the most resilient, and he was probably the best at negotiating," explained Ms. MacMillan, 58, who is currently Provost of Trinity College at the University of Toronto. "But Clemenceau knew what he wanted and focused on that. And Wilson had a tremendous moral stature. Wilson, of course, could adopt a high moral tone, because he hadn't suffered the devastation."
Although all three leaders had liberal backgrounds, they also brought different global perspectives to the bargaining table: Wilson, who arrived with his famous Fourteen Points on a postwar order for Europe, was an idealist who advocated "self-determination"; Lloyd George was a pragmatist determined to protect and expand the interests of the British Empire; and Clemenceau was leader of a wounded France that twice in his lifetime had been invaded by a militaristic Germany.
"Paris 1919" tracks the complex and heated negotiations that preceded the signing of the peace treaty with Germany in the Hall of Mirrors of the Palace of Versailles on June 28, 1919. But it also places the peace conference, which continued for three more years, in the broader context of the extraordinary reorganization of European borders that followed the demise of the Austro-Hungarian and Ottoman empires. In the Middle East, too, new nations were created -- Iraq, Syria and Jordan, among them -- while the idea of a Jewish state was born.
The decisions taken in Paris at the time have again assumed relevance today because, in many ways, the post-cold war era has seen the end of the world molded after World War I. Versailles and successor agreements were meant to temper ethnic nationalism by forming viable nations that included large ethnic minorities, but some multiethnic countries created after 1918, like Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia, have now broken apart.
"Decisions made in an off-hand, casual way that you think aren't going to matter that much, 50 years down the road matter an awful lot," Ms. MacMillan observed. "What you got after 1989, which I think is what you got in 1919, was nationalism running amok."
It is a view echoed in a foreword to "Paris 1919" by Richard Holbrooke, the former American troubleshooter in the Balkans. "Some of the most intractable problems of the modern world have roots in decisions made right after the end of the Great War," he writes. "Among them one could list the four Balkan wars between 1991 and 1999; the crisis over Iraq (whose present borders resulted from Franco-British rivalries and casual mapmaking); the continuing quest of the Kurds for self-determination; disputes between Greece and Turkey; and the endless struggle between Arabs and Jews over land that each thought had been promised them."
Looking back at his role in the Dayton peace talks that ended the Bosnian war in 1995, Mr. Holbrooke says that "we were, in effect, burying another part of Versailles."
Yet Ms. MacMillan still hesitates before condemning Wilson, Lloyd George and Clemenceau for the consequences of the Treaty of Versailles and the Paris peace conference.
"I kept on thinking, 'What would I have done differently?' " she recalled. "I'm never going to be a great statesman, but if I am going to criticize them, I have to at least think, O.K., what would I have done differently? And you know, I don't know what I would have done differently."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Inch Higher as Mixed News Saps Rally's Vigor

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks inched higher yesterday, shaking off earlier declines, as a gauge of consumer confidence showed a rise for November. And despite renewed threats of a terrorist attack, all three main market gauges registered gains for the week, continuing a rally that began in early October.
 But the rally has lost some of its vigor despite good economic news in the last week and a half, including a half-point rate cut by the Federal Reserve; a sharp rise in retail sales, excluding autos, in October; and the jump in consumer confidence. Initial claims for unemployment insurance also declined this week. 
 Even with these developments, the market gauges are still below the levels they climbed to after Fed policy makers announced their rate cut on Nov. 6.
At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 36.96 points, or 0.4 percent, to 8,579.09. It was up 0.5 percent for the week, its sixth consecutive gain. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index index climbed 5.56 points, or 0.6 percent, to 909.83, and rose 1.7 percent for the week. The Nasdaq composite index slipped 0.38 point, to 1,411.14. It finished up 3.8 percent for the week. These two indexes have been up in five of the last six weeks.
One reason the six-week rally may be slowing is the renewed focus on terrorist attacks since the surfacing of a tape earlier this week attributed to Osama bin Laden. Then on Thursday, the F.B.I. issued a terrorist attack alert that said: "In selecting its next targets, sources suggest Al Qaeda may favor spectacular attacks that meet several criteria: high symbolic value, mass casualties, severe damage to the American economy and maximum psychological trauma."
Another reason is that the positive economic data may show only that the worst -- another recession -- has been avoided, not that the economic recovery, which has been slowing this quarter, is ready to pick up speed again.
"The retail sales numbers were very good and the jobless numbers were very good if you were worrying about a double-dip recession," said Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at ITG/Hoenig. "But if you were anticipating a continuing moderate economic expansion, these numbers were ho-hum."
Mr. Barbera also dismissed the importance of the jump in the consumer confidence index, which rose to 85 in November, from October's 80.6, in the preliminary reading of the University of Michigan's sentiment index. Although it was the first rise in six months, Mr. Barbera said "it just tells you that last month the stock market was up."
"Consumer sentiment is a lagging indicator," he added.
The surprise half-point rate cut suggests that Fed policy makers may think that the economy is in more trouble than many investors seem to think. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, did not appear to make investors feel more confident after he testified before Congress on Wednesday that the economy was working its way through a "soft patch."
The Federal Reserve also reported yesterday that industrial production fell 0.8 percent in October, the third consecutive monthly decline.
Based on flows into equity mutual funds, investors have been at best neutral on the stock market recently. According to numbers from AMG Data for the week ended Wednesday, the four-week moving average of flows into equity mutual funds is flat. In the previous week, there were outflows of $278 million.
But the flows into taxable bond funds were at a four-week moving average of $1.7 billion this week, with much of that going into high-yield junk bonds and investment-grade corporate bonds.
The surprise in the most recent data for the week is the record $81 billion net inflow into money market mutual funds, which are yielding barely 1 percent after the Fed cut its overnight interest rate to 1.25 percent. Robert Adler, the president of AMG Data, said most of this money was from institutional investors but that it was hard to say whether the move was a temporary parking of cash or a significant sign of disenchantment with the stock market.
Technology stocks led the market lower early yesterday, with Intel down as much as 5.8 percent, Microsoft off as much as 2.3 percent, I.B.M. down 2.1 percent and Dell Computer off 6.2 percent.
Merrill Lynch downgraded several semiconductor stocks, including Intel, to a sell ranking yesterday. After the market closed Thursday, Dell reported a 31 percent jump in third-quarter earnings, but the chief executive, Michael Dell, also said that there was no broad recovery on the horizon.
General Electric fell as much as 4.1 percent after a downgrade by J. P. Morgan. As G.E. and the technology stocks cut their losses later in the day, the Dow and the S.& P. moved into positive territory and the Nasdaq wiped out all but a fraction of a point of its losses.
While technology stocks led the market lower early yesterday, they have been crucial to the market turnaround. The two technology-related indexes in the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index are up more than 31 percent since the current rally began Oct. 9. They each had fallen 51 percent up to Oct. 9.
Citigroup, which rose 2.1 percent, was among the stocks that led the Dow higher yesterday. Citigroup fell 3.8 percent on Wednesday after new reports in the controversy over what influenced a former star analyst's change in his rating of AT&T stock.
In the bond market, the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note slipped to 4.03 percent, down from 4.05 percent Thursday. Over the last week, the yield is up from 3.85 percent as bond investors pushed interest rates higher when new data indicated that the economy was stronger than many of them had expected.

HEADLINE: Production At Factories Dipped 0.8% In October 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
Industrial production fell 0.8 percent in October -- the sharpest decline since September 2001, heightening concerns about the health of manufacturing, a new government report showed today.
 Other data showed an unexpected pickup in inflation at the producer level, and a recovery in consumer confidence. 
 Steve Ricchiuto, chief United States economist at the Dutch bank ABN Amro in New York, said that the reports fit in with the "soft-spot slow-growth jobless-recovery mind-set." 
"All you really know is the economy isn't losing ground," he said.
The decline in industrial production was the third consecutive monthly decline and followed a drop of 0.2 percent in September, the Federal Reserve reported. Economists had expected a drop of just 0.3 percent in October.
Factory output, which accounts for the largest portion of total industrial production, slid 0.7 percent in October, its third consecutive monthly drop, but at least some of the decline stemmed from an auto parts shortage and a shutdown of West Coast ports that curtailed car manufacturing.
Nonetheless, industrial output excluding autos was down 0.4 percent, while output outside the high-tech sector -- computers, semiconductors and communications equipment -- fell by 0.9 percent.
Economists said temporary factors relating to autos also distorted a report showing the largest increase in producer prices since January 2001.
The Producer Price Index, a measure of prices paid to manufacturers, farmers and other producers, rose 1.1 percent last month on big gains in the cost of gasoline, cars and light trucks, the Labor Department said.
The core index, which strips out volatile food and energy costs, increased 0.5 percent in October, its biggest move up since a matching rise in September 1999.
While the size of the gains surprised economists, who had expected producer prices to rise just 0.2 percent over all and 0.1 percent excluding food and energy, they said it did not represent a resurgence of inflation.
Instead, economists noted that the out-size gains reflected a 2.2 percent rise in car prices and a 1.9 percent increase in the cost of light trucks, which they attributed to an easing of aggressive sales incentives from automakers as higher-price new models moved into the showrooms.
The department said the core Producer Price Index would have been up only 0.1 percent in October if the sharp increases in car and truck prices were excluded.
A separate survey showed consumer sentiment strengthening from its depressed levels. The University of Michigan's preliminary November consumer sentiment index rose to 85.0 from a nine-year low of 80.6 in October. That put a halt to a five-month slide in sentiment, and exceeded forecasts of a rise to 82.3.

HEADLINE: Leader Sees Lean Times in Westchester 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
Andrew J. Spano, the Westchester County executive, said today that he wanted to eliminate 229 vacant county positions, raise bus fares and cut more than $4 million from a broad range of social service, housing, art and recreation programs to help close a $100 million gap in next year's budget. 
 Mr. Spano also called for a 28.6 percent increase in the county property tax levy, the amount of tax the county collects, a slight drop from the 31.7 percent increase that he initially announced last month. Mr. Spano said he had directed his staff to make additional cuts to bring the tax rate down after residents said they could not afford the larger increase. 
 "This budget is cut to the bone," Mr. Spano said during a news conference at his office, in which he unrolled a 12-foot-long sheet of paper listing all of the cuts and other budget items. "There are people asking us to tighten our belts; we just put a noose around our neck."
Still, Mr. Spano's proposals amounted to a $1.37 billion budget that was 6.3 percent bigger than this year's budget, or an increase of $82 million. Mr. Spano, a Democrat who once pledged to reduce taxes, blamed state lawmakers in Albany, saying that the increased spending would be used entirely to offset rising costs in Medicaid and other state-mandated programs. 
But several Westchester legislators and residents said Mr. Spano was trying to deflect attention from his spending increases over the years. "Instead of blaming Albany, we need to look at what the county fundamentally does," said George Oros, the Republican minority leader of the Board of Legislators, where the 2003 budget now goes for approval.
Westchester's budget tightening comes as cities and towns across the state are scrambling to fill their own budget holes with new sources of revenue. In New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called Wednesday for a sizable new income tax on people who work but do not live in the city, a proposal that would affect thousands of Westchester residents.
Today, Westchester officials said that while they sympathized with Mr. Bloomberg's fiscal problems, they would strongly oppose the tax on commuters. Susan Tolchin, chief adviser to Mr. Spano, pointed out that roughly 58,000 New York City residents commuted to work in Westchester.
"We would never think of charging them a commuter tax," Ms. Tolchin said. "Because they're working here, they're eating in our restaurants, they're buying goods in our stores, and they're helping our economy. The same goes for Westchester residents working in New York City."
Mr. Spano's major cutbacks included saving $16.4 million by eliminating vacant county positions; $4.2 million by reducing county services, largely through a 15 percent cut across the board for groups that run programs on domestic violence, drug abuse and the arts, among other things; and $2.1 million by deleting some bus routes and stops.
At the same time, Mr. Spano justified setting aside $500,000 for a six-month study on acquiring the Indian Point nuclear plants in Buchanan. He announced this week that he wanted to shut the plants by buying them, or if necessary, taking them through a condemnation process, and replacing them with a new natural gas plant.
If approved, the 28.6 percent property tax increase, one of the largest in county history, would raise $100.4 million more than was raised this year, for a total of $451.5 million in property taxes. Mr. Spano also proposed raising an additional $3.4 million through a 20-cent increase in bus fares to $1.60 beginning March 1, and increasing other county fees.
The county tax is only a share of the total property taxes on a home. Depending on the municipality, county property taxes account for 15 percent to 20 percent of the average tax bill of a homeowner. The remaining taxes pay for school districts, as well as city, town and village operations.

HEADLINE: Still Wary, Taiwan Split Over Change On Mainland 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
Government and business leaders here welcomed today the orderly transfer of power in Beijing and a series of Chinese overtures to Taiwan, but a deep split is evident on how to respond.
 Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwan's minister for relations with China, said conciliatory statements by President Jiang Zemin and Deputy Prime Minister Qian Qichen during and just before the Communist Party Congress in Beijing showed a new willingness on the mainland to negotiate closer links with Taiwan. At the congress, Hu Jintao replaced Mr. Jiang as head of the party. 
 "The position of both sides, after consideration of what has been said by both sides, is closer than before," Ms. Tsai said in an interview today.
But Ms. Tsai was wary about moving quickly to conclude any new deals with Beijing, even after recent comments by Mr. Qian, who has called for closer transportation links across the Taiwan Strait and has softened some of China's demands before that can happen.
"We still have reservations in the sense that we have to wait for some time to see if what he said is going to be a stable and consistent policy of China," she said.
Taiwan business leaders were much less cautious today, calling for a quick opening of direct flights and shipping routes to the mainland.
"I just hope they can negotiate a deal as quickly as possible," said Y. C. Wang, chairman of the Formosa Plastics Group and Taiwan's richest and best-known industrialist.
Focused on Iraq and the campaign against terrorism, the United States has urged China and Taiwan to avoid confrontations in the coming months like the dispute that erupted in August when President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan briefly hinted at a more pro-independence stance. Beijing regards Taiwan as rightfully a province of China.
Some warming of relations is already apparent. Taipei announced on Tuesday that it would allow chartered flights between Taiwan and Shanghai for Chinese New Year early next year. That would address the annual problem of tens of thousands of Taiwan business executives trying to return home for the holidays on a limited number of flights.
But Taipei said the chartered planes would have to fly via Hong Kong or Macao, taking six or seven hours instead of the 80 minutes a nonstop flight would require, because the Taiwan Strait is less than 100 miles wide. If direct flights were allowed they would approach Taipei so quickly that air defense systems might have trouble distinguishing them from a military attack.
Taiwan businesses have been the biggest "foreign" investors in China in the last decade, and they contend that the lack of direct transportation links and closer governmental relations have hurt their competitiveness. Beijing has welcomed the investment and has increasingly tried to draw Taiwan into a close economic embrace, a policy especially apparent in speeches at the Communist Party Congress.
Taiwan's government has been more wary, especially since the election two years ago of Mr. Chen, of the Democratic Progressive Party, which leans toward greater independence. The party tends to represent less-affluent voters who are wary of competition from low-wage businesses in China.
The opposition Nationalist Party, which ran Taiwan from 1949 to 2000, is closer to the island's business community and favors eventual reunification with the mainland. 
In an interview on Thursday, Lien Chan, the party's chairman, said the Democratic Progressive Party was trying to placate those voters who strongly favor independence from the mainland. "If you do something to please them, you are sure to have 30 percent of them packed up for you," he said. "This is Chen Shui-bian's grand strategy."
Ms. Tsai declined to respond publicly to the criticism.

HEADLINE: Mexican Drug Dealers Turning U.S. Towns Into Major Depots 

BYLINE:  By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: DALTON, Ga. 

 BODY:
This sturdy town in the Appalachian foothills likes to call itself "the carpet capital of the world," and its industry has thrived over the last decade as thousands of Mexican immigrants have flocked to jobs in the mills.
 More recently, though, federal and local law enforcement officials say the same pipeline of immigration and trade has been exploited by Mexican drug traffickers, who have helped turn this corner of northwestern Georgia into a busy distribution center for methamphetamine and other drugs. 
 In Dalton and surrounding areas, drug arrests have steadily risen since the late 1990's, police officials said. Gang-related violence has become common. Outside the police headquarters, a fenced-in lot is perpetually filled with cars, most of them impounded from people suspected of being in the drug trade. 
"We keep arresting people and seizing drugs, but they just keep coming," said Chief James D. Chadwick of the Dalton police. "We're in a boat with a big hole. We can keep bailing, but the hole's still there."
Dalton is by no means alone. From Alaska to South Carolina, law enforcement officials said, Mexican traffickers have taken advantage of spreading Mexican immigration and freer North American trade to establish themselves as the dominant wholesale suppliers of illegal drugs across much of the United States.
The officials said the shift, in which the Mexicans have both displaced other traffickers and opened new markets themselves, has meant a steadily more efficient flow of drugs into the United States, even as border controls have tightened since Sept. 11.
For the traffickers, places like Dalton are often excellent sites to do business, close to growing rural markets and within easy highway access of big cities -- in Dalton's case, Atlanta, Chattanooga and Charlotte, among others. The towns offer the cover of hard-working immigrants and a pool of potential recruits among the out of luck and unemployed.
By establishing new distribution hubs far inside the United States, the traffickers are also posing new problems for undermanned rural police forces and for federal agencies like the Drug Enforcement Administration that have long concentrated their resources in border cities.
Traffickers from Mexico have long sold marijuana and heroin in American cities, particularly in the West and Southwest. Since the late 1980's, officials said, they have also contracted with drug producers in Colombia and elsewhere to smuggle most of the cocaine that enters the United States.
But in the last decade, according to government officials and a series of reports on drug surveillance, Mexican traffickers have come to control considerably more of the United States' illegal drug supply. 
They have improved the quality and increased the output of Mexican heroin and marijuana. They have negotiated to receive more cocaine from South American producers as in-kind payment for the loads they smuggle into the United States. They pioneered the large-scale production of methamphetamine, the United States' fastest-growing illegal drug, and they have scrambled to start producing other synthetic drugs like MDMA, or ecstasy.
"They have certainly emerged as the major wholesalers throughout the country," said Michael T. Horn, director of the National Drug Intelligence Center, a Justice Department agency that analyzes drug trafficking in the United States. "Their influence is moving aggressively eastward, and they are very aggressive about getting into parts of the drug trade that transcend their traditional involvement in marijuana and heroin."
Although it is impossible to determine how much of the drug trade Mexicans control, federal prosecutions point to their growing role. From 1994 to 2000, the number of Mexican citizens jailed in the United States on federal drug-trafficking charges nearly doubled, to 8,752 from 4,394.
Like the legitimate businessmen energized by the loosening of North American trade, the traffickers have sought new economies of scale, taken advantage of the freer movement of Mexican trucking into the United States and even shifted some production closer to consumers.
In Hawaii, drug intelligence officials said, Mexican distributors have now overtaken Asian organized-crime groups as the primary suppliers of crystal methamphetamine, or "ice," which is the islands' most serious drug problem.
In the Central Valley of California, Mexican methamphetamine producers have built scores of so-called super labs that turn out 10 or 20 times the amount of drugs that biker gangs and other traffickers historically produced, federal reports show. Elsewhere in the state, Mexican traffickers have begun growing marijuana in national forests.
From bases on the West Coast, officials said, the Mexican traffickers have moved across the Northwest and Midwest, hiding among fruit pickers in Washington, resort workers in Colorado and construction workers in Minnesota.
Like the Los Angeles street gangs that helped spread crack in the late 1980's, Mexican traffickers have followed Interstate highways to the Southeast, feeding a surge in methamphetamine use in states like Georgia, North Carolina and Tennessee. They have also built bases in New York, Florida and other former strongholds of Colombian dealers. 
So far, the Mexican traffickers' growing role in wholesale distribution in the United States has been accomplished with relatively little violence, officials said. In part, they said, that is a consequence of the breakup of Colombian cocaine cartels and the Colombians' focus on more profitable markets in Europe.
In many areas, officials said, Mexican traffickers have worked cooperatively with Colombian and Dominican traffickers, offering drugs on credit and helping to launder the profits. In other instances, the Mexicans have carved out sales turf by underselling Dominicans, Nigerians and American-born traffickers.
Mexican traffickers have also become more efficient, drug intelligence officials said. By smuggling large numbers of smaller drug loads across the border and around the United States in the process known as shotgunning, they have lowered the risk and thereby reduced transportation costs. By moving their distribution hubs away from the border, to the areas around cities like Atlanta and Chicago, they have kept drug supplies and prices more stable.
"The southwest border isn't along the Rio Grande anymore," said W. Michael Furgason, the special agent in charge of the Drug Enforcement Administration's Atlanta office. "It's in Atlanta and North Carolina and Chicago and even Yonkers and New Rochelle."
In addition, some Mexican drug gangs, like Colombian cartels before them, have organized themselves into networks of smaller, semiautonomous units responsible for specific tasks like building false compartments in cars or obtaining the chemicals to make synthetic drugs, officials say.
Those smaller groups may be even harder for law enforcement agencies to pursue, as is becoming evident in places like Dalton. Despite the city's changing demographics, the Dalton police force has only one fluent Spanish speaker among its 86 officers, and almost no capacity to infiltrate tight-knit Mexican criminal groups.
"The chances of these people getting caught are now somewhere between slim and none," Chief Chadwick said. "If the state patrol stops somebody on the highway and gets a load nowadays, it's pure accident."
Dalton has long had its share of drug problems, and its drug users remained overwhelmingly white and African-American. Police officials said drug abuse remained relatively low among Hispanic residents, who make up 22 to 35 percent of the 45,000 residents of the greater Dalton region. 
But where local methamphetamine cooks might turn out a couple of pounds of the drug at a time, Mexican traffickers offer much larger quantities and lower prices, police officials said, attracting dealers from nearby areas of Tennessee and North Carolina as well as Georgia.
"The sad truth is that our community is becoming known as a key area for the distribution and manufacture of narcotics," members of a Whitfield County grand jury wrote earlier this year in an unusual open letter to local newspapers.
The Mexican traffickers are notably low profile, and police officials say the immigrant workers on whom they prey are similarly discreet.
T. Jefferson Morris, a Spanish-speaking criminal defense lawyer in Salisbury, N.C., said he had seen a clear pattern in the recruitment of drug couriers. "Within two weeks of one of these guys' losing his job," Mr. Morris said, "he will be approached by somebody who will say: 'I know you have a family and you need money. I'll give you $1,500 to deliver something for me.' "
When the couriers are arrested, they often do not know whom they are working for, and while the police might jail them, the traffickers can usually do worse -- like threatening their families back in Mexico.
When federal and state law enforcement agents in Kannapolis, N.C., stopped Mexicans in a car carrying 27 pounds of methamphetamine, with a wholesale value of about $175,000, they were struck by more than the quantity of drugs.
The car, bought in Atlanta, had been driven to Southern California, outfitted with a hidden compartment for drugs, agents said, and an atlas showed the courier had simply headed east on Interstate 40 until reaching a trailer park on the edge of Kannapolis.
Federal law enforcement officials said much of the area's methamphetamine appeared to originate in the western Mexican state of Michoacan and in California, with clans of Mexican traffickers who dispatch their members to supervise distribution of the drugs in the United States.
"They deal with their own people and no one else, and they are extremely difficult to penetrate," a federal official said.
Nor do the Mexican distributors in the United States seem to have been weakened by a series of recent arrests of major traffickers in Mexico.
So far, the growing presence of Mexican drug distributors has yet to create much of a backlash for the immigrant workers they hide among. Even in places like Dalton -- where Mexicans are credited with helping save jobs in plants that might have moved elsewhere because of labor shortages -- the drug problem has begun to unnerve some of those who have tried to help accommodate the newcomers.
Unlike business leaders in some neighboring cities, those in Dalton have strongly supported Mexican immigrants, calling them saviors of a carpet industry weakened by aging American workers.
Nonetheless, the town sits in a region that is still growing accustomed to the presence of Mexican grocers and taquerias, and where the new immigrants still prompt fights at school-board meetings and occasional marches by the Ku Klux Klan.
"There are people everywhere in New York and Los Angeles, and in Dalton, Ga., who are going to say, 'These people are not like us; their morals are different,' " said Erwin Mitchell, a former Democratic congressman who founded an innovative program to absorb Latino children into the local schools. 
"But this is a place where not one American job has been lost to immigrant workers," Mr. Mitchell added. "And because of these immigrant workers, thousands of jobs have been saved for Americans."

HEADLINE: Senate Balks at Big Bills Sent Over by the House 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
Last-minute disputes erupted in the Senate today over major bills already passed by the House, halting progress on the creation of a Department of Homeland Security and demonstrating that the election results had not erased sharp differences in Congress. 
 Angry Senate Democrats, joined by a few Republicans, criticized what they described as special-interest provisions tucked into the domestic security measure by the Republican-led House. They planned a vote for early next week to strip the items, further clouding the bill's prospects for quick passage. 
 "It is a terrible shame that some in Congress have sought to add these irrelevant and unconsidered amendments to a piece of legislation as urgent as homeland security," said one of the bill's authors, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut. 
A group of Senate Democrats and moderate Republicans were also pressing the House for a more generous bill than the one it passed on Thursday extending unemployment benefits.
The House, whose members left town today, has scheduled no major business for next week, and its Republican leaders adopted a take-it-or-leave-it stance on both measures.
They said that if the Senate changed the domestic security bill as approved by the House, negotiations could last into December before a measure was approved. Further, a spokesman for Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois said the House had no intention of considering the Senate unemployment plan.
"We're done, we're closed up," said the spokesman, John Feehery. "Why don't they do ours?"
Three Republican senators -- Gordon H. Smith of Oregon, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Peter G. Fitzgerald of Illinois -- joined Democrats to push for added unemployment benefits. They argued that the House version was too stingy, given the economy's continuing struggles. They said their plan would cover two million people nationwide through March while the House approach would take in only 800,000 through January.
If the House and the Senate cannot agree, then extended benefits -- those beyond the standard 26 weeks -- will expire for thousands on Dec. 28.
"It would be unconscionable," Mr. Specter said, "for the Congress to adjourn without taking care of so many people who are unemployed with the economic downturn that has resulted from Sept. 11."
But House officials noted that their version would keep extended benefits in place until the new Congress convened in January and took another look.
The fight over domestic security, meanwhile, was another impediment to a bill that, having stalled for months, figured prominently in the election campaign, when Republicans accused Democrats of undercutting it. It finally seemed headed for adoption in the lame-duck session after Democrats agreed to let the White House alter Civil Service rules at the new department.
On Wednesday, the House approved the department for a second time. But Mr. Lieberman and the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota, moved today to kill seven House provisions that they described as extraneous favors to Republican constituencies, including the pharmaceutical industry.
A provision drawing significant criticism was one that Democratic lawmakers said would protect drug companies from liability for adverse reactions to vaccines, and even interfere with current court cases. A pair of Republicans, Senator John McCain of Arizona and Representative Dan Burton of Indiana, also faulted it.
"It's really disgraceful," Mr. McCain said, "watching the pharmaceutical industry getting the first rewards of their campaign contributions."
But other Republicans said the drug companies needed protections to help them develop vaccines safeguarding against terror attacks.
Some of the other provisions at issue included limits on liability of airport security companies, an easing of the ban on offshore corporations' getting government security contracts, and a research center that Democrats said was earmarked for Texas A&M University.
Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, defended the provisions, saying they were justified and were no more atypical than those of other major legislation. And "by stripping them out," Mr. Gramm said, "you are risking killing the bill."
Democratic leaders said that although members of the House had left town, that chamber could still accept both a revised domestic security bill and a more generous unemployment bill next week, since it has not yet formally adjourned.
"My view," Mr. Daschle said of the House's domestic security measure, "is that the Republicans would be embarrassed by this and ultimately would vote in favor of the bill with these provisions stripped out."
While balking today at the House versions of the domestic security bill and extended unemployment benefits, and at a bankruptcy overhaul that the House had stripped of an abortion rights provision, the Senate did give final Congressional approval to a wide-ranging inquiry into the Sept. 11 attacks.
The investigation is to be carried out by a 10-member independent commission, approved by the Senate without dissent, that will have authority to go beyond an intelligence inquiry conducted by Congress and explore the role played by federal agencies like those responsible for aviation and immigration. Relatives of those killed in the attacks had pressed for the investigation, which the White House resisted until a compromise was reached on the makeup of the panel.
The House approved the investigation early this morning as part of a broader intelligence bill, one of a handful of measures to win passage by House members, who worked into the early morning in an effort to bring the 107th Congress to a close.
They also approved a plan to make government aid available to the insurance industry in the event of future terrorist attacks. That bill is expected to win passage in the Senate next week.

HEADLINE: Broad Manhunt in Jordan Isolates, and Angers, a Town 

BYLINE:  By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: MAAN, Jordan, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
This tribal town in the desert in south Jordan has been sealed off for nearly a week, as police and army officials chase down a small-time Islamic militant who they say heads a defiant gang of drug and arms smugglers.
 Though the authorities have repeatedly insisted that the operation is only a local matter, it is of a scope that experts say is rarely seen in Jordan. It has resulted in the deaths of two police officers and two suspected gang members. As many as 100 people have been arrested, the police say, as house-to-house searches have uncovered dozens of weapons and a workshop to make more. 
 The people of Maan are angry.
"Nobody should imprison an entire village like this," barked one man at a barber shop, who gave his age as 22 but who would not, like most people here, reveal his name. "They locked up a whole town."
Another man on the street yelled, "This is political!"
It was impossible to learn what he meant because official minders corralled reporters back onto a bus, near the end of a controlled visit to demonstrate that order had been restored. 
Jordanian officials have acknowledged crosscurrents of crime, tribe and religion here that could lead to unrest in the event of an American war with Jordan's neighbor Iraq. And some critics suggest that this is just what is driving the crackdown: the government's desire to prove that any protest against a war will not be tolerated.
Moreover, these critics assert, almost three weeks after the slaying of an American diplomat, Lawrence Foley, in the Jordanian capital, Amman, the government appears to be seeking to reassure the United States that it is serious about crushing any hint of radical Islam. The police say Mr. Foley's death has no connection to the unrest in Maan, but the subject of their manhunt, Muhammad Ahmad al-Chalabi, who is also called Abu Sayyaf, reportedly staged a rally here in support of Osama bin Laden after the Sept. 11 terror attacks.
Wherever local people's sympathies lie, experts say, the scope of this operation may only further alienate places like Maan, a poor town of some 40,000, many from independent-minded Bedouin tribes strongly opposed to any attack on Iraq.
"It will backfire on the government," said Labib Kamhawi, a political scientist. "It is not enough to be heavy-handed."
Abdul Latif Arabiyat, a former Parliament speaker and head of the Muslim Brotherhood in Jordan, complained that the government had refused his offer to mediate the problem peacefully -- which he hinted suggested motives other than merely a desire to quell a local problem. 
"It is a mistake," he said. "You are not going to solve it this way. What after? What is the next step? You put a whole city under curfew -- for how long?"
Today the area's governor, Muhammad Breikat, described the operation as a reaction to an "outlaw" gang, in which he said Mr. Chalabi was a top member. 
He also said that the curfew imposed on Sunday had been lifted two days ago and that the "situation is calm and quiet now in Maan."
But Mr. Chalabi remains at large, and hundreds of special forces police officers in blue camouflage remained in the streets today to keep order.
Mr. Breikat said the gang manufactured guns, smuggled weapons and hashish, burned property and even shot at a dormitory of a university where women are enrolled.
"Because of the huge number of violations committed by this gang," he told reporters here today, "the people of Maan demanded protection."
To back up these assertions, the police displayed several dozen rifles, handguns, ammunition, rocket-propelled grenades and equipment for manufacturing weapons they say have been seized in the last several days. Earlier, police officials reported that they had seized a launcher and rocket-propelled grenades from Mr. Chalabi's house.
In general, the Jordanian authorities consider Maan a flashpoint town, with local tribesmen carrying weapons and operating, to some extent, outside regular law and order: since 1989, there have been three uprisings here, in protest of prices of commodities like bread and cigarettes, and against threatened military action against Iraq. Some experts say the discontent, in recent years, has become more political and religious than purely economic.
The current confrontation began on Oct. 27, when Mr. Chalabi, who is about 35, was stopped by the police as he left Maan, reportedly taking his crippled wife to the hospital in Amman, 130 miles north. Mr. Breikat said Mr. Chalabi, who he said was driving without a license plate, shot at the police and fled.
In a later shootout with the police, he was wounded, reportedly in the shoulder, then freed from a hospital by several gunmen. Officials say they waited two weeks for local tribal leaders to hand over Mr. Chalabi, and moved in with troops only when that effort failed. 
There have been few details of the fighting, though officials have said over the last several days that there were several fierce firefights. One resident, who gave his name as Muhammad Ali, said he he had seen three of his cousins shot dead by the police, and others said several houses had been seriously damaged.
One house in the Tora neighborhood, the site of the most intense fighting, was seriously damaged: windows were blasted apart, walls raked with gunfire and several rooms burned out.
At the same time, there were several hints of sniper positions on the roof, including a scattering of spent rifle shells. 
Mr. Chalabi reportedly escaped from the Tora neighborhood during a firefight early in the week.
His whereabouts are said to be unknown, though the police have said they arrested several of his top associates.
There is much debate about whether Mr. Chalabi is an Islamic preacher, a criminal or both. He was among about 60 suspected militants imprisoned in 1994 in connection with several minor bombings. Mr. Breikat said Mr. Chalabi and his associates merely "use religion as a cover."
But several people here today called Mr. Chalabi a staunch Muslim and nothing more. "He's 24 hours God, God, God," said the man at the barbershop. "He doesn't know drugs. He doesn't know terrorism."

HEADLINE: A Prospect Delayed In Canada's Arctic 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: INUVIK, Northwest Territories 

 BODY:
The streets of this town above the Arctic Circle and alongside the Mackenzie River are lined with heavy construction equipment and dormitory trailers for drilling workers, all poised for a long-expected natural gas bonanza.
 Seventy-three trillion cubic feet of proven and potential natural gas reserves -- three and a half times what the United States uses annually -- lie within the Mackenzie River delta area, mostly on native lands, promising to convert this remote region of Canada into a major energy provider for the vast American market. 
 Most of the native groups that once opposed drilling and a planned $3 billion pipeline project have abandoned their protests and now favor exploiting their energy resources. The territorial government is pressing Ottawa for an ambitious road and bridge program that would lower production costs. 
But as winter dawns, allowing for the movement of drilling teams down the region's frozen river system, energy companies are planning only one-sixth as much exploration and drilling this year as they completed in 2001.
With natural gas prices way down from their peak late in 2000, largely because of a slowing United States economy that has curbed American demand for the fuel, the bonanza that once looked so promising here has yet to materialize.
"Everybody's ready at the starting line and we're just holding our pose," said Ken Mitchell, vice president for transportation at the Inuvialuit Development Corporation, a local venture capital firm that has invested in seismic research and drilling and is a unit of the Inuvialuit Regional Corporation, a business and public interest group owned and operated by Inuvialuit Indians.
Still, Canadian energy experts and businesspeople here in the Northwest Territories say that the lull, part of a general slowdown in drilling across North America, is just a temporary delay of an expansion of natural gas development that will transform not only the Northwest Territories but much of the rest of northern and coastal Canada as well.
"We still think that the northern gas pipeline will go ahead eventually," said Martin King, energy commodities analyst at FirstEnergy Capital, an investment bank and brokerage house based in Calgary, Alberta. "Before too long, we think prices will be generally stronger, supplies tighter, and that will certainly help the economics of building the pipeline."
Canada is already the world's third-largest natural gas producer, after Russia and the United States, with about 50 percent of its 6.5 trillion cubic feet of annual production destined for the American market. Fifteen percent of the gas used in the United States, the world's biggest consumer, now comes from Canada. With known American fields maturing, that percentage is expected to rise substantially in the next decade.
There are signs that natural gas drilling in Canada will increase in coming years despite the current slowdown. Exploration has been picking up in recent years off the coasts of Newfoundland and Labrador and Nova Scotia, where the federal and provincial governments are trying to replace the flagging fish industries with energy prospecting, and there have been major hydrocarbon discoveries in the last few months. Also, Canada is considering lifting a moratorium on oil and gas development off British Columbia.
To many environmental groups, more exploration and longer pipelines threaten the pristine Canadian North and shorelines. "Canada's wilderness faces an onslaught of oil and gas development that is right now destroying and degrading habitat of endangered species," said a report released last month by the Sierra Club of Canada and the Natural Resources Defense Council.
The drilling efforts are intended not only to bolster exports, but to encourage the replacement of coal-fired power in Canada with gas-fired electricity to meet the country's commitments under the Kyoto protocol, which the government has signed and now seeks to have ratified by Parliament.
One of the most promising gas exploration and pipeline development projects is along the 1,200-mile Mackenzie River, a region with abundant grizzly bears and caribou and so far almost entirely lacking in roads or other infrastructure. Inuvik, a government and business town of some 3,000 set up in 1955 as a supply center for mining and hydrocarbon exploration, is the only place for miles and miles with video stores, a fashionable restaurant or two and more than the most basic amenities.
A consortium led by Imperial Oil Resources of Toronto -- including ExxonMobil Canada, Shell Canada Resources and Conoco Canada -- is moving far along in completing the regulatory process necessary for building the pipeline. They are supposed to be joined by the Aboriginal Pipeline Corporation, a company formed by 30 native leaders that is lobbying in Ottawa for loan guarantees so it can invest $630 million in the project.
The severe weather conditions and high labor costs make it expensive to explore in this region. But most Canadian and American energy analysts believe that the Mackenzie Valley route, which could connect the energy-rich Prudhoe Bay of Alaska via an offshore pipeline through the Beaufort Sea, is more cost-effective than an Alaska pipeline proposal now being considered to transport Arctic gas. They also say it is unlikely that both projects will be developed at the same time.
The competing Alaska pipeline, which would transport gas from Prudhoe Bay down along the Alaska Highway and through the adjacent Yukon Territory, received a big boost when the United States Senate passed an energy bill in April that offered $20 billion in subsidies and $10 billion in loan guarantees to companies willing to build the project. But the bill stalled in conference committee, and the fate of the Alaska pipeline depends on whether President Bush can revive the bill next year in the face of opposition from Senate Democrats to a separate provision opening the Alaska National Wildlife Preserve to oil drilling.
 That setback for Alaska led Imperial Oil to announce on Wednesday that it is considering expanding the capacity of the Mackenzie Valley pipeline to 1.9 billion cubic feet a day from a current planned capacity of 800 million to 1.2 billion cubic feet in response to increasing interest expressed by potential shippers. 
The snags have been encouraging for leaders of the Northwest Territories, who badly want a pipeline built here for the jobs, money and other benefits it will bring.
"It is only a matter of time before there is a pipeline that runs down the Mackenzie Valley with feeder lines to wells up and down the valley, giving local people access to heat and electricity," the territory's premier, Stephen Kakfwi, predicted. "Many communities will become twice the size, and all will have paved roads."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: SEOUL; 
Korea Leader Backs Plan To Block Oil To the North

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
President Kim Dae Jung has endorsed a decision to cut off shipments of heavy oil to North Korea beginning next month if that country fails to take steps to dismantle its nuclear weapons program, a senior official said today. 
 The official said that Mr. Kim was fully consulted on delicate negotiations among South Korean, Japanese and American officials and recognized the need for a strong position, despite his previous pleas for dialogue rather than tough action that might upset efforts toward reconciliation between North and South Korea. 
 The official suggested, however, that Mr. Kim had been disappointed to learn that the North had gone ahead with a program for developing nuclear warheads with highly enriched uranium in violation of a 1994 agreement. 
"How can President Kim abandon his 'sunshine' policy in the last stage of his presidency?" said the official, referring to Mr. Kim's efforts at engagement with the North since his election as president in December 1997. "He is making his last pitch." 
On Thursday, the United States, South Korea, Japan and the European Union all agreed to allow the delivery of a last shipment of oil to North Korea in the next few days, but to suspend all future shipments until that country gives up its effort to develop a weapon from highly enriched uranium.
President Bush said today that the United States had "no intention" of invading North Korea. But he also said that Washington would not consider improved economic cooperation with the North until it dismantled its nuclear weapons program.
Administration officials said that the president's statement, released late today, was intended to reassure the North that the cutoff of oil shipments was not an act of hostility, and did not presage the kind of confrontation now under way with Iraq.
"North Korea's clear violation of its international commitments will not be ignored," Mr. Bush said in the statement. "The United States hopes for a different future with North Korea. As I made clear during my visit to South Korea in February, the United States has no intention of invading North Korea. This remains the case today."
Mr. Kim's endorsement, however reluctant, appeared to have been critical in the support of the American demand to cut off the shipments. 
The decision was made at a meeting of board members of the consortium set up by the 1994 agreement to build twin light-water nuclear reactors to fulfill the North's energy needs. The oil is provided under that agreement.
The decision called into question the future of the project under which the consortium, the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization, has cooperated on building the light-water nuclear reactors on the northeast coast of North Korea. 
The official, in a briefing for foreign journalists, went to extraordinary lengths to disavow any sense that South Korea and the United States had been in fundamental conflict over how to respond to the revelation by the North. 
"I hope North Korea will understand where we want to go on this issue," the official said. "The ball is in the court of North Korea." 
While there was an agreement to suspend the oil shipment in December unless North Korea acts, a ship that is now en route to the North with a shipment of heavy oil was allowed to continue. 
Choi Jin Wook, senior fellow at the Korea Institute of National Unification, an adjunct of South Korea's unification ministry, predicted that North Korea would "try to attract attention from the world community" by attacking the decision but "does not have any cards."
The North Korean economy, he said, has deteriorated steadily while the country faces a cruel winter in which, according to the World Food Organization, thousands of people are likely to die from disease and starvation.

HEADLINE: THE MAYOR'S BUDGET PLAN: LAW ENFORCEMENT; 
Trim of 1,900 Has the Police Crunching Some Numbers

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's proposed cut of 1,900 police officers will place a significant challenge before Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly as he works to reduce crime and prevent possible terrorist attacks, say current and former police officials.
 Yesterday, at a news briefing on the arrest of man in the killing of a Russian immigrant, Mr. Kelly would not discuss specifics of the impact of the cuts, noting that the budget plan had not yet been finalized. He said that while the department would have fewer people, the exact size of the cuts remained unclear. 
 "So we have not yet put in place a plan to respond to the reductions," he said. Mr. Kelly said that staffing levels in precincts were as low as they had been since the early 1990's, and that the entire class of roughly 2,500 recruits in the Police Academy would be assigned to precinct patrol when they graduate early next year. "We have to make sure that we at least maintain and indeed increase the level of staffing that we have in our patrol commands," he said.
Toward that end, the Police Department will examine units that have grown in recent years, a senior police official said, focusing on the narcotics division, which had more than 2,000 officers as of June; the intelligence division, which had 690 officers; and the warrant section, the largest component of the fugitive enforcement division, which had more than 740 officers. "The other units will obviously experience some attrition," the official said. "We'll have to make some hard decisions."
Since taking office in January, Mr. Kelly has overseen a 6 percent drop in overall crime and a 12 percent drop in murder, even as he has assigned nearly 1,000 officers to counterterrorism duties. However, the police force, which peaked at 40,710 in 2001, was reduced by 1,600 officers earlier this year, and Mayor Bloomberg's proposed reduction of 1,900 more officers, announced on Thursday, would reduce it to 37,210 by July 1. At that level, Mr. Kelly would have roughly the same number of officers as the city had in 1996, and by July 1, 2004, attrition could bring the number as low as 34,800, according to projections by the city's Independent Budget Office.
"He's got to do more with a shrinking Police Department," said John F. Timoney, the first deputy police commissioner in New York and the former police commissioner in Philadelphia. "The impact of terrorism on the resources can't be underestimated, in terms of people working on it, training and deployment."
While Mayor Bloomberg spared the police -- along with the Fire and Education Departments -- from the full brunt of the 7.5 percent to 9.5 percent cuts he had originally sought, the reduction, coupled with attrition, could leave the department at its lowest levels since 1993, when there were 34,641 police officers on the city payroll, according to the Independent Budget Office.
But because crime has dropped since 1993, when there were about 600,000 felonies, today's department, which has handled just 131,350 felonies so far this year, has a much lighter load. Preston Niblack, the deputy director of the budget office, said that even with the mayor's proposed cuts, the city would have about 45 police officers per 10,000 residents, well above average for cities with more than a million residents.
"The situation today in 2002 and 2003 looks a lot different than it did 10 years ago," he said. "We had much higher crime rates then. The city was just coming out of a recession, which was much worse than this recent economic downturn has been. So is there a risk that bringing down the police force will result in an increase in crime? Yes. Is this 1993 again? No."
Mr. Kelly, who also served as police commissioner in the administration of Mayor David N. Dinkins, was one of the architects of the Safe Streets, Safe City program, which paid for much of the growth of the department beginning in 1994, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took office and chose William J. Bratton to replace Mr. Kelly. Some experts and police officials cite the broad expansion of the department, coupled with new crime-fighting strategies, as the driving force behind the declines in crime. The Giuliani administration, up until Mr. Giuliani left office, also spent several hundred million dollars on overtime programs that effectively put 1,000 more officers on the street every day.
So Mr. Kelly will have his work cut out for him. "These would be very heavy cuts, even in normal times," said Thomas Reppetto, president of the Citizens Crime Commission. "These are abnormal times because of the threat of terrorism against the city. So therefore, I worry about cuts of that level." 

CORRECTION-DATE: November 19, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about plans to reduce the New York Police Department by 1,900 officers misstated the position of John F. Timoney, who discussed the costs arising from terrorism. He is a former first deputy police commissioner, not the current one.

HEADLINE: Word by Word: Hu's Goals 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Nov. 15 

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of the statement today by Hu Jintao, the new general secretary of the Communist Party of China, as the members of the new Standing Committee of the Politburo were introduced to reporters, as translated by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service for the United States government: 
 On behalf of the newly elected members of the central leading organ, I would like to thank all comrades in the party for their trust. We must live up to the trust of all comrades in the party and the expectations of the people throughout the country, hold high the great banner of the Deng Xiaoping Theory, comprehensively implement the important thinking of the Three Represents, and earnestly fulfill the various tasks set forth by the 16th C.P.C. National Congress. 
 We will closely unite and rely on all party members and the Chinese people of all nationalities throughout the country in carrying forward our cause, forging ahead into the future, keeping pace with the times, and working hard to build a well-off society in an all-round way, speed up socialist modernization, and blaze a new trail in building socialism with Chinese characteristics.
I have heard that friends from the media wish to know how the newly elected collective central leadership will proceed with their work. Here I am willing to tell you very clearly.
The 16th C.P.C. National Congress has established the important thinking of the Three Represents, along with Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought and Deng Xiaoping Theory, as our party's guiding ideology that our party will adhere to for a long time to come. 
This is a historic decision and also a historic contribution that has clearly set the direction for our advance.
The report delivered by Comrade Jiang Zemin to the 16th C.P.C. National Congress has systematically summed up the basic experience over the last 13 years, comprehensively expounded the fundamental requirements on carrying out the important thinking of the Three Represents, and explicitly outlined the goal of endeavor for our party and country in the first 20 years of the new century. 
It has also set forth principles and policies in the economic, political and cultural fields, as well as on national defense, the motherland's reunification, diplomacy and our party building.
All these give expression to the will of the entire party and represent the aspiration of the Chinese people of all ethnic groups. They are the political declaration and program of action for our party in a new phase of a new century, and our new collective central leadership will implement them unswervingly and consistently. 
We firmly believe that guided and inspired by the spirit of the 16th C.P.C. National Congress, the Communist Party of China will further project a fine image before the world as a party that advances with the times in a pioneering spirit.
The entire party and Chinese people of all ethnic groups will be more closely united to concentrate on construction and development in order to consistently push forward the cause of China's reform, opening up, and modernization. 
We are convinced that China is bound to have a better future, and with its development and progress, China is bound to make even greater contributions to world peace and development. 
I would like to take this opportunity to express my sincere thanks to the friends from the press and media for your hard work in covering the 16th C.P.C. National Congress.
We look forward to better cooperation with you in the future. Thank you all.
