HEADLINE: ONE STREET AT A TIME; 
Vienna's Berggasse

BYLINE:  By Joseph Skibell; Joseph Skibell's new novel, "The English Disease," will be published by Algonquin Books in the spring.

 BODY:
On a slope between Vienna's car-clogged W* hringerstrasse and the green ribbon of its Danube Canal are several city blocks filled with the six-story Biedermeier buildings one sees everywhere here. There are one or two exquisite Baroque-style buildings and a few monstrosities from the Bauhaus era, but otherwise Berggasse seems like just another anonymous working-class street in a European capital.
 Berggasse might escape the attentions of all but its own residents, in fact, had it not been the locus operandi for two of the 20th century's most significant social movements. 
 Sigmund Freud spent nearly his entire working life at 19 Berggasse. From 1891 until 1938, he developed his theory of psychoanalysis here, famously writing his books and treating his patients in comfortable rooms on the building's second floor. 
Less well known is the fact that, among Freud's neighbors, living at 6 Berggasse from around 1896 to 1898, was Theodor Herzl, the founder of modern Zionism. Literary editor and Paris correspondent of the Neue Freie Presse, Europe's leading liberal newspaper at the time, Herzl published his tract "The Jewish State" in 1896 and lived on Berggasse, like Freud, as a celebrated giant and a derided crank.
(The two never met, although Freud dreamed of Herzl; and although Herzl ignored the copy of "The Interpretation of Dreams" Freud sent him, hoping for a review, Freud did psychoanalyze Herzl's son, Hans, years later, diagnosing the suicidal youth as suffering, not surprisingly, from a profound Oedipal conflict.)
Nothing commemorates the time Herzl spent on Berggasse, no plaque adorns the facade of No. 6. Indeed, one might search Vienna in vain looking for any public mention of his name. Zionists with a sense of history will have to settle for a slice of pizza at the Pizzeria Valentino or a drink at the Italian cocktail bar on No. 6's ground floor.
In contrast, the Freud Museum seems to form the cultural and economic epicenter of present-day Berggasse. Entering the building's Hapsburg-yellow foyer with its frosted, stenciled windows and its sinuous, black, vinelike stair railings, I'm overtaken by an overwhelming sense of dominating presence, a palpable spirit of place, and before I can shrug it off as deriving from my own imagination, my wife, Basha, says to me, "Did you feel that?"
We climb the stairs and ring the bell, as Dora and the Rat Man once did, and are soon in the rooms where Freud spent nearly 40 years, before he and his family were driven from their country by the Nazi SS and local collaborators.
Freud took the apartment's furnishings to London when he fled, and they remained there until 1968, when, on a trip to the United States, Josef Klaus, the Austrian chancellor, was embarrassed by questions about Vienna's conspicuous lack of Freudian commemoration. 
Responding to the Austrian government's request, Freud's daughter Anna returned the furniture from her father's waiting room, along with 79 pieces of his extensive collection of antiquities. (The rest, kept in London, are now on exhibit in the Freud Museum there.) The waiting room, restored in the mid-1990's, is where Freud and the members of his Vienna Psychoanalytic Society held their Wednesday evening meetings, the men seated on its plush, burgundy-upholstered sofa and chairs.
Although Berggasse had been, at the turn of the century, a step up for Jews like Herzl and Freud, who moved there from the ethnic slums of the Leopoldstadt, behind the Prater on the far side of the canal, the street grew decidedly working-class in the wake of Vienna's post-World War II occupation.
Ten years ago, when Massi Baumgartner moved his playfully contemporary furniture shop, Massi Design und Handels, into 30 Berggasse, the building was a -- unable to remember the English, Massi sends his ponytailed assistant bouncing back into the showroom for a German-English dictionary; after consulting it, she returns to the sidewalk where we're standing to utter the words he needs -- "coal shop." Now Massi's streamlined designs fill the light and airy showroom: shelves of elegant glass bowls and vases, desk lamps resembling Picasso's sketches of Don Quixote, a wall of light bulbs with wings.
The street is gentrifying, Massi tells us, nodding to an exquisitely white Baroque-style building near the Freud house. The restored ground floor, which was once an auto-parts factory, will soon display custom-made English furniture. Although the coal shop and other businesses have been forced from the street, elbowed out by more fashionable replacements, like an ergonomic furniture store, a few holdouts from the postwar years remain. Next to Massi's is a dingy shoemaker's shop, and across the street is a uniform shop for firemen.
Near the top of the hill, at 3 Berggasse, is an army surplus store called Gelegenheitsschwemme. Every shelf and bin in its closetlike rooms is bursting with military merchandise, both new and antique, mostly from the Austrian Army, although there are many items from the United States, Russian and German armies, as well as Dutch trousers, Belgian shoes and Italian jackets.
Kurt Hellmann inherited the store from his parents, who opened the shop in 1955 when the British, American, French and Russian occupying forces left Austria. In the wake of the Allies' withdrawal, Kurt's father came into possession of thousands of pairs of boots that he had to raffle off, so great was the demand for decent footwear in the ravaged Vienna of that time, and that is how the store was born.
"And where do you get your merchandise these days?" I ask.
"We have to have some secrets," Kurt tells me.
Perhaps most emblematic of this era in the street's history is Mobel Beer, at 32 Berggasse (Freud's famous patient Dora is said to have onced lived here). A block from the canal, at the corner of Hahngasse, Mobel Beer is an enormous secondhand shop run by Charlotte Beer.
Signs in the windows proclaim the bargains within: "Alle Mobel um 50% billiger!!!" and "Alles zum halben Preis."
Plastic laundry bins of used clothing and tablecloths line its front walk. A canister of canes shares space with a tray of clocks and one of silverware and one of tools. Basha finds a pair of lace tablecloths, one hand-embroidered, both elegant, and pays around $2 for each of them.
The interior is dark and dusty for an Austrian shop, which is to say hardly dark and dusty at all, but darker and less dusty than the newer shops down the road.
For $100, you can buy a pair of big, sturdy armoires. "The only problem would be shipping them," Basha says, as we reluctantly leave without having made a sizable purchase.
The restaurants on Berggasse seem to reflect its changing face as well. There's a Cafe Freud, of course, next to the Freud Museum, and two sushi restaurants peek out from a couple of side streets. There are places for Chinese food and fish and a Mexican restaurant serving, according to its sign, "Acapulco Mexikanische Spezialit* tan." There's a gay coffeehouse called Berg at 8 Berggasse that turns into a gay bar at night. A discreet pink triangle is incorporated into the sign it shares with Lowenherz, the gay bookstore next door. 
There are cafes on every block and more than half a dozen traditional Wiener kuchen, all with outdoor seating. The most inviting of these is Wiener Beisl, at 24 Berggasse. Its menu features traditional Austrian specialties along with reasonably priced vegetarian dishes.
At the foot of Berggasse, along the canal, is a bike trail that runs all the way to Germany. Sitting on a bench, Basha and I enviously watch the cyclists who whiz by on one of the 1,500 free "Vienna bikes" supplied by the city. 
Overlooking the slow waters of the canal, a bar called Summer Stage has concerts and art exhibits in its glass pavilion. Six sculptures rotate on motorized pedestals in the sculpture garden. Nearby is a sandy volleyball court next to a trampoline station for children. Parents heft large beers and eat nachos while the kids grow dizzy and faint.
There's no knowing what Freud and Herzl would make of their old street; no knowing what Freud would mutter to himself as he passed Die Philosophie im Boudoir, an erotica shop with a mural over its front door depicting a half-dressed peasant girl sneaking coquettishly into bed; no knowing if Herzl would stop in at the Persian rug shop at 14 Berggasse and shake his head over the current situation in the Middle East with its proprietor, Dr. Mohammi. But there's probably no better street in the world on which to sit in a cafe over a kaffee melange and wonder about such things.

(Reiner Riedler/Anzenberger for The New York Times) Map (Gorka Sampedro for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1723 words

HEADLINE: A Tale Of Two Moscows 

BYLINE:  By JANUSZ GLOWACKI; Janusz Glowacki is a Polish playwright who moved to New York in 1984. His plays include "Cinders," "Hunting Cockroaches" and "Antigone in New York."

 BODY:
ALONGSIDE the Moscow River, near Gorky Park, positioned several feet above the highway, stands a cutout of a life-size man in a business suit, hands forward, ready to jump. Under him reads an inscription: "Before you jump, think again. Take a Stresstab." 
 In our age of globalization, perhaps the one thing that truly connects the whole world, more than the Internet, pop culture or so-called free trade, is that sinking feeling, that urge to jump. Russia has been depressed for centuries; today, with terrorism, a sputtering economy and cultural anomie, America is catching up. 
 My new play, "The Fourth Sister," was inspired by Chekhov's "Three Sisters," but it is neither a fictional continuation, nor a new version, nor a pastiche of Chekhov. It's merely an ironic allusion to his play and points out a few depressing steps the world has made since Chekhov gazed upon it. 
The underlying conviction of Chekhov's characters was that, although their own world was filled with trials and suffering, their children's would be a better one. It was easier for Chekhov to have some hope for the future at the end of the 19th century, when the concepts of truth, honor, commitment and love were seriously embraced. (Sometimes too seriously, since Russian officers at that time had duels when they offended each other, and shot themselves in the head when women rejected them.)
But today's Moscow has very little to do with Chekhov's Moscow. There are no more troikas and very few lofty dreams. I was in Moscow about four years ago, when Russia was preparing for war with Chechnya. I walked through the center of Moscow with Svetlana, the 14-year-old daughter of the driver from the Ministry of Culture who was chauffeuring me around the city. We passed a disco called Hammer and Sickle; Giorgio Armani's store; a Mafia-looking restaurant, Up and Down; a dealer for Rolls-Royces; and Afghan vets lining the streets, panhandling. These war heroes had medals but no legs. They gloomily looked on as policemen, who used to chase criminals, saluted Mafiosos lounging in black stretch limos. In the 21st century, a fifth substance, money, triumphs over the four ancient elements of fire, water, earth and air.
The day before, a bomb exploded in Moscow. The Chechens were blamed. But people whispered that it was actually the K.G.B., since it wanted to justify the impending war and deflect attention from the nation's poverty. Svetlana shook with anger. As several ambulances and armored cars passed us, she furiously told me that she read recently that the greatest artist of the 20th century was Yves St. Laurent. She said: "No way! Any idiot knows that Versace was the one."
Maybe Nietzsche was right when he said that humor is the epitaph on the grave of a painful memory. I wrote this play out of despair -- maybe that's why it's funny. One of the fathers of the theater of the absurd, Samuel Beckett, after surviving both wars, decided that Godot will never come and that nothing is funnier than misfortune. Though Chekhov lived in the 19th century, this sentiment wasn't foreign to him, either, except his laughter has always been filled with compassion.
During Communist times, when I still lived in Warsaw, the Minister of Culture censored a comedy I wrote. When I asked why, he explained that he realized that laughter was necessary, and that he himself laughed every day for 10 minutes -- with a stopwatch in hand -- for the purpose of mental hygiene. But he professed that there are only two kinds of laughter: constructive (or pro-Communist) and destructive (or anti-Communist). I hope "The Fourth Sister" falls into a third category.
In "The Fourth Sister," which opens on Thursday Off Broadway at the Vineyard Theater, the most recurring line is "I'm depressed," a seemingly strange line for a comedy. In fact, I'm not sure if my play is a comedy or a tragedy, but the difference between them is sometimes nettlesome to define.
You see, one character in the play, a retired general who once fought in Berlin and Kabul, tries to get work as a model to pay for his youngest daughter's dance lessons. The oldest daughter is the sex-pet of a married politician who hates Jews, though he himself is half-Jewish. The middle daughter finished law school and now feeds animals in the circus. Just a few years earlier, they knew what to expect from life. Now, they are at a loss.
The third and youngest daughter, Tania, has a better setup. Although she confuses Dostoyevsky with Versace and Bulgakov with Britney Spears, she has a moral guiding force in her life: the movie "Pretty Woman" with Julia Roberts. Back in the old days, prostitutes pretended to be virgins. In our times, virgins pretend to be prostitutes.
Tania once went to a museum and the only painting that caught her attention was one by Marc Chagall in which a boy hangs upside-down with one shoe. Perhaps it reminded her of something. Tania doesn't get emotional over the death of 30 women and children burned alive by a car bomb. But that doesn't mean she's callous. She just probably already used up all her tears by crying for five days, along with the entire planet, over the death of Princess Di. I read in one newspaper that 9/11 yanked at the hearts of Europeans almost as tragically as the death of the Princess. In "The Fourth Sister," naturalism blends with surrealism, and here too, the difference between them has become rather impossible to define.
Chekhov had doubts about whether he had the moral privilege to write, since he couldn't even answer the basic question: "How should we live?"
In my play, the retired Russian general asks far simpler questions: "Who rules here? Where is the money? How will it all end?" And no one is in a hurry to answer him.
I decided that my play about Moscow would begin in Hollywood, at the Academy Awards ceremony, which is broadcast all over the world, and has become part of our new global inter-connectedness, along with CNN. CNN is watched by those who blow up embassies and those who protect embassies, those who take hostages and those who rescue them. An Egyptian writer I met in New York said he was addicted to American television. He knew more than I did about O. J. Simpson and Washington interns, but he was truly amazed to find out that there were some religious New Yorkers.
Others have no access to television, like the children of Moscow who live in sewers and soiled public restrooms. Those kids are usually missing all their teeth, but they know how to use guns. Today, kids all over take aim at an early age. Those in Moscow shoot to get a pack of Marlboros. At the Mafia's request, they kill people they have never seen before. Since they are children, they sometimes make mistakes, killing the wrong people. But actually, the Mafia itself also messes up on occasion because it is overworked.
In Moscow, many photographers and film directors roam the streets, documenting stories about the Mafia and child prostitution. I put one of these directors in my play. He received an Oscar for the gripping candidness of his documentary, "The Children of Moscow," about child prostitution in Russia. Only, in today's times, the difference between truth and falsehood has become almost impossible to define.
I brought back home the two most popular toys in Russia. One was given to me by my driver, Svetlana's father. It was Wanka Wstanka, a kind of Russian superman. Push him to the side and he always springs back into his standing, ready position. "Watch out," the driver said, "nobody'll beat Russia." The second one I bought on my own. It was the famous Matrioshka, a colorful doll that holds inside of her another smaller version of herself but with a different face. Inside that smaller version, another face appears, and yet another one, and so on. I wonder what kind of face Russia will show in the coming years.
At the end of the 19th century, Chekhov wrote that Russians love the past, hate the present and fear the future. They don't realize when the future becomes the present that they hate so much and, a moment later, the past, which they miss.
For Chekhov's "Three Sisters," the magical place that gave them hope of a better life and happiness was Moscow. For me, when I lived in Warsaw during Communist times, the promised land was America. In "The Fourth Sister," the characters don't know where to go.

The Fourth Sister
Vineyard Theater, 108 East 15th Street. In previews; opens on Thursday; closes Dec. 8.

Chekhov All Week
JANUSZ GLOWACKI has said about his new play, "The Fourth Sister," that it is neither a version of nor a continuation of Chekhov's "Three Sisters," but rather an ironic allusion to Chekhov. 
The life and works of the man himself are being celebrated this month in the fourth annual Chekhov Now Festival at the Connelly Theater, 220 East Fourth Street, in the East Village. Performances are in their final week, through next Sunday. In addition to productions of "The Cherry Orchard" and "Three Sisters," there is a "sequel" to "The Cherry Orchard" and a gay musical adaptation of "Three Sisters." 
The LITE Theater Company (Laboratory for International Theater Exchange) is presenting the festival. Here are some of the productions: 
* "The Ghost of Firs Nikolaich," a sequel to "The Cherry Orchard," by Sam Mossler. A Dream Out Loud production directed by Tim Herman. What happens to those trees. 2 p.m. today and 5 p.m. next Sunday.
* "Moscow," a musical adaptation of "Three Sisters" by Nick Salomone and Mary R. McIntyre in which three gay men are trapped in a deserted theater with a script of the Chekhov play. 8 p.m. tomorrow and 10 p.m. Friday.
* "Gull," an Ellen Beckerman & Company production, directed by Ms. Beckerman. A hit at the festival two years ago, it focuses on the text of "The Seagull," and has minimal movement and design. 8 p.m. today and Thursday; 5 p.m. Saturday; 2 p.m. next Sunday.
* "Rothschild's Fiddle" and "The Lady With the Dog," a double bill. "Fiddle," based on Chekhov's novella of the same name, is an adaptation by Judythe Cohen and the festival's artistic director, Adam Melnick, set in pre-revolutionary Russia among peasants and their Jewish neighbors. "Lady" is adapted from a Chekhov short story about a married woman who has an affair while on a holiday in Yalta. 8 p.m. Tuesday and 8 p.m. Friday.
Information: 212-414-7773 or, on the Web, chekhovnow.org.

LENGTH: 738 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
Making Images Other Than His Own

BYLINE:  By FRED BERNSTEIN

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. 

 BODY:
IN his three runs for district attorney of Los Angeles, Gil Garcetti counted on the local ironworkers' union for support. So last year, when Mr. Garcetti phoned the union's business manager, Jack Holt, Mr. Holt answered not with "Hello" but with "We'll send you $1,000," Mr. Garcetti said here recently.
 In fact, Mr. Garcetti wanted permission to photograph the 130 ironworkers helping to build the Walt Disney Concert Hall, Frank Gehry's magnum opus in downtown Los Angeles, which is to open next year. Voted out of office in 2000, Mr. Garcetti was spending his days taking black-and-white photos at the construction site. 
 This wouldn't be much of a story -- unemployed lawyer finds hobby -- if Mr. Garcetti's work hadn't struck a chord. One hundred of his photos have been published as "Iron: Erecting the Walt Disney Concert Hall" (Balcony Press, $40). The Peter Fetterman Gallery in Santa Monica, Calif., which represents the likes of Sebastiao Salgado and Elliott Erwitt, has scheduled a show of Mr. Garcetti's work, opening on Dec. 7. And his images have won rave reviews, not only from Mr. Gehry but also from the renowned architectural photographer Julius Shulman, who called them "remarkable."
Theodore Stebbins Jr., a curator of American art at Harvard's Fogg Art Museum, said: "I was amazed by Gil Garcetti's photographs, which go back to Lewis Hine and especially to Charles Sheeler. But his images are not derivative."
Mr. Garcetti is the latest in a long line of photographers to find beauty in unfinished buildings. Mr. Shulman, 92, also compares Mr. Garcetti's work with that of Lewis Hine, who created revered images of the Empire State Building and Rockefeller Center being built.
Architecturally, Mr. Garcetti may have the best subject of all: an astonishingly complex assemblage of 12,500 pieces of steel, no two the same, ranging in length from several inches to hundreds of feet, and welded together at every conceivable angle. Photographed in contrasty black-and-white, the girders resemble the brushstrokes of an abstract painting.
Most architects dislike having their buildings photographed before they are finished, Mr. Shulman said. But Mr. Gehry, speaking from Los Angeles, said he was glad that the structure now disappearing under the concert hall's titanium skin has been documented by Mr. Garcetti. In an introduction to Mr. Garcetti's book, Mr. Gehry notes that two "windows" inside the hall will offer glimpses of the structure, but nothing like the sweeping views available during construction.
Mr. Garcetti is as interested in the ironworkers as in the iron; his best photos reveal humanity and geometry in equal measure. In that respect, they are reminiscent of Mr. Hine's photos, which have been credited with dignifying the American Indian ironworkers who labored to erect New York's tall buildings.
Given the complexity of Mr. Gehry's design, Mr. Garcetti said, the Disney Concert Hall drew California's finest ironworkers: 129 men and 1 woman, each a tightrope walker, weight lifter and engineer. "I wanted others to feel the awe I felt watching these workers," Mr. Garcetti said.
During his eight years as Los Angeles district attorney, Mr. Garcetti was involved in the prosecution of O. J. Simpson and the aftermath of the trials of the officers accused of beating Rodney King. This fall, he is teaching a seminar at Harvard on, as he puts it, "the interaction of the criminal justice system with politics and race." In his apartment here, he showed off several of his black-and-white photos, most of which he printed in a Santa Monica darkroom. Donning a pair of white cotton gloves ("my Michael Jackson moment," said Mr. Garcetti, who declined to prosecute Mr. Jackson when he was accused of child abuse), he unwrapped the photos, stood them on his lap, then handed them to his wife, Sukey, a foundation president, to return them to their wrappers.
Mr. Garcetti says he doesn't know what he will do professionally when he returns to Los Angeles next month. Although he does not plan to practice law, he is a presence at several law firms, which have bought his prints (at $950 to $1,250 each) to hang on their office walls.
As for photography, he wants to see where it leads him. Mr. Shulman, who has introduced Mr. Garcetti at several book parties, said, "he's had a joyful, glorious reincarnation."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Westchester; 
In Weak Market, Strong Demand for Medical Offices

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
AS other developers hasten to build more housing for the increasing number of older residents remaining in Westchester instead of retiring elsewhere, Robert P. Weisz is tapping into a directly related, and growing, real estate market: medical office space.
 In the past year, Mr. Weisz, the developer, owner and manager of about one million square feet of prime office space in Westchester and Fairfield, has acquired 190,000 square feet of medical office properties a short drive from the White Plains Hospital Center here. Mr. Weisz paid $26.4 million for the five buildings and an undeveloped 7.5-acre parcel on a stretch of Westchester Avenue known as Platininum Mile -- a premier strip of offices that was home for many years in the 1970's and 80's to Fortune 500 companies. 
 On the vacant land, Mr. Weisz plans to build a $15 million, 75,000-square-foot medical office building. He said it would be the first new Class A office project built for leasing to multiple tenants in Westchester since 1988, when many corporate giants began to downsize and some moved away. 
Since the recession of the late 80's and early 90's, the city has struggled with a high office vacancy rate -- more than 30 percent at times. The rate now in White Plains is 20.7 percent, as of the third quarter of this year.
By contrast, the office buildings Mr. Weisz recently purchased are almost fully occupied and have been for several years, although that was not the case before they became medical complexes. "Like many other buildings in the city, those along Westchester Avenue that are now owned by Mr. Weisz have reacted in the past to the ebbs and flows of the office market," said Glenn P. Walsh, a senior director for Cushman & Wakefield.
Mr. Walsh, whose company is the leasing agent for the properties, said the recently acquired buildings are the only large medical office complexes in the county. "There are smaller buildings scattered between White Plains and outlying areas," he said. "Wherever there's a hospital, we see a cluster of smaller medical offices, but there's nothing else in Westchester of this scope." In his first medical office acquisition earlier this year, Mr. Weisz bought 244 Westchester Avenue, a 20-year-old, 90,000-square-foot building, along with the undeveloped land, for $13.6 million from Ivy Equities, based in Clifton, N.J. In addition to constructing a new office building on the property, the developer plans to spend another $1 million for improvements to the existing four-story glass and anodized aluminum building. 
In the second acquisition, which occurred last month, Mr. Weisz purchased Harrison Court, a 100,000-square-foot complex of four buildings at 222, 224, 226 and 230 Westchester Avenue. He acquired the complex for $13 million from GE Capital, which had acquired it through foreclosure in the early 1990's. Mr. Weisz will invest another $7 million to upgrade the 40-year-old brick complex of one- to five-story brick buildings. 
Mr. Weisz, who founded his company, the RPW Group, here 25 years ago, attributed the high occupancy rate of the recently acquired medical office buildings to the changing demographics in Westchester. Figures from the Westchester Department of Senior Programs and Services show that more than 170,000 residents -- 18 percent of the population, a high rate -- are 60 years or older. Those numbers are expected to increase steadily through 2025 as the baby boom generation ages out.
"Because many of these older residents are choosing to stay where they already have ties to the community, we're seeing a parallel need for more geriatric medical services in the county," the developer said.
The effects of that trend can also be seen in downtown White Plains, where 1,700 new apartment units are expected to be built over the next several years. Much of the new housing stock is being marketed to older residents who have already raised a family and no longer want to own a large home, but who do not want to follow previous generations of retirees to places like Florida, Arizona and, more recently, the Carolinas.
Metropolitan Lithotriptor Associates, the medical arm of Allied Urological Services, is typical of medical practices that have grown in recent years in large part in response to the shifting demographics and have moved into the buildings recently purchased by Mr. Weisz. The company, which rents 2,700 square feet at 222 Westchester Avenue, treats patients with kidney and prostate ailments, said Jodie Corngold, the company's spokeswoman. It also specializes in an outpatient surgery known as lithotripsy, which uses shockwaves to crush kidney stones. 
In 1998, when it first leased space in Harrison Court, Metropolitan Lithotriptor Associates treated 200 patients. Today, Ms. Corngold said, the Westchester branch -- the company also has offices on Long Island and in Manhattan -- sees 650 patients a year, many of them 50 years old and over.
Ms. Corngold attributed the growth of medical practices like Metropolitan Lithotriptor Associates in part to advances in medical technology that permit ambulatory surgeries like lithotripsy to be performed outside of hospitals. Although the procedure requires that a patient be anesthetized, it can be performed in a doctor's office. The firm owns the costly machinery needed to perform the surgery, and 50 urologists from Connecticut and Westchester and Putnam Counties use its White Plains office, which is next to Interstate 287 and is close to several other major highways.
Mr. Walsh of Cushman & Wakefield said the location of the medical complexes on the outskirts of the city, but less than a 10 minute drive from White Plains Hospital Center, is better for both patients and doctors than downtown White Plains, where traffic is often heavy and parking for patients is in short supply. 
LAST month, the hospital center itself opened its first breast imaging center outside downtown. In part, the establishment of the new center in Rye Brook is a response to the drop in the number of local doctors providing mammograms, largely because of the high costs involved, said Jon B. Schandler, president and chief executive of the hospital. But Mr. Schandler said the hospital also wanted to ensure that such services as mammography screening, bone densitometry and some biopsy procedures are convenient and accessible for women living elsewhere in the county.
Downtown presents problems for patients trying to find parking spaces, and, further, many medical office buildings near the hospital have become "old and tired," Mr. Walsh said. "By that I mean many are not wired to handle the state-of-the-art medical equipment that doctors require today and the larger practices we're seeing. Moreover, some floors in older buildings cannot carry the heavy load of the new equipment."
New construction of interior spaces for doctors' offices and laboratories runs $40 to $50 a square foot compared to $25 for standard offices, Mr. Walsh said. Medical offices require more plumbing for bathrooms and sinks and more electrical outlets that can handle high voltages, Mr. Weisz said. Annual asking rents for office space in Harrison Court are $32 a square foot, compared with $28 a square foot for standard office buildings.
Clearly, the medical market today has placed new demands on office buildings. "First of all, the hours are much more demanding," Mr. Weisz said, "with most physicians starting early in the morning and working late at night, in most cases six days a week and occasionally seven, requiring access, lighting, HVAC and security to accommodate them. Medical practices today need buildings that are open and working at all hours."

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK 

BYLINE:  Compiled by Warren Strugatch; E-mail: libiz@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Venture-Capital Spending Falls 9 Percent in Region
Venture-capital spending in the New York area fell 9 percent during the third quarter, and only one Long Island company received funding, according to an industry report released Monday.
 CorrectNet, a provider of computer network products in Hauppauge, received $750,000 during the quarter, the report said. During the second quarter, four Long Island companies received over $40 million in venture investments. 
 Bob Sturm, the managing partner in the Melville office of PricewaterhouseCoopers, which helped compile the report, attributed the fall-off to business cycles and the decline in technology spending. "Venture capitalists are concerned that young companies are going to have difficulty gaining traction in terms of customers and revenues," he said.
The Silicon Valley attracted over $1.4 billion in venture capital during the quarter, or 31 percent of the national total, leading the country. The New York area placed fourth, attracting $295 million or 6.6 percent of the national total. 
In addition to PriceWaterhouseCoopers, the National Venture Capital Association and Venture Economics helped compile the figures.

Profit at Weight Watchers
 Weight Watchers International (NYSE: WTW) of Woodbury reported on Tuesday that profits rose to $36.8 million, or 34 cents a share, for the third quarter, up from $15.7 million, or 14 cents a share, during the same quarter last year. Revenues rose 31 percent to $189.2 million, up from $144.1 million in the third quarter of 2001. Weight Watchers now operates in 30 countries.

Income Rises at DCAP
The DCAP Group (OTC: DCAP) of Hewlett, a chain of independent storefront insurance agencies in the Northeast, said Wednesday that profits for the third quarter were about $256,000, up from $40,000 during the same period last year.
Quarterly revenue rose 88 percent to $1.2 million, up from $643,000 for the same quarter last year, the company said. The results reflect the addition of the Barry Scott Companies, acquired in August, as well as substantial growth in DCAP's premium financing operations, said Barry Goldstein, the company's chief executive. HEADLINE: Why It Costs So Much to Fix a Light Switch 

BYLINE:  By SHELLY FEUER DOMASH 

 BODY:
IF a homeowner on Wellington Road in Garden City hires an electrician to repair a light switch, the electrician is required to go to Village Hall, fill out an application, pay $115 for a permit and an additional $45 for an inspection, and wait for approval.
 Down the street in Garden City South, outside the incorporated village, the forms can be faxed in and the total fee is just $45. 
 That, said Anthony Lennon, the executive secretary of the Nassau Electric League, is why if all the bureaucratic hurdles are jumped, the same small job will cost about $450 in Garden City and about $125 in Garden City South.
If a homeowner wants to convert a boiler and water heater to gas and lives in the Town of Oyster Bay, it would cost a licensed plumber $160 for the permit. In North Hempstead the same permit costs $325. 
Seeking to reduce costs that they say must be passed on to consumers, members of the electric league and the Plumbing, Heating and Cooling Contractors, industry organizations for licensed electricians and plumbers in Nassau County, are calling for countywide licenses and uniformity in fees for permits for individual jobs. Hunter Botto, the president of the plumbers' group, said that plumbers in the county have to pay $3,000 to $4,000 a year just to comply with the license requirements in the county.
"We have to get licenses in the three towns and within those jurisdictions there are numerous villages and cities that all require their own licenses," he said. "Every incorporated village has its own requirements as far as licensing and permits fees."
Mr. Botto said that since a uniform plumbing code goes into effect in New York State on Jan. 1, his organization could see no reason for multiple licenses.
It costs $175 for a two-year plumber's license in the Town of North Hempstead. The same license in the Town of Oyster Bay costs $300 for three years, and the Town of Hempstead charges $200 for one year. The Cities of Glen Cove and Long Beach and all of the county's 64 incorporated villages also require their own licenses, and none of them are free.
Once a license is obtained, permits are needed to begin a job. "Some villages have a $50 filing fee; some are as high as $350," Mr. Botto said. "Some do inspections; some let us do inspections. There is no consistency." 
He said the proliferation of fees and paperwork encourages plumbers to skirt the law by working without permits and sometimes without licenses. "If we were to follow the law to the T, I would have one person in my office every day to file the permits that are required," Mr. Botto said. "The only ones that can do that are the larger companies like Sears, KeySpan and Petro."
The electrical association faces similar regulations and fees. The Town of Oyster Bay charges $350, and Hempstead charges $200 for a one-year electrician's license. In North Hempstead it's $250 for two years. In addition, 13 villages have their own electrician's licenses, ranging from $50 to $300. 
Philip Zuardi, the president of the Nassau Electric League, said that some municipalities require separate insurance with the municipality named on it, in addition to the forms and papers that have to be filled out individually for each municipality.
(Suffolk County has less redundancy in licensing. Bruce Dragonette, the county's assistant director of consumer affairs, said an electrician's license was good for the whole county and cost $200 per year. A plumber's license costs $200 a year and covers most of the county except the Towns of Babylon, Islip and Huntington. Lindenhurst is the only village in the county with its own licensing fees, Mr. Dragonette said.)
Experts cite the proliferation of license requirements as an example of the Balkanization of Long Island. "All you have to do is look at your tax bill to see all the different entities," said Paul Tonna, presiding officer of the Suffolk County Legislature. "There's the library, fire, school, town, village, county, state, and that is a problem for those people who don't spend a lot of time with it. We have a lot of redundancies. Nobody is willing to give up their piece of the pie."
"You have to look to Albany for some fundamental change, and there doesn't seem to be the will," Mr. Tonna said. "Each entity has its own power structure, their own kingdom, and they seek to protect it. We have some major problems in regard to any attempt to streamline government."
Richard Himelfarb, a Hofstra University political science professor, said Long Island's byzantine government alienates citizens. "Every state has counties and cities, but here we have entities called incorporated towns, which have their own laws and their own layer of bureaucracy," he said. "There are so many different entities that average citizens aren't sure who represents them, who they pay taxes to and who to call if they have some problems with roads or the police." 
"The insiders benefit from all of this confusion," Dr. Himelfarb said, "because when people like me throw up their arms and say, 'I don't understand all this, and I won't get involved,' who makes the decisions? It's the politician who gets elected with 9,000 votes out of 80,000 residents, and it's the people who contribute money to the campaign. It is not the average person, because the average person is alienated from this mess."
Some of the fees collected from tradesmen may even be illegal. A. Thomas Levin, a partner in the Garden City law firm of Suozzi, Meyer, English & Klein and president-elect of the State Bar Association, said he recently represented landlords in Freeport who argued that the village was charging far more to register rental properties than it was spending on overhead costs. The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled that "to the extent that fees charged are exacted for revenue purposes or to offset the cost of general governmental functions they are invalid as an unauthorized tax."
"The decision confirmed that a municipality is entitled to set fees for various permits and applications for permits and different kinds of approvals and licenses," he said, "but the fees have to bear a reasonable relationship to the expense the municipality incurs to administer the permit process and enforce the permit requirement. It is not supposed to be a way to generate revenues to the community in order to keep taxes down." 
Representatives of the electricians' and plumbers' groups say the wide range of fees indicate the money is being used for more than administrative purposes.
"It is definitely income for them," Mr. Botto said.
He and Mr. Zuardi said that except for one or two villages, enforcement of permit requirements does not exist in Nassau County.
The lack of enforcement eventually hurts the consumer, they said. "It is basically like traveling down the expressway and knowing there are no police out there," Mr. Botto said. "Obviously a lot of time and money is going into these towns to do enforcement, and our biggest issue is enforcement. There is none. They say there is, but there is none."
William Titterton, an electrician from New Hyde Park, said: "We are the ones following the rules and regulations. We come up with the insurance, the workman's compensation, and they just keep piling on the regulations. All it does is discourage competition. Because of the exorbitant expense of licensing, not all electricians acquire all the licenses for each village, and therefore there are fewer electricians in those areas."
Mr. Botto said the goal of his plumbers' organization was to cut through much of the bureaucracy and "create a common code enforcement agency." 
"Standards should involve the one state code," he said. "We are not trying to absolve ourselves of inspections. That still should be done, and the village has to be paid for that service. But we want one common license, which would alleviate thousands of dollars in fees and at least 80 different insurance requirements."
"It would make an industry that is better policed by having one common license and one common code enforcement," he said.
David Wasserman, the commissioner of buildings, planning and economic development for the Town of North Hempstead, admitted that if a problem is reported, it takes "a couple of days" to send an inspector. 
Allan Landsman, superintendent for the division of building for the Town of Oyster Bay, said he was aware of the problem with enforcement. "Our inspectors need to see someone doing the work, see it with our eyes," Mr. Landsman said. "On occasion we can't get inspectors there quick enough because we don't have the resources."
He argued that the permit system helped licensed tradesmen. "We are probably the biggest advocates for them," he said, "because we won't issue a permit unless a licensed plumber applies for the work."
But, Mr. Landsman added, he thought the trade organizations should be more active in seeing that the license and permit system is honored.
"They have to clean up their own act," he said. "I don't know what they're doing with their trade association fees. I don't see what they're doing to educate the public."
Mr. Botto was having none of that. "I totally disagree," he said. "The municipalities who issue the licenses should be in charge of code enforcement."

County Fees Have Gone Up Steeply in Last Year
PROBLEMS with a proliferation of license requirements and rising costs to obtain them are not limited to Nassau's town and village governments. The county government has imposed steep increases for many permits and licenses in the last year.
Home improvement license fees doubled, from $200 to $400 for two years. The county now charges $400 to review applications for building permits.
Even fishermen found themselves having to pay new fees. With a Parks Department leisure pass, which costs $10, they had been allowed to fish at Nassau Beach early and late during the summer and all day during the winter. Now it will cost them $25 a year.
"They're doing nothing for it," said Richard Johnson, a licensed fishing guide. "There is no additional security, no bathroom, no added benefits."
But the increase that has drawn the loudest protest is the one for a handgun permit renewal, which was raised from $25 to $200 for five years. The same renewal costs $10 in Suffolk County.
A group of Nassau residents are suing the county over the pistol permit increase. In the lawsuit, filed in February, the plaintiffs claim the fee is "an unlawful tax assessed upon valid pistol and revolver license holders."
Charles McQuair, the plaintiffs' lawyer, contended that the County Legislature passed the increase because "it was politically correct." 
"This is not gun control," he added. "People who want to carry arms will carry them. They have a constitutional right to bear arms."
County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi's office declined repeated requests for comment.
Judy Jacobs, the presiding officer of the County Legislature, said she had been made aware of the protests before Mr. Suozzi took office. "It certainly seemed like a valid complaint to me," she said.
 SHELLY FEUER DOMASH

LENGTH: 1247 words

HEADLINE: A Vegetarian Spot Where Feminism Is a Main Course 

BYLINE:  By LISA PIERCE 

 BODY:
FOR just over 25 years, customers like Trevor Fanning have been responding to the curious combination of ethnically inspired vegetarian cuisine, comforting informality and unapologetic feminism offered at Bloodroot restaurant in Bridgeport.
 Despite the fact that Mr. Fanning is not a vegetarian and is at least a generation removed from the political upheavals that inspired three Fairfield County feminists to open Bloodroot in 1977, he seemed at home as he rhapsodized about the food on a recent autumn evening. 
 "Everything here is so absolutely delicious," Mr. Fanning said as he slouched against a shabby-chic antique chair in the corner of the restaurant that houses an on-site feminist book store. "I treasure every bite. Toward winter, when it gets colder and the menu gets heartier, I'll come three nights a week." 
Far from feeling intimidated by the radical feminism evidenced by the position papers that line the walls and the books that line the shelves above his head, Mr. Fanning, 25, who teaches at Fairfield College Preparatory School, views Bloodroot's owners, Selma Miriam and Noel Furie, as mentors.
"You don't think of sending a card to a restaurant thanking them for changing your life," he said, adding that a year ago he did just that. "When you come here you're rejuvenated not only by the food but by the people."
Among the patrons, Mr. Fanning has gotten to know are Sheila and Jack Faxon, vegetarians and animal rights activists who drive two hours from Stockbridge, Mass., every Friday night.
"That gives you some idea how attached to this restaurant we are," said Ms. Faxon, who added that the couple have been dining here for 23 years.
"We come not only because the food is fantastic and the ambience is lovely, but because this is like a salon where people of like minds meet."
On this particular night, the Faxons shared their table with friends: Pedro Hecht, a vegan, and his wife, Judy, who have been traveling 40 miles from Roxbury to dine at Bloodroot's about once a week for the last 16 years.
"As a vegan you can usually find something to eat on a menu but here you can have a full meal," Mr. Hecht said.
Indeed, the menu is one of the few things that has evolved over the last 25 years at this stubbornly activist and technologically averse gathering place. 
Fish was dropped from the menu in 1980 and vegan dishes have become increasingly prominent on the blackboard menu above the kitchen here and in the Bloodroot Collective's three cookbooks. There were 52 vegan recipes in the first cookbook (published in 1980), 55 in the second (1984) and 138 or 85 percent of the total in the latest (1993).
Recalling how the restaurant began, Ms. Miriam said, "A whole bunch of women's book stores opened in 1977, and I thought it would be great to have a place where people could sit and chat and eat while they looked at books."
The restaurant and book store was named Bloodroot after a North American wildflower that blooms in April, its intertwined roots symbolic of the cooperative spirit the restaurant represents.
"We called it a collective because that was important to us," Ms. Miriam said. "There was an implication of equality."
To that end, jobs are shared by employees and collective members, although certain specialties have emerged. For example, Ms. Miriam stocks the book store shelves and makes the pleasantly tangy rye bread.
The Bloodroot Collectives membership has shifted several times since 1977. The one constant has been Ms. Miriam.
Ms. Furie joined as an employee a few months after Bloodroot opened and eventually became a collective member. Presently they are the only two members.
Although she was not a vegetarian at the time, Ms. Miriam welcomed the challenge of coming up with a meat-free menu.
The Bridgeport location was chosen so that the restaurant would be accessible to customers from diverse economic and ethnic backgrounds, a goal that would be reflected in the culturally varied menu.
"Instead of doing stir-fried veggies we really went looking for different ethnic origins to find the way poor people have lived with very little or no meat," Ms. Miriam said.
From the beginning the restaurant's menu placed an emphasis on seasonal dishes heavily reliant on locally produced ingredients, including herbs, kale, tomatoes and other items from Ms. Miriam's gardens. 
"There's no sense in doing strawberries in January or fresh tomatoes in salads in winter," Ms. Miriam said.
"They just don't taste like anything. And unless you get them locally, they don't taste like anything the rest of the year either." 
This dedication to using local produce has only intensified as Ms. Miriam and Ms. Furie have become increasingly concerned about the proliferation of industrial farming and hormone and chemical-laden produce.
The most notable manifestation of Bloodroot's dedication to equity may be the absence of a wait staff. Orders are written down on slips of paper, which customers hand to the cooks at a window.
"It really leveled the field in terms of equality between us and the customers and has really made it much more friendly," said Ms. Furie, who has worked as a waitress at other restaurants.
Because Bloodroot is a collective, there is more fluidity in job functions than in a traditional restaurant with its hierarchy of a a chef, other cooks, managers, waitresses and cashiers. At Bloodroot, collective members and employees share all these functions.
Collective members are expected to work full time, take responsibility for the success or failure of the business and make an initial investment of $1,200. When members leave the collective they retrieve their $1,200 but receive no additional equity.
Bloodroot employs about 15 full- and part-time employees.
A wall of portraits of women, visible as customers enter the dining area, is another tangible reflection of feminism. Some of the photographs depict the mothers and grandmothers of customers, employees and collective members.
"I look at those women and I cherish their lives," Ms. Furie said. "We're connected to them in some way."
There have been some changes over the last three decades. Customers rarely visit the book store anymore. "Frankly, the book store wouldn't be here if it weren't for the restaurant," Ms. Miriam said.
And of course, prices have nudged up as the cost of obtaining local produce has increased. The average customer spends $18 on dinner, $10 on Sunday brunch and $9 on lunch, exclusive of wine and beer, Ms. Miriam said.
Recent dinner items included green tomato pie with caramelized onions 
"So rich it was almost desserty," Mr. Fanning said.
Other items on the menu that night included: a three-grain pilaf, a vegan option, served with pureed parsnips and delicious fried kale, sourdough chocolate devastation cake and pumpkin tofu custard with coconut creme, both dairy-free desserts.
The owners' disdain for technology is palpable in the restaurants exposed wood beams, eclectic collection of antique furniture and its absence of digital devices.
There is no microwave, no cash register and no credit cards are accepted.
"There's a poverty in technology," Ms. Furie said. "I can't imagine that people who spend their life in front of a computer screen have real joy because the real joy comes from life and the real life is out there in the garden, in the dye pot, at the loom or stirring the pot."
Bloodroot is situated in the Black Rock section of Bridgeport at 85 Ferris Street; (203) 576-9168. Reservations and credit cards are not accepted.

For instance, one couple drives two hours from Stockbridge, Mass., every Friday night for a meal here.; Noel Furie, left, and Selma Miriam, owners of the Bloodroot restaurant in Bridgeport, which opened in 1977 and also maintains a feminist bookstore on the site. (Photographs by Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times); A wall with old photographs, including those of customers and employees.

HEADLINE: 10 Who Love Their Work 

BYLINE:  By CARIN RUBENSTEIN 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to jobs, Americans are anxious. Fully half are concerned that someone in their household may soon be looking for another employer, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll conducted last month. 
 Measured statistically, Westchester has it good. Unemployment is well below the national rate. About 405,000 people have jobs here, according to the New York State Department of Labor. 
 But how many of these jobs are superlative? Which jobs are the very best in the county? 
A search on land, sea and air turned up five men and five women who hold the best jobs in Westchester. They're all passionate about their work, whether they earn almost nothing or more than $250,000 a year. 

A Chocolate Artist
Who wouldn't love a job that requires tending a 90-pound vat of swirling, molten milk chocolate, not to mention the chance to do taste tests all day long?
Jennifer Cardone, a bright-faced 24-year-old, has just such a job. She is a culinary school graduate and certified pastry chef, and she owns a chocolate store, For the Love of Chocolate, in Armonk. The store, a charming, lilac-painted chocoholic's nirvana, is filled with beautifully wrapped lollipops and graham crackers and Oreos, apricots and cherries, airplanes and swans and top hats, all either made of, filled or draped with chocolate. 
The best part of Ms. Cardone's job, she said, "is actually making the items, because you get to see what you create instantly." She smiles with delight as she paints the feet and feathers of a turkey mold with white chocolate, perfecting the details on one of hundreds of milk chocolate turkeys she will make this Thanksgiving season.
The worst part of her job, Ms. Cardone said, is cranky customers, like the woman who wanted to know exactly which chocolate sail was the jib, or the one who would buy only a gingerbread duplex, not an ordinary house. Fortunately, though, most of her customers are more like one mother, who spends a dollar every day to buy her toddler son a dark chocolate-covered marshmallow.
Ms. Cardone usually works from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. six days a week. During the holiday season, she may work until midnight, finishing dozens of Christmas gift baskets. Her apprentice, Jane, is also her mother, and Ms. Cardone has a raft of loyal relatives willing to help out when necessary, including her father, brother and a handful of aunts and uncles. Last year, Ms. Cardone earned about $40,000, after expenses, according to her mother, who is also her accountant.
At For the Love of Chocolate, Ms. Cardone will cover just about anything in chocolate: Pringles, popcorn, four kinds of pretzels, even Champagne bottles. 
She eats what she makes, too, an essential quality-control measure. "Unfortunately for my pants, I eat chocolate every single day," she said, laughing.
That is why Ms. Cardone has a second job. She teaches a 45-minute spinning class in the Bronx, four or five times a week. "I call it maintenance, or guilt-free chocolate eating," she said. "I never gain any weight and I never lose any." 

The County's Farmer
He is the only person officially employed by Westchester County to be a farmer.
Joe Plummer, 52, oversees about 70 animals, horses, cows, sheep, pigs, goats and 100 head of poultry, including chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys and guinea hens. He also helps to maintain 777 pungent acres at Muscoot Farm in Somers, one of the last working farms in the county.
Mr. Plummer is in charge of two, just-born twin goats he calls Him and Her; of a 65-pound female calf born in mid-October, named Bandit; and of three male piglets born a day later. He also grows and harvests 5,000 bales of hay each year. Last month, Mr. Plummer had to transport about 2,500 pumpkins into the fields, so farm visitors could pretend they were actually harvesting them. 
It's also his job to answer questions from the sheltered suburban public, like why cows have udders. Every so often, he has to explain that a chicken on the ground is not dead, "all she's doing is taking a dust bath to get the bugs off, same as you taking a shower every day."
Mr. Plummer, who was raised on a dairy farm in Vermont, loves caring for animals. Being a county employee, he doesn't have to worry about droughts or floods ruining his crop or disease killing his herd. He is paid about $50,000 a year and has a house on the property, regardless of how much hay he brings in or how much milk the cows give.
Still, the farm is open 362 days a year, and Mr. Plummer has to be outside year-round, both in 95-degree heat and zero-degree cold. Mr. Plummer usually works from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., unless an animal is giving birth or he has to oversee special weekend activities like the late October Boo Walk and the antique tractor show. 
"You can't get bored working on a farm, because there's always something different going on," he said cheerfully.

A Watchman on the River
John Lipscomb, 49, can't leap tall buildings in a single bound, but he does fight the noble fight against polluters of the Hudson River. 
Mr. Lipscomb is the boat captain for Riverkeeper, a Garrison-based environmental organization, and patrols a 200-mile stretch of the Hudson by boat, from the Battery in New York City to Troy, seeking out polluters and reporting them, "like a neighborhood watch for the river," he said. 
His Batmobile is a 36-foot diesel motor launch, a former lobster boat designed for shell fishing in Delaware, which is docked in Nyack. It is noisy and ungraceful, but the practical working boat proudly bears the word "Riverkeeper" in foot-high letters, 12 feet across, so that it is easily identifiable. That way, "people who live along the Hudson and use it for recreation and business are aware that there is a watchdog," said Mr. Lipscomb.
Indeed, Mr. Lipscomb is well equipped to prowl the Hudson shoreline: he has large binoculars, nautical charts, a sonar depth sounder, Global Positioning System chart plotter and radar. He looks for sewage or oil deposits or building materials or milky slicks, "or any pollution that shouldn't be put into the Hudson," Mr. Lipscomb said. He also does habitat mapping and navigational surveys, and he helps conduct studies to see how fast and well the river flushes impurities out of the system.
Mr. Lipscomb has been aboard one boat or another since he graduated from high school, when he joined the crew of a 60-foot sailing vessel for an 18-month, 16,000-mile trip around the world. Now, after two years as the captain for Riverkeeper, he is intimately familiar with every reef, sandbar and oyster bed along his lengthy stretch of the Hudson River.
Mr. Lipscomb motors under the Tappan Zee Bridge, checking to make sure that painting contractors are containing the hazardous paint chips and rust they are sandblasting off the sides of the structure. (They are.) He eases up to a small boat anchored near the pilings that is flying a diver-below flag, and notes the name and number of the boat, to make sure that it is official. (It is.) 
Mr. Lipscomb is supposed to work an eight-hour day, but he often works seven days straight, 14 hours a day. "It's a get-it-done kind of job, driven by my wanting to get things done," he said. 
"I love boats and I love being on the water, and it's wonderful to do what I love for a greater good, to benefit society," he said. Riverkeeper would not allow Mr. Lipscomb to disclose how much he gets paid.
Mr. Lipscomb loves boating, even in bad weather, but he hates having to be patient, to wait for polluters to fix their mistakes. 
"If I see a problem, I like to fix it," he said. "It's hard to see a clear violation of the Clean Water Act and not get angry if it doesn't get fixed right now."

A Rescue Pilot
 He is a guy's guy who gets paid to fly helicopters and to play with grown-up toys. 
Charlie Robinson, 53, said his job as the aviation manager for the Stabilization, Treatment and Transport (STAT) flight team at the Westchester Medical Center in Valhalla was somewhat like the first flying job he had, piloting a medical evacuation helicopter in Vietnam. But this job is better, because nobody is shooting at him, Mr. Robinson said.
He flies a rescue medical helicopter to pick up the injured at the worst accident scenes, and to transport desperately ill patients, and has successfully landed on major highways, on the Tappan Zee Bridge, and in a field at an abandoned strip mine. He flies in rain and snow and sunshine, at dusk and in the dead of night.
"If you need us, we'll come and get you," Mr. Robinson said, explaining the point of his job in starkly simple terms.
Mr. Robinson, who has been flying helicopters since the Army trained him almost 33 years ago, said he loved this job because "we have neater, better toys on the civilian side" than they have in the military. Mr. Robinson's helicopter has a traffic collision avoidance system that allows him to hear other aircraft as far as six miles away. He has storm-scope detection equipment gives a visual display of nearby lightning strikes. And soon, STAT pilots will be using the latest night vision goggles, Mr. Robinson said with pride. When Mr. Robinson isn't flying, he is tinkering with the office computers, which he also helps to program and maintain.
Mr. Robinson works from 7 a.m. to 7 p.m., four days in a row, rests for a day, then works from 7 p.m. to 7 a.m. for another three days. Then he gets seven days off. (STAT has eight pilots in all.) For this, Mr. Robinson makes between $75,000 and $100,000 a year, which means that he is not among "the better compensated pilots," he said.
Still, he says, this is the best job he has had. (He has also flown helicopters to drop water on forest fires and to land at a heliport on West 30th Street in Manhattan).
"Flying puts a smile on my face and I still love doing it," he said. "I'm doing something positive, and I'm helping somebody who needs it."

A Maker of Wine
Combine the goatee, the white tufts of hair and the wild eyebrows with the gentle whisper and the habit of fussing with his pipe, and Dr. George Naumberg could be taken for the psychiatrist he used to be. But the purple stains on his fingers give him away: At 84, he is in a second career as the owner of North Salem Winery, the only working vineyard in Westchester County.
In 1965, while he was a psychoanalyst living in Manhattan, he bought 18 acres of grape vines; his holdings have now grown to 269 acres of idyllic property off Hardscrabble Road in North Salem.
On a chilly day in late October, Mr. Naumberg is overseeing a wine press that holds 3,000 pounds of crushed grape skins, the first of 20 batches that will be pressed for juice. The outdoor work area has a heady, yeasty scent, and the concrete floor is puddled with dark purple grape juice. Today's chore is preparing the juice to be stored in a 2,900-gallon stainless steel tank, where it will ferment for up to a month, before it is moved to other tanks, and then left to chill for six or seven months. In June, he will filter and fill about 15,000 bottles of wine. 
Dr. Naumberg estimates that he works about five hours a day, seven days a week. While his vineyard grosses about $85,000 a year, Dr. Naumberg says he doesn't reap a profit. "If I live long enough, maybe we'll make money," he said.
Dr. Naumberg is not nearly so fond of the selling of wine as he is of the making and drinking of it, he said. He has at least two or three glasses with dinner, every night. Dr. Naumberg's vineyard bottles sweet red table wine, merlot, seyval blanc and a rose called "Doc's Own," with a drawing of his face on the label.
"I know what I want to do, but sometimes I physically can't, and the fun of this is doing it yourself," Dr. Naumberg said, with a hint of regret. So he employs a full-time vineyard manager. But he loves his work, he said, because "you're always learning and it's never the same twice, and that was true of psychiatry too."

For Her, It's All Roses
Clare Levy has a job with a view -- and a scent. 
Ms. Levy, 36, a rosy-cheeked woman who wears her curly, auburn hair in a no-nonsense ponytail, shows up for work in boots and heavy-duty work pants. Her tool of choice, a red-handled pruner, dangles from her waist.
Her No. 1 responsibility: : Tending 400 rose bushes in a special garden at the Rockefeller estate in Pocantico Hills. Her charges include hybrid tea roses, floribundas, tall Queen Elizabeths and exotic Rio Sambas, which begin as yellowy-red blooms and slowly change to a light pink. She has a view of the rolling hills of the estate, all the way across the Hudson River to New Jersey. While she deadheads the roses, she is also checking for black spot. Then she moves on to prune decorative junipers. As she works, the perfume of a few still-blossoming roses wafts across the path, perfuming the air as she clips. All around her are sculptures by Henry Moore, Alexander Calder and Louise Nevelson.
"Taking care of plants is something I enjoy doing, and the best part is being outside all day, surrounded by artwork," Ms. Levy said, who used to own a small nursery and cut-flower business in Washington State. In this job, she said, "I'm freed from paperwork, and I get to make a place aesthetically pleasing.
"I have a sense of independence, but we also work as a team," she said, referring to her six colleagues on the gardening staff. Over the next three years, Ms. Levy would like to restore the garden to its early 1970's color scheme, when it had only white, pink and red rose bushes. 
Ms. Levy works 42 weeks of the year, from 7 a.m. to 3:20 p.m. She says she makes less than $50,000.
Her work is not just to beautify a private estate, she pointed out. Because the property is part of the National Trust and Historic Hudson Valley, her rose garden is open to the public, not merely a rosy oasis for the super-rich.

She Is a Neurosurgeon
It is probably just about the most difficult job anywhere, ever, but Deborah Benzil, 43, adores it. 
She is among the barely 100 female neurosurgeons in the country, and one of just two in Westchester County. It's a job for those with extreme confidence and competence, and Dr. Benzil has both to spare, along with deep compassion, empathy and laser-sharp skill. She practices and teaches at Westchester Medical Center, working from 7 in the morning until nearly 7 at night, five days a week and one weekend a month. For this, she earns more than $250,000 a year. 
Dr. Benzil seems to hover everywhere at once while she is in the operating room. She comforts a shivering patient who is having a lesion in his cerebellum biopsied and decompressed. She prepares the equipment, including the 10-inch needle she will use to pierce the patient's brain, while a revolving cast of nurses and medical technicians move about the room. Finally, Dr. Benzil shaves the patient's head and swabs it with iodine, part of a ritual that allows her to set herself up mentally to perform an operation with "military precision," she said. Then she takes a drill bit and aims it carefully at the one-millimeter-spot she must hit.
The first time Dr. Benzil cut open a patient's skull and looked at a naked brain, "it was the most thrilling thing I'd ever done in my life," she said. 
"Neurosurgery is a passion, it's my first great love," she said. "It's hard for me to imagine working at a job where I'm not helping people."
She has removed a pencil from a patient's eye, and recently operated on an 8-year-old whose skull had been penetrated by an 18-inch cleaver. "The girl spent two and a half days in the hospital and when she went home, she was absolutely fine," Dr. Benzil said, matter-of-factly.
The best part of her job, is "getting to know the patients," she said. 
The worst part of her job is watching helplessly as patients suffer and die of incurable brain tumors.
"In the past 25 years, survival for malignant brain tumors has improved by only 1 percent," Dr. Benzil said. "Everybody dies, but I can have a tremendous impact on how a person views his loved one's death."

An Inventor of Desserts
Normajean Longfield, a corporate Everymom with a blond bob, sensible shoes and a bright blue apron, has a job in which she gets to smoosh Oreos with her bare hands and sprinkle them over a concoction of Cool Whip and orange Jell-O. That is what a senior consumer foods manager in the dessert division for Kraft does: she invents desserts that can be made from the company's products and sometimes gets to help invent new products as well, like X-Treme Jell-O and cheesecake-flavored Jell-O pudding.
In an unassuming brick building in Rye, Mrs. Longfield, 43, spends eight hours a day thinking up new ways to use Jell-O pudding and Cool Whip, Baker's chocolate and Minute Tapioca, Chips Ahoy! and Cameos (made by Nabisco, a subsidiary of Kraft). Her office, with a prominently displayed "Very Berry Barbie" doll, packaged with a box of Very Berry flavored Jell-O, is barely 10 steps away from the constantly fragrant Kraft test kitchens, which are stocked like a teenager's dream house, with nothing but dozens of sugar-packed ingredients for potential high-calorie desserts. Mrs. Longfield said her pay falls in the range between $50,000 to $75,000 a year.
In more than 20 years as a food writer, consultant, stylist, tester and inventor, Mrs. Longfield discovered that Americans prefer to cook without really cooking. So it is her job to invent desserts that people can assemble quickly and easily. The best part of the job, "is the creative part and that it's different every day, and never boring," she said. The worst part of her job "is trying not to eat the whole portion," Mrs. Longfield said, laughing.

There to Hear the First Cry
Ida Vega helps bring babies into the world; by one estimate, she has helped deliver at least 1,485 babies during her 12 years as a labor and delivery nurse at Phelps Memorial Hospital in Sleepy Hollow. 
Ms. Vega, a former hairdresser who went back to school at 35 to become a nurse, loves her work. "No matter how many babies you see born, it's always special," she said. "There's a spiritual connection, too, when you witness a birth.".
Ms. Vega's first language is Spanish, and she is one of nine Spanish-speaking nurses assigned to work at the prenatal clinic at Phelps, where almost all of the patients are from Ecuador, Guatemala, Peru, Colombia or Mexico. (She was born in the United States.)
Ms. Vega is as warm and friendly as the prenatal clinic to which she is assigned once a week. A Spanish-language video about breast feeding plays in the waiting area, and the hallway echoes with the sweetly eerie sound of amplified fetal heartbeats. Ms. Vega charms her patients with iron pills, offers of free breakfast and a compassionate ear.
"They know absolutely nothing when they come here, and most have had their babies at home," she said. "This is their first hospital experience. They have a lot of fear and a lot of anxiety, and I love that I'm able to help them out. The language connects me to them, and they suddenly open up when they hear me speak."
Ms. Vega works a 12-hour shift, either three or four days a week. She gets paid $70,000 to $80,000 a year.
The best part of her job is "starting with a couple in the morning, and by evening we have a baby," she said. "I'm connecting with people at the most primitive level, when they're in pain. Whoever is here, I'm there for them. No matter what social class or culture, pain is a common denominator.".
The only bad part of her job is having to help a woman deliver a stillborn baby. "It takes forever, because there is no live baby pushing back," Ms. Vega said. "But you have to find a way to deal with it, you have to acknowledge what's happened."
Ms. Vega, who plays conga drums in a classic rock group in her spare time, is recovering from breast cancer and a knee replacement. She said that taking care of babies every day "puts you in touch with the miracle and wonder of life -- You think about it because you're touching it, you're in it."

The Ice Cream Man
At 53, Nolan West is a man with patrician good looks, who makes, tastes and sells ice cream for a living, a very good living. His business, Longford's Own-Made Ice Cream in Port Chester, does about $1 million in sales annually.
Entering Mr. West's small factory is like taking a stroll in a vanilla forest, only with cow-themed pottery items. The scent is heavenly, the stainless steel counters are shiny clean, and two employees are quietly and gently mixing and freezing tubs of Tahitian vanilla ice cream, made from special beans grown in Tahiti. 
Longford's ice cream has the highest butterfat content possible: 16 percent. (Anything higher, and "it gets to be like Crisco," explained Mr. West.) The company, named after a county in Ireland, produces 23,000 2-gallon tubs of ice cream a year. That's 2,875,000 single scoop cones, including the newly created, fall flavors of cranberry/apple cobbler, key lime pie and Swiss chocolate cookie. 
Mr. West sells his ice cream in a Longford's store in Rye, and in several other shops, but the bulk of his business is selling to upscale caterers, restaurants and country clubs. His clients include Abigail Kirsch Culinary Productions in Tarrytown, Rao's Restaurant in Manhattan and the Sleepy Hollow Country Club. 
Inventing new flavors is the best part of his job, said Mr. West, who works with his wife, Patricia. "We do a lot of licking and throwing plastic spoons in the garbage," he added. During ice cream high season, from April through September, Mr. West works from 7 a.m. to about 6 p.m. Now that it's almost winter, he works a much shorter, seven-hour day.
That is the only bad part of his job, when ice cream sales slow down so sharply, that it's "like somebody threw a light switch," Mr. West said.

Tough Jobs: Hard Work, Low Pay
What are the worst jobs in Westchester County? Here are two prime candidates:
IN A BOOTH -- At the Tappan Zee Bridge in Tarrytown, toll collectors work one of three eight-hour shifts, around the clock. The starting wage is $11.78 per hour, and after five years reaches $17.06 per hour, which is about $29,000 a year. On a busy day, about 165,000 cars pass through the tolls, according to Terry O'Brien, a spokesman for the New York State Thruway Authority. Collectors take money, make change, give directions, deal with complaints about traffic and occasionally have to answer dim-witted questions like "What was that thing I just went over?" (Answer: the Tappan Zee Bridge.) The job is slowly being made redundant by the popularity of E-ZPass.
BEHIND BARS -- At the Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining, guards work one of three eight-hour shifts, around the clock. The starting salary is $28,444 a year and goes up to $34,742 after one year. Guards are responsible for supervising 1,761 maximum-security prisoners and 535 in medium security. They have to conduct searches for contraband, in body cavities, and maintain order in the mess hall, in the yard and on the cell blocks. They have no weapons, but are equipped with a personal alarm system and a walkie-talkie. They can take breaks during their shift, but they aren't allowed to leave prison grounds.
