HEADLINE: Leaving a Legacy After a Lifetime In the Bogs 

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO 

DATELINE: CHATSWORTH 

 BODY:
CRANBERRY season has just ended here, and nearly all the scruffy pink bushes have been stripped clean of their jeweled red fruit -- all except the nearly 800 acres of prime bogs owned by James Garfield DeMarco, the nation's third-largest cranberry grower.
 Since last spring, when Mr. DeMarco gave several indications that he would not bring in a harvest this fall, rumors have swirled about the intentions of this 64-year-old millionaire, who also happens to be the local political power broker. He and his brother and sister control about 35 percent of the state's most productive cranberry bogs, and they also own more than 9,400 acres of pristine woodlands in the heart of the sprawling Pine Barrens. 
 Speculation ended when Mr. DeMarco disclosed in an interview last week that he had signed an option with the New Jersey Conservation Foundation to sell or donate nearly all his landholdings to the preservation organization. It is believed to be the largest private conservation acquisition in state history. 
"My family's been involved here for many years," Mr. DeMarco said, "but you reach the point where you have to think about going forward."
One of the largest privately owned tracts of land remaining in New Jersey, the property -- owned by the DeMarco family for more than 60 years -- includes all its cranberry bogs, 300 acres of dormant blueberry fields and a vast stretch of unspoiled land that spans Woodland, Tabernacle and Bass River townships.
Michele Byers, executive director of the New Jersey Conservation Foundation, said her organization would pay Mr. DeMarco's company, A. R. DeMarco Enterprises, $12 million, about half the value of the land as determined by two independent appraisals commissioned by the foundation. Mr. DeMarco said the remainder would be considered a gift, the value of which would have to be reappraised for tax purposes.
Mr. DeMarco's stunning move to turn his land over to a conservation group struck many as particularly ironic since the influential grower has battled efforts to control the Pinelands, has been cited by the state Department of Environmental Protection for wetlands violations and has referred to environmentalists as "leftist, egalitarian fanatics."
To fellow cranberry growers, it was one more example of Mr. DeMarco's elitist attitude toward a business that has made him a millionaire many times over.
Mr. DeMarco is the first to acknowledge that he has made enemies along the way, especially among the state's other cranberry growers, who may have tried to buy his premium cranberry bogs -- if it were not that Mr. DeMarco is suing most of them and does not talk to them anyway.
"The other growers aren't too happy with me," he said with his signature guttural laugh. "They think of the environmentalists as the enemy, and they see me as Benedict Arnold."
By selling his property to the Conservation Foundation, Mr. DeMarco will reap additional profits from land on which he has already collected more than $7 million in development credits. He will also be able to wash his hands of a business that has become a personal and professional battleground in recent years. Perhaps most important, the transaction will give Mr. DeMarco -- who can trace his local roots to the 1700's -- a chance to create a legacy.
"People will learn about my family's contribution to the state and what my family has done here," Mr. DeMarco said, adding that he hoped there would be some kind of formal acknowledgment, perhaps in the naming of the conveyed property.
Far from considering a name for the tract -- which is expected to be transferred by the end of next year -- the Conservation Foundation is trying to figure out how to raise the $12 million to buy it. To that end, Ms. Byers said her nonprofit organization had set up a Heart of the Pine Barrens Fund, seeking support from corporations, other conservation groups and individuals.
Negotiations on the tract began more than a year ago, when Mr. DeMarco called Ms. Byers to discuss the future of the property, which is jointly owned by Mr. DeMarco, his brother, Mark, 71, and sister, Anna Papinchak, 61.
"I love the area. I love the land. I don't believe in cutting trees. My feelings about it are very much the same as Michele's and the other environmentalists," Mr. DeMarco said, adding that he had no heirs and that the children of his brother and sister had expressed no interest in taking over the farm operation.
Former Gov. Jim Florio, who was recently appointed chairman of the Pinelands Commission and has in the past been on the receiving end of Mr. DeMarco's efforts to thwart preservation policies, said the decision made sense given Mr. DeMarco's apparent scaling back of his business.
"I assume it was an economic decision on his part, compatible with his interests," Mr. Florio said. "But if he wants to sell the land and have it preserved, that's commendable."
Though Ms. Byers said it was not unusual for her to get inquiries from farmers interested in exploring preservation options, she said Mr. DeMarco's call "came out of the blue."
"It was very exciting," she said. "The first thing I did was ask my staff to put together a big map to see what we were talking about. We were astounded."
For the 42-year-old organization, the agreement represents a major coup, and it is the latest step in a 30-year effort to preserve one of the state's most environmentally sensitive areas, first recognized in 1978 when Congress established the 1.1-million-acre Pinelands National Reserve.
The DeMarco property is situated amid five state-owned properties. Like a missing puzzle piece, the tract will link Brendan Byrne State Forest, Wharton State Forest, Bass River State Forest, Greenwood Wildlife Management Area and Penn State Forest.
"To be able to consolidate lands in the core of the Pine Barrens, and with the size and scope of this property, opportunities like this just don't come along very often," said Ms. Byers, who first met Mr. DeMarco in the early 1980's when his company bought the T-shirts for the annual cranberry and blueberry races to benefit the Whitesbog Preservation Trust.
For environmentalists, the plan is significant because it provides protection of the water, plant and wildlife resources within the property. According to surveys, the land holds 1,500 acres of reservoirs, 600 acres of Atlantic white cedar -- many of these increasingly scarce trees are more than 100 years old -- and thousands of acres of wetlands and upland forest that provide habitats for bald eagles, white-throated sparrows and the Pine Barrens tree frog. What is more, it serves as the headwaters for 14 tributaries of the west branch of the Wading River that feeds the Great Bay estuary.
"This land has all of the rare characteristics and endangered species of the Pine Barrens," said Carleton Montgomery, executive director of the Pinelands Preservation Alliance.
With his siblings and individually, Mr. DeMarco will continue to hold about 70 acres of property, about 50 of which is developable land in and around Chatsworth. But for the most part, he will be divesting himself of property his father began acquiring in 1940.
Sitting on a concrete loading dock in front of his cranberry packing plant here last week, the robust Mr. DeMarco spoke at length about his decision, disclosing a mix of emotions about leaving a business that has consumed him for the last 38 years.
"Certainly there is some remorse there, because of the wonderful team we had and what we accomplished," Mr. DeMarco said. "But I also take great satisfaction that this will be a nature preserve. That my family and I put all this together. That it will remain as one solid entity, for the protection of the environment and the enjoyment of the public."
He added with a touch of pride, "I'm sure my father would have wanted that."
Although Anthony DeMarco has been dead for almost 40 years, Garfield DeMarco seems to have spent much of his adult life making decisions that would please his father.
Not long after Mr. DeMarco -- who attended Dartmouth College -- graduated from Yale Law School, his father was struck and killed by a drunken driver on New Year's Eve in 1964. At 26, the younger Mr. DeMarco took over the cranberry business and management of the 4,500 acres of land his father had amassed. He also had to care for his mother, Gladys, who suffered from acute arthritis, until her death in 1986.
Over the years, Mr. DeMarco nearly doubled the family's land holdings; at the same time, cranberry production rose to levels of 120,000 to 150,000 barrels a year.
During that time, Mr. DeMarco also assumed his father's mantel as a political power broker, moving his base of influence from the family's homestead in Hammonton, in Atlantic County, to Burlington County, where he rose to Republican Party chairman in 1974. For 16 years -- from 1974 to 1990 -- he ran the county's Republican machine and since 1986 has been chairman of the Burlington County Bridge Commission, wielding his power and wealth to ensure Republican dominance of the county freeholder board.
Because of his grip, he has also been accused of exerting his influence in Trenton to extract rulings favorable to his Pinelands property.
"He held a tremendous amount of sway" in the administration of Gov. Christie Whitman, said Jeffrey Tittel, director of the New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club. "She wouldn't have won the Republican primary if it weren't for the Burlington County G.O.P."
For his part, Mr. Tittel battled Mr. DeMarco on several occasions, most recently in encouraging the Department of Environmental Protection to re-examine the settlement of a 1998 complaint. During Governor Whitman's tenure, the agency -- headed by Robert Shinn, a political and business associate of Mr. DeMarco -- proposed that the grower give the state 74 acres of land and relinquish the sale of development rights on 591 more acres of forest in lieu of a $594,000 penalty imposed against him for filling in 22 acres of wetlands.
Last year, during the short-lived administration of acting Gov. Donald DiFrancesco, another Republican, the environmental agency reinstated the fine after a report found that the proposal violated the Freshwater Wetlands Act. At the same, the agency sugar-coated the bitter pill by allowing Mr. DeMarco to expand his cranberry operation. When the current Democratic administration came into power, however, it decided not only to seek payment of the fine but also to demand that Mr. DeMarco restore the destroyed wetlands.
If Mr. DeMarco has frequently found himself at odds with the state's environmentalists, he has become the archenemy of most fellow cranberry growers.
Mr. DeMarco, a former Fulbright scholar who drives a gold Mercedes and spends much of his time at his family's Victorian-style mansion in Hammonton, does not often see eye-to-eye with the other farmers. Since filing a lawsuit last year against the Ocean Spray Cranberry cooperative, of which he and most of the other local growers are members, Mr. DeMarco has been accused of harming the state's cranberry business.
Mr. DeMarco dismisses such contentions, saying that the industry has been in decline for years because of competition from abroad as well as from an antiquated cooperative structure, leading him to file a suit against the cooperative's chief executive and 11 board members.
Mr. DeMarco's lawyer, Robert Fiebach, said the suit sought more accurate information concerning the finances of Ocean Spray -- owned by the 804 cranberry growers and 126 grapefruit growers nationwide -- so that the shareholders could make an informed decision if they wished to have the cooperative explore the options of sale or merger.
Last month Ocean Spray filed a motion with Delaware's Court of Chancery to dismiss the case, but Mr. Fiebach said that so far there had been no decision. Last week, Northland Cranberries Inc., a competitor of Ocean Spray, filed an antitrust suit against the cranberry giant, accusing the cooperative of monopolistic practices.
The problem is this: business has been dwindling, and New Jersey -- which, with 22 growers, is the third-largest member state after Wisconsin and Massachusetts -- is feeling the pain. Competition from Canada and an oversupply in general has driven down the average price per barrel of berries grown in this country to a low of $17 in 2000 from a high of $66 in 1996, according to agricultural surveys.
To offset the glut, the Agriculture Department imposed limits on production for two years. As a result, the annual value of the New Jersey cranberry growers' crop has plummeted to less than $8 million from $32.9 million over the last five years.
To keep farmers in business, Ocean Spray has been exploring new markets, including the introduction of white cranberry juice in 2000. Chris Phillips, a spokesman for Ocean Spray, called the drink the most successful new juice product in 10 years. Ocean Spray also reported that its earnings increased to $158 million in fiscal 2002, up from $59 million in 2000. Despite the improving financial picture, however, the chief executive, Robert Hawthorne, recently resigned.
Although reluctant to talk about his case, Mr. DeMarco said the conveyance of his land to the Conservation Foundation would not affect his suit against Ocean Spray, and he speculated that Mr. Hawthorne's resignation could only support his position that the cooperative was in trouble.
"If there were all these improvements, then why did they force Hawthorne out?" he asked.
Mr. DeMarco calls the prospects for the cranberry business bleak. "The future is not in New Jersey or Massachusetts, or anywhere on the East Coast," he said. "Wisconsin is ascending, and Canada is on the horizon, and eventually Eastern Europe."
But other local farmers are more optimistic. They see the tide turning and resent the fact that not only has one of their own sued them, but also that he might be taking his prime bogs off the market for good.
Joe Darlington, one of the state's three largest cranberry growers, said Mr. DeMarco never came to meetings of the cooperative and had not spoken to anyone about his plans, let alone give any of the other farmers a chance to buy his valuable bogs. In any event, most growers think Mr. DeMarco -- who was removed from the Ocean Spray co-op board in 1998 -- would refuse to sell them his bogs out of spite.
For his part, Mr. DeMarco said that no one had ever approached him about buying the bogs. "I would have listened to what they had to say if they had come in with anything of substance," he said. "But I've had no overtures, no official contacts."
The likelihood of such contacts even occurring seems remote.
"There have been cases where growers have encountered him in the grocery store and he walks away," said Mr. Darlington, a fifth-generation farmer whose bogs are in Whitesbog. "It really annoys us. When the company should be working on our market problems we also have to deal with this expensive lawsuit."
Given the state of the business, Mr. Darlington acknowledged that it would be hard for any one farmer to buy all of the DeMarco cranberry operation, though a consortium of farms adjacent to the DeMarco property might have come up with a way to make a deal.
Though one might argue that having a major cranberry grower go out of business might help alleviate the glut, the attitude of the New Jersey growers is that they would rather see the farm survive.
"It isn't a big community," Mr. Darlington said. "There are only 35 cranberry growers in total in New Jersey, so it's a shame if we lose someone among us."
In practical terms, dividing up the property was unlikely anyway. "It would have been very problematic to separate the bogs of the middle, since the bogs are so dependent on the water supply," Ms. Byers of the Conservation Foundation said. "That would have put us in a position of managing the water for someone else."
This is not the first time A. R. DeMarco Enterprises stands to make money off this land. Over the years, Mr. DeMarco has agreed to restrict the deed to nearly all of the land in question by selling $7.2 million in development rights to the state and private developers. In a program created by the Pinelands commission to compensate landowners of zoning-restricted Pinelands property, Mr. DeMarco has been the primary beneficiary.
Responding to criticism that he had monopolized the program's funds, Mr. DeMarco said that he encouraged fellow farmers to apply for the credits but that they chose a different compensation program.
With most of the land not suitable for development, selling it to a conservancy makes sense. Mr. DeMarco could also have done business with neighboring cranberry growers, or he could have sold the land to loggers interested in the white cedar and pitch pine. Neither option appealed to him.
"Other farmers will cut down the cedar, which helps keep the water table up, or cut hundreds of acres of pitch pine, causing total destruction," he said. "I don't want to do that. I want it to remain natural."
As for the future, Mr. DeMarco said he would not decide whether to grow cranberries next year -- probably his last -- until next spring "based on how sales are going and what I hear about the prices."
In addition to pulling out of the cranberry business, Mr. DeMarco said he had also scaled back his political involvement, focusing on county issues and only on an "as needed" basis.
"If people want to search me out and ask my opinion, my advice, fine," he said. "But other people are in leadership now. I had my day, now it's time for others."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: JACKSON HEIGHTS; 
In Queens, the Chronicle Of a Memoir Foretold

BYLINE:  By ADRIANA LOPEZ

 BODY:
"Gabo, Gabo, Gabo, that's all you hear around here these days," said Viviana Luna, an Argentine book vendor who sets up shop at Roosevelt Avenue and 80th Street in Jackson Heights, the heart of Little Colombia. "It's like he were a brother or friend of theirs."
 With his curly white hair and bushy dark eyebrows, Gabriel Garcia Marquez, affectionately known as Gabo, is perhaps the world's most popular living Latin American writer. The 75-year-old Colombian, a Nobel laureate, whose masterpiece was the 1967 novel "One Hundred Years of Solitude," has been fighting lymphatic cancer since 1999. Now, after 13 years of expectation, the first volume of his three-part autobiography, "Vivir Para Contarla" ("To Live to Tell It") has finally appeared. 
 Not surprisingly, its publication has set off a frenzy in this neighborhood, where imported and sometimes pirated copies -- many sold at inflated prices in underground market fashion -- have been more popular than anything since "Yo Soy Betty la Fea" ("I'm Betty the Ugly"), last year's top-rated Colombian telenovela about a homely woman who becomes the heroine of her workplace.
For transplanted Colombians in this predominantly working-class community, the book has been both a unifying force and a nostalgic link to their homeland, all the more so because the trilogy is likely to be the author's last great work. As Ruben Ramirez, owner of a Colombian family-owned bookstore called Getrex, put it, "His readers search for another encounter with him to get a little closer to their own humanity." 
Early last month, the 579-page work was published in Spain and Latin America, setting sales records throughout the Spanish-speaking world. Knopf, which had won a bidding war for both English and Spanish rights in the United States, responded by moving up the release of its Spanish-language version to Nov. 27, scrapping an earlier plan to release both Spanish and English versions next fall. 
But for weeks, propelled by the buzz in the Latin American news media, Latino readers have been flocking to Little Colombia, where copies have found their way to street vendors and independently owned Latino bookstores.
On Roosevelt Avenue, under the shadow of the elevated No. 7 train, street vendors like Ms. Luna do a brisk business hawking copies of the memoir, which they get from her buyers in South America and Spain, for up to $40 apiece. Around the corner on 37th Avenue, at the more genteel Getrex, Mr. Ramirez has been getting 20 books at a time from his Argentinian and Colombian suppliers. He has sold about 130 copies at $30 apiece and has nearly 200 names on the waiting list.
Some customers shy away from the street vendors in response to a Colombian news media campaign urging readers not to buy illegal copies of the book. Some pirated copies are said to be circulating clandestinely. But the majority of Little Colombia's street booksellers appear to be selling the real thing, a quality-bound edition whose cover bears a haunting sepia image of the author as a child.
Mr. Ramirez's wife, Irma, recalls the day she realized how much the book was touching a nerve among her fellow Colombians.
"I saw a young man sitting in Flushing Meadows Park reading a copy," she said. "And The tears were just running down his face." ADRIANA LOPEZ

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
Doing Good Can Mean Big Headaches

BYLINE:  By WELD ROYAL 

 BODY:
WHEN Jerry Goldman, a senior tax partner in Ernst & Young's New York office, signed up as a trustee for the Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance in 1998, he anticipated nothing but cultural enrichment.
 He and his wife had recently moved back to Manhattan after raising their kids in the suburbs, and he figured serving on the board would reconnect him with the city's cultural scene, teach him more about modern dance theory and enable him to give something back to society. 
 What he didn't realize is that it would also give him a giant headache. "I had no comprehension of the magnitude of the financial crisis, nor did I appreciate the legal battle the company would face," Mr. Goldman, 52, said. 
The books were a mess. And in short order, the artistic director sued the center, which manages the Martha Graham Dance Company and the Martha Graham School, claiming he owned the troupe's 181 dances. To fight the legal battle and to pay off debts, Mr. Goldman and the eight other volunteer board members ponied up $750,000 of their own money and raised $1 million from other sources. They also sold the center's only asset, its Manhattan headquarters, pulled dancers out of scheduled performances and announced they would suspend operations until the financial problems were solved. The 20 hours a year Mr. Goldman estimated he would spend volunteering for the group turned into almost 100.
At some time in their career, most successful executives will be asked to pitch in at a church, a school, a cultural organization or another one of the nation's more than 819,000 nonprofit organizations.
Serving on these boards can bolster their careers by putting them in touch with well-connected individuals and giving their companies a good name. It also lets them use their management expertise for the good of society.
That much the executives expect. What many don't anticipate, however, is how frustrating the work can be. No longer are they operating in a hierarchy, where the boss's wish is the subordinates' command. On the contrary, their fellow volunteers don't have paychecks to motivate them, and thus can be slow in carrying out their assignments and solving problems. They can also talk back. Moreover, money is almost always tight, leaving little room for financial maneuvering.
And, therein lays a paradoxical risk. Corporate executives are driven by the imperative of delivering value to shareholders, and they thrive by fixing, selling or shutting down financially troubled operations. But if they try to administer the same medicine to troubled nonprofits, they could do more harm than good. "Executives have a real focus on cash flow and bottom-line management," said F. Warren McFarlan, a Harvard Business School professor who teaches courses in nonprofit management and governance. "They may miss completely the organization's mission."
Mr. McFarlan, who has served on more than 10 nonprofit boards, including those of the Windsor School in Boston and the Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass., recalls sitting on the board of a school that was running a cash deficit. "The C.E.O. who was chairman of the board announced he would cancel all advanced-placement courses and double class sizes," he said. An outcry by parents and other trustees blocked the moves, but the incident illustrates the dangers of mixing business practice with altruistic purpose, Mr. McFarlan says.
SOME organizations have set up training seminars to help match executives with nonprofits. BoardSource, in Washington, has held workshops covering everything from legal liability to the basics of fundraising to differences between businesses and charities.
A little bit of individual research can also help. Before he joined his first board last year, Gerry DeRoche, director of consumer systems and support at FleetBoston Financial, wrote down his strengths and weaknesses. He identified three interests -- education, children and sports -- that made him an ideal candidate for the board of Nativity Preparatory School, a Jesuit middle school for boys from poor families living in Boston. Mr. DeRoche signed on and soon had organized a network in Boston for helping alumni who were recent college graduates find jobs. He quickly found himself "owning the whole program," he said.
Charities need more than just ideas and energy from executives. They need money. "We make it clear that 100 percent of board members must give philanthropically," whether $50 or $500,000, said Alice Korngold, chief executive of Business Volunteers Unlimited, a Cleveland organization that links executives with nonprofits. An extra bonus is that foundations that farm out grants look favorably on organizations whose board members give.
They also need bodies. A recent study by the consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton and the Volunteer Consulting Group of New York found that one million to three million board seats become vacant annually, a number so huge that filling them is a constant struggle. To address that dearth, in January, the Volunteer Consulting Group started boardnetUSA, a Web-based service that pairs individuals with groups that want new trustees.
Sometimes, executives face unaccustomed tasks at nonprofits. At first, Sandy Stark, former vice chairman of small-business services for Cleveland's KeyCorp, hated asking people for donations to the Urban Community School for poor children. "I felt like I did in my first sales job, pushing products," she said. But she warmed to it, and two and a half years into the $16 million campaign, she has helped raise $6 million.
At the Martha Graham Center, dance is again the primary focus. More than two years since the board suspended operations and after winning two lawsuits that gave the center rights to use all but one of the disputed dances, the organization is building new studios. It recently announced that it would kick off next year's season in January with two weeks of performances in Manhattan at the Joyce Theater.
So, does Mr. Goldman understand more of the theory behind modern dance? Not really, he admits, but he has joined two more boards.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 24, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Executive Life page last Sunday about the challenges facing executives who help nonprofit organizations misstated the time it took one such institution, the Urban Community School in Cleveland, to raise the first $6 million in its current $16 million campaign. It was seven months, not two and a half years.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.; 
Move Over, Mannequin. Here's Laser

BYLINE:  By LISA SUHAY 

DATELINE: LAWRENCEVILLE 

 BODY:
WHAT is a great-fitting pair of wool pants worth?
 The new technology says it's worth standing in your underwear in a dark booth as lasers whisper, unfelt, over every inch of your body. Afterward, your most intimate measurements are sent off a computer. For all that, you fork over $99. Then, after a few weeks, with a perfect sewing pattern in hand, you whip out those wonderful pants. 
 Some see this as a way to revitalize the home sewing industry, which has deteriorated over the last two decades.
Others see it as something of a ripoff.
Time and a measure of vanity will probably tell whether it succeeds.
"The price is high," said Jane Cappo, 60, of Mount Laurel. But "the concept I love. I'm pear-shaped and very hard to fit. That means spending all my time altering things. This could be a miracle." 
A version of the potential miracle is headed for New Jersey. It is called Bodyskanner, and it will be at Stony Brook Sew and Vac in Mercer Mall, Lawrenceville, Dec. 4 to 7. 
But Ms. Cappo, president of the Princeton Chapter of the American Sewing Guild (ASG), recently traveled to Southampton, Pa., to try it out. "I knew it was coming to New Jersey," she said, "but my friends and I just couldn't wait until December."
Her wider circle of friends is at least a small legion. Her ASG chapter, with 250 members, is the largest of four Jersey chapters. ASG, a 20-year-old organization based in Houston, claims 18,000 members and more than 100 chapters, according to its Web site, www.asg.org. And a recent survey by the Home Sewing Association counts 31 million Americans who still sew at home.
If even a small percentage of those sewers gave Bodyskanner a try, Tanya Shaw Weeks might rattle her high-tech bobbin in celebration. Ms. Weeks, 31, founder and chief executive of Softwear Design Group Ltd. of Nova Scota, conceived of the Bodyskanner idea for her company.
"Home sewing is going high tech," Ms. Weeks said. "It's not about economy. It's about self-expression."
Her concept of this self-expression starts when the person to be scanned disrobes to her foundation garments in a dressing room attached to a small octagonal booth. Once in the booth, the client places her feet on Arthur Murray-style footprints and holds on to two handrails for stability as 12 lasers (similar to those in a laser pointer) sweep over the body for about 45 seconds. The equipment has been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for low-emission lasers, Ms. Weeks said. 
Bodyskanner is one of several such machines in the world that use laser and computer technology to scan and map a person's measurements (accurate to within 1/16th of an inch) and use a plotter to create precise garment patterns.
To those who sew at home, scan technology means eliminating arduous hours spent adjusting the fit of standard size patterns.
Elizabeth Anderson, owner of Sew and Vac, clarified the problem with standard pattern sizing.
"Sure, size 12 is the most common size in the U.S.," she said, "but I can line up 10 women who are all size 12 and all will have totally different body shapes. The alterations and fittings are what take up all your time sewing and what makes it so tedious." 
Indeed, that may help explain why the number of home sewers in the United States has dropped by 20 million, or 40 percent, since 1984. The type of sewing has also changed. Now, home sewing is mainly made up of quilters and crafters instead of clothing makers, Ms. Cappo said.
The new technology is trying not only to combat the falloff in the home sewing market but also to create a more accurate sizing system for retail clothing. The TriForm BodyScanner, for example, is being adapted for such uses in Germany, according to Heute Magazin.
In a phone interview from her office in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, Ms. Weeks said she was in talks with several manufacturers that are considering using Bodyskanner for alterations in retail sizing. She envisions scan kiosks in stores all over North America that could generate patterns on the spot.
"You can now make a really gorgeous pair of wool trousers with quality of fit and fabric," Ms. Weeks said. "That is what women in North America want and can't find in a retail environment." 
For now, though, the Bodyskanner application is home sewing only.
The $99 price includes the initial scan, membership in the pattern club, a how-to video and a choice of one pattern. Additional patterns cost $19.99 each from a selection of about 1,200, with designs ranging from the sublime to the 1970's ridiculous, trendy low riders to hausfrau frocks.
Traditional garment patterns bought at chain stores, from companies such as Simplicity, Easy Sew and McCall's, average about $1.50 to $3.50 each. More complex patterns from Vogue average $10.
Ms. Weeks says most people don't sew their own clothing to cut costs, but as a hobby that is a means of personal expression, much like those who build their own classic cars or model railroads.
Ms. Cappo agreed.
"Sewing your own clothes is very expensive," she said. "That's what people don't understand. You don't do this to save. You do it as a creative outlet." 
Many people become disenchanted with making clothing because of the problems with fit and high prices for fabric, she added. "If you are going to spend all that money on fabric, your feeling is that it better fit right when you're done," she said. 
At Wal-Mart in Moorestown on a recent Saturday, plenty of shoppers were milling about the home sewing department, fingering bolts of goods and loading their carts. But their goal seemed to be pillows, not pinafores.
"I sewed my own clothes for years and years," said Edie Allen, 77, of Southhampton, in Burlington County. "I started making my dolls clothes. But now I'm just sick of it all. Too much aggravation. I buy my clothes now and when I do, I buy 'em on sale."
Clara Clark, 82, of Mount Laurel, gave the idea a squint and a shake of the head as she fingered the faux denim goods that would soon be a quilt. "That's a good idea they've got there, but sewing my own clothes is just too much trouble anymore," she said. "Most of the ladies I know who still sew are likely to stick with their quilting and leave that pricey stuff alone." 
A check of New Jersey fabric shops and several major chains yielded the following average costs for making a gorgeous pair of wool trousers (size 12): 1 yard of good wool fabric, $30; zipper, $2.98; 1 yard of binding, $1.25; 2 spools thread, $3; lining, $5; sewing machine, $99 for a very basic model to $8,000 for an advanced models; time spent cutting and sewing, 3 to 12 hours; over-the-counter Vogue pattern, $10, or bodyskanner pattern, initially $99.
The look on people's faces when you tell them what it took to achieve those pants? Priceless.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
The Gifts ThatKeep On Giving

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I AM a terrible gift giver. It's not that I'm cheap -- on the contrary, I probably spend way too much when I actually go out and buy a present. But that's usually to compensate for my re-gifting habit.
 You might know the term; the TV show "Seinfeld" popularized it a few years ago. It's the phenomenon when someone gives you a gift you find so awful or useless or unnecessary that you pass it on to someone else. 
 I'll give you an example: My friend Jill moves into a new apartment. I shower her with candles, lotions and a lovely book on decorating.
"I loved the inscription!" she said a few days later.
Inscription?
"Yeah, the one that said, 'Dear Abby, enjoy your new home!' " She laughed.
I didn't even try to talk my way out of it; I was caught smack in the act of a blatant re-gift. Thank goodness she had a sense of humor, and her own re-gifting moment. A few years earlier, she said, her parents re-gifted a box of chocolates -- unaware that two pieces had been swiped from the box by their grandchildren.
Almost everyone I know has experienced a re-gift faux pas, a tale of purpose and good intent that has gone embarrassingly awry. There's the vase that has somehow made its way back into the hands of the original person who bought it. The gift certificate made out in someone else's name. The shirt that mysteriously fits the giver, but not the beneficiary.
"You have to be really careful in re-gifting that it doesn't come back to bite you," said Dini von Mueffling, co-author of "The Art and Power of Being a Lady" (Atlantic Monthly Press, 2001). "I have a policy of holding onto a gift for a year before I recycle it, even if I know I'm never going to use it, or giving it to someone I know will never come across the person who gave it to me in the first place."
Re-gifting is such a touchy issue that sometimes people are presumed guilty, even if they're not. Hilary Black, 31, the entertainment and books editor at More Magazine has an office in Manhattan stacked with new book releases. In fact, the place looks a little like a library. As it happens, she genuinely likes giving books as gifts. But she said, "I can't do it anymore, because people think I'm being cheap and giving them something I got for free even when I've actually bought it."
It's a tough situation -- and an unfair one. Yet even if Ms. Black does give away something she received free, so what? After all, the economy is not exactly booming, so why shouldn't young people who receive perks in their jobs share the wealth, and save some money, too? 
Why? Because although the thought should count, we all know that what's inside the robin's-egg-blue box holds infinitely more cachet. Ours is a culture of price tags, and sometimes they matter more than the offerings themselves.
This is a shame, because re-gifting isn't only about passing on objects other people have bestowed upon you. It can be about giving away pieces of yourself -- even sharing things you have had for some time and no longer need, say, jewelry or artwork. Recipients should feel both grateful and honored.
Sometimes re-gifting is about practicality. My father recently turned 65. My family threw a surprise party for him here in New York and my boyfriend, Peter, came along. Now my father doesn't drink, and he doesn't really need anything, but for a brief moment I considered giving Peter a bottle of Veuve Clicquot I had in my house to hand off to my dad. Seemed like a win-win situation: my father would be pleased that Peter had given him a gift; Peter would be pleased that my father was pleased, and I would get my bottle back, because I knew there was no way my folks would lug it home to Boston. I ultimately decided that was a lame idea.
For many young people, this holiday season could become the Season of Our Gift-Giving Discontent. Indeed, with so many bank accounts horribly overdrawn and so many young professionals jobless or hustling for work, I'm confident that more than the usual amount of re-gifting will take place.
The thought has certainly crossed Maarten Devos's mind. Mr. Devos, 30, who lives in Brooklyn, has been unemployed since he lost his job as a project manager at the USA Network last December. "Now more than ever I'll have to re-gift," he said. 
FORTUNATELY, he recently got married, so he has a closet full of potential castoffs. "If it's something I don't like and am not going to use, that's a re-gift," he said.
Instead of keeping the practice under (gift) wrap and risk offending someone, I say let's embrace it. Let's expose re-gifting for what it is.
This holiday season, I'm going through my closet and picking out trinkets for specific people. Then I'm affixing stickers: "This has been especially re-gifted for (fill in a name)." If nothing else, at least the recipients will know I'm thinking of them.

GRAPHIC: Photo (Katherine Streeter)

HEADLINE: URBAN TACTICS; 
The Return of the Parasol-Topped Cocktail

BYLINE:  By HELENE STAPINSKI; Helene Stapinski is the author of "Five-Finger Discount: A Crooked Family History," published last year by Random House.

 BODY:
BRIAN FISHERMAN came from California with his vibes and a dream to play his Polynesian-tinged exotica lounge music in a New York City tiki bar. 
 "I would say tiki, and people would say, 'What's that?" said Mr. Fisherman, scratching his goatee, his eyes wide behind rectangular glasses. "Nobody had ever heard of it. I was sad." 
 Little did he know when he arrived 14 months ago, New York had been a tiki-free zone for nearly a decade. In the late 80's, the Hawaii Kai staged its last hula floor show. Trader Vic's at the Plaza Hotel, a favorite haunt of both Richard Nixon and Salvador Dali, closed in 1993. Its replacement, the Polynesian-themed restaurant Gauguin, lasted just over a year. 
When Mr. Fisherman arrived on the East Coast, the only place in town with a bamboo hut booth and a drink topped by a little paper parasol was the Jade Island restaurant in a strip mall on the Jersey side of Staten Island. 
Things have changed. The tiki gods are finally smiling on New York. As if rising from the mist like mythical Bali Hai, a wave of new tiki bars has suddenly appeared at half a dozen places around the city; three opened in the last year. The mai tai, a rum drink invented by Trader Vic in 1944, is making a comeback, served by waiters in Hawaiian-print shirts, watched over by hand-carved wooden tiki heads. 
Tiki, a West Coast creation, took off after Americans returned home from the South Pacific after World War II with fond memories of grass huts, white sandy beaches and tropical flora.
"It was the flip side of World War II and the horrors of war," said Michael Batterberry, editor and publisher of Food Arts magazine. "Tiki was fantasy land."
Today, the stress brought on by attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and the subsequent military action against terrorists, fear of travel and need for emotional escape help explain tiki's return, especially in New York. 
"Traveling to a place like Bali is out of the question for most people nowadays," said Sven Kirsten, the author of "The Book of Tiki" (Taschen, 2000), a coffee table book considered a bible by tiki enthusiasts. "The terrorists have nothing better to do than blow up a surfers' club in a beautiful, peace-loving, open-hearted tropical paradise. So now you go to your neighborhood tiki bar. The great social escape is tiki. You can enter the bar and leave the world outside."
On a recent night at Waikiki Wally's at Second Street and First Avenue in the East Village, paradise lay just beyond the tiki-guarded front door. A cluster of tropical birds, including a cockatoo named Wally, greeted an assortment of guests that this evening included a couple with a baby, a single man ordering a rum-filled zombie and eight young women from Connecticut at a bachelorette party. 
"I've been to tiki places in the Bahamas and in Hawaii," said Lisa Kontomerkos, the bachelorette, lei around her neck, tiara on her head. "But never in New York."
The owner, Hayne Suthon, who also runs the drag-queen supper club Lucky Cheng's, was a little disappointed to hear that New York had other tiki bars. "I didn't want to be part of a trend," she said.
Decor includes a huge mural of a beach scene, silk coconut palm trees, a bar with a thatched roof, South Seas dioramas that look like something out of the Museum of Natural History and a waterfall gurgling with tiny bubbles. Ms. Suthon even had Don Ho sing for opening night in September, and every Monday night, Wally's is host to the Tiny Bubble Band.
Only one thing is missing: the pu pu platter. In place of the traditional torch-lit, rotating wooden tray of shrimp toast and spare ribs, Ms. Suthon offers more sophisticated fare, like ponzu-marinated sesame salmon and Asian pear salad.
The main attraction, though, is Mi Cheng, Ms. Suthon's diminutive partner (and Lucky Cheng's namesake), who struts around in a grass skirt and Hawaiian shirt with a lei on his head. "He created his own persona," Ms. Suthon said. "He looks as if he was spewed out of a volcano." 
Typically, tiki bars reflect their neighborhood. At 22nd Street and Fifth Avenue is Tiki Room, a Silicon Alley minimalist take on tiki created by Nancy Mah, the designer of Lotus bar and restaurant. There's not a palm tree or thatched roof in sight. Instead, flat-screen television monitors show beach images and the bar's Web site to the singles crowd. A burlap menu offers drinks like the Causeway Spray and the Burning Bush, plus pan-Asian fare with touches of coconut and pineapple. There's even a V.I.P. section.
By contrast, Otto's Shrunken Head at 14th Street and Avenue A serves drinks out of skull mugs while a D.J. spins the Clash. Richard Nixon would not have been comfortable here. At the opening last month, a fellow with a Mohawk greeted neo-punks at the door, while the bartender, wearing black eyeliner and a rhinestone dog collar, taught another bartender how to cut a pineapple.
WITH its Playboy pinball machine and faux leopard-print fabrics, Otto's is more tacky than tiki. But there's a bamboo bar, a tiki drink menu scratched on the wall and puffer fish lamps floating overhead. 
Until last year, Steve Pang, Otto's owner, ran a music rehearsal studio on the Lower East Side, but his dream was a bar that was sort of rock club meets tiki. "I didn't want to serve cosmopolitans and martinis," he said. "I was sick of that whole exposed-brick wall, open-space thing."
Since 9/11 and the economic downturn, bar and restaurant owners in New York have been making their surroundings more comforting and amiable. 
"Everything is warming up," Mr. Batterberry said. "Even the pu pu platter has something very atavistic about it. Sitting around and grilling your food in the cave -- there's this sense of community."
Despite the recent spurt of enthusiasm, New York was late in coming to the tiki table. For years, tiki "didn't seem to suit New York's mentality and consciousness," Mr. Kirsten said.
That is why, he believes, he had a hard time finding an American publisher for "The Book of Tiki." Most publishing houses are based in New York, he pointed out, and publishers would say: "Tiki? What is this guy talking about?"
After a decade shopping around "The Book of Tiki," Mr. Kirsten found a German publisher to release it in the United States. The book is in its second printing and is to appear in paperback next spring.
"The beautiful thing about tiki," he said, "is that it functions well in tropical climates, like in Florida and California, but it works just as well in the snow or in a harsh urban climate like New York. In the concrete jungle, you need some relief."
Tiki also stirs powerful, atavistic memories among many New Yorkers. Somewhere deep in the memory banks of many people in their 20's and 30's is a recollection of a coconut- and pineapple-flavored family dinner at a place like the Hawaii Kai.
Mr. Pang, a native New Yorker, remembers walking past the Hawaii Kai when he was a kid. "I remember the midget outside yelling at people to come in," he said with a laugh. 
The tiki renaissance is not limited to Manhattan. Across the East River, the Zombie Hut bar has been attracting Brooklyn's youthful Smith Street crowd ever since it opened in August. The owner, Tod Bullen, and his partner, Renee McClure, have brought in comfortable couches, drinks like the Gilligan and custom-made skateboard cocktail tables. 
By contrast, Otto's, in the East Village, is adolescence distilled, with album covers on the walls and a giant, blue-eyed tiki head that blows smoke from its nostrils. One night the machine went haywire and filled the room with noxious smoke, but no one seemed to mind.
Mr. Fisherman, who was soaking in the tiki vibe at the bar before going on stage, beamed. "All these places opening up at the same time," he said. "It's a dream come true for me, baby."

GRAPHIC: Photos: At the Zombie Hut bar, left and above, and other places, tiki chic is back in New York. (Photographs by Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Leasing Loses Allure For Car Dealers and Buyers

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
NOT too long ago, discounted lease deals on cars and trucks were everywhere. But consumers who were seduced by the no-money-down, low-monthly-payment deals of the mid- to late-1990's are getting a jolt now that their contracts are running out. For many people, it's getting harder to simply drive into dealerships with their old cars and drive away in new ones, with comparable monthly payments.
 The problem isn't so much that prices have risen -- they have gone up slightly -- but that many carmakers have cut back significantly on subsidized leases. Instead, they are pushing zero percent financing and big rebates on cars and trucks that consumers buy outright, rather than lease. 
 "Zero percent financing has become the incentive du jour; our focus has shifted from leasing," said George M. Pipas, chief sales analyst for the Ford Motor Company, echoing the sentiment of many of the other big automakers. 
Not surprisingly, lease volume has softened. Only 23 percent of all vehicles sold this year have been leased, down from 32.2 percent in 1998, according to CNW Marketing Research, a company in Bandon, Ore., that tracks the auto industry. 
The main exception, though, has been in the luxury car and truck market. Leasing remains a popular way for consumers to afford a more expensive vehicle. But even here deals aren't as attractive as they used to be.
In most cases, car shoppers have to search harder for good deals, and sometimes switch models in order to keep payments at a level they want to pay. That is what happened with Joseph G. Farrell, 28, of Macomb, Mich. He wanted to lease another Ford Expedition when the three-year lease on his 1999 Expedition ran out last winter. He was not interested in a zero percent loan, although he probably would have qualified for one.
"Leasing is the best answer if you like driving a new car every year," said Mr. Farrell, a computer engineer who enjoys changing vehicles frequently. "There's no money out of your pocket, you have lower payments and no maintenance because you're essentially driving a new car."
But when he tried to lease a new Expedition, he found that the cheapest payment he could negotiate from his Ford dealer would be $550 a month over three years, based on a $32,000 sticker price. He was paying $432 a month on his old Expedition, which had cost $31,000. 
Mr. Farrell decided instead to lease a 2002 Chevrolet TrailBlazer, a bit smaller than the Expedition, and a little less expensive. He negotiated a lease payment of $405 a month for three years, based on a price of $28,000. He said he did not tell the dealer that he planned to lease the vehicle before he settled on the price -- advice he often passes along to fellow lease shoppers.
Negotiating price is, in fact, the best way to bring down the cost of a lease car. Another area where lease customers might be able to negotiate is in what is known as "the money factor," or the effective interest rate that they will be paying. (Lease rates are roughly tied to new-car loan rates, although they are not published in the same way. Instead, they are expressed as a percentage, which you multiply by 24.)
Sarah Parga, 26, of Los Angeles, researched rates and terms through Edmunds.com, an automotive Internet site, before she signed her lease agreement last spring. She said she ended up paying the equivalent of a 4.9 percent interest rate on the lease for a 2002 Volkswagen Jetta, which had a $23,000 sticker price. She said that was the rate she could have gotten on a loan for a new car.
Ms. Parga, who works for the campus police department at the University of California at Los Angeles, said a car loan was not attractive. To get the same $336 monthly payment that she got on a three-year lease, with $1,400 down, she would have had to put down $6,000 on a six-year loan. "I didn't feel comfortable committing to six years on a car," said Ms. Parga, who leased two Honda Civics before leasing the Jetta. 
It is much harder, however, to negotiate better terms on a vehicle's residual value, which is what an auto company estimates a vehicle will be worth at the end of a lease contract. The higher the residual, the lower the payment.
At the height of the leasing craze during the mid-1990's, auto companies and other lenders deliberately inflated residual values in hopes that the profit that they earned on each transaction would offset any losses later. That drove payments to miniscule levels, as low as $79 a month at one point on small Chevrolet pickup trucks. "The dealers used to say, 'Why do you want to buy a car, when you can lease it cheaper?' " said Ron Pinelli, an analyst with Autodata Inc., an industry statistics company in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.
But once the consumers brought their vehicles back to dealerships, lenders were essentially stuck with them, because residual values did not match up with the low prices that the cars and trucks brought as used cars.
Auto finance companies, banks and other financial institutions are expected to lose $10 billion on leases this year, according to CNW Marketing. General Motors told analysts in October that it was losing $100 to $200 on every leased vehicle. Leasing is now down to just 12 percent to 13 percent of its auto sales, half what it was a few years ago. Leasing at Ford is also down by that much, Mr. Pipas said.
It is a different story, however, in the luxury market in which leasing has always been a common tool to attract buyers to higher-priced cars and trucks.
In fact, although leases at Toyota Motor dealers have dropped to about 13 percent of its total business from 23 percent in 2000, leasing still makes up around 35 percent at the Lexus division, said George Borst, president of Toyota Financial, the credit operation for the automaker. And leasing has actually risen this year at the German automaker BMW, which is enjoying record sales and is seeing strong demand for preowned models, keeping its residual values high. Leases comprise about 38 percent of BMW's sales, up from 33 percent last year, said Martha McKinley, a company spokeswoman.
From July through September, BMW offered a three-year lease on its $35,000 Z3 sports car for $378 a month, with $2,500 down. That monthly payment was "substantially less" than any leases BMW had ever offered on the Z3, which was replaced this fall by the Z4, Ms. McKinley said.
Indeed, luxury companies would have a difficult time convincing all but the wealthiest customers to come into showrooms were it not for lease deals. A buyer purchasing a Lexus GS 300 costing $41,594 would have to put down at least $5,000, and pay nearly $850 a month in car payments, based on a new-car loan rate of about 5 percent and a four-year loan. Generally, that same Lexus can be leased for the same period of time for about $500 a month, with a down payment of $2,000. The figures may vary depending on the type of discounts that are available. Like many auto companies, Lexus offers better deals in parts of the country where it most needs to attract business.
WHILE that lease deal is still more affordable than buying outright, that is a much higher payment than luxury car buyers got used to seeing during the last few years, when deals of $399 and $499 a month were regularly advertised for many luxury sedans and sport utility vehicles. 
Such offers still appear from time to time when auto companies need to clear out an excess inventory of certain models. For example, luxury car companies typically offer discounted lease deals at the end of the life cycle of a vehicle as Mercedes did earlier this year on its E-Class sedan, before it introduced a new version this fall.
Often, such discounts will prompt the manufacturers of competing vehicles to offer similar bargains on their vehicles. So it pays for consumers of all types of vehicles, not just luxury ones, to compare ads, read fine print on lease ads, research competing deals on the Internet and keep crunching numbers until they find a bargain that they like.
For even with the losses that some in the industry have encountered, automakers will increase their lease business in response to customer demand -- and especially if they start to lose many lease customers. After all, lease customers have higher incomes and better education levels than typical car buyers, making them better credit risks, according to CNW Marketing. Also, "the most loyal customers are lease customers," Mr. Borst said. "We absolutely would love to expand our lease portfolio."

LENGTH: 2340 words

HEADLINE: Deepening Shadows 

BYLINE:  By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS

 BODY:
SOMETHING in the air seems to be changing. Once again, it's not uncommon to feel a vague sense of dread when walking down a shadowy street. Strangers look slightly menacing. The sound of footsteps provokes a sense of unease.
 It's not as bad as it was a decade ago, when crime was every New Yorker's waking nightmare. But New Yorkers are more fearful these days, and that is odd, given the city's dropping crime rate. 
 Police statistics show that crime is the lowest it has been in four decades. For the first time since the early 60's, the annual murder rate is on pace to fall below 600. 
Yet a new New York Times poll, taken late last month, shows that a growing percentage of New Yorkers feel that their city is less safe today than it was four years ago.
The sense of insecurity began growing in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, but it has continued to climb steadily in the last six months, according to the poll.
Asked about how safe the city is now compared with four years ago, nearly a third of New Yorkers -- 30 percent -- said it was less safe, up from 21 percent in June and just 12 percent in August 2001. The numbers suggest a profound and rapid shift in attitudes among New Yorkers. The poll, which sampled 359 adults, has a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points. 
"This is an endless topic of conversation among people now," said Fred Siegel, a senior fellow at the Progressive Policy Institute in Washington who lives in Flatbush, Brooklyn, and teaches history at Cooper Union. 
"All across the political spectrum, there is just an uneasiness, a sense that something is happening, though people can't put their finger on it," he added. "Thoughtful, intelligent people who have no political ax to grind have a sense that something is going wrong."

The Search for Answers
There are several possible explanations for the disparity between perception and reality. One is that New Yorkers are sensing winds of social change that have not been fully reflected in the crime statistics. It is also possible that in these uncertain times, people are more fearful of crime because of Sept. 11 and the economic downturn.
Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly, who took over after the celebrated crime-fighting years of the Giuliani administration, is one of those who takes the view that Sept. 11 remains a major factor. His challenge is to convince New Yorkers that, despite diminishing resources, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is not soft on crime, and he argues that much of the fear is driven by the public mood after the terrorist attacks. 
"Your fundamental question is why that perception," Mr. Kelly said. "Everything is now related to terrorism." 
Others point out that the farther the city gets from Sept. 11, the more the fear of crime manifests itself.
In interviews after the poll, some New Yorkers did mention the terrorist attacks, but they also grounded their answers in a growing fear of conventional crime. A universal theme was the conviction that former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was much more immersed in fighting crime than Mayor Bloomberg, and that the city's current budget woes will only compound the problems.
Other factors may also be at work. People reported more visible disorder -- more homeless people, more panhandlers, more people urinating in public, dirtier streets and sidewalks. All those signs of disarray make it easier for people to feel less safe, whether or not that feeling is justified. 
Anecdotal and some statistical evidence indicates that while citywide averages, especially for major crimes like murder, are dropping, there are pockets where the crime rate is rising, as are the number of low-level offenses. The perception that the city is unsafe may reflect local reality, as the Bloomberg administration has acknowledged with its recent crackdown on the homeless.
That perception can become a self-fulfilling prophecy. 
"If you really believe something, then you become fearful and become as entrapped by it as if it were a real crime wave," said Ron Schiffman, director of the Pratt Institute Center for Community and Environmental Development in Brooklyn. "You're not hurt by it unless you imprison yourself, unless you stop going out on the streets. And that might lead eventually to more crime."

The Giuliani Factor
Jackie Solano, a 35-year-old university administrator who lives in Inwood, said she felt less safe now than she did four years ago. For the first time in several years, she said in an interview after the poll was conducted, she has begun to hear teenagers who are out late at night on the corner near her apartment at 211th Street and Broadway. Also, nearby Academy Street, which had been closed to traffic to deter drug dealing, has been reopened. This, she said, has heightened her sense that the neighborhood had backslid.
Like many questioned in the poll, she traced the changes to the new mayoral administration. "I just really think there is a lack of police protection," Ms. Solano said. "When Giuliani was around, he cleaned up a lot of streets."
Although Ms. Solano, who is of Dominican descent, feels comfortable in her predominantly Dominican neighborhood, she recently surprised herself by toying with the idea of leaving the city. She fears a rise in crime, and she worries that her two children, one a kindergartner at a parochial school and the other a 2-year-old, will not have a bright future here. Her husband was laid off from his job in the hotel industry, adding to the family stress.
Another New Yorker who linked his growing apprehension to the change at City Hall was Sherman Jackson, a 55-year-old former government worker and lifelong New Yorker. Mr. Jackson, who lives on the Upper West Side, was mugged for the first time in his life three months ago while crossing West 71st Street.
As he remembered the incident, a drunken man swung a beer bottle at him, then menaced him with what turned out to be a pellet gun. Officers from the 20th Precinct responded, Mr. Jackson said, and told him that they had arrested his assailant a dozen times. Yet not long after, Mr. Jackson spotted the same man sitting on Columbus Avenue, a bottle of beer in each hand.
"In the Giuliani administration, that kind of stuff just didn't happen," Mr. Jackson said. "The cops didn't have any tolerance for public drinking. Perhaps because their attention has been diverted post-9/11 -- I don't know what to ascribe it to -- but you see a lot more of that."
Political and police analysts say the loss of Mr. Giuliani as an anticrime leader may be taking a psychological toll. At times, he seemed to be the de facto police commissioner, while Mr. Bloomberg has a much lower profile in fighting crime.
These perceptions are reflected in the poll results. Almost no one (only 9 percent) thought Mr. Bloomberg was doing a better job than Mr. Giuliani in fighting crime. But 46 percent said Mr. Bloomberg was doing worse than his predecessor, up 13 points from 33 percent in June.
But Edward Skyler, Mr. Bloomberg's press secretary, pointed out that nearly 70 percent of New Yorkers polled said they did not feel less safe. He said the mayor has not been timid about crime.
"I'll tell you what, he talks about it quite a bit," Mr. Skyler said. "But it doesn't make the papers. You know why? Because it's not news."
Ms. Solano of Inwood sees things differently. "Bloomberg is trying to run the city as a businessman," she said. "He's trying to cut the budget and save money. But I don't think he's looking at the overall picture, which is to make sure the city is safe and create jobs."

A Sense of Lawlessness
Even if Mayor Bloomberg is perceived as different from his predecessor when it comes to fighting crime, police officials are still amazed that so many New Yorkers feel less safe than they did, given the stunning reductions in the numbers.
The Compstat statistics -- used to track and fight crime by precinct -- show that most major crime in New York is at a 40-year low and continues to fall.
Murder is at its lowest level since 1963. Police estimate it will peak at about 570 murders this year, down from 621 last year and 2,245 in 1990. Although rape is up, city statistics do not distinguish between acquaintance rape and forcible rape, which F.B.I. statistics show is down 3.3 percent for the first half of this year.
Police Commissioner Kelly said the perception that crime is growing, "flies in the face of logic." He suggested that the constant drumbeat about declining crime from the news media and the Giuliani administration had made it almost a parlor game to wonder whether the new administration could keep it up.
"Call me crazy," Mr. Kelly said. "There's a reach here." He said a television crew trying to film a true-life crime show in the East Village had been forced to go elsewhere because there was so little activity.
As for the impact of terrorism, he said that recent terrorist attacks like the bombing in Bali only deepened fears. New Yorkers say their heightened sense of insecurity comes less from major crimes than from more subtle shifts.
Their feelings may be related to the so-called broken windows theory of policing, pioneered in the early 1980's by James Q. Wilson and George Kelling. According to this theory, public disorder like vandalism and littering breeds bad behavior and even crime. A study in Newark showed that while increased foot patrols did not reduce crime, people felt more secure, tending to believe that crime had been reduced.
"'Clean streets equate in people's minds to lower crime rates," said Mr. Schiffman of Pratt Institute. "Now with all the discussions about budget cuts and reductions in the amount of money going for policing and fire, all these anxieties are beginning to rise. So people's perception of what may happen begins to be blurred with what has been happening and what is the reality."
Mr. Jackson, the former government worker, said he had noticed that panhandlers outside a deli at 84th Street and Columbus Avenue appeared to be steering people to drug dealers working nearby, in exchange for a $10 or $20 bill in their cup. While crime may not have risen, he said, "you feel it's imminent."
"It's a very ominous feeling," he added. "It makes me almost feel as if I want to escape. The other shoe is going to drop soon enough. I am feeling more defensive, I genuinely am."

'It's Been There All Along'
Another theory is that citywide averages mask pockets of increases in borderline neighborhoods, increases that may hint at worse problems to come. The New York Times poll documents a slight bump in the number of people who say that they or members of their immediate family have been the victim of a crime in the city in the last year. The percentage of victims has risen to 14 percent from 10 percent a year ago. Although the increase is just below the limits of statistical significance, it reverses the downward trend that polls have shown in the last five years.
Lenora Howard, 24, a single mother of four in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, said drugs and gangs in her neighborhood had been pushed deeper underground, but she fears they will return at the first sign that the police are lowering their guard. "It's not gone," she said. "It's been here all along, in certain neighborhoods."
When New Yorkers were feeling victorious over crime, Mr. Schiffman added, they may have been more willing to overlook the reality that crime continued to persist in certain neighborhoods. 
An examination of the Compstat statistics shows that while overall crime is down, some categories are inching up in some precincts.
In Mott Haven, in the Bronx, every category of crime except for grand larceny has been dropping. But in one week straddling late October and early November, the number of robberies jumped 33 percent, to 16 from 12; the number of serious assaults jumped 150 percent, to 10 from 4, and the number of grand larcenies rose 67 percent, to 5 from 3.
Emily Resvanis, a 55-year-old homemaker who lives in Jackson Heights, Queens, said her neighborhood of two-family homes had recently experienced a rash of crime.
"I've had quite a few burglaries in my neighborhood, which was one of the best neighborhoods in the city," said Mrs. Resnavis, who has three children, two still living at home. "Something is going on. My son is going off to work, he worries about what's going on on the train. I see an increase of people stealing pocketbooks off women."
She did not blame the police. 
"The police are probably overburdened," she said. But she did say they seemed to be responding less aggressively than in the past. Her neighbor, she said, had to call the police several times after a burglary before they came to take fingerprints. She also said she sees more abandoned cars, apparently stolen, on the streets.
In Jackson Heights, police statistics bear out Mrs. Resvanis's observations. So far this year, crime in the 115th Precinct has risen 1.69 percent, although over the last two years, it has dropped more than 7 percent. People don't notice averages, however; they notice what they see and hear. Within those averages, murder is up 75 percent, to 7 murders from 4; rape is up 26 percent, to 29 from 23; robbery is up 19 percent, to 418 from 352, and burglary is up 8 percent, to 449 from 414.
Mr. Kelly did not dispute the numbers, but said, "If I show you crime is down in 66 out of 76 precincts, is that good or bad?"

Living With Ambiguity
Most New Yorkers, of course, feel the city is as safe as it was four years ago. 
Eberto Pineiro, a 33-year-old methadone counselor, said Park Slope, Brooklyn, where he lives, and the East Village, where he socializes, have become so gentrified he finds it hard to believe they could slide back to what they were in the 1980's. If anything, he said, he sees less desperation among clients at the clinic where he works.
He confessed to some uncertainty about the future. 
"I do have that fear," he said. "But it's not due to anything outside of just the fact that in cities this enormous, things fluctuate. You have periods of crime and periods of less crime."
