HEADLINE: From Middle Class to the Shelter Door; 
In a Trend, New Yorkers Face Poverty After Last Unemployment Check

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
The tidy apartment in a house in Staten Island rents for just $650 a month, but Salvatore and Lorraine Nardulli can no longer afford it. They cannot pay the phone bill, or the electric bill, or the insurance on their 10-year-old Pontiac Grand Prix. There is an empty space next to the VCR where the cable box once stood; dunning letters are stacked up on the kitchen table.
 Mr. Nardulli, 53, who worked for an airline for almost three decades, has been unemployed for 18 months and cannot find a full-time job. Mrs. Nardulli, who is several years younger, worked for years as a legal secretary but more recently has been a homemaker and student; she cannot find any work. 
 They have run through their $12,000 or so in savings. They have borrowed to the limit on their credit cards, another $12,000. And in June, Mr. Nardulli's extended unemployment insurance ran out. 
Turned down twice for public assistance, the Nardullis say they fear that they will end up in a homeless shelter. "If we have to leave this apartment -- God forbid," Mrs. Nardulli said. "I feel like we are being punished because my husband lost his job."
No one knows for sure how many people are in the same boat as the Nardullis: people whose comfortable lives have abruptly unraveled because of the recession and the economic aftereffects of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, 2001. Some economists say there may be hundreds of thousands of them across the country, based on trends in the labor market and in unemployment insurance, which has traditionally been a safety net of the middle class, as public assistance has been for the poor.
The percentage of people who have exhausted their regular unemployment benefits is at the highest level in two decades. In New York State, 156,000 people have also used up the additional three months of temporary unemployment benefits that Congress authorized in March; that program expires at the end of December.
While New York has by far the largest number of people who have run out of temporary benefits, nationally there are about 1.5 million, according to the federal Department of Labor. Wendell Primus, director of the income security division of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research institute in Washington, estimates that up to a million of them have not found jobs and are not eligible for more aid.
Of course, even among those who have not found work, not everyone is necessarily experiencing as much hardship as the Nardullis. Many may have had more savings, and about 40 percent are likely to have had working spouses, according to studies done in previous years for the Labor Department by Mathematica Policy Research. 
What clearly makes the Nardullis unusual is their willingness to talk about their plight. Some New Yorkers in similar straits have said they were too embarrassed or ashamed (or worried what their landlords would think) to let their names be used publicly. 
Mr. and Mrs. Nardulli struggled with the idea of discussing their situation but said they finally decided that their story might help other people by drawing attention to the problems of the unemployed.
Besides, Mr. Nardulli said: "We've got nothing to lose. We're going down anyway. I used to be optimistic, but now that's all gone."
Such gloomy sentiments are new for a couple who describe themselves as "life of the party" types who love to dance. They met in 1977, at a disco in Brooklyn, where they lived until three years ago. "We were 'Saturday Night Fever' fans," Mrs. Nardulli said.
In those days, Mr. Nardulli's job seemed not just secure, but glamorous, he said. The travel benefits at the big international airline where he was a cargo agent meant that he could go skiing in Switzerland, swimming in Caracas, "travel the world," he said. With overtime, he eventually made as much as $45,000 a year. And what member of the Teamsters union ever got laid off?
"I felt secure with him," Mrs. Nardulli said. They were married in 1981; Mr. Nardulli still carries two copies of their wedding photo in his wallet. And Mrs. Nardulli, the more voluble of the two, constantly sings the praises of her husband as "a good man" and "a good worker."
Neither of them has a college degree. "I couldn't afford it; I was supporting my family," said Mr. Nardulli, whose father died when he was 13. Mrs. Nardulli studied business for a year at Pace University and then worked for about a dozen years as a secretary. 
A few years after they were married, Mrs. Nardulli decided to stay home. "I thought I was going to have a baby, but I didn't," she said. It left her depressed.
Eventually, she began going to school. She studied to become a paralegal, got a real estate license and became a notary public. She did temporary work sometimes, but mostly she decorated her apartment and kept it spotless and enjoyed music and parties and friends, she said.
Both of them have regrets. "If I had known this could happen, I would have done things differently," Mrs. Nardulli said. "I would have made sure I got a job immediately."
As for Mr. Nardulli, he wishes that he had heeded the warning signs, in the late 1990's, that there was trouble at the airline (which he does not want identified because he still hopes to get a pension). But his department was shuttered in 1998. "I worked for 28 years straight and I have nothing to show for it," he said. 
He did get a severance package, but that was used up quickly as he hunted for a new job, and in the course of their move to Staten Island. (Brooklyn had become too expensive.)
After a short stint running the shipping department of a small factory, Mr. Nardulli got a job at a customs clearing concern, where he worked until April 2001. But as the economy slowed, the owner decided to downsize, and to move what was left of the company to New Jersey. Mr. Nardulli got two weeks' pay. 
What kept them afloat after that was the $362 a week Mr. Nardulli got in unemployment benefits. He ran out of benefits before Thanksgiving last year, and used a credit card for living expenses until he became eligible for three more months in the spring under the emergency unemployment program.
He has diligently looked for a job, and has inches of faxed resumes to prove it. "I had a chance before Sept. 11," he said. But since then, the steep decline in travel and shipping has spawned huge cutbacks at New York's airports. Airport-related jobs have plunged by almost 16.5 percent, or about 10,000, according to the Center for an Urban Future, a nonpartisan research group.
Mr. Nardulli has tried looking in other industries but has been told that there are hiring freezes or that he lacks the right job history, he said. "I went to a supermarket and the guy said, 'With your qualifications, why?' I said, 'I need a job.' But he refused me because I had no experience." 
Mrs. Nardulli said she had been rejected for jobs because her experience was not a perfect match for, say, a doctor's office, rather than a lawyer's office. Temporary agencies tell her that nothing is available. Both she and Mr. Nardulli are getting computer training, courtesy of the State Labor Department, but she said their school was not holding out much hope of finding them work.
If they could both find even low-paying jobs, Mrs. Nardulli said, "with steady paychecks, we could pool them and make it."
More than that, Mr. Nardulli said, "I want a job that pays the rent."
In desperation, the Nardullis turned to public assistance, an experience that they said was humiliating and ultimately pointless.
Here, too, they seem to be illustrative of a trend.
Welfare rolls have not increased consistently this year, but there have been sharp increases in applications for public assistance since June, according to the New York City Human Resources Administration. The number of people in the city not on public assistance but getting food stamps, which some analysts say is a better measure of economic hardship, has risen by more than 60,000 in the last year, an increase of almost 17 percent.
The Nardullis, after going through all kinds of examinations and investigations and skills tests, got a two-month supply of food stamps, and Mr. Nardulli was promised a job as a security guard. He said he worked only three days, bringing home just $100. But according to the paperwork, he was making $2,000 a month at that job, so he was refused any further assistance.
Through a friend, Mr. Nardulli then found a part-time job driving a van for disabled people. He enjoys the work, likes the passengers and wants to succeed so much that he has spent hours memorizing city street maps.
But as the employee with the least seniority, he works only three days a week, usually bringing home $150 a week after taxes. He has started spending his days off doing yardwork and anything else he can, but it is not enough to pay the rent and utilities, much less buy food.
Still, it is enough to disqualify him for public assistance. As a letter the Nardullis got from the city put it (complete with misspellings), his "income is suffican to meet the budgetory needof your family unit."
Mr. Nardulli's translation: "You have to lose everything before you get help."
The Nardullis have not yet lost everything, not quite. There's still the green Pontiac, which flies an American flag. Though it broke down recently, a cousin of Mrs. Nardulli's gave them the money to repair it and to pay for the insurance.
And they are still in the apartment, though they are two months behind on the rent. "The landlords are very nice, very nice people," Mrs. Nardulli said. "But, of course, they would like their money."
If worse comes to worst, Mrs. Nardulli said, she will get a lot of bubble wrap and pack up all the treasures she has accumulated during her marriage: all the silk flowers and Precious Moments figurines, all the apple-themed kitchen gear and the framed maxim, "When there is love in the house, there is joy in the heart."
She has already asked friends whether they will store her things if she ends up in a homeless shelter.
"They think we're kidding," Mr. Nardulli said. "But we're just realistic."

HEADLINE: More Trouble in Chinatown As Job-Training Effort Fails 

BYLINE:  By DAISY HERNANDEZ 

 BODY:
The organization that provides most of the nonprofit job training in Chinatown has eliminated its program for dislocated workers, causing worries in a community still reeling from a battered economy and the aftershocks of the Sept. 11 attack.
 The organization, Chinatown Manpower Project, sent a letter to the New York City Department of Employment in September, saying it would not continue its four-year contract with the city because it could not meet its performance goals. The contract was worth $355,446 annually, but the organization received full payment only after it found jobs for workers. The program was the only one using money from the city's Department of Employment and directed at dislocated workers who are Chinese-American. 
 A department spokesman, George Rodriguez, said the city had been pleased with the program, which in its last cycle had about 20 students pass the state exam to become certified nursing aides. But he said the department could not do much in response to the cancellation.
"We can't force them to take the contract," Mr. Rodriguez said.
Many of the students were former garment-industry workers. The 12-week program was successful among those who graduated and found jobs at nursing homes, where the demand for bilingual aides has grown in recent years with an increase in elderly Chinese patients.
The Chinatown Manpower Project has been a fixture for 30 years. It runs a dozen programs, including job training and literacy classes.
The organization's longtime executive director, Sue Lee, left earlier this year and was replaced on Nov. 4 by James Melendez. When asked about the dislocated-workers program, Mr. Melendez said he did not know about past decisions affecting it. He added, however, that he had reviewed the group's other training programs and that "all those programs are doing very well."
But David Fischer, project director at the Center for an Urban Future, said nonprofit organizations have had a difficult time operating dislocated-worker programs because government funding for job training is tied to performance and worker placement has become more difficult since the attack.
David Chen, executive director of the Chinese-American Planning Council, agreed, saying that his organization has had to "do more with less."
"But what if you already do more with less?" he said.
Mr. Chen said his group, like others, finances job training with the hope that it will later receive government funding.
Instead of eliminating job training, Mr. Chen said, his group has cut back on the hours it is open for walk-in services, when Chinatown residents often seek help with everything from language translation to employment problems. And the organization has had to consider what was once the unthinkable: charging people for some services.
Despite the closing of the Chinatown Manpower Project's dislocated-workers program, training continued for the 21 students who had already registered for the nursing-aide course. One student, Walter Tang, said classes had been delayed twice, but were finally begun at the end of October. When he heard that the program had been dismantled, he was alarmed.
"We want to keep the program running," Mr. Tang said. "We want to get jobs."
Mr. Tang said he had been unemployed since January and that he had applied for airport and Postal Service jobs. But he said he had not been called back for interviews and that he was especially worried because his unemployment benefits end in February.
"We have to get training as soon as possible," he said.
Since the closing of the Chinatown Manpower Project, the Chinese-American Planning Council has been inundated with workers seeking help, said its project director for employment and training, Jeffrey F. Chen.
"You have a waiting list of hundreds of people," he said. "It's almost like a desperate situation." 

CORRECTION-DATE: November 20, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the closing of a job training program for dislocated workers at a New York nonprofit organization, the Chinatown Manpower Project, referred incorrectly at one point to the organization's status. It remains open; it did not close with the training program.

HEADLINE: Survey Shows 27 Presidents Of Colleges Top $500,000 

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
Although academia is not traditionally known for high salaries, 27 private college presidents earned more than $500,000 last year, a survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education shows. 
 The survey of 595 private colleges found that the median pay for the presidents of research universities increased 30 percent from the 1997 fiscal year to the 2001 fiscal year. In contrast, the pay for presidents of liberal arts colleges grew by 4 percent in that period. 
 Still, the survey found, it was a liberal arts college president who topped last year's chart: Claire L. Gaudiani, the Connecticut College president who resigned under pressure from the faculty, with a half-million-dollar severance package that brought her total compensation to $898,410. 
Ms. Gaudiani's compensation included her pay and benefits, $346,000, plus the $551,500 severance. Trish Brink, a spokeswoman for the college, said the severance reflected the contributions Ms. Gaudiani had made in 13 years as president. 
"President Gaudiani had a long tenure here at the college, during which time significant advancements were made, including the establishment of five academic centers in international studies, arts and technology, environmental studies, museum studies and community action," Ms. Brink said. 
Ms. Gaudiani's severance package is far greater than that of some more prominent college presidents who stepped down last year. 
Harold T. Shapiro, who ranked third in the survey, received $705,863 in the year he stepped down as president of Princeton, including deferred compensation estimated at $200,000. Ruth J. Simmons received about $145,000 in deferred compensation when she left Smith College to become Brown University's president, bringing her total compensation from Smith for that year to $539,169. Robert Edwards, who left as president of Bowdoin College, received $217,250 in severance pay, bringing his 2001 compensation to $591,000.
No. 2 on the compensation list -- and the highest paid of presidents staying in place -- was Judith Rodin, who received $808,021 last year at the University of Pennsylvania. 
Others on the Top 10 list are William R. Brody of Johns Hopkins, at $677,564; L. Jay Oliva, the former president of New York University, at $651,000; Constantine N. Papadakis of Drexel, at $637,839; Richard C. Levin of Yale, at $612,453; Steven B. Sample of the University of Southern California, at $605,086; H. Patrick Swygert of Howard University, at $603,031; and Jon Westling of Boston University, at $591,017. 
College presidents are by no means the highest-paid people in academia: many medical-school professors and others earn more than the presidents of their universities. At Vanderbilt University, for example, the highest paid official was William T. Spitz, the vice chancellor for investments, who earned $3,217,311. 
But college presidents' pay is growing far more rapidly than professors'. At Penn and Princeton, where faculty pay rose 4.8 percent from 2000 to 2001, the president's pay went up by 16 percent and 43 percent, respectively. 
Competition for the top recruits has never been fiercer, with public and private universities increasingly vying for the same candidates. Compensation for those who lead large state university systems, too, has escalated, so that Texas and Tennessee now top $700,000. 
Patrick M. Callan, president of the National Center for Public Policy and Higher Education, said the rising pay for college presidents poses dangers to higher education. 
"As the president's pay goes up, it raises what you pay the provosts, the deans, and so on, and that cost escalation, at a time of recession when we're going to have to raise tuition anyway, sends a pretty insensitive message," Mr. Callan said.

HEADLINE: Where the Powerful and Famous Nosh; 
A Haven for Politicians

BYLINE:  By LISA FODERARO 

 BODY:
 FOOD isn't the only reason to go out to a restaurant, and you don't have to go in to Manhattan to mingle with a glitzy crowd. Westchester and nearby counties are rife with its own celebrities -- actors and rock musicians, artists and classical performers, and of course, a full cast of politicos. 
 Here is a handful of restaurants that for whatever reason -- the menu, the atmosphere, the space between the tables -- have become regular haunts of the see-and-be-seen crowds.
On the outside, Mulino's of Westchester does not make a punchy first impression, hidden as it is on a side street in downtown White Plains behind a nondescript brick facade.
But inside, the space is bright and elegant, and it becomes instantly clear why the restaurant is the preferred dining place in Westchester for powerful politicians and business leaders.
Sparkling, jewel-toned bottles of Italian brandy, or grappa, fill mirrored shelves in the small bar area. In the dining room, tables draped in white linen offer an unexpected view through a wall of windows: a manmade waterfall in the courtyard. Diners are welcomed by solicitous waiters bearing platters of Parmesan cheese, bruschetta and marinated zucchini.
No wonder the restaurant's reservation book is filled with so many high-profile names. Regulars from the business world include Nicholas M. Donofrio, senior vice president for technology and manufacturing of I.B.M.; Barry I. Slotnick, the defense lawyer; and Louis R. Cappelli, the county's uber-builder.
Among the many elected officials who frequent Mulino's are Andrew J. Spano, the Westchester County executive; Nicholas A. Spano, a New York State senator (who is no relation to the county executive), along with his brother, Michael J. Spano, a state assemblyman, and their father, Leonard N. Spano, the county clerk; Joseph M. Delfino, the White Plains mayor; and Janet DiFiore, a state Supreme Court justice-elect.
"It is the 'in' place for everybody, but especially for politicians," said Vincent Natrella, former chairman of the county's Conservative Committee. "If you're going to speak to somebody, like a senator or assemblyman or mayor, nobody bothers you. You're treated very respectfully."
Gov. George E. Pataki dines at Mulino's with local politicians a couple of times a year. Even two former New York City mayors, Edward I. Koch and Rudolph W. Giuliani, have made their way to White Plains for the restaurant's Northern Italian cooking.
Part of the restaurant's success, apart from the fresh, flavorful food (a full meal costs about $50 a person), is because of its attention to detail. Marcello Giansante, the smooth-as-Sambuca manager, commits his customers' likes and dislikes to memory.
Favorite tables? Mr. Giansante said Mr. Natrella likes to sit right up front by the entrance "so he doesn't have to walk too far to shake hands," while the Spanos prefer the upper dining level. Salvatore J. Carrera, Westchester's director of economic development and real estate, is happiest at a corner table by the window.
Most of the politicians forgo a cocktail in favor of a good red wine, whether a Brunello from Italy or a cabernet sauvignon from California. One important customer, Brenda Spano, wife of the county executive, is highly allergic to a particular nut. "We make sure that none of the specials have any nuts at all" when she comes for dinner, Mr. Giansante said.
For Mr. Carrera, who came to county government after 30 years in the high-powered world of Manhattan real estate, Mulino's helped smooth the transition to Westchester. "I always enjoyed a good lunch or dinner at a classy four-star restaurant, and that's what I find at Mulino's," he said. LISA FODERARO
Mulino's of Westchester, 99 Court, White Plains. (914) 761-1818.

 INTERNATIONAL 3-18

Horn of Africa a New Base In U.S. Anti-Terror Drive
The United States military is building its combat power in the horn of Africa, for the first time since American troops withdrew from Somalia after a bloody firefight in Mogadishu. The main goal is to put American forces in position to strike Al Qaeda cells in Yemen or East Africa. The Pentagon has also begun to use Djibouti to train its forces in desert warfare, possibly for an Iraqi offensive. 1

Al Qaeda Suspect Arrested
Kuwait has custody of a Qaeda member who has confessed to planning last month's attack against a French supertanker off the coast of Yemen, a Kuwaiti security official said. The man identified as Mohsen al-Fadhli, has also confessed to a planned attack on a hotel in Yemen used by American military officials that was to happen this month. 20

Uneasy South Africa Alliance
South Africa has made moves lately in support of troubled Zimbabwe, but those steps have outraged the Zimbabwe opposition leaders, who accused the government of intimidation of its critics and worse. 14

Israel Mourns Dead
As Jewish settlers massed to pray at the site of a Palestinian ambush that killed 12 people, the Israeli Army described the attack as a carefully planned assault on settlers returning from prayer, a trap laid to draw security forces into an exposed alleyway. 12

Crackdown on Hindu Extremists
In Ahmedabad, India, the Hindu nationalist government cracked down on Hindu extremists, as state riot police arrested for the first time the leader of a hard-line ultra-nationalist group, Pravin Togadia. 18

Agencies Monitor Iraqis In U.S. for Terror Threats
The Bush administration has begun to secretly monitor Iraqis in the United States in an effort to disrupt potential domestic terrorist threats posed by sympathizers of the Baghdad regime, senior government officials said. 1

Democrats Adrift, Leaders Say
Democratic leaders say their party is bereft of obvious new leaders and threatened by divisive ideological battles as it struggles to determine how to deal with the new Republican dominance in Washington. 1

Report on Kennedy's Health
The first thorough examination of President John F. Kennedy's medical records has found that he suffered from more ailments, was in far greater pain and was taking many more medications than the public knew at the time or biographers have since described. 1

Missing Persons Cases
Four young people in Minnesota and Wisconsin have disappeared since Oct. 30 under similar circumstances. Law enforcement officials say they have not ruled out a connection but have found no evidence of any. 23

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Hampton's Destination Appears to Be Atlanta

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
In a stunning development to what was initially a two-team, six-player trade, pitcher Mike Hampton was on his way to the Atlanta Braves last night.
 Neither the Colorado Rockies, who began the sequence by trading Hampton to Florida, nor the Marlins confirmed the development, but a person familiar with the trade talks said the Marlins were talking to the Braves and were expected to complete a deal for the left-handed Hampton. 
 "Hampton will never pitch for the Marlins," the person said. 
The turn of events came on a day when Hampton and Marlins catcher Charles Johnson had to waive the no-trade provisions in their contracts for the two teams to complete their trade. Johnson did not waive his no-trade clause by the 2 p.m. deadline, but Scott Boras, his agent, said later in the day that Johnson agreed to accept the trade once the Marlins agreed to pay him $1 million to offset Colorado's state income tax.
Hampton, according to the person familiar with the trade talks, initially said he would not waive his no-trade clause to go to the Marlins, but would waive it if the Marlins traded him to a team that had a chance to contend.
Mark Rodgers, Hampton's agent, disputed that characterization, saying Hampton had waived the provision earlier in the day before the deadline.
The pending acquisition of Hampton, who was a disappointment in two years with the Rockies, was expected to have an impact on the Braves' plans for their two free-agent starters, Tom Glavine and Greg Maddux.
The Braves have not made a strong effort to re-sign either one, and now that they appear to be on the verge of acquiring Hampton, they may let Glavine and Maddux go elsewhere.
It is still possible, however, that the Braves could re-sign one of the pitchers.
The Mets and the Philadelphia Phillies have been the two most aggressive pursuers of Glavine, a left-hander, both making him three-year offers. No team has publicly acknowledged going after Maddux.
Hampton, whose eight-year, $121 million contract is the richest ever signed by a pitcher, wants to leave Colorado after two seasons in which he struggled with a 21-28 record and a 5.75 earned run average. 
The struggling Marlins were not what he had in mind, but the Braves, with their 11 consecutive division championships, certainly appeal to him.
When the Rockies and the Marlins agreed to their trade last Wednesday, contingent on the acceptance by Hampton and Johnson, the Rockies agreed to send Hampton and center fielder Juan Pierre to Florida for Johnson, center fielder Preston Wilson, reliever Vic Darensbourg and infielder Pablo Ozuna.
The Hampton trade was to be the first step in a three-pronged plan to create payroll flexibility for the Rockies. 
They are also talking to the Mets about trading pitcher Denny Neagle for shortstop Rey Ordonez and outfielder Jeromy Burnitz, and to the Arizona Diamondbacks about trading them outfielder Larry Walker.
The Rockies and the Marlins wanted to make the deal for economic reasons. The Rockies wanted to shed the remaining six years and $84.5 million on Hampton's contract, while the Marlins wanted to reduce their financial obligations in the immediate future.
The Marlins not only would get rid of the last three years of Johnson's and Wilson's contracts, but they would also not have to pay Hampton. It was not known whom the Marlins would get from the Braves, but they were not expected to be high-priced players.

HEADLINE: Correspondent's Report; 
Tough Times Bring Bargain Rates to Capital

BYLINE:  By Philip Shenon 

DATELINE: Washington 

 BODY:
There are several variations of a grim joke told in this city's beleaguered tourism industry. And most of them end with the same biblically inspired punch line: "So when do the locusts arrive?"
 Over the last 15 months, it has been one blow after another for hotels, restaurants and tourist attractions in the nation's capital. First the tourism industry struggled with the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attacks. Then the city was panicked by the deadly anthrax mailings, which shut down Congress and convinced already wary travelers that they were wise to stay away. 
 And just when things were looking up this autumn and tourists had begun to return to Washington in siable numbers, the city and its suburbs were terrorized by a series of sniper attacks that left 10 people dead.
 The capture last month of two men accused of the sniper murders has brought a sense of relief to the capital, but the arrests may have been too late to salvage the city's autumn tourism season.
 "We really haven't done an economic tabulation of the damage," said William A. Hanbury, president of the Washington D. C. Conventiona nd Tourism Corporation, the capital's tourism bureau. "But there absolutely was an effect. You can't deny it."
 While no major conventions were canceled, he said, there were many cancellations among the large school and youth groups that usually flood into the city after the opening of the academic year. The city's restaurant industry was devastated as Washingtons chose to stay home rather than risk a sniper encounter.
 Before the sniper attacks hotel reservations were nearly back to pre-Sept. 11 levels, thanks in part to uninterrupted business from the federal government and its contractors. Occupancy rates had been about 80 percent, close to normal for the fall season. (In the first weeks after Sept. 11, almost three out of four hotel rooms in the city went empty.) Over the summer, rates had been down about 5 percent from the year before, according to figures from the city's tourism agency.
 The sniper attacks put an abrupt end to this rebound. Now, hotel managers and restaurateurs say they will try to make up for lost time before the holiday season.
 Perhaps no one in the travel industry has more reason to be relieved by the sniper arrests than Jorge E. Trevito, the director of hotel openings for Kimpton Hotels, the San Francisco-based chain with the bad timing to have opened five new boutique hotels in Washington since last fall.
 "It has been a tough time," said Mr. Trevino, who is also the general manager of the Hotel Monaco, which may be the most talked-about new hotel in Washington, given its flamboyant interior decor in this decidedly button-down city. He said that while the sniper attacks had "not caused a blizzard of cancellations, we did see a slower pace of bookings."
 The tough times have brought bargain rates at many of the city's best hotels.
 The 184-room Hotel Monaco, one of 37 boutique hotels managed by Kimpton around the country is offering an introductory weekend rate of $169 a night for a double room on its Web site (www.monaco-dc.com), more than half off the regular rate of $350. (Those rates are before taxes, which add 14.5 percent to all hotel bills in the city.)
 Most of the major government attractions that were shut down after Sept. 11 and the anthrax mailings have since been reopened to visitors, including the Capitol and the Bureau of Engraving and Printing. The Washington Monument was reopened in February after a $10.5 million renovation that was under way at the time of the terrorist attacks.
 The White House, the Pentagon and F.B.I. headquarters have resumed public tours, although on a limited basis because of security concerns. The White House generally accepts only school and military groups for tours, and only those with advance reservations.
 To entice visitors back to the capital, the Convention and Tourism Corporation has mounted a $2.5 million advertising campaign that features stars of the television drama "West Wing" urging patriotic visitors to "come, be inspired" by the capital. A separate television and features the first lady, Laura Bush, Senator John McCain and the soccer star Mia Hamm joining in a rendition of the Gershwin classic "Of Thee I Sing."
 The travel bureau is also promoting a series of new events and exhibitions around the city, including a display of Julia Child's reconstructed kitchen at the National Museum of American History to mark her 90th birthday; a new 3-D Imax movie at the National Air and Space Museum featuring the journeys of the Space Shuttle; and the new International Spy Museum, which has proved a hit with its interactive displays on the history of espionage.

HEADLINE: CHILDREN'S BOOKS; 
The Subject Was Noses

BYLINE:  By Sam Swope; Sam Swope is the author of "The Araboolies of Liberty Street." His next children's book is "Jack and the Seven Deadly Giants."

 BODY:
 PINOCCHIO
By Carlo Collodi.
Illustrated by Gris Grimly.
222 pp. New York:
Tor/Tom Doherty Associates.
$15.95. (All ages)

THE ADVENTURES
OF PINOCCHIO
The Story of a Puppet.
By Carlo Collodi.
Illustrated by Iassen Ghiuselev.
150 pp. Vancouver, British Columbia: Simply Read Books. $22.95. (All ages)

THE ADVENTURES
OF PINOCCHIO
Story of a Puppet.
By Carlo Collodi.
Translated by Nancy Canepa.
Illustrated by Carmelo Lettere.
209 pp. South Royalton,Vt.:
Steerforth Italia/Steerforth Press.
Paper, $12.95. (All ages)

PINOCCHIO THE BOY
Or, Incognito in Collodi.
Written and illustrated by Lane Smith.
Unpaged. New York:
Viking. $16.99. (Ages 5 and up)
 GepPetto wasn't looking for a son. The puppet he made was meant to be his meal ticket. He had planned to take it all over the world, make it dance and do flips, and in that way earn his "crust of bread and glass of wine." As Geppetto carved his puppet, however, it sprang to life, then kicked Geppetto on the nose and tore off down the street. 
If Pinocchio had known what lay in store for him, how he would be adapted, abridged and reimagined (four new versions just now), he would have kept on running, jumped right out of the book and fled his Destiny, which was that he would become a literary superstar and everyone would want a piece of him. 
Carlo Collodi was the pen name of Carlo Lorenzini, a political journalist who never married and lived with his mother. He began "Pinocchio," his first bit of "childishness" as he called it, in 1881, when he was in his 50's. The story appeared in installments in a children's magazine over the course of two years. In 1883, it was published as a novel and was an immediate sensation in Italy, but Collodi, who never had any money, did not share in the book's financial success and died without knowing that there would one day be hundreds of translations of his book in more than 100 languages. 
"Pinocchio" is a rich mix of fairy tale, commedia dell'arte, fable, picaresque, quest, realism and bildungsroman. It has been interpreted, analyzed and dissected in ways literary, religious, political, economic and psychoanalytic. It is able to be all things to all people because Pinocchio is Everyman, and his struggle to be "real" is a captivating, timeless metaphor for the human condition. 
"Pinocchio" holds mythic status in Italy, where it is widely considered a masterpiece equal to "The Divine Comedy." International scholars admire it, too, favorably comparing it to the "Odyssey," the "Aeneid," "The Pilgrim's Progress" and "Huckleberry Finn." Considering its reputation, comparatively few people know it. 
I've done an informal survey, asking my literate friends if they've read the book, and while most assume they have, when questioned they turn out to know only Disney's charming 1940 adaptation, which, though scary at times, brightens and softens Collodi's story and simplifies and sentimentalizes his puppet, making Pinocchio trusting and adorable. They're unaware that the original puppet had rougher edges, was egocentric, obstinate and rash, yet also self-sacrificing, generous and passionate -- in short, Italian. 
Likewise, they're shocked to hear that Collodi's Pinocchio hurls a hammer at the moralizing Cricket, squashing it flat, or that the Blue Fairy first appears as a little girl who is dead and tells Pinocchio she is waiting to be taken away in a casket.
Great stuff!
One hundred and twenty years later, "Pinocchio" continues to be remade, revamped and retold; Roberto Benigni stars as the puppet in a new movie opening on Christmas Day. Yet the original Pinocchio refuses to die. Even Collodi couldn't kill him, though he tried: he intended to end the story with Chapter 15, when the puppet is hanged from a tree by the Fox and the Cat and left for dead, but such was the hue and cry from the writer's young audience that he brought Pinocchio back to life. 
There have been hundreds (if not thousands) of versions of "Pinocchio" in English, from board books to pop-ups to lavish full-color volumes. The boy puppet has been rendered by illustrators in countless guises, everything from Little Lord Fauntleroy Pinocchios to Charlie McCarthy look-alikes. On the whole, though, Pinocchio has been lucky in his illustrators, the most brilliant of whom was Atillio Mussino, whose marvelous illustrations are now out of print. Successful depictions of the character always give Pinocchio a puppet's hinged arms and legs but a head more human than mechanical. This is critical because Pinocchio, while certainly a puppet, is really a boy, and a boy with outsized emotions at that.
This season, different artists give us their Pinocchios, with mixed results. 
Gris Grimly's black-and-white drawings capture something of the tale's manic pace, but his Pinocchio is all puppet. He's rough-hewn, a folk art doll, and it's hard to feel the human drama Pinocchio suffers. Grimly, who illustrated "Monster Museum," sets "Pinocchio" not so much in 19th-century Tuscany as in his own wacky world, which is part Gothic, part Mad magazine, a place with crooked telephone poles and characters who resemble aliens. 
I loved Iassen Ghiuselev's magnificent full-color paintings and drawings in his jaw-droppingly beautiful oversized edition, but they're too somber for "Pinocchio." They lack the commedia dell'arte spirit that lightens the story's horrific events. Moreover, his puppet is no devilish scamp but a heavy, almost tragic figure; even Pinocchio's smiles are melancholy.
The prose in the Ghiuselev book is more fluent than that in the Grimly, though no translator is cited in either. Collodi wrote in a 19th-century Tuscan dialect that I'm told is sinewy and beautiful, but the English in children's editions has always been choppy and awkward. Thank goodness for Nancy Canepa, who at last gives us a "Pinocchio" written in graceful and lively English prose. This paperback seems aimed at adults, but there's no reason not to give it to a child. It's the least expensive of the bunch, and children can skip the introduction and ignore Carmelo Lettere's sketchy and uneven drawings, which are sometimes suggestive and sometimes confusing and probably won't appeal to kids.
In every edition of "Pinocchio," the least satisfying illustration is the last one, when the puppet turns into a boy. Somehow he always looks less real, less believable, than he did as a puppet. Collodi understood the problem, and ended the story immediately after the transformation. Where's the fun in reading about a good and obedient child?
Lane Smith, counterintuitively, chooses that very moment as the starting point for "Pinocchio the Boy," which he wrote and illustrated. Smith, who illustrated Jon Scieszka's stories "The True Story of the Three Little Pigs" and "The Stinky Cheese Man," is no stranger to wiseacre books poking fun at classic children's tales. This fits in that category. The illustrations and design are characteristically brilliant; they're appealing, original and amusing. If only his story were up to that level.
Smith's characters are banal and his plot is an embarrassment, so trivial I can't bring myself to describe it, except to say that his real boy Pinocchio goes out into the world and runs into trouble ludicrously mild compared to the agonies undergone by Collodi's Pinocchio, who was robbed, hanged, jailed, turned into a donkey, floured and almost fried, and swallowed by a shark. 
Oh, what a falling off was there! That the great Pinocchio should end up such a cipher! In this age of beautifully illustrated books, story has suffered terribly, and our picture books are all too often like the meal the Snail brings to a starving Pinocchio -- delicious seeming but made of plaster.

GRAPHIC: Drawing: A girl pesters Pinocchio; detail of an illustration by Lane Smith from "Pinocchio the Boy: Or, Incognito in Collodi."

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Bargain Shops Invade Upscale Streets

BYLINE:  By Terry Pristin

 BODY:
In 1999, a company called Wolf Camera spent about $1.6 million building a lavish new store on Manhattan's Upper East Side with custom wood and metal finishes. But the company went bankrupt and closed its store on 86th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, after less than two years.
 Wolf's blue carpeting with its curvy pattern (chosen to subtly suggest unspooling film) has outlasted the camera store but is now almost entirely obscured by racks of steeply discounted designer clothing crammed into a cluttered new store called Luxury Brand Outlet. 
 With its hand-lettered paper sign plastered across the stainless steel store entrance, Luxury Brand Outlet is hardly the kind of tenant usually found in the area. The window display consists of a haphazard arrangement of Ferragamo shoes peeking out of their boxes. Inexpensive icicle lights are strung across the ceiling. 
 But in spite of its desheveled appearance, Luxury Brand Outlet has something that Wolf Camera Lacked: plenty of customers.
 Discount stores have long flourished on Orchard and Canal Streets, and in other parts of the city as well. But in these troubled economic times, they are also popping up more and more frequently in more affluent shopping districts. Odd-Job, a chain describing itself as "closeouts with class" that sells everything from toys to toolboxes, has a store on East 60th Street, opposite Bloomingdale's. Home Brands Warehouse, a bustling housewares store that would never be mistaken for Gracious Home, has replaced a sleepy stationery shop that was on Third Avenue and 81st Street for many years.
 Luxury Brand Outlet will have to give up its 86th Street space next year when a Gristede's supermarket moves in. But Richard Dweck, the clothing store's owner, has opened three permanent stores since August 2001 - two of them also on the Upper East Side and one on Broadway and 93rd Street - and plans to open as many as six more in the city before too long. Off-price stores carry surplus goods bought very cheaply, often with cash on the spot, from manuacturers or other merchants, including department stores.
 Though many retailers have cut back on inventory in anticipation of slower sales, Mr Dweck said he had no difficulty finding merchandise. "Every day I get called," he said. "The department stores are getting killed. They are buying a little thinner, but there's still tons of stuff on the market."
 Even consumers with money to spend tend to be value-conscious and in search of new shopping experiences, according to industry experts. "At the moment, traditional retail outlets are not doing anything that really intrigues the shopper," said Wendy Liebmann, the president of WSL Strategic retail.
 This may explain why Mr. Dweck attracts a range of customers, including regulars like Wendy Brewer, an investment banker who lives on the Uppder East Side and gets a kick from ferreting out a good buy. "It's treasure hunting," Ms. Brewer said as she combed through a rack of evening gowns. She was wearing a pair of $695 Theory leather pants she picked up at the store for $100 but said her prize find was a taupe Armani jacket reduced from $2,095 to $299.
 Of course, shoppers know that department store merchandise will eventually go on sale - these days, sooner rather than later - and yet many do not want to put up with even a short delay, said Burt Flickinger III, the managing director of Reach Management, a retail consulting company. "Customers have neither the time or the patience to wait for markdowns and keep having to go back again, rather than get it cheap the first time," he said.
 Mr. Flickinger and others in the retail industry said they expected more off-price stores to open as national chains that over-expanded during the 1990's begin closing underperforming stores.
 Many landlords turn up their noses at off-price tenants. But others need the retail income, or simply prefer to fill a space with an unsightly store, at least temporarily, rather than leave it empty and risk creating the impression that the location is tainted. Steven B. Greenberg, the president of the Greenberg Group, a retail real estate consulting company, estimated that the retail vacancy rate in Manhattan was about 8 percent, about double the 1999 rate.
 "The better landlords - they're not going to cave in," Mr. Greenberg said. "But a mom-and-pop landlords, or a company sitting with a vacancy for nine months, they're going to take the tenant."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Discount stores like Luxury Brand Outlet on the Upper East Side have been gaining popularity during the economic slowdown, often moving into high-end shopping areas. (Michael Nagle for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Election Lifts Market in Turkey

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE 

 BODY:
AN electoral landslide by a party known for its Islamist roots is an unlikely magnet for investment, but the triumph of the Justice and Development Party in Turkey has sent the country's stock market soaring. 
 Turkish shares rose by about 50 percent in the weeks immediately before and since national elections earlier this month as it became apparent that the Justice and Development Party would have a large parliamentary majority. That is a rare event in Turkey, and the stability it heralded pleased investors. 
 "It removes a political cloud and marks a pivotal shift for Turkey," said Ahmad Zuaiter, who manages the Turkish Investment Fund, a closed-end fund run by Morgan Stanley and traded on the New York Stock Exchange. 
The Justice and Development Party has pledged to use its mandate to seek admission to the European Union as soon as possible and to pursue economic reforms sought by foreign creditors like the International Monetary Fund. The I.M.F. wants Turkey to cut government spending, revamp its banking industry and reduce farm subsidies.
Analysts who follow Turkish stocks for Merrill Lynch said the outlook for reform had brightened. In a report recommending an overweight position for Turkey in global portfolios, they argued that "the sheer scale of Justice and Development's majority bodes well for political stability and implementation of reforms" and that the party's "landslide does not represent a victory for political Islam."
Mr. Zuaiter is more circumspect, saying that Justice and Development "has a lot more to prove because it has a limited track record."
"It has also sent mixed signals in the last couple of months," he said.
Nevertheless, he described himself as "cautiously optimistic from a foreign-investment standpoint."
The Turkish stock market is extremely volatile, in large part because of large and sudden changes in inflation expectations and interest rates. It is common for yields on short-term debt to fluctuate by several percentage points in the course of a few weeks or even days. A sharp and swift rise in rates can make debt a more attractive investment option and spark an exodus from the stock market. When rates fall, as they have in the last couple of months, a flood of equity investment typically follows.
The Turkish Investment Fund is a convenient way for Americans to get broad, undiluted exposure to Turkey, although other funds have sizable holdings. T. Rowe Price Emerging Europe and Mediterranean, an open-end mutual fund, has 17 percent of its assets in Turkey. The closed-end Templeton Emerging Markets Fund has 5 percent there.
Mr. Zuaiter's fund rose 3.2 percent in the last 12 months, a period in which the Standard & Poor's 500 index lost more than one-fifth of its value. The fund's largest holdings include Akcansa Cimenti, which has activities in construction and building materials; the bank Akbank; Trakya Cam, a glass manufacturer; Koc Holdings, a conglomerate with interests in automobiles and consumer goods; and Turkcell, which provides two-thirds of Turkish wireless-phone service.
While most telecommunications stocks have performed poorly, Turkcell, traded on the New York Stock Exchange (it is the only Turkish stock with such a listing) was up 13.3 percent in the last 12 months.
The company "is very well managed," Mr. Zuaiter said, "with foreign strategic partners like Sonera," a Finnish telecommunications concern that controls nearly half the shares.
Turkcell "invested a significant amount of money early on, establishing dominance in the market," he said. "It has been pivotal in expanding mobile penetration," in part by luring away customers from Turkey's creaky state telephone system.
UBS Warburg is less enthusiastic and has a "hold" rating on Turkcell. Noting that its other major shareholder, Cukurova Group, controlled a bank that recently failed, Warburg's analysts say that the government may press Cukurova to sell its stake, depressing the stock.
Mr. Zuaiter said he owned Koc Holdings because it was "an entrenched brand name in Turkey and provides exposure to a number of facets of the economy." The Koc family owns a controlling interest in Migros, the country's largest retailer. Migros, which has its own listing, is the largest Turkish holding of the T. Rowe Price regional fund.
The Akbank investment is a bet on growth in Turkey's underdeveloped banking sector. Mr. Zuaiter said he liked the cement and glass companies "because we think there will be significant growth in construction activity, not just in Turkey but in the surrounding region."
HE was referring especially to Iraq, which accounted for 25 percent of Turkish trade before the Persian Gulf war. If there is another war, and if Iraq is defeated quickly, companies like Akcansa and Trakya would have a great deal to gain, he said. Iraq will have to be rebuilt, Mr. Zuaiter said, and he figures they will be among the Turkish companies winning work contracts.
As a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that borders Iraq, Turkey appears to have much at stake in a war.
"If it's a short and contained conflict, there is going to be a short-term hit to risk perceptions, and on the fiscal side too because tourism revenues will be down," Mr. Zuaiter said. "Long term, Turkey is well positioned to be a bridge for Western investors who want to get into Iraq."
But he cautioned prospective investors that "in a protracted war, there is a lot to lose."

HEADLINE: The Unclassifier 

BYLINE:  By Max Frankel; Max Frankel, former executive editor of The Times, helped to publish and analyze the Pentagon papers a generation ago.

 BODY:
 SECRETS
A Memoir of Vietnam
and the Pentagon Papers.
By Daniel Ellsberg.
Illustrated. 498 pp. New York:
Viking. $29.95.
 THERE are no new government secrets in Daniel Ellsberg's "Secrets." But you can hardly blame him for finally ruminating after the age of 71 on the familiar yet still startling events 30 years ago when his history and the nation's fatefully collided. 
For a new generation, here is the story of how Ellsberg, a former Pentagon and State Department official and defense consultant at the Rand Corporation, came to appropriate a top-secret 7,000-page government archive on the history of America's catastrophic war in Vietnam and how he gave it to The New York Times in 1971 at considerable personal risk in the hope that proof of presidential deceits would shock the nation into a withdrawal from Southeast Asia. That archive came to be known as the Pentagon papers and prompted a landmark ruling by the Supreme Court against practically every kind of censorship on national security grounds. 
But the war slogged on while the papers provoked an even more dramatic turn. A furious President Richard Nixon, frantic to prevent further leaks, set out not only to prosecute but also to smear Ellsberg personally by creating a hit team of "plumbers" to rifle the files of his former psychoanalyst. That break-in and other governmental misconduct destroyed the legal case against Ellsberg, but the plumbers survived to run other White House errands. And their break-in at the Watergate offices of the Democratic Party in 1972 eventually caused Nixon to commit obstruction of justice, the cover-up of which led in 1974 to the threat of his impeachment, his resignation and -- at long last -- the collapse of America's defense of a non-Communist South Vietnam.
An obviously intelligent, highly emotional and impulsive man, Ellsberg tracks the evolution of his sense of patriotism from bureaucrat to whistleblower. From his first days as a Pentagon aide and analyst in 1964, he saw how the bonds of secrecy and loyalty caused even the highest officials to suppress their doubts about presidential policy and to lie in its defense. On daring ventures into combat to report on conditions in Vietnam, he recognized the futility of the American cause and the fakery of internal reports of progress there. 
Not until he got to work on the history that become known as the Pentagon papers, however, did he decide that the more serious lying ran in the opposition direction -- that every president back to Truman had simultaneously misled the public about our right to interfere in Vietnam and our chances, with every military escalation, for success. America was bleeding for stalemate at best, to avoid losing terrain to the Communists and votes at home. "For Kennedy, as for Johnson, in fact, it was the president who was deceiving the public, not his subordinates who were deceiving him," Ellsberg writes.
There are, of course, more generous interpretations of presidential action, but Ellsberg no longer credits them. As he himself once believed, American leaders thought that Communist advances in nations left divided after World War II -- Germany and Korea as well as Vietnam -- had to be resisted to avoid a wider war. Their further belief that North Vietnam's attacks on the South were part of a global Chinese-Soviet aggression was surely a terrible mistake, as was the hope that a military stalemate would eventually produce a negotiated compromise that would preserve the credibility of other American commitments. Not all misjudgments, however, are crimes. 
But Ellsberg concluded in 1969, when yet another president was hanging tough in Vietnam, that he no longer considered the war "a case of good intentions that failed of their legitimate, though perhaps infeasible, aims." The Pentagon papers persuaded him that the war was unjust from the start and that unjustified killing amounted to "mass murder": "Could it ever be precipitate to end a policy of murder?" 
So he saw it as his duty to destroy a system of deceit and secrecy, a system in which Nixon and his aides believed that a president was free to leak secrets and commit burglaries and cover-ups that for all others were crimes. "In other words, they assumed that the president, and they in working for him, were above any domestic law. Along with my colleagues working on foreign policy and military matters, I certainly believed that to be true in the area of national security. . . . Along with that belief in exclusive, untrammeled presidential jurisdiction and freedom in these fields goes the assumption of unlimited right to control what the public will know about executive decision making in these matters. As I had belatedly come to see it, that way lay monarchy and more Vietnams, or worse."
And so Ellsberg removed the stamps of "Top Secret" on every page and furtively photocopied the documents that he thought proved his case. He hoped in vain that critics of the war in Congress would publish them (at less risk to himself). That failing, and believing that Nixon would keep on fighting and bombing even as he slowly withdrew American ground troops, Ellsberg finally released the papers in a conspiratorial dance with the Times correspondent Neil Sheehan. When the courts temporarily stopped The Times from publication, he gave the papers to The Washington Post, and parts of them to a dozen other publications. The Pentagon history stopped in 1968, but Nixon feared that other disclosures would reflect on him as well as on the Democrats. So he called for his plumbers, and drowned in their criminal flood. 
There remains, however, a vexing personal secret at the heart of the Ellsberg morality tale: what peculiar combination of genes, brains and circumstance produced such an adventurer? Ellsberg repeatedly risked life and limb in Vietnam for a few morsels of information and takes obvious pleasure now in reproducing long, indeed tedious accounts of his derring-do. As a Marine officer and civilian cold warrior, he was drawn to the thick of the action and came to feel superior to those who shunned such risk. And so it was when he switched sides, longing for a leading role in the army of war resisters. Neither modesty nor moderation are much in evidence in his life and memoir. 
So why not truly reveal himself? Readers should feel cheated by Ellsberg's reluctance to surrender more of his inner loves and torments. The drama of his life lay in his extreme exchange of idols, as he puts it, from the worship of a gun-toting John Wayne to the veneration of pacifist fighters like Rosa Parks and Martin Luther King Jr. Yet the crucial moments of his transformations are only sparingly examined. 
What is the meaning and relevance of the cryptic fact that Ellsberg was raised as a Christian by Christian Scientist parents, but told by his father that "we were Jews, though 'not in religion' "? What was his upbringing and schooling? Why psychoanalysis? And was it only coincidence that his shifts of public career and conviction ran parallel to his private affections? 
It was when married to the daughter of a Marine colonel that Ellsberg became a Marine officer, "enjoyed" life as a platoon leader in a rifle company and extended his term of service to stay with his unit in a Middle East hot spot. Years later, while he was awaiting divorce, his first date with Patricia Marx took him to a protest rally against the Vietnam war. But when he then misinterpreted her "burst of feeling for a radical German poet," he suddenly fled the safety of the Pentagon and volunteered for high-risk missions in Vietnam.
In time, Marx had to prove that she was "adventurous enough" for him by wading into the holy, ash-laden waters of the Ganges, but their continuing arguments over Vietnam disrupted their engagement for four more years. She finally emerges as "the love of my life" and a collaborator in the Pentagon papers escapade, but only after another woman had infected Ellsberg with the philosophy of Gandhian civil disobedience. She was an Indian whom he overheard saying in early 1968 that she came "from a culture in which there is no concept of enemy." From "someone less striking," he might have let the remark slip, he recalls; but she was "beautiful, and her speech was like singing," and she taught him that wrongdoing was "not merely to be condemned but to be resisted, nonviolently but militantly, at personal cost to oneself."
All these obviously influential female and family spirits make only cameo appearances in Ellsberg's memoir. He has left room for a genuinely revealing sequel.

HEADLINE: Kids in the Balance 

BYLINE:  By Robin Toner; Robin Toner is a senior correspondent in the Washington bureau of The Times.

 BODY:

JOINED AT THE HEART
The Transformation of the American Family.
By Al Gore and Tipper Gore.
Illustrated. 417 pp. New York:
Henry Holt & Company. $26.
 SOMEWHERE, in the bowels of some Republican opposition research operation, "Joined at the Heart" is no doubt getting an exceedingly close reading by eagle-eyed young conservatives in search of ammunition for 2004. After all, the right considered Al Gore's last serious book, "Earth in the Balance," a treasure-trove of wacky liberal thought about the environment, demonstrating Gore's unsuitability for the presidency, or at the very least his unsuitability to receive the votes of autoworkers and coal miners in key states.
It is, in short, very hard to read "Joined at the Heart" outside its political context as a book by a once and perhaps future Democratic contender. Which is probably too bad. At face value, this is an earnest and sympathetic account of the strains on the modern American family, at a time when what passes for a serious debate about families in Washington is how much to cut the estate tax. "Joined at the Heart," written with Tipper Gore, talks about the struggle to balance work and family, to build marriages that last, to blend stepchildren and stepparents into a supportive whole, to deal with disability and illness among children and aged parents when everybody is working outside the home. 
All of this, of course, is vastly more complicated when people have greater expectations of what a marriage should be, and when the demands of work and the tether of technology are steadily eroding what used to be "family time." As the Gores put it, "the ways we work, commute, communicate and learn have all been revolutionized over the past few generations," creating "a new emotional landscape with few of the guideposts and landmarks by which families used to get their bearings."
Consider the sheer amount of work performed by a two-parent family today: citing a study by the Economic Policy Institute, the Gores point out that between 1989 and 1998 alone, the total number of hours worked annually by middle-income mothers and fathers rose by 246 -- an extra six full-time workweeks a year. The Gores note that two-thirds of American families no longer eat dinner together regularly -- and of the third who do, half of them are watching television while they eat. They write that the average child over 8 watches three and a half hours of television a day, in part because weary parents use it as a baby sitter at the end of a long day.
Stressed-out families have little time for other forms of connection: while the World War II generation was "a generation of great joiners, organizers and supporters of clubs and civic organizations," membership has fallen steadily since. The way so many postwar communities were built -- the suburban sprawl that Al Gore tried to make an issue in 2000 -- works against the very idea of community. "A family that lives in a neighborhood with sidewalks, playgrounds and pleasant stores within walking distance has a very different relationship to the community than a family that must drive to purchase even the most basic amenity," the Gores write.
Against these darker trends, the Gores tell little homilies of hope. An Indianapolis man who grew up in a family filled with turmoil finds a way to create a happy family of his own, thanks to a strong male role model and a disciplined wife. A Southeastern couple divorce but stay closely connected through the shared care and custody of their disabled son. A gay couple adopt two children, one of them the son of an addicted, H.I.V.-positive mother, and build a strong two-parent family not unlike the ones they grew up in in Maryland. 
The hunger for family runs deep, the Gores conclude, even if it is redefined, based on bonds of love rather than blood and economic necessity, and tested by the culture as never before. This bracing truth is captured in "The Spirit of Family" (Holt, $35), a companion collection of more than 250 photographs of American families they compiled. 
"Joined at the Heart" has the tone, at times, of one of those dinner party seminars that Al Gore was once famous for, with walk-on parts for leading experts like Robert Putnam (on the decline of civic participation in the modern era) or T. Berry Brazelton (on the emotional development of children). It can be preachy and didactic, and there were times when I could hear Al Gore's voice explaining some social trend veerrry sloooowwwly so I could un-der-staaaaand it.
The Gores' tendency to use examples from their own family life is also, at times, distracting. These are careful little glimpses of the private life of this most public of families -- Tipper's battle with depression after her son is seriously injured, Al's tendency to disappear into work, the complicated emotional legacy from Tipper's mother and the long shadow of Al's father. The cynic in me wondered if these struggles had really ended as neatly as the book suggests, or whether the Gores had tidied them up, consciously or not, for political consumption, to make some uplifting argument and to humanize a candidate widely scorned for not being human enough.
At one point, "Joined at the Heart" describes the elaborate roughhousing games that the Gore children played each day when Al got home, a glimpse of the former vice president in a state of ease that was rarely seen in his public life. But then, very quickly, the old Al-Gore-as-national-teacher returns, making the somewhat obvious observation that "at every stage of our lives, play is essential to who we are as human beings and vital to how we find strength and happiness in our families."
Whatever the reason, psychological or political, the Gores seem to be struggling to break out of their roles in this book, to be something other than the candidate and the candidate's wife. There were times, in fact, when I was hungry for more discussion of actual public policy in "Joined at the Heart," and less therapy-speak about the need for communication in families. Only in the last chapter do the Gores really talk about the public policy implications of the book, like the need for universal preschool and more assistance for long-term care.
But the Gores deserve credit for simply paying attention to what has become the unmentionable elephant in the room of Washington politics: that American families are not what they were. It is an easy subject to dismiss, as something on the feminized margins, at a time of war. But as "Joined at the Heart" suggests, the threat of war is not the only anxiety among families these days -- and maybe not even the greatest.
