HEADLINE: CELLPHONE SERVICE HURT BY SUCCESS 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Americans' use of cellphones has increased so quickly that wireless networks are becoming overloaded, causing a growing number of customers to complain about calls that are inaudible or are cut off or are never connected in the first place.
 And things could get worse before they get better, industry experts say, because even as cellphone companies are rolling out fancy features like digital photography and Internet-based games, they are hard-pressed to spend the money needed to improve basic service. 
 "This is a situation in which the wireless industry is a victim of its own success," said James D. Schlichting, a deputy chief of the wireless communications bureau at the Federal Communications Commission.
Many of the industry's service problems are a result of a huge growth of new customers. In 56 percent of the nation's households, someone now subscribes to wireless phone service, more than double the percentage in 1995. 
The surge in users is overwhelming the capacity to handle calls on wireless systems -- whether because local transmitters are too few or too small, or because the local airwaves have become too crowded and carriers are unable to obtain larger swaths of radio frequencies. 
The problems are compounded by basic economics. Customers have been attracted by the plunge in prices for wireless service. The average per-minute cost has dropped to 11 cents this year from 56 cents in 1995. For the phone companies that has meant a decline in average revenue per customer to $61 a month, from $74 in 1995.
And so, just when the wireless companies need to invest more money to accommodate all those new users, the companies are under increased financial strain.
As a result, the complaints are piling up.
The F.C.C. tracks only the few hundred complaints it receives each quarter -- it recently reported fewer than in past years -- but acknowledges that an increase in subscribers had worsened service problems. And surveys conducted for the industry itself show that complaints are rising.
"If I make 10 calls, at least three have to be redialed because they don't go through," said Orville Mills, who lives near Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx and recently switched carriers to Sprint from T-Mobile. "The new services are just a distraction from not having the basics down."
The percentage of all wireless subscribers who have called customer-service centers at least once in the last year to complain about service or because they had other problems has climbed to 61 percent, from 53 percent in 2000, according to J. D. Power & Associates, a company that measures customer satisfaction in many industries and sells it to the companies being scrutinized.
The level of such calls is higher than for many other consumer-service providers, including land-line telephone companies, cable-television operators and stockbrokers, according to Power. About 30 percent of the calls to customer-service centers were complaints related to dropped calls, bad reception or calls not going through, up from 19 percent in 2000. Other reasons included complaints and questions about billing, equipment and services.
The author of the study, Kirk Parsons, said the wireless companies are aware of the problem. He said he expected complaints to grow as the companies add new services, contributing to stress on the networks and subscribers' confusion.
"It's important to remember that cellphones are glorified radios," said Travis Larson, a spokesman for the Cellular Telecommunications and Internet Association, the wireless industry's main trade group. "They're subject to interference from a lot of things, from building walls to sunspots to the weather. There will always be a trade-off between mobility and call quality."
Meanwhile, the stock prices of AT&T Wireless Services and Sprint PCS, the two largest stand-alone publicly traded carriers, are down more than 45 percent this year on investor concern about revenues. And the two largest carriers, Verizon Wireless and Cingular Wireless, which are controlled by regional Bell companies, are struggling to find and pay for additional swaths of airwaves to carry calls.
The industry received something of a financial reprieve last Thursday from the Federal Communications Commission, which ruled that wireless companies would not have to pay the $16 billion they had offered for additional airwave licenses during a bidding process that is now being contested. The licenses had been seized by the F.C.C. from NextWave Communications and auctioned after NextWave filed for bankruptcy protection. But the licenses, and the airwave capacity they represent, are tied up by NextWave's appeal of that seizure, which is now pending before the Supreme Court.
Another industry problem is the sheer technical complexity of sending and receiving wireless calls. Unlike conventional telephone systems, in which every customer is hardwired to the network, wireless systems rely on a delicate mesh of thousands of antenna towers -- which often face resistance from local governments -- and cellular relay stations.
The stations can easily be flooded by an increase in calling volumes. That vulnerability became clear in the hours after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, when the local wireless networks were effectively shut down by the surge of attempted calls.
Various new companies are trying to develop towers and other forms of transmission technologies that could handle such surges. But so far carriers remain reliant on systems that, in some ways, still resemble radio communications networks that were first developed in World War II.
Because of brisk demand, financial problems at wireless carriers are not as severe as those in other areas of telecommunications, where large companies like WorldCom and Global Crossing have sought bankruptcy protection. Even so, some investors think the only way to ensure industry stability will be to winnow the competing wireless players. Instead of six nationwide carriers, they say, a more economically feasible number might be three or four.
"Consolidation among wireless companies can't fix these problems, but it can make them less severe," said Frank J. Governali, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs.
For months, investors have been waiting for mergers that would shrink the number of large competitors. No deals have yet materialized, though, partly because of technical obstacles. Unlike nations in Europe and Asia with higher wireless usage rates, the United States does not have a single wireless technical standard that would make it easy for carriers with different systems to combine operations.
Verizon and Sprint, for instance, employ an American-designed standard called code division multiple access, or C.D.M.A. Meanwhile, AT&T Wireless, Cingular Wireless and T-Mobile, formerly known as VoiceStream, use the global system for mobile communications, or G.S.M. format, common in Europe and Asia. Another large American carrier, Nextel, uses its own technology, called Iden.
Carriers have also resisted measures that would make the industry more consumer-friendly. In response to industry lobbying, for example, the F.C.C. has postponed until next fall a deadline for companies to start allowing "number portability" -- letting customers keep their cellphone numbers even when they switch providers. The companies are reluctant to implement the measure, fearing it will create new costs while also encouraging customer defections.
"I've had the same number for three years," said Sarah Vanderslice, a student at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law in New York who subscribes to Sprint's service. "The fear of losing it is the only thing that keeps me from dropping my cellular company."
The F.C.C. has also repeatedly extended the industry's deadlines for improving emergency-call abilities for wireless phones. Calls from cellphones are still much more difficult for emergency officials to pinpoint than calls from land-line phones. And the issue has become more pressing as the number of emergency calls from cellphones has grown to the current rate of more than 30 percent of 911 calls.
"The wireless industry is in need of a stricter taskmaster," said David Heim, the managing editor of Consumer Reports magazine, which publishes an annual feature each year on cellular service problems. Although the F.C.C. has jurisdiction on certain operational matters, the wireless industry remains largely unregulated.
But few people expect the Bush administration's F.C.C. to try to exert significant new authority. And even a former F.C.C. chairman from the Clinton years says that, in the main, it would be prudent to avoid more regulation.
"We have a robustly competitive wireless industry," said Reed E. Hundt, the former F.C.C. chairman, who is now a senior adviser on information technologies for the management consultant firm McKinsey & Company. "Younger people recognize this in opting for wireless over wire line and putting up with some flaws in exchange for freedom of movement."
Like their counterparts in Europe, carriers in the United States are hoping new services like text messaging and transmission of digital photos will eventually generate the additional revenue they need to put their finances on stronger footing. But aside from a small but loyal following of mainly younger subscribers that exchange text messages, none of the new services have attracted a large number of users.
And anyone who expects competitive market forces to quickly improve cellphones may be overly optimistic, some experts say. They note that the conventional wired telephone system has been evolving for more than a century and became widely dependable only in recent decades.
"Don't hold your breath," said Jeffrey Kagan, an independent telecommunications analyst in Atlanta. "Service and the economic evolution of wireless are works in progress -- it might be years before customers are truly satisfied."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL; 
Knicks Are Off Their Game, and the A-List

BYLINE:  This article was reported by Alan Feuer, Seth Schiesel and Mike Wise and was written by Mr. Feuer. 

 BODY:
The court was crowded with second-stringers. So was celebrity row.
 Missing from the Knicks' starting lineup were Latrell Sprewell, Charlie Ward and Antonio McDyess. The faithful had to root for Howard Eisley, Frank Williams and Michael Doleac -- a scrub, a rookie and a man nobody knows. 
 Missing from the stands were Spike Lee, Sean Combs, Tom Brokaw and the Baldwin brothers. The stargazers had to settle for lesser lights: Lou Gossett Jr., Matthew Modine and Tom Cavanagh, from the TV series "Ed." 
It seemed a far cry from the jump-shot-and-martini days of the 1990's, when a Knicks ticket was the hottest thing in town and the Lincoln Continentals were parked three-deep on Seventh Avenue an hour before the game. When the Chicago Bulls came around back then, the titans clashed: Jordan versus Ewing, Jackson versus Riley. There was a purr of money, a glamorous hum. Madison Square Garden buzzed with an ionic charge.
These days, after 433 consecutive sellouts, the Garden is no longer packed to the rafters every night. Woody Allen still shows up, but he sits yawning and crossing his arms. The dancing girls get more applause than the players. People leave at halftime. People boo.
"There's no joy in Mudville," sighed Spike Lee, a rabid fan, who missed the game on Tuesday night with the Utah Jazz. He was working and was glad to have been working. The Knicks were crushed by more than 20 points.
"Back in the day," Lee recalled, "I was so hyped about the games I'd get to the Garden even before the players showed up. Now, we're the laughingstock of the league."
With a budget crisis looming and a gaping hole in the ground downtown, New York would seem to have more pressing problems than the Knickerbockers and their sorry 1-8 start. Do not, however, dismiss the power of basketball.
"It's on a lot of people's minds," Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said. He told this story: Someone saw him on the No. 6 train last week and shouted, of all things, "Fix the Knicks!" as the doors began to close.
There are, of course, fallow and fertile periods in basketball and all professional sports, but fixing today's Knicks will not be easy, given the management's string of questionable decisions and the team's remarkable bad luck. The Knicks failed to make the playoffs last season for the first time in 15 years and now dwell in the basement of the Eastern Conference.
Instead of patiently rebuilding with draft picks, for years the Knicks have chosen a Band-Aid strategy, plastering their wounds with overpaid, over-age and often injury-plagued players. They have tried hard to spend themselves out of their problems, amassing one of the largest payrolls in the National Basketball Association at $93 million.
The result is that under the league's salary cap, they are virtually unable to add any more top-flight veterans.
The Knicks are not the worst team in the N.B.A. -- the Memphis Grizzlies are 0-10 -- but they could be in the worst predicament.
"A team can sell one of two things: wins or hope," said a Western Conference general manager, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "If you have a veteran team with a high payroll, you're selling wins. And if you're playing young guys, you're selling hope."
The Knicks, however, are aged and losing, and their selections of young players in the annual draft have almost universally been poor. They sell neither victory nor hope.
James L. Dolan, the Garden's chairman, contended in an interview on Friday that the Knicks still had an innate attraction and were building a promising future.
"If you love basketball, we're still going to be a fun team to watch," he said. "For those people who only come to games because they believe the team is going to win the championship that year, they probably had best get a ticket to Los Angeles. But for those who are loyal Knick fans and who love New York, this is still the New York Knicks. And it's still going to be a great way to spend an evening."
If the Knicks' free fall is nothing new in the N.B.A., there is still a sense that fans in other cities with losing squads can take it better than New Yorkers. After all, basketball is part of the city's swagger.
"This is where the mystery of basketball comes from," said John Bykowsky, director of the New York Urban Professionals Athletic League. "Where have all the great players come from? The ones with all the moves that everyone's talking about? The streets of New York City. That's why it's so unbearable to see the Knicks playing like this."

The Decline
A Table at Elaine's, Then a Fateful Trade
A decade ago, the Knicks were perennial underdogs, and the city loved them. They were scrappy, muscular, resolute. They were New Yorkers.
Although they never won a title in the 1990's, they were often in the running, playing twice for the championship, and their flair for gritty games thrilled the hometown crowd even if they lost.
Moored by Patrick Ewing at center, the Knicks had a bruising forward in Charles Oakley and a hair-trigger shooting guard in John Starks. When the lights dimmed at the Garden and the home-team players were announced, the place erupted with a booming, chesty roar.
"What an exhilarating moment, walking out onto that floor with the city behind you," Pat Riley, the Knicks' coach from 1991 to 1995, recalled last week. "It was the time and the place."
The party often went on well past the game. Slicked-back and stylish, Riley turned up after games at Elaine's on the Upper East Side with his wife. A spot was reserved for them in back. The penne was always al dente, the sauce tomato cream.
On some nights, the coach was joined by Kim Basinger and Alec Baldwin, along with any number of other famous faces. "Name after name would show up," Riley said. "Mira Sorvino. Ashley Judd. Winona Ryder. You would go in, sprinkle your stardust around and go home. That's what it was like."
When Riley left for Miami, he took the stardust with him. His assistant Jeff Van Gundy, who eventually became the Knicks' coach, was a different sort of man, a sleep-deprived workaholic and one of the most pessimistic people in sports. A framed quote in his office read: "If you think they are all out to get you, you're not paranoid -- you're perceptive."
Although Van Gundy went on to preside over more victories with the Knicks than Riley did, he was there when the team began its slide. It started in September 2000, essentially with a single move: Ewing, unhappy and in the last year of his contract, was sent to Seattle in a three-way trade for Glen Rice, Luc Longley and Travis Knight.
"It all started when they traded Patrick," Lee said with a catch in his voice. "That's when the curse began."
Had the Knicks kept Ewing another season and let him go as a free agent, they would have lopped his $16 million salary from their payroll. Instead, they were saddled with his replacements' expensive long-term contracts, worth a total of $90.4 million, leaving them with almost no flexibility under the salary cap. Knicks officials note, however, that even if Ewing had played out his contract and left the following season, the team would still have been over the salary cap.
A few additional moves sent the Knicks' payroll through the ceiling and their fortunes through the floor. In July 2001, they signed Allan Houston to a six-year, $100.4 million contract when the most he could have received on the free-agent market was $72 million. The following month, they traded Rice in a three-team deal for two high-priced reserves: Eisley and Shandon Anderson, whose long-term contracts totaled $83 million. 
The knockout punch, however, was Van Gundy's startling resignation last December. Citing personal reasons, he left the team with a 10-9 record. Under Don Chaney, the assistant coach who replaced him, the Knicks finished 30-52.
Nevertheless, there was a glimmer of hope in June when the team traded Marcus Camby, Mark Jackson and a No. 7 draft pick, Maybyner Hilario, to Denver for McDyess, the All-Star power forward.
During a preseason game last month, McDyess rose to slam in a missed shot and landed awkwardly, falling on his surgically repaired left knee. His kneecap was fractured, and he is not expected to play this season.
A few weeks earlier, Sprewell shocked his teammates by showing up at training camp with a broken finger -- injured, he said, in a fall on his boat. He was fined $250,000 for failing to notify the club promptly, and he underwent surgery, followed by weeks of rehabilitation.
Although Sprewell played for the first time this season Saturday in a game against the Philadelphia 76ers, scoring 16 points, it was not enough to gain the Knicks a victory, or to draw A-list celebrities. Pearl Jam was the boldest name in the crowd.
Sprewell's troubles, McDyess's absence and minor injuries to Houston, Charlie Ward and Kurt Thomas have left the Knicks looking like a pickup team in the early weeks of the season. Their current hope for the future, many have said, may lie with landing the first pick in the draft next spring and choosing LeBron James, a high-school phenomenon from Akron, Ohio.
A similar circumstance brought Ewing to the team in 1985, when the Knicks were one of the league's worst teams. While a repeat of that scenario seems a bit far-fetched, at least a far-fetched fantasy provides a whiff of hope.

Management
An Enthusiastic Fan Takes the Reins
Dolan, chairman of the Garden and president of Cablevision, which owns the arena and its teams, has always fashioned himself as a fan of New York sports. He once spoke of the grandeur of the Garden. Last year, he rented out a hotel ballroom during a trip to Cleveland, racing miniature cars with his players to break the tension of a long season.
At the same time, Dolan has been criticized for the way he handled a variety of incidents with Sprewell. Many fans have questioned whether Dolan has the expertise to run the team and have criticized him for supporting the team's president and general manager, Scott Layden, who has been skewered almost daily in the news media for his personnel decisions.
Last season, Sprewell skipped a pregame shoot-around in Miami. The Knicks fined him $125,000, but Dolan reduced it to $2,500.
In rescinding the fine, Dolan asked for only one thing in return: that Sprewell stay in touch with the team during the off-season, as other players do. Sprewell is notoriously impossible to track down.
Sprewell's contact, however, was minimal. The first time he appeared, in fact, was on media day, Sept. 30, when he showed up with a broken finger. Officials familiar with the situation said Dolan was irate. That was the major reason Sprewell was fined $250,000 and banished from practicing with the team.
Dolan's unwavering support for Layden and Chaney has puzzled many Knicks fans. What remains unclear is whether Dolan believes they are the right men to see the Knicks through a trying time, whether he thinks he must support his management team in public or whether he is trying to avoid firing Layden and absorbing the remainder of his contract while paying Chaney a fraction of what some of his predecessors made.
For all his enthusiasm as a fan, Dolan has occasionally failed to grasp the fundamentals of Knicks history. He once referred to Red Holzman, the legendary Knicks coach, as Red Auerbach, who coached the Boston Celtics. Not only did he confuse his Reds, he confused them in front of Holzman's daughter, Gail, unaware that Holzman and Auerbach were mortal rivals.
In the interview Friday, Dolan described himself as a lifelong Knicks fan who would take the D train to the old Garden for games. As chairman of the Garden now, he said he took a hands-on approach to running the team, but deferred on personnel and other basketball matters to his coach and general manager.
He admitted that the Knicks did not look good, although he contended that injuries, not poor decisions, were to blame. And he argued that, over all, the team was moving in a positive direction.
"I think we're getting younger and I think we're progressing," Dolan said. "We obviously have suffered setbacks, and a start that is one I don't think anybody in the league would envy. And you know, there are reasons for it. We've been riddled with injuries."

Finances
Lavish Spending Has Its Consequences
Cablevision, which Dolan controls, has spent much of the last few months cutting costs. It closed 26 of its 43 Wiz electronics stores. It put its chain of movie theaters up for sale. It cut more than 2,000 jobs.
The company's shares have soared with the news, more than tripling to close at $16.26 Friday, up from $4.67 in mid-August.
The Knicks' collapse does not appear to be related to the cost-cutting. Paradoxically, it seems the team's decline has stemmed from Cablevision's financial interest in keeping it competitive.
It is not unusual for a sports team to go through periods of rebuilding, sacrificing victories to finish low in the standings, all to gain a high draft pick around which to build for the future. Rebuilding is especially important in leagues with salary caps like the N.B.A. The idea is simple: suffer losses, save money and maneuver for one or two top draft picks.
The Knicks, however, have refused to rebuild. They have consistently acquired expensive veteran players meant to help the team win immediately.
Dave Checketts, who once ran the Garden, used to say openly that he did not think New Yorkers had the patience to endure a rebuilding period. A person close to Cablevision said team officials continued to pursue that strategy because "they thought that New York would not tolerate a rebuilding team." From a financial standpoint, however, it seems that Cablevision, too, would find it hard to tolerate rebuilding.
In addition to controlling the Knicks, Cablevision also controls the MSG cable television network, which telecasts most of the Knicks' games to about eight million homes. Financial analysts say that the Knicks may only break even, and that the team makes its real money on the MSG network. Dolan confirmed that analysis.
"There is more of a premium on success because if the Knicks are successful, they get a double hit," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College. "They get a hit through Knicks revenue, and they also get a hit through Cablevision revenue."
The general belief among analysts of the media industry is that Cablevision has chosen the quick fix to justify increasing MSG's subscriber fees, or at least stabilizing them. This season, MSG lost the Yankees to the YES network, making it even more important to create a competitive Knicks team.
"Cablevision only cares about having a product good enough to justify the subscriber rates it was charging," said Richard A. Bilotti, the head media stock analyst at Morgan Stanley. "The fan would have wanted them to restructure the team two years ago and rebuild like the Celtics. For years, Cablevision propped up the channel with expensive free-agent additions to keep the team just good enough so it would go to the playoffs."
The upshot of the quick-fix strategy is that the Knicks now appear to have nowhere to turn. The team committed so much money to so many second-tier players with long-term contracts that it is finding it difficult to trade those players to other teams.
"Because they never rebuilt the team," Bilotti said, "they kept putting off the inevitable. And now the inevitable is happening anyway, which is that the team is really horrible."
The horror was evident at Tuesday night's game. The first boo came with 24 seconds left in the first quarter. The first profound boo came with 1 minute 19 seconds left in the second quarter. The first flagrantly obnoxious boo came 15 minutes later.
Wearily, Lee recalled a remark uttered by Micheal Ray Richardson, a guard for the flaccid Knicks teams of the 1980's: "The ship be sinking."
"Well, I'm going to update that," Lee said. "I'm going to say, 'The ship be sunk.' "

HEADLINE: The Angels Have Sung So 'Harlem Song' Lives 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN

 BODY:
The producers of "Harlem Song" at the Apollo Theater, who two weeks ago said the show would have to close before the end of its scheduled run unless they could raise $300,000, said yesterday that they had raised that much and a little more, adding that the show would run through December as planned.
 "Harlem Song," created by George C. Wolfe, chronicles the history of Harlem through music, dance, filmed interviews and historic photographs. It posted a closing notice last month because it was running at a loss, and the producers said they felt they could not afford to keep it open. 
 Among the groups that stepped up to sustain the show is the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, which had previously denied the "Harlem Song" application for $1.2 million in financing that its producers had requested. 
John Schreiber, the lead producer, said the additional funds would allow him and his partners to cover running costs of $200,000, to market the show more extensively and to bring it back next year. 
The producers created "Harlem Song" in the hope that it would become an annual event at the Apollo Theater, like the Radio City Christmas Spectacular. 
The $4 million show, performed Saturdays through Mondays, had been running at a loss since it opened in August, most recently about $30,000 a week. "Harlem Song" used up its $500,000 reserve as well as $750,000 from the Time Warner Foundation and the New York City Investment Fund, a private fund started by Henry R. Kravis. 
Although the show had generated more than $2 million in ticket revenue and an estimated $4 million in ancillary retail and restaurant income in the area, it still had difficulty drawing theatergoers uptown in sufficient numbers to break even.
"Organizations came together in a terrific and public-spirited way to help fulfill the promise of the show's first year and help ensure its future," Mr. Schreiber said.
The show had also been considered an important addition to Harlem's revitalization and to the Apollo's current $53 million restoration. 
Mr. Schreiber said Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem was among those who had been helpful. "All these different people -- members of the board -- came together in a unanimous and bipartisan way and said this show is important to the community," Mr. Schreiber said. "It was a great vote of confidence for us."
Kathryn Wilde, the president and chief executive of the New York City Investment Fund and its parent, the New York City Partnership, said: "We felt both symbolically and in terms of the benefits to the local economy that an original production showcased at the Apollo really makes a difference. Having this particular show playing there really sent the message loud and strong to the community that the renaissance of Harlem was based on the continued contribution from black culture."
The other donors, some of which Ms. Wilde's organization helped to secure, include the Rockefeller Foundation; the Citigroup Foundation; Goldman, Sachs & Company; Merrill Lynch & Company; and the Wolfensohn Family Foundation. Additional financing is being provided by the Sony Foundation, H.I.P. of New York and the Vornado Realty Foundation. 
"The investment is intended to establish this as a successful and hopefully annual production," Ms. Wilde said, "to give them the chance to show they can fill the theater and establish a track record so they can attract support in the future."

HEADLINE: OVERSEAS; 
Flash Points Loom In War on Hunger

BYLINE:  By DANIEL B. SCHNEIDER 

 BODY:
OVER the last decade, the news about world hunger has not been all bad.
 On the plus side, the number of people who are chronically undernourished or starving dropped by 20 million during the 1990's, according to a recent report from the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. 
 On the minus side are two grim facts: the overall number is still huge -- 840 million -- and the strong gains in a relatively small number of countries, notably China, must be measured against a steady slide in the 47 worst-off countries. These are mostly in Africa, where the ranks of the hungry grew by 96 million.
At the moment, the news is particularly disheartening. The World Food Program, a United Nations agency and the world's largest food distribution organization, "has probably never had as many serious challenges as we have today," said James T. Morris, the executive director of the agency. 
As a matter of perspective, it should be noted that the percentage of undernourished people in most developing countries has actually decreased, while the absolute number has risen largely as a result of population growth. And while prospects are bleak in sub-Saharan Africa, Central America and the Middle East, both the prevalence and the amount of undernourished people have been reduced, in some cases drastically, in West Africa, Southeast Asia and South America since the 1990's. 
But droughts and famines unfold almost in slow motion, and emergency relief must often wait until after the effects of a food shortage become evident and intrusive. In the interim, the suffering worsens. "Those disasters that receive the highest profile, the most attention in the media, receive the most support," Mr. Morris said. "It's not surprising. The more the world knows about what's going on, the more the world responds." 
Donors in the United States have responded to crises in Africa for years, but there are indications that fatigue is setting in. It is the wrong moment. An extraordinary famine is threatening six nations in southern Africa, where more than 14 million people could face starvation in the next year. 
Though primarily a result of years of drought alternating with devastating floods, this current drought, the worst in a decade, hits a rural population already decimated by the H.I.V.-AIDS epidemic. In the countries facing mass starvation -- Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe -- an infection rate of one in five people is typical, and half of those infected are employed in farming. Many households are without one or both parents.
"It's devastating," Mr. Woods said. "You put serious weather problems in a place with four and a half million orphans, and those people have just lost their coping mechanisms." 
THE catastrophe has been compounded by government mismanagement and political turmoil in several of the afflicted countries. The government of Malawi sold its grain reserves last year. The new government in Zambia alleges that the previous administration misappropriated state food supplies. 
In Zimbabwe, once a model of self-sufficiency, President Robert Mugabe's politically charged efforts to seize land from white farmers have resulted in a huge drop in crop production, leaving almost half the population needing emergency aid. 
Poor rainfall over the last year has also decimated cereal crops in the Horn of Africa. As many as 12 million people are threatened with starvation in Ethiopia and Eritrea in the coming months, only two years after widespread famine was last averted by an infusion of international food assistance. Aid workers have already compared the current crisis to the Ethiopian famine of 1984, when almost a million people died.
With much of the developing world, the effects of armed conflict have intensified the effects of a natural calamity. Because of the recent border war between Eritrea and Ethiopia, which simmered from 1998 to 2000, vast swaths of land cannot be farmed for fear of land mines, and conscription to military service has depleted the agricultural work force in many areas, adding to food insecurity at the household level. 
In Ethiopia, the number of people who need food aid is expected to rise to 10 million to 14 million next year from the current 6 million. Recent assessment missions reveal widespread losses of maize and sorghum, staples in rural areas, which are harvested green and eaten during lean seasons, in addition to reduced sources of pasture and water for livestock. 
"We have started distributing food in affected areas early enough to contain the crisis, but if we don't get more pledges quickly, aid agencies' relief stocks will run out before December and the situation will deteriorate rapidly," said Georgia Shaver, a representative of the World Food Program, in a recent report.
Poverty in Eritrea is so pervasive that virtually the entire country is susceptible to food shortages. More than a million people -- about a third of Eritrea's population -- are said to be threatened by the current crisis. 
North Korea's long slide into widespread malnutrition began in 1991, when the Soviet Union collapsed and its satellite states stopped providing food and economic aid. Since 1995, floods, droughts and tropical storms have multiplied the country's misery, and it is widely thought that barring political, economic and agricultural reforms, it will be years before North Korea will be able to feed its citizens.
Between 1994 and 1998 at least two million North Koreans were reported to have died from starvation and related diseases. According to the most recent World Food Program studies, at least 45 percent of children under 5 are malnourished, while four million school-age children are also severely underfed, impairing their capacity to grow physically and mentally. 
THE United States, a longtime principal donor, has diverted substantial food aid from North Korea to meet demands in Afghanistan, and other countries are also scaling back donations. Neither the recently exposed attempts of North Korea to develop a nuclear weapons program, nor the longstanding suspicions that food aid is hoarded by the government, are likely to improve the situation. 
Though agricultural production is up for the second straight year, North Korea is more than a million tons short of its minimum food needs. The slump in grain donations forced the World Food Program, which has been feeding about a third of the country's 23 million people, to begin halting food aid in September to millions of malnourished women, children and older people. By the end of the year, about three million people will be cut off from aid, and another 1.5 million are expected to follow early next year. 
"We simply no longer have the resources to do the things we need to do," Mr. Morris said. 
The problems in Afghanistan are also manifold, despite the surprising success of aid efforts over the last year and a pronounced recovery in agricultural production in some areas. Roiled by two decades of war and scorched by a four-year drought, the country is mired in an extended crisis, its rural economy in a shambles and its essential services all but nonexistent. 
The years of drought have had a damaging effect on range vegetation, thinning critical livestock herds as much as 60 percent since 1998. The unanticipated return of almost two million refugees since last year has outstripped both the capacities and the financing of the relief agencies, and the situation may worsen over the winter, when approximately two million people living in areas that will be rendered inaccessible by heavy snows or cold will be particularly vulnerable. 
Severe undernourishment has not spared the Americas. Malnutrition is spreading through rural areas of the Central American "drought corridor," where rains faltered during the May to August planting and harvesting seasons. The region is also recovering from recent natural disasters, like the mudslides in Guatemala last August. 
Residents are extremely poor, living on infertile land, and the recent glut of coffee in world markets has removed a steady source of additional household income. The World Food Program estimates that about 1.5 million people are threatened with malnutrition in Honduras, Nicaragua, Guatemala and El Salvador.
Earlier this year, with little fanfare, the World Food Program delivered emergency food aid to 6,000 children in Guatemala who were acutely malnourished and near death, the accumulative effect of two years of drought and rural unemployment. "We have to work very hard at telling the story," Mr. Morris said. "The world can't respond if they don't know about it."

HEADLINE: THE ARTS; 
New Jersey's Arts Center: 5 Years of Hybrid Success

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

 BODY:
LAWRENCE P. GOLDMAN, the president and chief executive of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, which just celebrated its fifth birthday, says that he has always felt the need to be upfront with potential donors about what the center is, and what it isn't. 
 The center, known as NJPAC, is not Lincoln Center. It draws big names but does not automatically attract the biggest. It is not an automatic moneymaker, nor are there millionaires fighting for a spot on its board. But the center is a success in terms of the goals it set at inception, ones that illustrate the many purposes a nonprofit arts center can serve. 
 Early on, NJPAC decided it was to be something of a hybrid. "They did not dub themselves a cultural institution alone," but as an investment in Newark as well, said Elizabeth Strom, an assistant professor of political science at Rutgers University in Newark who studies cultural financing. 
Ray Chambers, a co-owner of the New York Yankees and the New Jersey Nets, who is an active philanthropist for urban causes "gave several million dollars, and I don't think he gave to cultural institutions like that before," Professor Strom said. "The Prudential Foundation doesn't have a large cultural donation in its portfolio. They certainly went for cultural donors, but then they also went out and found people to invest in Newark, too."
Prudential Financial has its name on the main concert hall; Prudential's president and chief executive, Arthur F. Ryan, is a co-chairman of the board of trustees. His company, he said, became a big donor for somewhat selfish reasons. "I love our hall," he said. "It is a beautiful space. But Prudential has been in Newark for nearly 130 years and that was the compelling reason for us to be a part of this. 
"What you need is to have people come to the city to live and to work," Mr. Ryan said. "And to do that, you have to have a great sense of pride. We have world-class arts here now, but the facility has also created an uptick in Class A office space and more commercial development. That is what we were hoping for."
The bulk of the original money for the building, more than 60 percent of the $187 million, came from federal and state economic development funds. Ms. Strom compared the use of such money to the approach that was taken by Ed Rendell, a former mayor of Philadelphia (and the newly elected governor of Pennsylvania), which led to the building of the Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts there.
"Until Ed Rendell called it an urban development project, it was on the drawing board for 20 years," Ms. Strom said. 
If busy evenings are a sign of success, NJPAC is rolling along. The 135 scheduled performances this year range from the New Jersey Symphony to the pop-diva Lauryn Hill. The center has the sixth-largest budget of all arts centers in the United States. To make that budget, which is $23 million this year, about $11 million in grants, subscriptions and donations must be raised. Tickets, T-shirts, food concessions and educational fees make up slightly more than half the money that is needed to stage those shows and hold workshops. 
Even the successful concerts are not necessarily a lot of money in the bank. "We had Lauryn Hill here," said Jeffrey Norman, the center's vice president of public affairs. "New Jersey artist. Sold out 2,750 seats in 41 minutes. We made all of $2,000 on that show. Symphony concerts can lose money. The economics of the arts can be difficult to understand."
Ms. Strom said that Ms. Hill's concert may have been, in some ways, a loss leader. "Did they sell more NJPAC mugs or T-shirts?" she asked. "I don't know. But they certainly got an audience that normally wouldn't be at a symphony hall. So, maybe they will come back."
While the audience that came to Ms. Hill's concert may not contain future big donors, the concert and the other educational projects and events like Planet Hip-Hop, a festival that took place earlier this month, can translate into big money. The center is two years into a four-year $1.25 million grant from the Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund for young organizations providing diversity in their programming.
"We look for organizations paving new ground in reaching new people and engaging them more deeply, and clearly NJPAC is doing that," said Rory MacPherson, the senior program officer at the Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund. Mr. MacPherson pointed to a program where Reg E. Gaines, the creator of "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk," worked with women in the community, creating a spoken-word work called "Brick City Blues," based on their experiences.
"This kind of thing brings a tremendous impact that other places just don't match," Mr. MacPherson said.
Another reflection of how successful the center's business strategy has been can be found in the growing commitment of a large donor at the other end of the music spectrum. Josh S. Weston, a longtime lover of classical music, said he was upset with his peers in the New Jersey elite. 
"I had seen some list and it showed that New Jersey ranked 48th among the states in the percentage that wealthy people give to charity and cultural institutions," said Mr. Weston, a retired chairman and chief executive of Automated Data Processing, a business services company in Roseland, N.J. "I became determined to find jewels in New Jersey to mine."
Still, Mr. Weston was a bit of a skeptic early on, Mr. Goldman recalled. "It was Newark and we were new. Sometimes, in order to raise money from good people, you have to prove yourself in many ways."
The center has evidently proven itself to Mr. Weston. Last year, he told Mr. Goldman, the NJPAC chief executive, that he and his wife, Judy, would give $5 million if Mr. Goldman could find two matching donors. Because the center needs to cover $11 million of its $23 million annual budget with grants and donations, and keep a capital fund in reserve, Mr. Weston's potential gift was important.
"I could have just written a check, but I wanted to get more mileage," he said. 
Mr. Goldman and his development staff loved the idea of Mr. and Mrs. Weston's challenge and eventually got two New Jersey foundations, the Victoria Foundation and the Jon and Joanne Corzine Foundation, to match his $5 million. But Mr. Weston did not want to stop there. He pushed the State Legislature to create the New Jersey Cultural Trust. Formed last year, the trust matches any donation of $100,000 with a similar state grant to qualified cultural institutions. "The state should do its share, too," Mr. Weston said.
The arts center also goes through some traditional channels to raise money. Despite the hip nature of some of its programs, it has the Women's Board, which holds an annual ball (this year's raised $2.5 million) and asks for donations from women in northern New Jersey. The center estimates that 75 percent of tickets to its events are bought by women.
"We had Lionel Richie at our gala this year and it was wonderful," said Barbara Bell Coleman, who owns a business consulting firm, BBC Associates, and is the current president of the Women's Board. "But the point of it is that we are doing something to uplift the whole community here."
Ms. Coleman grew up in Newark and continues to live there. She thinks the center's relationship with the city has changed. "It was definitely important that NJPAC was in Newark, but I think it doesn't matter any more," Ms. Coleman said. "Now people come here just because it is the event they want to see. That, in turn, gets us more customers and, then, more donations."
"We are an established arts group now," she said. "I think we can count on people willing to give for a long time."

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Your Taxes At Play . . . For the Knicks

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
WHAT we're trying to do is say that everybody that works in the city benefits from all of the services -- the Fire Department, for example," Mayor Bloomberg said. "And it is only equitable that everybody pays some share of that."
 So declared the mayor last week on the subject of his tough budget, and while it does seem that his plan goes easier on the wealthy than on the poor, at least his words embrace the idea of shared sacrifice. And who would argue against that? 
 Therefore, a question or two about the city's well-aged policy of granting tax abatements, subsidies and other incentives to businesses to keep them in town.
No doubt that some of the deals help the city by retaining companies, preserving jobs and generating new business. A range of businesses have gotten incentives, from banks and insurance firms to media companies -- including The New York Times, which is preparing to build a new headquarters on Eighth Avenue.
There is also a counterargument that some companies would have stayed anyway -- especially when the city was booming in the 1990's. Another point: some benefits seem to go on and on -- extended with little debate -- even if that was not the original intent.
Take Madison Square Garden. In 1982, the Koch administration faced a threat that the Knicks would leave for the Nassau Coliseum and the Rangers for the Meadowlands. To a city still recovering from the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, it was unthinkable that the Rangers and Knicks would go the way of the Giants and the Dodgers.
City Hall, with approval from the state, negotiated a tax abatement package for the Garden. Its centerpiece? Forgiving the Garden's property taxes for up to 10 years.
That was 1982, remember. It is now 2002. Even as the mayor proposes a 25 percent increase in the property tax rate, Madison Square Garden continues to get a full real estate tax exemption. The Finance Department's most recent "Annual Report on Tax Expenditures" shows that the value of the Garden's unpaid taxes was $8.8 million in the last fiscal year. 
Would the Garden leave if it had to pay property taxes? If it got a 25 percent increase -- on zero?
"Why should Madison Square Garden continue to get tax breaks forever?" asked Jonathan Bowles, research director of the Center for an Urban Future -- a nonpartisan research organization supported by foundations and trusts. "I think it is definitely time to rethink corporate subsidies and incentives." 
Mr. Bowles said that a city program to encourage smaller companies to expand -- often manufacturing firms -- was effective. But he was less certain about the many discretionary deals granted to larger companies to make sure they stayed in New York City; he estimated that from 1988 to 2000, the city negotiated about $2 billion in incentives to retain 80 companies and financial exchanges. The businesses took advantage of up to $1.4 billion of that.
WHETHER such incentives were necessary in every case or just an accepted way of doing business is a question that has been debated since the first deal was negotiated and probably always will be.
"Most of those companies were not going to go," said James A. Parrott, chief economist for the Fiscal Policy Institute, a labor-backed research group. "Ninety percent of those who asked for it got it. They just knew what buttons to push, what hoops they had to jump through." But what about now? In today's climate, exacerbated by the impact of Sept. 11, the city is vulnerable to losing companies, and the jobs that come with them. Dr. Parrott said that puts an even greater burden on the city to do a better job of defining its terms. "It may," he said, "be appropriate to at least put up a cautionary flag, say this has to be revisited."
The Bloomberg administration has been tightening up on discretionary programs, said Andrew M. Alper, president of the Economic Development Corporation. Because of the sluggish economy, the administration shelved a proposed deal with the New York Stock Exchange for a heavily subsidized new trading complex, for instance.
Mr. Alper said he was unaware of plans for a broad revision of the city's incentive programs. As for Madison Square Garden, he said he was unfamiliar with its deal, so could not comment.
Mr. Bowles, of the Center for an Urban Future, said he was not sure if the city has the legal authority to renegotiate existing agreements, but agreed with Dr. Parrott about the future: "I think we could get a lot smarter about this in years to come."

HEADLINE: Commuter Tax Draws Attention, but Bloomberg's Wish List to Albany Is Much Longer 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's ambitious plan to impose an income tax on people who work in the city but do not live there is hardly his only budget proposal requiring the approval of Gov. George E. Pataki and state lawmakers.
 The budget plan the mayor outlined last week included a wish list of things Albany could do to help the city out of its fiscal mess, ranging from a state absorption of the city's share of Medicaid costs, which would save City Hall $4 billion next year, to permitting OTB parlors to take bets on nighttime thoroughbred races, raising an estimated $15 million. 
 And Mayor Bloomberg -- who took pains to praise Governor Pataki, his fellow Republican, at every opportunity during the governor's successful re-election campaign -- signaled that he might now be willing to flex a bit more muscle to get what he wants from the state. 
While continuing to thank Mr. Pataki and the legislative leaders for their help earlier this year, Mr. Bloomberg also used his budget address on Thursday to highlight the many ways in which the state has hurt the city over the last four years.
The mayor showed reporters a chart of recent state actions that he said had cost the city more than a billion dollars a year: repealing the old commuter tax ($405 million); adding pension benefits ($363 million); eliminating compensation the state used to give the city for the loss of the old stock transfer tax ($114 million); and a number of other changes with effects totaling tens of millions of dollars.
"What these things have done is taken away $1.1, $1.5 billion," Mr. Bloomberg said. "So we're just getting back some of what we've lost."
The mayor's plan, written in hopes of closing a $6.4 billion budget deficit in the fiscal year that begins July 1, relies on more than $1.6 billion in revenue and savings that would require Albany's approval.
Mr. Bloomberg wants the state to give the city $275 million a year to help it pay for its new contract with the United Federation of Teachers, which raised teachers' salaries in exchange for longer work days. Governor Pataki helped pave the way for that agreement by giving the city more than $200 million in a one-time infusion of education aid. He went on to win the endorsement of the teachers' union. Now Mr. Bloomberg wants the state to make it an annual source of aid.
The mayor is also counting on Albany to take a combination of other actions that would either net or save the city $200 million next year, and he outlined a broad menu of things the state could choose from to help reach that target.
Some proposals, Mr. Bloomberg said, would cost the state nothing: reining in Medicaid costs; charging a 2.4 percent levy on hospital care to pay for health care for children who are not eligible for Medicaid; limiting the city's liability for lawsuits; allowing the city to refinance its debt; permitting the city to sell 900 new taxi medallions over the next three years; using money from state environmental bonds to pay for the city's recycling program; letting the city use more cameras to catch drivers going through red lights; and allowing OTB parlors to simulcast thoroughbred races at night.
Other proposals could be quite costly to the state. Unlike most states, New York passes along a quarter of its Medicaid costs to local governments, and New York City's share will reach $4 billion next year. The mayor proposed having the state bear that cost, saying, "We would not be in the situation we are today if we didn't have to pick up that cost."
But with the state facing its own budget deficit, many officials say they are hard pressed to understand how it could assume such costs.
Mr. Bloomberg is also counting on $200 million in transportation initiatives that would require either the state's approval or the approval of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which is controlled by the state. Those include imposing tolls on East River bridges, a move Governor Pataki has opposed, and having the M.T.A. take over city-subsidized private bus routes in Queens.
Finally, there is the income tax proposal, which would be the biggest source of revenue by far that Mayor Bloomberg wants the state to approve. The mayor's plan counts on $1 billion in new revenue from his tax plan, which would reduce the income tax rate on city residents to offset a 25 percent property tax increase, while levying an identical income tax on commuters who work in the city and live elsewhere.
The official line in Albany, where lawmakers in 1999 repealed a commuter tax that was one-sixth the size of what Mr. Bloomberg has put forth, is that the new proposal is being studied. Privately, some Democrats in the Assembly have sounded open to it, while Republicans in the State Senate have vowed to kill it. Governor Pataki, who denounced the old commuter tax during his latest re-election campaign, has been noncommittal.
Mayor Bloomberg continued to press the issue yesterday. "New York City is the economic engine for the entire region and state, so keeping the city strong benefits everyone," he said in his weekly radio address.
Governor Pataki was still weighing his options.
"The governor is reviewing the mayor's proposals," said Lynn Rasic, a spokeswoman.

HEADLINE: White House Letter; 
Cold Shoulder or Warm Handshake?

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
First, President Bush refused to congratulate Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany on his re-election victory, then Mr. Bush ignored a personal letter from the chancellor. When he finally took a phone call from Mr. Schroder on Nov. 8, their conversation was businesslike and brief. 
 Now the question remains: Will Mr. Bush shake Mr. Schroder's hand at a major NATO summit meeting in Prague this week? 
 "I'm sure they will see each other at NATO," Condoleezza Rice, the president's national security adviser, said crisply and vaguely to reporters last week. 
But as of now, there is no scheduled one-on-one meeting between the leaders of the United States and Germany, the most important economic power in continental Europe and the center of gravity of the alliance.
Mr. Bush is still angry that Mr. Schroder campaigned this fall on a platform opposing a war in Iraq, and was further infuriated when a minister in Mr. Schroder's government was reported to have compared the president's tactics to those of Hitler. Administration officials readily acknowledge that the president's sense of betrayal ensures that his relationship with Mr. Schroder, which was not easy in the best of times, will never be the same again. 
"No question," a senior White House official said last week. "It will remain professional, but it's hard to imagine it being personal."
As if to underscore the change, the president's NATO calendar is filled with meetings with other European leaders. 
Mr. Bush has plans to sit down one-on-one at the summit meeting with President Jacques Chirac of France, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic and President Ahmet Necdet Sezer of Turkey. Then in Russia on Friday, he is to meet with President Vladimir V. Putin.
White House officials say that Mr. Bush is a mature leader who understands the importance of the American relationship with Germany, but they acknowledge that the trouble between the president and the chancellor shows how much Mr. Bush values personal loyalty -- and demands allegiance -- in his foreign policy. 
Their falling-out, diplomats say, also reflects the difficulty in establishing a bond between two sharply different men. One is an establishment-bred Republican raised in his famous father's shadow and the other is a Social Democrat who grew up in poverty without ever knowing his father, and who only recently visited his grave.
German diplomats tried last week to put the best possible face on a problem that has embarrassed and irritated them. They pointed out that not only did Mr. Bush take Mr. Schroder's call, but that Bernd Mutzelburg, Mr. Schroder's foreign policy adviser, met at the White House with Ms. Rice on Friday. 
They also emphasized that Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld recently received Peter Struck, the German defense minister, at the Pentagon, and declared the relationship between the two nations "unpoisoned." 
In September, shortly after Germany's election, Mr. Rumsfeld had pointedly ignored Mr. Struck at a meeting of NATO defense ministers in Warsaw, and afterward told colleagues that he did so to be loyal to his angry president.
"Everyone is now speaking with everyone else, and we're back in a normal working atmosphere," said Wolfgang Ischinger, the German ambassador to the United States, who last week played down the lack of a scheduled meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Schroder. "There will be numerous opportunities for dragging someone into a corner for discussion." 
Other German diplomats say they understand President Bush's anger, even as they call it "emotional." They also justify Mr. Schroder's successful campaign talk as the kind of hardball political practice the White House itself uses and admires. 
"I think the president perceived the position the chancellor took as a position against him personally," Karsten Voigt, the German foreign ministry's coordinator for American relations, said. At a critical moment when Mr. Bush was seeking support for this campaign against Iraq, Mr. Voigt said, "a leading ally was not only saying no, but was using the peace argument in an election campaign."
Last week, as the leaders of NATO's 19 governments prepared for an important meeting in Prague and their invitation to 7 former Communist countries to join the alliance, Ms. Rice continued to brush off suggestions that the lack of a scheduled meeting, or bilateral, between Mr. Bush and Mr. Schroder amounted to anything at all.
"There are a lot of very important countries with which we're not having bilaterals at the NATO summit," Ms. Rice said.
Even though Germany has refused to take part in a military strike on Iraq, Ms. Rice noted that the nation is set to take command of the peacekeeping force in Kabul, the Afghan capital, when Turkey relinquishes it next month. 
"Let's be realistic," she said. "The Germans have done a lot in Afghanistan, in the war on terrorism there, in counterterrorism. We appreciate that very much."
Or, as a senior German government official said this past weekend about the relationship between the president and the chancellor: "We're sure that rationality is going to prevail."

HEADLINE: An Urban Drought 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Last week's painful PowerPoint presentation by New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg, in which he offered up a brutal combination of proposed tax increases and service cuts, should have been televised nationally.
 "Coming soon" could have been the tagline, because the problems that have led to New York's worst fiscal crisis since the 1970's are circulating like a virus through cities all across America. 
 Mayor Bloomberg is making budget decisions in an environment plagued by a weak national economy and the debilitating aftereffects of the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. With little in the way of help on the horizon from the federal or state government, the mayor has come up with a plan that would raise taxes by more than $4 billion and cut services by close to $2 billion over the next year and a half. 
Those who think this is a problem peculiar to New York should think again. The National League of Cities, in its annual research report, released in August, said:
"Amid the current economic downturn, the fall of the stock market, and federal and state budget crises, fiscal conditions in America's cities are also declining. For the first time in a decade, the majority of city officials report that they are worse off financially than in the previous fiscal year."
Cities in virtually every section of the country are taking a big hit on revenues from sales and income taxes, and from tourist-related levies, such as restaurant and hotel taxes.
At the same time, in this era of terror, public safety spending is up. And other inescapable expenditures -- on health care, for example -- continue to rise.
The result for many cities is a cruel fiscal squeeze. Mayor Wellington Webb of Denver, in an interview last week, told me: "Fifty-four percent of all our revenue comes from the sales tax, and our sales tax collections for 2001 were the same as 2000. That was the first time in history we did not have an increase in sales tax collections. Now, on a month-to-month basis, we're finding that 2002 is running behind 2001."
He said he has imposed a hiring freeze and delayed the start of annual raises for city employees from Jan. 1 to July 1. The purchase of needed equipment for the Fire Department has been delayed and the city has cut its support for some cultural and recreation programs.
The outlook is worsening, not getting better. The League of Cities report said: "Expectations that these trends will continue into the future have local officials predicting a further worsening of conditions in 2003. Two-thirds of city officials believe that their city will be less able to address financial needs in fiscal year 2003."
Over the past several years there has been a growing understanding that the fiscal health of cities is a crucial component of the nation's overall economic health. Cities, often the vital hubs of vast metropolitan areas, are the engines of economic growth in the U.S.
The cities' problems can only be solved in the context of national policies. And it is essential that those policies include a more equitable approach to taxation and the development of aggressive, coordinated strategies to spur stronger economic growth and increased employment.
A national economic policy that consists almost solely of tax cuts for the very rich will lead only to further disaster.
Thomas Menino, the mayor of Boston and president of the U.S. Conference of Mayors, said: "The cities are struggling because we don't have the partnerships that we've had in the past with the state and federal governments. They've somehow abandoned our needs and that's unfortunate."
He spoke contemptuously of the tax-cut mania that is draining government coffers of the money needed to provide even basic services.
"I'm not a big raising-taxes kind of guy," he said. "But you have to get revenue from somewhere to pay your basic costs. . . . We don't run government with voodoo economics. We run it with real cash to fund real programs that help people."
Referring to cities in Massachusetts, he said, "We have a real financial crisis on our hands."
Optimism at the moment is in short supply. On the same day that Mayor Bloomberg was saying that New York could not "pray" its way out of its current crisis, Denver's Mayor Webb was saying, "I think it's going to be a rough few years."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: PREPARATIONS; 
U.S. TAKING STEPS TO LAY FOUNDATION FOR ACTION IN IRAQ

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is initiating a series of diplomatic and military steps that must be completed before the United States could go to war in Iraq, American and allied officials say.
 The tasks, some of which could take weeks or even months to carry out, include formalizing allies' roles in any offensive, discouraging neighboring countries like Turkey and Israel from taking their own action, and deciding whether to seek United Nations support for an attack. Failure to accomplish many of these objectives could delay or complicate the onset of war. 
 The administration is moving urgently to accomplish its objectives, even before the start of the weapons inspections ordered by the United Nations. One goal is to create a credible threat of force, which might pressure President Saddam Hussein of Iraq to comply with the new resolution of the United Nations Security Council. The other main reason for acting speedily is to be ready for combat in Iraq before the hot weather sets in there next year. 
There has already been some progress, officials said.
American officials have privately secured informal assurances of basing and overflight rights in several Central Asian and Persian Gulf countries, including Kuwait and Qatar, but those commitments need to be formalized. Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld is expected to consult with allies this week at the NATO summit meeting in Prague on how they might fill in for American forces now in Europe and the United States that would be moved to the gulf area.
The United States has stockpiled tanks and heavy equipment for more than 30,000 troops in several gulf states and on ships nearby. But additional heavy equipment for Marine or Army divisions would take three to four weeks to reach the Persian Gulf from ports like Beaumont, Tex., or Savannah, Ga. 
American diplomats have intensified talks with two important allies, Turkey and Israel, to persuade them to remain on the sidelines during an invasion. Quietly, often through informal channels, Washington has also broached discussions with Iran about preventing Iraq's Shiite majority from trying to seize control of Baghdad or form a separate state if Mr. Hussein falls.
If Mr. Hussein defies or obstructs weapons inspectors, the Bush administration will have to decide whether to seek approval from the Security Council for a military strike. Administration officials say President Bush would like Council support, provided it can be obtained quickly. Diplomacy to lay the groundwork for winning that swift passage is in the most preliminary stages.
Senior military officials say the portion of a total force of about 250,000 troops needed to begin the "rolling start" of an air, land and sea attack could be in place within 30 days of Mr. Bush's order.
"We're making preparations every day," Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz said on Friday. "I don't want to start saying exactly when we're at peak readiness, but it would be a terrible mistake for anyone to underestimate our ability to act if needed."
The timing of any offensive, however, hinges greatly on the outcome of the weapons inspections. "A lot depends on how things come out with the U.N. resolutions," said one senior military official.
But the administration has already begun laying the groundwork with dozens of countries for a possible attack. In a flurry of recent meetings and telephone conversations, some in Washington and some overseas, American officials have asked for assistance from allies and antagonists -- and received demands in exchange for their cooperation.
Turkey, which has several bases that would be critical for American troops and aircraft driving into northern Iraq, has received some of the most serious attention. In the past two weeks, Marc Grossman, the undersecretary of state for political affairs, and John E. McLaughlin, the deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency, visited Ankara, while the new Turkish chief of staff, Gen. Hilmi Ozkok, met with officials in the Pentagon and State Department.
Turkey wants assurances from Washington that independence-minded Kurdish factions in northern Iraq will not attempt to form a separate state, a move that it fears could incite Kurdish separatists in its own country. Turkey has more than 3,000 troops in northern Iraq and could take steps to counter any efforts by Kurds there to seize territory. To ease Ankara's concerns, the Pentagon is preparing war plans to dispatch troops to protect the oil fields around Kirkuk in northern Iraq.
At Ankara's behest, Washington is also pushing European countries to accept Turkey into the European Union. Turkey, a major trading partner with Iraq, is also seeking compensation for economic losses that might result from war. Negotiations are under way for a multibillion-dollar aid package that would include forgiving Turkish debts, and military aid and grants, diplomats said.
"Should a crisis come because of Iraq's defiance, we will work to ensure that the safety net under Turkey's economy stays in place," W. Robert Pearson, the American ambassador to Turkey, said in a statement.
The Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, has vowed to retaliate if Mr. Hussein launches missiles at Israel, a move that could swiftly undermine the support of moderate Arab states for an American invasion, perhaps igniting a broader war.
To allay Israel's concerns, Mr. Bush has approved a war plan that calls for American forces to seize land in western Iraq to destroy Scud missiles that could reach Israeli cities. Also, American diplomats are urging Israel to limit any responses to Iraqi aggression to purely defensive actions, such as firing Arrow antimissile weapons.
In turn, Israel, during a meeting between its national security adviser and senior Pentagon and State Department officials last Thursday, urged the United States to help resolve a water dispute with Lebanon and Syria, officials said.
The administration has quietly reached out to Iran, often through third parties, to enlist Tehran's support in discouraging Iraqi Shiites, who represent 60 percent of Iraq's population, from engaging in terrorism or forming a breakaway republic, officials said. Those channels include the Swiss Embassy in Tehran, which represents American interests in Iran, various relief groups, the United Nations and a Tehran-based Iraqi Shiite opposition group, the Supreme Council for Islamic Revolution in Iraq.
In exchange for cooperation, Iran wants the United States to release billions of dollars in assets frozen in American financial institutions after American Embassy workers were taken hostage in 1979. It is also seeking pledges of assistance for Iraqi refugees who might pour into Iran if war breaks out.
In one sign that Tehran was trying to reach out to Washington, Javad Zarif, Iran's ambassador to the United Nations, requested permission to visit Washington this week to meet with members of Congress. But the State Department, which must approve his travel plans beyond New York, would not allow him to stay overnight, and he canceled the trip.
"I think sooner or later we will have better relations with Iran," Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said on Friday. "We stay in touch with people who might be on the same side of this as us, but I don't want to give the impression there is a great rapprochement about to take place with respect to Iran."
The diplomatic talks are closely linked to troop deployments.
American diplomats and senior military officials -- including Gen. Tommy R. Franks, commander of American forces in the Persian Gulf area -- have fanned out across Europe and Southwest Asia in recent weeks to discuss basing agreements for American troops and aircraft, and to determine which nations may contribute forces or equipment to an offensive to disarm Iraq.
General Franks said in a recent interview that the United States had not yet made formal requests for assistance. But several countries have given private assurances to provide troops, equipment, basing, supplies and other support for a war, officials said. Saudi Arabia, the most important gulf ally in the 1991 war, has given conflicting signals on whether it would allow the military to use a major air operations center outside Riyadh or its spacious air bases for another war against Iraq.
General Franks has set up an alternate command post in Qatar, and other countries, from Kuwait to Oman, could pick up the slack if the Saudis restrict their bases.
"We'll have the access we need wherever we need it to do our job," said Gen. Charles F. Wald, a former head of American air forces in the gulf who is the new deputy commander of United States forces in Europe.
The United States has already stockpiled hundreds of M1 Abrams tanks, Bradley fighting vehicles and armored personnel carriers in the region, particularly in Kuwait. The military has also been stockpiling precision-guided munitions in the area and lining up local contractors to provide supplies for troops.
And while tens of thousands of American air, land and sea troops are now within striking distance of the gulf, an offensive, and any peacekeeping operation afterward, would require many thousands more.
Logistical equipment -- tugboats, forklifts and other equipment used to unload heavy gear -- is either en route or ready to be sent, as is portable bridging that the Army would use to ford rivers in Iraq. Heavy equipment for Marine or Army divisions would go via fast sea-lift ships that take about a month from Gulf of Mexico and East Coast ports. 
B-2 bombers, which would play a pivotal role in destroying Iraqi air defenses, would fly from bases in Britain and the British territory of Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean. The bombers' sensitive radar-evading skin requires the Air Force to erect portable hangars.
"There's an enormous amount already in theater, and I'd say within 30 days of an order, we'd have a substantial tank and mechanized force in place," said Gen. Barry McCaffrey, a retired Army commander from the gulf war in 1991.
A war with Iraq could require more than the 265,000 National Guard and Reserve troops summoned to active duty in the war in 1991, largely to protect valuable sites in the United States like airports, power plants and pipelines. 
Finally, any military campaign against Iraq would begin with a psychological operations campaign intended to turn Mr. Hussein's forces against him. Mr. Rumsfeld has approved the outlines of an ambitious plan that goes beyond traditional leaflet drops and broadcasts, a senior Defense Department official said. Of course, officials said, the buildup of American forces in the region is a big psychological operation in itself.
