HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Extending Franchises: Alive! Dead!

BYLINE:  By JANET MASLIN

 BODY:
PREY
By Michael Crichton
367 pages. HarperCollins. $26.95.

FOUR BLIND MICE
By James Patterson
387 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $27.95.
 James Patterson's "Four Blind Mice" has a scene at an airport where Detective Alex Cross notices somebody reading Jonathan Franzen. That's nice, but it's unduly modest. Thrillers by Mr. Patterson and Michael Crichton are what you'll spy in waiting rooms everywhere. 
 Each of these brand-name authors returns to his most viable franchise with "Four Blind Mice" and "Prey." While Mr. Patterson's latest nursery-rhymer is one of his better, less sadistic Cross mysteries, Mr. Crichton turns to scary science for another lesson in technology run amok. In this case it's not resurrected dinosaurs who rampage but groups of molecular entities with as many as 1025 parts apiece. Think of "Prey" as "Jurassic Particles."
"Prey," a tight techno-adventure shaped to fit the footprint of Mr. Crichton's biggest hits, begins with the spectacle of Jack Forman buying place mats while his high-powered wife, Julia, neglects the household. Julia works for Xymos Technology and is engaged in developing nanocomputers (which is one hot research field among novelists; it also figures in Michael Connelly's new "Chasing the Dime"). 
While Jack stays home near San Jose, Calif., Julia is off at the "fab complex," which is not a high-fashion playland. It's the fabrication plant in the desert where Xymos is manufacturing trouble.
There are three things we know about "Prey" from the get-go:
1) Jack will not be sitting around the house long. (He is an unemployed Silicon Valley expert in distributed parallel processing, or computer programs that "model biological processes by creating virtual agents inside the computer and then letting the agents interact to solve real-world problems." This will come in handy.)
2) Julia will pay for being nicer to swarms of rogue particles than she is to her own children.
3) Although the premise of "Prey" is that these particles supposedly have no memory capacity, there are certain collective behavior patterns that they definitely understand. They know it's time to go berserk in the story's third act, after its highly interesting lecture phase is over.
Because there has been a teeny little leak of research specimens into the atmosphere, Jack is summoned to the fab complex to troubleshoot. What he knows -- and what Mr. Crichton explains in clear and fascinating detail -- is the difference between artificial intelligence and artificial life. Jack's specialty is studying the latter by projecting the rogue behavior of known entities once they form groups. 
As Mr. Crichton puts it most colloquially: "Trying to program distributed intelligence is like telling a 5-year-old kid to go to his room and change his clothes. He may do that, but he is equally likely to do something else and never return."
Without giving away too much of "Prey" before it arrives in bookstores on Monday -- or before somebody turns it into a special-effects fiesta on screen -- here is some of what Jack has to say as the plot unfolds:
"So you have a runaway swarm."
"Acting autonomously."
"You think that swarm is capable of hiding?"
"There's more than one?"
"How can it learn? The agents have no memory."
"They have memory?"
"You mean these are new swarms since noon?"
"So what you're telling me is this swarm reproduces, is self-sustaining, learns from experience, has collective intelligence and can innovate to solve problems."
Well, yes. 
And for anyone who cares to see what can happen when nanotechnology, biotechnology and computer technology collide, Mr. Crichton has both a high-octane story and a serious warning.
Since Mr. Patterson is someone who writes "Pop-pop-pop-pop-pop" four times on the same page to simulate gunfire, his is a less sophisticated undertaking. He simply sends Alex Cross, the Washington, D.C., police detective of "Roses Are Red" and "Violets Are Blue" and so on, to investigate a string of murders. He comes to the defense of a friend's Army buddy who has been accused of killing three women. 
"He painted their chests and stomachs," says the district attorney prosecuting the case. "It is gruesome and twisted." Of course by the standards of Mr. Patterson's earlier books, this is not much worse than jaywalking.
Although the killers are identified early and have been given the catchy nickname Three Blind Mice for reasons best understood by Mr. Patterson's publisher, this latest story is not out either to sicken or insult its readers. With a trail of intrigue that involves the Army and has links to the Vietnam War, "Four Blind Mice" constructs a straightforward mystery investigation punctuated by scattered moments of suspense. The book's most chilling section has the three killers for hire (we do not know who is paying them or why) roaming the Appalachian Trail looking for prospective victims. There is also a moment of actual symbolism, when the sight of a commercial airliner is used to generate terrorist-related foreboding.
No one is likely to mistake Mr. Patterson for an artful stylist. (One killer can be found "leering eerily.") But he and Alex Cross make better than usual company this time, as "Four Blind Mice" includes various homey and romantic interludes, not to mention a smell-the-roses awareness of life's fragility. 
The principals stop to enjoy themselves. And so do the killers. But Mr. Patterson makes his bad guys cigar-smoking, cholesterol-happy carnivores whose memories of Vietnam loom large and whose taste in background music suggests "Apocalypse Now." 
Maybe that's not fun after all.

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA; 
A Literary Tour Guide Interpreting the City of Dreams

BYLINE:  By Marc Weingarten

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
Like this city itself, the literary tradition of Los Angeles is seemingly largely misunderstood and unjustly maligned. It is Raymond Chandler and Charles Bukowski and countless screenplays both celebrated and unproduced, but it's also Bertolt Brecht, Charles Mingus and a host of less familiar, though equally vital, names. At least that was the organizing principle behind "Writing Los Angeles," the latest literary colossus from the Library of America. 
 Its subject matter ranges from this city's amorphous geography to its Googie coffee shop architecture, lifestyle trends and peculiar social rituals. The anthology's 91 selections by 77 writers -- a mix of fiction, poetry, essays, journalism and diary entries -- make a convincing claim for Los Angeles as a fertile source of regional writing. The book, which was published this fall, received more advance orders than any title in the Library of America's 20-year history, 13,000 copies out of a first printing of 25,000, and is selling mostly in Southern California and New York. The 880-page book, priced at $40, was on the Los Angeles Times's best-seller fiction list for one week in October. West Coast critics have been effusive. Los Angeles Magazine called "Writing Los Angeles" the "fullest picture of Los Angeles's impact on America ever put between two covers," while The Los Angeles Times praised the book's editor, David L. Ulin, for doing a "masterful job of choosing some of the more compelling efforts to evoke a city whose essence has proved maddeningly elusive." 
 Mr. Ulin is a freelance editor and writer who moved here from Manhattan 12 years ago. "When putting together a book like this, there's an enormous amount of freedom to see L.A. literature fresh, without having a lot of received expectations," he said. "Historically, it's been a very tough city to pin down. There's really no defining narrative." 
But there are some obvious signposts, mainly from the literature of urban dissipation that Los Angeles has inspired more than any other American city. In the 1930's, transplants like Nathanael West and Raymond Chandler perpetuated the defining myth of Los Angeles as a city whose heavenly climate and leisurely lifestyle masked a viper's nest of compromised moral values.
That stark contrast, which the social critic Mike Davis has called the sunshine/noir dialectic, has been a wellspring of material for this city's writers. West's dystopic Hollywood novel "The Day of the Locust" is perhaps the most famous of these anti-Los Angeles texts. Then there are Chandler's roguish crime stories; the Joan Didion essays "Fire Season" and "Los Angeles Notebook," which counterbalance this city's wary optimism with an undercurrent of impending doom; and the 1977 book "The Sexual Outlaw," John Rechy's unsparing look at the gay underground of Los Angeles. 
All of these works are included or excerpted in the anthology, but not all of the writers in "Writing Los Angeles" focus on this city's bleak underbelly; there is genuine boosterism as well. The real pulse of Los Angeles is revealed in this book's intimate personal stories.
In his 1996 memoir, "Holy Land," for instance, D. J. Waldie writes affectionately about Lakewood, Calif., his native city and one of the many anonymous tract-home developments that sprang up like desert wildflowers in the 1950's. Finding joy and beauty in the suburban prosaic, Mr. Waldie reveals the hidden history of the "other" Los Angeles that is often criticized as a blight on the Southern California landscape. 
Similarly, Mary Helen Ponce's tale of life in 50's-era San Fernando Valley, "Hoyt Street: Memories of a Chicana Childhood," reveals the chasm between the Hollywood myth machine and those Angelenos who never went anywhere near a movie set. 
During a panel discussion for "Writing Los Angeles" at the Los Angeles Central Library recently, Ms. Ponce, who was joined by Mr. Ulin and Mr. Waldie, recounted her life as a young translator of Roy Rogers and Hopalong Cassidy westerns for the Hispanic matrons in her Pacoima neighborhood.
"We were fascinated by Hollywood," Ms. Ponce said. "We all lived for the myths, but we were rooted in the valley. We were hicks who never had a sense of Los Angeles."
Modern Los Angeles was built on myth. Marketed in the 1920's as America's Mediterranean, an Edenic land of temperate weather and endless financial opportunities, this city filled up with exiles and fortune seekers who quickly discovered that the hype didn't square with reality. The influx of countless novelists and journalists seeking movie work in Hollywood in the 1920's and 30's led to the first accounts of Los Angeles as a city of rootless wanderers, eccentrics and hucksters. Los Angeles, wrote Aldous Huxley in a 1926 essay in the anthology titled "Los Angeles: A Rhapsody," was a "city of dreadful joy," where "thought is barred" and "conversation is unknown." 
Max Rudin, the publisher of the Library of America, said: "When the New York writers came to Hollywood, that's when writing about L.A. gets a national audience. That kind of thinking about L.A. in almost apocalyptic terms begins then." 
In his 1935 short story "Golden Land," William Faulkner, who loathed the time he spent writing movie scripts, described "white villas whose owners' names and faces and even voices were glib and familiar in back corners of the United States where those of Einstein and Rousseau and Aesculapius had never been sounded."
For those early writers, Los Angeles was a philistine's paradise, the great social experiment that failed miserably. That idea ran through much of the writing about Los Angeles before World War II. "L.A. was where manifest destiny hit the sea," Mr. Rudin said.
After the war ended, Los Angeles was inspiring a different scenario. With a booming economy driven by entertainment and aerospace, this city's sprawling suburbs and autocentric culture had set the tone for the way the rest of the country lived. An essay like Tom Wolfe's 1964 Esquire piece "The Kandy-Kolored Tangerine-Flake Streamline Baby," which gives serious consideration to the 1960's-era efflorescence of Los Angeles youth and car fetishism, would have been anathema to the previous generation of writers.
By the 70's, writers began to treat the city more sympathetically, celebrating the very things that had been historically denigrated. In his 1973 essay "Autopia," the Dutch novelist Cees Nooteboom wrote that Los Angeles "mixes images of vulgarity and vitality" and "conveys the feeling that it stretches to all sides around you, but never looks down on you or presses you down, an open world that forms itself as a unity despite its fragmented appearance."
Los Angeles continues to be a rich mine of material for writers and a metaphor for the nation. "L.A. is about everything that's central to American culture: the car, the horizontal nature of urban space, fast-food, modern architecture," Mr. Rudin said. "It's the quintessential 20th-century American city." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: The anthology "Writing Los Angeles" represents more than 70 authors in its 880 pages, reflecting one region's shifting identities.

HEADLINE: MAKING BOOKS; 
Poetry Hits The Jackpot

BYLINE:  By Martin Arnold

 BODY:
Financial bombshells in the book world usually mean huge best sellers and jumbo advances. But last week the big number was a bequest, and in a country coping with corporate scandal and economic affliction and about ready to march off to war, there was something marvelously innovatory, out-of-step almost, about someone investing what could be as much as $100 million in Poetry, the magazine, and in poetry, the art. Which is exactly what Ruth Lilly did, invest in poetry, a stunningly pure benevolence. One can but wonder what this will do for that most marginalized literary form. Visibility, for sure, since suddenly there's lots of 0000's at the end of the $$$$'s attached to the word poetry. 
 For the monthly Poetry, which celebrated its 90th anniversary this year, the money from the 87-year-old heir to the Eli Lilly pharmaceutical fortune insured its existence into perpetuity, an astonishing happening for an esoteric publication with a circulation (until today) of about 11,000. Certainly I think it's good for poets and poetry. But Poets are a quirky lot, and the first, but not lasting, reaction from some was concern, since this peripheral art's loneliness was seen as part of its strength; the next common reaction was that the idea of connecting money to poetry was somehow unpoetic. John Hollander, poet and Yale professor, questioned whether it would be a plus to publish thousands more poetry books. But it would be wonderful, he said, if some of the money could encourage better poetry criticism. 
 Alice Fulton, this year's winner of the $10,000 Bobbitt National Prize for Poetry for her book of poems "Felt" (W. W. Norton), explained: "I was almost scared when I heard about it. I had come to believe that marginalization let poetry do what it wants to do, that the money would take something good and make it bad. But that's being afraid of change. Giving this to literature is staggering; very few people care about poetry, and this will make it a positive thing to people, so it can be empowering to writers." 
Rita Dove, Pulitzer Prize-winning poet in 1987 and America's poet laureate from 1993 to 1995, said, "I think it's a myth that if one receives money for writing, it's corrupting." She added: "That's one of the myths literary people have consoled themselves with. That poetry is going to have money is a good thing. And I can't think of anyone more deserving of money than Poetry magazine, which has remained refreshingly honest over the years, hasn't gone for trends." Ms. Dove's latest collection was "On the Bus with Rosa Parks" (W. W. Norton, 1999).
Poetry magazine was first published in 1912, and since then to appear in it was to be part of a great literary continuum, which ranged from Yeats and Eliot and Sandburg and Stevens to Ms. Fulton and Ms. Dove and Billy Collins (but not Ms. Lilly, whose own poetry was rejected by the magazine). Mr. Collins, the current poet laureate, said that "raising the fee from $2 a line to $2,000 a line would be one poet's suggestion" for using the money. Mr. Collins was, of course, joking, although Joseph Parisi, the magazine's editor, said that fees to contributors will be increased somewhat. 
For starters, he wants to use the money to educate middle school and high school teachers in the richness of poetry. "If you have dollar signs in front of something, then people take an interest, can't seem to help but focus, but that's not the best way to get attention," he said. He envisions programs where teachers meet active poets "and ask them such questions as 'Where do their ideas come from?' and 'Why do you write?' The best way to spend money is with teachers in workshops."
He described it this way: "Make poetry a reality, something of pleasure and love, not dry-as-dust theory," the joy and passion to be passed on to students. The magazine, published by the Modern Poetry Association, also plans to publish first collections of poetry -- "We get to see everything, and we get a pretty good idea of who will be the new important poets," Mr. Parisi said. The association has a collection of about 25,000 first editions of poetry stashed away that it now wants to catalog and display for scholars.
But for now the magazine and the association -- and the community of poets -- are simply trying to cope with the immensity of it all. Deborah Cummins, president of the association and a published poet, said, "For most people poetry belongs in another sphere, and if significance is measured by the dollar sign, as many believe, then the underlining message of all this is that maybe poetry has an importance we didn't know about." 
Poets speak. From Lisel Mueller, 1997 Pulitzer Prize winner in poetry for "Alive Together" (Louisiana State University Press): "Poetry is always a minority art, as is chamber music a minority music, and I don't think this will affect the reading public; I don't know if this will have any general effect on poetry in general, but it will allow the magazine to do more outreach programs, and that will obviously be a shot in the arm."
John Ashbery, winner of the Pulitzer Prize, the National Book Award and National Book Critics Circle Award, all in 1975, said he didn't "think all that money was going to turn America into a country of passionate poetry readers." He added, "That she did it after having her own poetry rejected is almost the most interesting thing about it." Mr. Ashbery's latest collection is "Chinese Whispers" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux).
For all that poets feel they are seldom read, there are mainstream houses that have strong poetry programs like Farrar, Straus & Giroux, Alfred A. Knopf, Norton and Houghton Mifflin. The belief that money attached to anything is like flypaper in its attraction extends even to something as way out as poetry.
Carol Houck Smith, who is a poetry editor at Norton, said that when it comes to poetry "so many say, 'Oh, I can't read that,' but certainly more people are writing poetry, and the announcement will make people less anxious about poetry, and that's wonderful."
Jill Bialosky, a Norton poetry editor and Knopf poet, said the bequest "will bring more media attention and more review attention to poetry and help create a larger readership." And Deborah Garrison, poetry editor at Knopf, also said she believes that the money "is a boon for everybody who writes poetry," and addedthat when "poetry is in front of people, they love it."
All this may be true. But if Mr. Parisi and his people could use money to get everyone who, in their loneliness and passion, secretly scribbles verse to buy a book of poetry that would truly revolutionize the art.

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK; 
From the Bottomlands, Soulful Stitches

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

DATELINE: GEE'S BEND, Ala. 

 BODY:
AT this time of year, when the shadows grow long and pecans fall heavy on the red earth, the memories of old women in this loop of land encircled by the Alabama River turn to quilting.
 For it was in autumn, after the cotton crop was brought in, that the granddaughters and great-granddaughters of slaves on this former plantation land would whip cotton with plum-tree switches and then gather together to "put a quilt up." 
 "We'd get together and make the quilts just like we're praying together," recalled Mary Lee Bendolph, 67, one of 45 Gee's Bend quilt makers whose work goes on view today at the Whitney Museum of American Art. The quilts' journey from Gee's Bend to New York is yet another chapter, as yet unfinished, in the community's long and often difficult story. Ms. Bendolph was sitting on her front porch one recent afternoon beside a worn copy of the Bible. "We had no TV, no radio, no nothing. That's the way we learned -- sitting watching our mamas piecing the quilt. When the sun came down you be in the house together, laughing and talking. We were more blessed then." 
The bittersweet history of a place where isolation and poverty still reside is stitched into the trouser legs, cornmeal sacks, dress skirts and Sears corduroy swatches that constitute one of the country's most unbroken and deeply imaginative quilting traditions. When Early Pettway, 73, surveys the hand-painted headstones in the cemetery beside the Pleasant Grove Baptist Church, where the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. preached in 1965, he remembers generations of women, many his own relatives, and their jubilant stitchery airing on wire fences in the sun. "Way back yonder," he said, "everybody here but the men quilted." 
The artistic legacy of African-American women in this hamlet of 300 families, where 42 percent of the residents earn less than $10,000 a year, springs from a deep and powerful well. As a little girl, Arlonzia Pettway, 79, an accomplished quilt maker and Mr. Pettway's sister, would sit with her siblings and baby cousins on her great-grandmother's string quilt every day after the noontime dinner. Grandmama Dinah Miller, a slave who died at age 102 in the 1930's, would lay down the quilt, the single material legacy of her mother, on the gaping floorboards as protection from the wind, cold and dust. Then the stories unfolded: of slave ships cruelly decorated with red ribbons to lure people on board; of Grandmama Dinah Miller's baby boy who was fathered by a white man and then taken away; of the terrifying click-clicking sound the horses' teeth made when the slave masters came. "I'd wake up at night and think of the stories she told," Mrs. Pettway said. "I didn't forget them. I pawned them in my heart."
Despite countless forays by sociologists, photographers and writers from the 1930's onward, Gee's Bend's isolation served to preserve an idiosyncratic style of quilt making that is as direct and unvarnished as the landscape itself. "What makes Gee's Bend distinct is the freedom with which the women approach their art," said John Beardsley, a senior lecturer at the Harvard Graduate School of Design and a co-curator of the exhibition at the Whitney. "Many African-American quilts in the South emphasize recycled materials and abstract patterns. What's unusual in Gee's Bend is the density of accomplishment."
Alvia Wardlaw, a curator at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, where the show originated this fall, likens the avant-garde look of Gee's Bend quilts to the improvisational quality of jazz. "There is the same self-assuredness and freedom, a lack of hesitancy about who they are as people," she said. "The quilts reflect the bold rhythms of a life of doing, the flurry of activity, where being at home was the center of the universe and the bed a place to exhibit creativity." 
The 70 quilts in the exhibition, over half by living artists, are among roughly 530 Gee's Bend quilts amassed over the last five years by William Arnett, a controversial Atlanta collector and passionate documentarian of vernacular African-American folk art, whose relationship with some artists he has championed has led in the past to accusations of exploitation. 
As a pre-emptive strike, perhaps, Mr. Arnett has created a nonprofit foundation, the Tinwood Alliance, to own and conserve the quilts -- for which he said he paid an average of $275 each -- and to sell an as yet unknown number to museums, including the Art Institute of Chicago, which is in the process of buying as many as five. He says he plans to funnel any profits into the community, though he has not said how that would work. "I paid them three or four times the going rate," he said. "But these quilts may be worth a hundred times that one day." 
His supporting cast includes Jane Fonda, recently attracted to Southern African-American art, who has given $1 million to Tinwood Media, an Atlanta publishing company Mr. Arnett created to produce lavish and comprehensive books on rural African-American artists, including two hefty new volumes: "The Quilts of Gee's Bend" ($45.50) and "Gee's Bend: The Women and Their Quilts" ($75). The company has also produced a documentary film on the quilt makers by Mr. Arnett's son, Matt, and Vanessa Vadim, Ms. Fonda's daughter. The film will be shown at the Whitney show.
Among the most striking quilts are those made by Loretta Pettway, which are neighborhoods of emotion rendered in material form. She exploits every nuance of denim, fashioning strong abstract collages from the barest scraps. "I didn't have a good scissor," she recalled, enveloped by warmth from a gas fire in her living room. "I mostly had to rip them loose. I just fit them the way they were cut. The Lord built in me how to fit them. Because I needed them."
Like many people here, Mrs. Pettway, the mother of seven, barely gets by, living, she estimates, on about $5,000 a year. The art world may herald her "austere masterpieces," as one museum curator put it, but she romanticizes the quilts not a wit. They were hard work, akin to chopping wood, hauling water and making laundry starch from scratch out of boiling water, flour and "a little kerosene to make the clothes slip." 
"I never had no time to myself," she said.
Sometimes the walls of her childhood home inspired her. "We didn't have no sheet rock," she said. "We nailed torn boxes to the wall and then plastered them with newspapers and catalogs. I saw some quilts in those papers and liked how they were made. I couldn't make no pretty quilts, but it did me good to look at them." 
Her last name, shared by many Gee's Benders, was assigned by Mark Pettway, a plantation owner who in the 1840's moved his family and more than 100 slaves from North Carolina to Gee's Bend, forcing all but his family and a cook to make the journey on foot. During the Depression, the widow of a merchant in nearby Camden who had been advancing credit to tenant farmers in the Bend foreclosed on their debts and ordered a raid, driving the community into complete destitution.
"We went through some rough times," said Annie Mae Young, in whose hands strips of denim and corduroy assume the eloquence of a flag. "You couldn't get the money to piece quilts with. You needed fire to keep warm. You can't quilt cold."
Spurred by documentary photographs, the federal government stepped in in the 1930's and made Gee's Bend a model of the New Deal, reimagining the town and replacing skinned-pine log houses chinked with clay with "Roosevelt houses," as they are still called, equipped with leakless roofs, cast-iron stoves and other improvements. The program created a rarity: a whole community of independent African-American landowners in the impoverished rural South. For years, the Bend's connection to the "mainland" was a ferry to the far side of the river and the predominantly white county seat of Camden. During the civil rights movement, many quilt makers here, along with their families, began to cross the river to register to vote, resulting in the abrupt termination of ferry service in 1965. Service has never been restored to Gee's Bend. The closest hospital, high school and police station require a 45-mile drive. 
The civil rights movement led in 1966 to the creation of the Freedom Quilting Bee, organized by Francis X. Walter, an Episcopal priest who was in Alabama documenting civil rights abuses. He seized upon quilts as a vehicle for economic empowerment and helped local women set up a cooperative, leading to highly publicized auctions in New York. The first check from New York, $2,065 for more than 70 quilts, went to necessities like washing machines, indoor plumbing and, in at least one instance, college tuition for the great-granddaughter of a slave.
For a fleeting moment in the 1970's, the Quilting Bee's work, made in Rehoboth, just up the road, was promoted at Bloomingdale's, in Diana Vreeland's Vogue and by the decorator Sister Parish, who outfitted the summer house of William S. Paley, the chairman of CBS, with orange and yellow fabric stitched at the Bee.
"The Bee was the first business black people in Wilcox County owned," said Nettie Young, 85, an original Bee leader who learned to quilt at age 7. "It was the first time I knew I was special, the first job I had, excusing cotton picking." 
The Bee, which is now struggling to survive, eventually went commercial, diluting the Bend women's singular designs to produce eyeglass cases, crewel-work TV Guide covers, conference tote bags and other less than distinctive products. But many quilt makers here would like to see the Bee, which is currently reorganizing its board, return with the kind of quilts now hanging in the Whitney. 
That so many Benders, including the quilt makers, were willing to part with their creations reflects the complex texture of a place where chickens and cows share the road and generations of families are often clustered in a phalanx of weatherworn houses and mobile homes. Created as objects of utility, the "raggly" or bedraggled antique quilts, squirreled away under mattresses and in chicken coops and wood piles, were often used to mop up motor oil, cover up cars from the rain and even, as Arlonzia Pettway herself did, "lit on a big old wood pile and burnt." 
But hindsight can be a hard teacher, especially when illuminated by museum spotlights. At the moment the town is divided between those who feel fairly compensated for their quilts and those who now consider them "a gold strike" for the buyers, in the words of the Rev. Clinton J. Pettway Jr., pastor of Ye Shall Know the Truth Church. 
"We didn't know these quilts would have value, like Babe Ruth cards," he said. His mother sold some quilts to the Arnetts, which he regrets. "When I first heard about selling quilts I was against it," he said. "But at the time people needed the money. It was like telling someone not to eat when food was in front of them."
Mr. Arnett, who said he borrowed $1 million to purchase, conserve and research the quilts, said one goal might be to help get the Freedom Quilting Bee going again, possibly with a quilting museum inside. Nowadays, in a Wal-Mart culture, there is less time and motivation for younger women to make quilts. A potential model could be Mississippi Cultural Crossroads in Port Gibson, Miss., which has gotten grant money to foster quilting through apprenticeships.
For Annie Mae Young and Arlonzia Pettway, who had given up their art because of old age and arthritis, the sight of their joyous creations being celebrated in books and art museums has inspired them to begin quilting again. It has made Essie Bendolph Pettway, 46, who works long hours in a sewing factory in Selma, to renew her commitment to the art she hones deep into the wee hours of morning "just to see how that quilt turns out."
Nettie Young, who has made quilts to commemorate each of her 22 grandchildren's high school graduations, has recently started to teach her 29-year-old granddaughter, Carolyn Pounds, how to quilt. Like the strips and pieces of work clothes and old dresses in a quilt, she sees the past and present coming together. 
"Quilting is the whole history of my family," she said, sitting with three generations beside her on a velveteen sofa. "I learned this year that what my foreparents did is recognized today to be art, not just cover. But it was always special to me."

HEADLINE: Home Building Fell Sharply in October 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
Housing starts dropped sharply in October, falling 11.4 percent, the Commerce Department reported today. Economists said the decline was probably weather related. 
 Groundbreaking for new homes showed the biggest monthly drop since January 1994 and erased a big gain in September, the agency said. 
 The pace of starts was the slowest since April, but economists said it remained relatively high, and they cited heavy rain in October as a potential factor for the decline. 
"Looking at what we have from the weather bureau for October, virtually all the regions in the country, except for the west region, were unusually wet," said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. 
The West was the only region of the country to record a gain in the number of starts in October. 
Over all, groundbreaking for new homes slid to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.603 million units last month from a downwardly revised 1.810 million in September.
While housing starts fell, building permits, an indication of builder confidence, rose 1.7 percent, to 1.763 million units. Economists said the rise in permits and a climb in mortgage applications signaled stamina in the housing sector . 
Despite the drop in October, economists said the fundamentals for the housing sector were good. 
"There is little doubt that the fundamentals for the housing sector are extremely favorable," said Kevin Cummings of RBS Greenwich Capital. "Mortgage rates are at their lowest level in almost 40 years, demographics are positive, resulting in part from high levels of immigration, and people have a new-found appreciation for the wisdom of investing in real estate in the wake of the stock market plunge." 
Housing starts had posted their biggest gain in seven years in September as buyers seized on low mortgage interest rates to snap up homes in large numbers. The October rate was still 4.7 percent higher than the 1.531 million level in October last year. 
Ian Morris, chief economist at HSBC Securities, said that "1.6 million units is still a high level." 
Single-family housing starts, the biggest category of building, slid 7.0 percent in October, to a 1.350 million unit annual rate. Multifamily housing starts tumbled 31.4 percent to their lowest level since January 1997. 
Starts fell 18.8 percent in the Northeast, 14.3 percent in the South and 19.5 percent in the Midwest. They rose 3.6 percent in the West.

HEADLINE: States of Pain 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Watching the fiscal crises gripping cities and states across the U.S. is like watching a chain-reaction auto wreck in slow motion. I don't think the general public has a good sense yet of the pain that will result from the carnage.
 California residents learned last week that their state, already laboring under a huge budget gap in the current fiscal year, will face a potentially catastrophic shortfall next year -- $21 billion, which is far higher than almost anyone expected. 
 In New York, state officials will have to close an estimated $10 billion gap next year. This comes as New York City is appealing for help from the state in closing a municipal budget deficit that already has the mayor -- a Republican businessman -- calling for a couple of billion dollars in service cuts and more than $4 billion in new taxes. 
At some point the ability of cities and states to deliver even essential services begins to come into question. 
"It's not a pretty picture," said Arturo Perez of the National Conference of State Legislatures, when I asked him to describe, in general terms, the fiscal conditions confronting the states. He said very serious budget gaps had emerged in the fiscal year that began July 1, 2001.
"For the most part the size and the number were unexpected," he said. "But then again, who could have predicted the events of Sept. 11? And, of course, we were already in a decline at that point, so Sept. 11 was sort of the push down the stairs that we did not need."
State officials did what they could to close the initial gaps without big tax increases or drastic service cuts. Some resorted to one-time measures, such as tapping reserve funds, while hoping for a turnaround in the national economy that would replenish faltering state tax revenues. 
"Go back to January and February," said Mr. Perez, "and look at what national economists were saying about where we would be in mid-2002. They forecast a rebound, gradual growth in the economy by mid-year. Well, June, July and August came and went and nothing happened." 
According to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities:
"States now face a gigantic revenue problem. Total state tax revenue in fiscal year 2002 was some $38 billion lower than in the previous year after adjusting for inflation. Some 45 states lost revenue. Official forecasts released to date suggest that state revenues at best will hold steady after adjusting for inflation in fiscal year 2003, meaning that none of that $38 billion is likely to be recouped this year. Indeed the revenue hole could get even deeper."
While the national economy remains stagnant, some state budget obligations continue to grow. And during the boom years of the mid- to late 90's, many states enacted permanent tax cuts that shut off revenue streams that are desperately needed now. 
The states are in a fix and no one at the moment sees a way out. Big-time tax increases and painful service cuts are inevitable in some places. In others, the resistance to tax increases is so extreme it is difficult to imagine how a reasonable budget solution can be crafted.
In California, for example, the brutal fiscal situation has not weakened the opposition of Republican legislative leaders to tax increases. Just a few days ago The Los Angeles Times quoted the Senate Republican leader, Jim Brulte, as saying, "I don't see any Republican votes" for higher taxes.
On Election Day in Massachusetts, which will face an estimated $2 billion deficit next year, voters moved perilously close to a tax revolt that was breathtaking in its mindlessness. Nearly half the voters -- 45 percent -- supported a ballot proposal to eliminate the state income tax, a move that would have plunged the state into a fiscal emergency. 
Democratic and Republican leaders, including the gubernatorial candidates of both parties, opposed the ballot measure. It was pushed by the Libertarian Party, and when the votes were tabulated even supporters of the measure were surprised by how well it did. 
There are those who have long dreamed of the day when governments would be so drained of revenues they would have no choice but to call a halt to many of their functions. The realization of that dream is getting closer, in part because its tragic implications remain obscure to vast segments of the public served by those governments.

HEADLINE: Security Chief Hopes to Curb Airport Lines 

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 

 BODY:
The chief of the Transportation Security Administration said today that airport security personnel would make common-sense judgments to avoid creating "multihour lines" at Thanksgiving and Christmas.
 The official, James M. Loy, under secretary of transportation for security, also said that with aviation security preparations beginning to fall into place, he would soon turn more attention to other modes of travel. 
 Mr. Loy said he was committed to strong security but also to preventing that security from creating problems for travelers and damaging the American economy. "It doesn't take much of a viewer, an observer," he said, "to recognize that it was the economic dislocation as a result of things that occurred on Sept. 11" that penalized the country in the aftermath of the attacks that day. 
Speaking with reporters at a breakfast sponsored by the Aviation Safety Alliance, an advocacy organization of the airlines, aircraft manufacturers and related industries, Mr. Loy said that when he met with screeners, as he does regularly, he told them "to remember the pleases and thank yous." Screeners can make travel a pleasant experience rather than a nightmare, he said, and "I want those people to be encouraging those experiences, so people aren't opting for a train to New York as opposed to the Delta shuttle." 
Thanksgiving always produces long lines at airports. The Transportation Security Administration's routine goal is to take no more than 10 minutes to screen a passenger, but officials of the agency say the counting begins only when the passenger reaches the head of the line and enters the actual screening process.
Lines have become shorter, though, with the hiring of new screeners and the opening of new lanes. In fact, some travelers have observed that between peak periods, screeners have little to do.
"If I want to err in this security business," Mr. Loy said, "I want to err on the side of producing too much initially, and pare it back." 
A bigger challenge may come on Dec. 31, the effective date of new requirements that checked bags be screened for bombs. But the domestic security bill just passed by Congress gives Mr. Loy the authority to grant his agency exemptions, airport by airport, for up to a year. An earlier version of the bill would have limited the exemptions to 40 airports; Mr. Loy said he would keep that number in mind, although the bill as passed has no limit.
Mr. Loy said that while most of the security deadlines set by Congress concerned passengers and bags, "we can't lose sight of perimeter security" at airports. And, he said, security at seaports and other transportation points also requires attention.
Mr. Loy said he spent the first 45 minutes of each day listening to an intelligence briefing. "The threat that the president constantly reminds us of," he said, "is a very, very real thing."

HEADLINE: Industries Welcome U.S. Aid on Terror Insurance 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Deborah Beck sighed with relief yesterday.
 For 14 months Ms. Beck, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, a powerful trade group, had been spearheading a campaign on behalf of the great buildings of New York -- places like the Chrysler Building and the Empire State Building -- as well as scores of huge but less-distinguished buildings. The buildings' owners and lenders all wanted terrorism insurance, she said, but they could not get enough -- or, in some cases, any at all. 
 Late Tuesday night, however, the Senate answered her prayers by passing legislation, which, once signed by President Bush, will put Washington in the terrorism insurance business and make it likely that such coverage will be available.
Without the backing of the government -- which in the event of a major attack will pay most of the losses under policies provided by private insurers -- most insurers have been unwilling to sell terrorism coverage.
Of course, construction projects and big property deals that have stalled for want of the insurance did not suddenly begin to percolate on news of the breakthrough, Ms. Beck said. But, gradually, she and others said, as new policies are written, deals will start going through and the economy will pick up. "It's not going to happen overnight," Ms. Beck said. "But now it will be sooner rather than later."
David W. Liddle, a spokesman for the Financial Services Round Table, a group of the country's largest banks, insurance companies, investment banks and brokerage firms, said, "The impact immediately is to restore some certainty to the markets."
There was also an immediate impact, and some furious activity, at insurance companies across the country yesterday, as they reviewed policies and tried to figure out just what to charge for the new coverage. They were also busy fielding calls from brokers, who were fielding calls from their corporate clients.
But nobody had much in the way of answers. "How everything will happen, we don't know yet," said Bruce D. Guthart, president of United States operations for Hub International, an insurance brokerage firm with offices in Manhattan. 
In Washington, officials at the Treasury Department began meticulously taking apart the legislation, which they will be charged with carrying out. And since insurance is regulated state by state, with no federal oversight, the Treasury officials are starting from scratch. "We need to learn a lot about the insurance business," an administration official said.
One early phone call was to the National Association of Insurance Commissioners, the organization of state insurance regulators, to signal cooperation rather than competition.
The legislation provides for the federal government to pay for 90 percent of all losses of more than $10 billion in the first year of the three-year program. For losses of less than $10 billion, insurers, initially, will be required to pay up to 7 percent of the premiums they collect. In the third year, the government is to take on 90 percent of the costs above $15 billion; for less costly attacks, the insurers will have to pay up to 15 percent of their premiums.
An important issue not spelled out in the legislation is price. The days of free terrorism coverage, which had been included in commercial policies, ended with the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon last year.
And terrorism coverage, at least at first, is expected to remain expensive, even with the government's backing. But Ms. Beck, insurance brokers and rating agencies said that as more insurers offer the coverage, the price should fall.
Though terrorism coverage is clearly an added cost that businesses would prefer to avoid, they will be under increasing pressure to buy it as it becomes widely available.
Some pressure is already coming from the agencies that rate bonds that finance big buildings and construction projects. In September, Moody's Investors Service lowered the credit ratings on loans on some prominent buildings in New York, including the Rockefeller Center complex and two towers in Times Square, which it said had inadequate terrorism coverage -- moves that increased their borrowing costs.
Tad Philipp, a managing director of Moody's, said that with the new provisions for terrorism coverage, the agency did not expect to be cutting the ratings on loans on other buildings soon. 
For the buildings already downgraded, he said: "Passing a bill does not necessarily mean that a borrower is going to order the appropriate insurance. We want to see the insurance policies in our hands before taking further action."
Some insurance experts were surprised to discover that the legislation applies exclusively to terrorism committed by foreign groups or nations. Attacks by Americans, like the Oklahoma City bombing in 1995, will not be covered.
Some experts were also concerned that the legislation left many details to be worked out by the government administrators. "It's a good blueprint," said Bruce S. Zaccanti, a senior insurance specialist at Ernst & Young, "but it doesn't spell out all the fine points."
During the legislation's long gestation, there was much debate over how badly the economy was being hurt by the lack of terrorism insurance. President Bush and other backers said billions of dollars worth of projects had been affected, leaving hundreds of thousands of people without work. Critics said the lack of terrorism insurance was just one of many things hurting the economy.

HEADLINE: L.I. Rental Shortage Is Linked To Labor Needs, Report Says 

BYLINE:  By ELISSA GOOTMAN 

DATELINE: MANHASSET, N.Y. Nov. 20 

 BODY:
Of all the counties in the New York metropolitan area, Nassau and Suffolk have the lowest proportion of rental homes within their total housing, according to a study released today. 
 The lack of rental housing coupled with soaring housing prices poses a serious threat to the Long Island economy, which needs low- and moderate-income workers who can afford to live here, said Dr. Pearl M. Kamer, chief economist at the Long Island Association, a group of business, labor and civic leaders. Dr. Kamer, who conducted the study for the Long Island Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group, said the study was based on figures from the 2000 census. 
 "Unless Long Island can immediately expand its stock of homes that young workers can afford," Dr. Kamer said, "it will not be able to generate the labor supply needed by Long Island's expanding businesses." 
Dr. Kamer's remarks were made at a news conference at North Shore University Hospital here, a site selected because health care workers -- nurses, mental health counselors and pharmacy technicians, for example -- are among those who earn too little to live on Long Island. 
That Long Island housing prices are beyond the reach of many people comes as no surprise. In April, for instance, a newly organized coalition called the Long Island Campaign for Affordable Rental Housing held a news conference in which one man, a union organizer, described how he moved to the Poconos region of Pennsylvania and endured a three-hour trip each way after his family was forced to leave the Long Island house they had rented. 
Dr. Kamer said she was surprised to find that in 26 percent of the households on Long Island -- 227,000 residences -- families spend at least 35 percent of monthly household income on rent or ownership costs including mortgage payments. The 35 percent figure was used because it is slightly higher than the housing industry and the federal government's benchmark, which suggests people spend no more than 30 percent of their income on housing. 
"We had thought the number of unaffordable units on Long Island was anywhere from 50,000 to 90,000," Dr. Kamer said. "Certainly the 227,000 figure was an eye-opener." 
By now, she estimated, with housing costs rising about 20 percent a year in each of the past two years, that figure is probably closer to 250,000. The study, which was paid for by the Roslyn Savings Foundation, also found that roughly 30 percent of those who rent houses or apartments on Long Island spend at least half their monthly income on rent. But the ratio of renters to owners -- a figure that does not take into account illegal accessory apartments and situations in which adult children return home to live with their parents -- is relatively low. 
In Nassau County, 19 percent of the housing stock is rental housing. In Suffolk, that figure is 18 percent. To the extent that these figures include not only year-round but also seasonal rentals in spots like the Hamptons, the figures could overstate the actual rental housing pool. 
In Westchester County, by contrast, 38 percent of houses and apartments are rented, according to Dr. Kamer's analysis of census figures; in Rockland County, 27 percent of homes are rented and in Fairfield County, 29 percent of the housing stock is rental housing.
Nationally, about a third of the housing stock is rental housing, said Cushing N. Dolbeare, a housing policy consultant who founded and is chairwoman emeritus of the National Low Income Housing Coalition, a nonprofit group based in Washington. 
Ms. Dolbeare, who had not seen Dr. Kamer's study, said of the shortage of homes that working families can afford: "It's appalling over all, and it's probably worse in Long Island than a lot of other places." 
To address the problem, Jim Morgo, president of the Long Island Housing Partnership, proposed things like changing zoning laws to make it easier for homeowners to create accessory apartments and ensuring that a percentage of land the government sells would go to build less expensive housing. 
Long Island's lack of rental and legal multiple-family housing stretches back to its roots. "We have always been a suburb with one-family houses," Dr. Kamer said. "We've tried to preserve that, but we could be condemning the Long Island economy to a decade of subpar economic growth if we fail to generate the workers needed by our businesses. And we will not generate those workers unless we can give them housing that they can afford."

HEADLINE: Fallout Spreads After Collapse Of a Health Services Lender 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL ONEAL 

 BODY:
The collapse of National Century Financial Enterprises toppled another of its clients yesterday when Doctors Community Healthcare -- a company based in Scottsdale, Ariz., that owns five hospitals in low-income neighborhoods in Washington, D.C.; Chicago and Southern California -- filed for Chapter 11 in the Federal Bankruptcy Court for the District of Columbia. 
 Doctors Community joins several other major customers of National Century that have filed for bankruptcy since the health care finance company, based in Dublin, Ohio, began to come apart in late October. The PhyAmerica Physician Group in Durham, N.C.; Tender Loving Care, a unit of Med Diversified in Andover, Mass.; LifeCare Solutions in San Diego; and Lincoln Hospital Medical Center in Los Angeles have all sought Chapter 11 protection in the last two weeks after they stopped receiving payments from National Century. 
 Hundreds of other National Century clients are also scrambling to find alternative financing. Those that operate hospitals in depressed communities may be the hardest hit. 
"This is a knife in the heart for those institutions," said Rick Wade, a spokesman for the American Hospital Association. With rising costs, slow-paying insurers and lots of uninsured patients, many hospitals in low-income neighborhoods "are on the edge," he added. 
National Century itself filed for bankruptcy on Monday and has become the target of both an F.B.I. investigation and allegations of gross mismanagement brought by its clients and holders of $3.35 billion worth of its asset-backed securities.
The company's former chairman and chief executive, Lance K. Poulsen, resigned both posts under pressure on Nov. 8. 
The Doctors Community filing will provide protection from creditors to all five of its hospitals: Greater Southeast Community Hospital and Hadley Memorial Hospital in Washington; Michael Reese Medical Center in Chicago; Pine Grove Hospital in Canoga Park, Calif.; and Pacifica of the Valley Hospital in Sun Valley, Calif. The company issued a statement promising that wages and benefits would continue to be paid as the privately held company restructures. 
But the troubles of Doctors Community have already affected medical services in one of Washington's poorest neighborhoods. Karen Dale, chief executive of Greater Southeast Community Hospital, said that while she was confident the quality of care had not been affected at her hospital, the number of patients it can care for has diminished because of the severe cash squeeze. 
Two of the four companies that had been supplying nurses to Greater Southeast have withdrawn their employees because they were not being paid. The other two have reduced the number of nurses they will supply, Ms. Dale said. That means the hospital can accept fewer patients, especially in its intensive and critical care units. When its emergency room got too crowded over the weekend, for instance, Ms. Dale said the hospital was forced to divert ambulances to other hospitals. 
Meanwhile, Ms. Dale is spending much of her time trying to persuade her doctors and nurses to stay put. "The danger would be that the staff panics and decides to leave," Ms. Dale said. "We are located in Ward 8 -- the area with the worst health indices and a lot of poor people. This is devastating." Greater Southeast was the lead hospital in a highly publicized effort to privatize the District of Columbia's health care system for indigents in 2001. 
The troubles at Doctors Community began in late October when National Century, one of the largest health care finance companies in the country and the primary source of financing for most of its clients, began to fall apart. National Century lent money to cash-short health care companies in return for taking over rights to their receivables -- payments expected from insurers and government programs like Medicare and Medicaid. It then packaged those receivables into collateral for bonds and sold the bonds to investors, who received interest derived from the insurance payments. National Century gets a part of each transaction. 
But last spring, after Fitch Ratings downgraded the bonds, investors started to shy away from National Century, depriving it of new capital. In response, the company took money from reserve accounts backing two bond trusts worth $3.35 billion. When investors discovered that almost $350 million was missing from a trust called NPF XII, it was clear National Century was facing a liquidity crisis. The company stopped making payments to hundreds of hospital and home health care clients and the value of its bonds collapsed.
Since then, a bondholder group has charged in the Franklin County Court of Pleas in Columbus, Ohio, that National Century owned large stakes in many of its biggest clients -- companies like Med Diversified and Doctors Community. Other documents in the Ohio court proceedings claim that the company was lending far more money to these clients than they generated in receivables. Instead, court papers say, National Century was taking real estate and even artwork as collateral for the loans, violating the bond indenture. 
In effect, bondholders have charged, National Century was using its AAA-rated bonds to prop up distressed companies in which it had a direct ownership interest. Bank One, the trustee for a portion of National Century's bonds, said in a court filing that "the evidence of systematic financial trickery continues to mount."
Some of the bondholders are moving on. The Ambac Financial Group announced on Monday that it would write down 70 percent of its $174 million investment in the bonds. Others with big exposure include the Pacific Investment Management Company, which is a unit of Allianz, and Alliance Capital Management, which is a unit of AXA. 
Investors in asset-backed securities are still questioning how bonds that had carried a top credit rating could now be worth just a fraction of their face value. Moody's Investors Service rated National Century's bonds AAA until Oct. 25. Credit Suisse First Boston underwrote the bonds, and J. P. Morgan Chase had two bankers on the National Century board, including Hal Pote, head of the audit committee. Deloitte & Touche audited the books. Both Bank One and J. P. Morgan were bond trustees. 
Most of these securities are backed by mortgages and other assets with relatively predictable cash flows. "They're supposed to be bullet proof," one specialist said.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
No Taxes, No Foul At the Garden

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
QUESTION: How does a temporary tax abatement become a permanent one? Answer: When it was permanent from the start. Even if it wasn't supposed to be. Or was it?
 Call it the mystery of the tax exemption that will not go away. 
 On Monday, a Metro Matters column about the city's budget distress examined the city's policy of granting tax incentives and other subsidies to businesses and noted that Madison Square Garden has paid no property taxes since 1982, when the Knicks and Rangers threatened to leave town. 
The value of the tax break -- the forgiven taxes over 20 years -- has reached $200 million adjusted for inflation, the city's Independent Budget Office calculates. With the city facing both budget cuts and tax increases in the next fiscal year, it will not collect an estimated $6.9 million from the Garden in property tax. 
That seems odd, especially since City Hall originally portrayed its tax agreement with the Garden as a temporary one, expiring in 10 years. Just yesterday, former Mayor Edward I. Koch said he had thought in 1982 that he was authorizing a temporary tax benefit. "It was not only my intent -- I went to bed at night believing it was a 10-year abatement. There's no question," Mr. Koch said this week.
News accounts later questioned whether the deal was temporary, but the former mayor was still so sure that in a letter last year to a city councilman, he asked "who extended the tax break and why?"
Allen G. Schwartz, who represented Mr. Koch in negotiations with the Garden, thought the same. A tax break in perpetuity "was not my understanding, not what I negotiated," Mr. Schwartz, now a federal judge in Manhattan, said on Tuesday. "The deal we made, as I understood it, was that the Knicks and Rangers would be required to remain in New York City and the extent of the abatement would be for 10 years." What happened? "Somehow there was a slip between the cup and lip."
That the city would give tax relief of some duration to the Garden was not in question. It was a different city 20 years ago. Memories of the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's were still raw, and the prospect of losing more sports teams was unacceptable. The teams' threats to leave were taken seriously.
"The big money was in cable," recalled Judge Schwartz, Mr. Koch's first corporation counsel. "It didn't matter if the teams played in Madison Square Garden or across the river or in Nassau. When all was said and done, the consensus was, we had to keep them in the Garden."
THE agreement gave the Garden concessions from the unions, a reduction in power costs from the state and, as The Times wrote in April 1982, to no demurrals from the Koch administration, "a 10-year tax abatement" of the Garden's annual real estate tax bill. A subsequent Times article that month noted that if either team stopped playing in New York City for 10 consecutive years, the abatement ends "and the property is returned to the tax rolls."
As city and state documents confirm, the reference to 10 years was not to the abatement's duration, but to a requirement that the teams remain in the city for at least 10 years from the date of the agreement. The formal memorandum of understanding of July 15, 1982, said that the tax exemption "shall continue, as long as both of said teams play their home games therein and no longer."
Hadley W. Gold, the first assistant corporation counsel in 1982, drafted the agreement with Mr. Schwarz, he recalled this week. "To put some teeth into it, we said 'You've got to stay at least 10 years.' It doesn't say the exemption lasts 10 years."
In Mr. Gold's opinion, the agreement accurately reflected the city's intent and the state legislation, which he assumes was also drafted in the city corporation counsel's office, though he did not know by whom.
The memorandum of understanding was signed by Mr. Gold, Nathan Leventhal, a deputy mayor, and Richard H. Zahnd, then general counsel to Madison Square Garden. Mr. Zahnd said yesterday that he always understood that the abatement would apply as long as the teams played in New York City. Mr. Leventhal, who now advises Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, did not return calls to his home and office.
Mr. Koch said he took responsibility for the agreement since it happened on his watch, but -- ever the pragmatist -- said he was sure the tax exemption would have been extended if it had expired. O.K., but what went wrong? "Obviously something happened on the way to the forum that I was unaware of."

HEADLINE: THE MAYOR'S BUDGET PLAN: DEBT; 
Borrowing Called Tactic Best Left In the 70's

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
For people who recall the mid-1970's in New York well enough, what is happening now can raise hairs on the back of the neck.
 The city and the state face enormous budget deficits, they are already deeply in debt, and the economy is sluggish. It is hard now for many New Yorkers to remember just how bad the bad old days were, but the current talk of severe budget cuts, mass layoffs, higher transit fares, tax increases and appeals to Washington for a rescue seem like a flashback to the disco era. 
 Add one more throwback to that list, one that independent budget experts find especially troubling. For the first time since the 1970's, New York City is borrowing money on a large scale to pay for day-to-day operating expenses, rather than just for capital projects. New York State officials are also talking about doing the same thing, by selling bonds backed by revenue from the national tobacco settlement. 
Borrowing to pay for government operations was not part of the solution to New York's earlier fiscal crisis. It was part of the problem, a practice from the early 1970's that helped put the city (and, to a lesser degree, the state) into that deep hole.
"Borrowing for operating expenses is a big, big no-no, and the city has done it two years in a row," said Charles Brecher, research director of the Citizens Budget Commission. The commission is part of a small industry of watchdog groups that keep up a constant critique of city and state finances, all of them dedicated, to one degree or another, to making sure New York does not repeat the experience of the 1970's.
Brian D. Backstrom, president of Change New York, a conservative, anti-tax group, said: "The perfect analogy is to the '70's, when New York City set itself up for bankruptcy by using debt to pay for everyday operating expenses. I can't say this too forcefully: borrowing more money does not cure the problem, it only postpones it and makes it much, much worse. You're setting yourself up for fiscal disaster."
No one has suggested that fiscal gimmickry has sunk to the levels of three decades ago. Nor is there any doubt that New York, battered by recession and the destruction of the World Trade Center, is in severe enough straits to warrant extreme measures.
The city's problems appear especially dire. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has no easy options, and he is running out of hard ones, as well; he is calling for budget cuts, tax increases, and help from Albany. His plan is already in trouble, as state officials have said they will not approve his proposal to tax people who commute into the city.
The city has a $1.1 billion deficit in its current fiscal year, and projects a $6.4 billion deficit in the year starting next July 1. Gov. George E. Pataki's administration has refused to say how big a deficit the state is running in the current year, or how large the problem will be in the fiscal year that starts April 1. Most experts believe the state can cover its shortfall for the current year without any drastic moves, but the next year's deficit has been estimated at $5 billion to $10 billion.
It is standard practice for governments to borrow more than usual in bad times to bridge the chasm. But New York City and State already carry the heaviest debt burdens in the nation, other than the federal government, and financial analysts and Wall Street rating firms frown on their borrowing more.
Last week, Mr. Bloomberg vowed not to repeat the mistakes of the 1970's. He said one of his guiding principles was to "address the problems that we have and take responsibility ourselves to solve those problems, not to postpone them with debt financing and not to give them to the future with one-shot solutions."
Earlier this year, though, the mayor requested and received permission from Albany to borrow $1.5 billion to pay for operating expenses. Mr. Bloomberg called that a one-time departure, to cover the effects of the trade center attack.
It is not clear yet what the state will do, but a growing number of legislators are talking about borrowing against the tobacco settlement to get through the next year or two. The hope behind that approach is that the economy will turn, revenues will rise and the crisis will resolve itself without great sacrifice.
The critics said that was a dangerous theory.
"It won't work, even if we return to a late-1990's growth rate," Mr. Brecher said. "There is no way to imagine an economic scenario that closes deficits as big as the city and state have. We are not just going to grow our way out of this."

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: Britain: Support For Rate Cut Ebbs 

BYLINE:  By Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

 BODY:
 Support for an interest rate cut among Bank of England policy makers ebbed at the most recent meeting, on Nov. 6 and Nov. 7, notes from the meeting show. Two members voted to lower interest rates at the meeting, compared with three who did so at the previous meeting in October. 
Policy makers cited improvements in the domestic economy, including an increasing rate of economic growth in the third quarter, and soaring house prices, as reasons to hold the benchmark interest rate steady at 4 percent, its lowest level in 38 years. In contrast, United States Federal Reserve policy makers voted unanimously on Nov. 6 to lower the benchmark borrowing rate by half a percentage point, to 1.25 percent, to stimulate economic growth. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
BLACK & DECKER TO CLOSE MARYLAND PLANT AND MOVE JOBS

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

 BODY:
 Black & Decker, the maker of power tools, will shut a factory in Maryland and cut 1,300 jobs in the state by 2004 to reduce costs. 
Power-tool assembly and manufacturing will move from Easton, Md., to Fayetteville, N. C., and to Reynosa, Mexico. About 750 full-time and 550 temporary jobs will be eliminated in Maryland. Black & Decker plans to take 2,400 jobs from regions with higher wages and replace them with 1,900 elsewhere in the United States and in other countries. The company, based in Toeson, Md., said increased competition led to the decision.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK; 
'Homestand' for Expos Approved by Owners

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
For a team that was earmarked for extinction a year ago, the Montreal Expos consume a disproportionate amount of Major League Baseball's attention. At an owners meeting in a Dallas suburb yesterday, a 22-game schedule of Expos games was approved for next season in San Juan, P.R., and a committee was appointed to study the Expos' permanent relocation in the near future.
 Commissioner Bud Selig did not set a 2003 payroll for the Expos, but club officials believed that with the additional revenue generated by the games in Puerto Rico, they would be able to retain higher-priced players like Vladimir Guerrero, Bartolo Colon and Javier Vazquez. 
 The clubs, which own the Expos and would like to see them increase their revenue, approved the plan for three homestands at Hiram Bithorn Stadium, where 19,891 fans saw Toronto and Texas play the first game of the 2001 season. The Expos averaged 10,000 a game last season.
Although the players association must still approve the plan, it calls for 10 games in April against the Mets (a four-game series April 11-14), Atlanta and Cincinnati; six in June against Anaheim and Texas; and six in September against Florida and the Chicago Cubs. All of the teams have attractive Latin players.
Even more important will be the recommendation of a committee that is studying the options for the Expos' relocation. Two club officials, Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox and Wendy Selig-Prieb of the Milwaukee Brewers, and several major league officials will determine the city that will provide the greatest likelihood of success for the Expos, who will be the first major league team to move since 1972.
Early this year Selig called Washington the prime city for relocation, and Washington, along with Portland, Ore., have been the most aggressive cities interested in landing a major league team. But baseball has to decide if putting the Expos in Washington or northern Virginia would undermine the Baltimore Orioles' economic base.
In another scheduling decision, the clubs approved a season-opening two-game series between Seattle and Oakland March 25 and 26 in Tokyo. It will be the fourth time in the last five years that the season will open outside the United States and Canada.
